title: Even With a Struggling Stephen Drew on Bench, the Yankees Go Quietly Against the As
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  It is hard to argue with the Yankees decision to let Robinson Cano leave for Seattle as a free agent, not when the Mariners committed $240 million to him through the age of 40. This is especially true at the moment, when Cano is off to a worrisome start, having just hit his second home run on Saturday.

title: Dennis Hasterts Name Removed by Alma Mater
description: The alma mater of J. Dennis Hastert, the former speaker of the House of Representatives, announced on Sunday that it had scrubbed his name from the schools public policy center, after his indictment on charges that he lied to the F.B.I. about financial transactions he made to cover up past sexual misconduct.

title: Louis Johnson, Bassist and Singer for the Brothers Johnson, Dies at 60
description: Louis Johnson, a bassist who had a string of funk hits with the Brothers Johnson and worked as a session musician for Quincy Jones, notably on the Michael Jackson albums Off the Wall and Thriller, was found dead on May 21 at his home in Las Vegas. He was 60.

title: E.C.B. Policy Meeting, U.S. Employment and the Greek Repayment Deadline
description: On Monday at 8:30 a.m., the Commerce Department reports on personal income and consumption growth in April. Economists estimate that consumption spending rose 0.2 percent, while personal income rose 0.3 percent. Despite the big fall in energy prices over the last year, consumers have been cautious about spending, one reason that experts think consumption in April was muted.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of June 1
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Up on the Roof: Top-Floor Attractions Help Maximize Revenues
description: In a city crowded with venerable towers and gleaming new skyscrapers, builders and developers are trying to squeeze more money out of their real estate by taking advantage of one of their last available spaces: their rooftops.

title: U.S. Citizens Held in Yemen by Houthis
description: CAIRO  Several American citizens are being detained in Yemen by the Houthis, a Shiite rebel group that controls the capital and parts of the country, a United States official said Sunday.

title: And Theyre Off: Crowd Numbers Will Be Smaller at the Belmont Stakes
description: In the nearly four decades since the last sweep of horse racings coveted Triple Crown, 12 horses have left the Belmont Stakes starting gate with a shot at the feat. The New York Racing Association promoted those events and attracted gigantic crowds, including 102,199 last year, when the popular colt California Chrome failed to secure a sweep. A record 120,139 showed up in 2004, when Smarty Jones lost his bid.

title: For Charter Communications Chief, Time Warner Cable Is a Long-Sought Prize
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Thomas M. Rutledge declared victory last week when Charter Communications struck a $56.7 billion deal to acquire its much larger rival Time Warner Cable.

title: For Swapped Taliban Prisoners FromGuantnamo Bay, Few Doors to Exit Qatar
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two of them are accused of mass murders. Another defended the killings of foreigners. One has been described by the United States military as an opium drug lord and an associate of Osama bin Laden. Another was a top official in the feared intelligence service of the Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar.

title: Prices Are Down, but Saudis Keep Oil Flowing
description: HOUSTON  The international cartel of oil producers has long followed the same basic strategy. When the market was soft, the group slashed production to raise prices.

title: Use of Tasers Is Scrutinized After Walter Scott Shooting
description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  It was late on a Sunday in May 2014 when Officer Michael T. Slager of the North Charleston Police Department stood outside an apartment and faced off with a man whose fists, he said, were clenched as he assumed an aggressive stance. Mr. Slager, who said he had just watched the man assault a roommate, forced him to the ground with a five-second burst of electricity from a Taser.

description: The evidence is compelling. The cartel of Asian electronics makers worked for more than five years to set the prices of liquid-crystal display screens used in computers and cellphones. They gathered for monthly meetings in private conference rooms at luxury hotels.

While the work they present comes in all shapes and sizes, from the highly technical to the trendy and provocative, the coveted first day of a key weeklong session is given over to research that will make a media splash.

description: The double-decker bus rolled across the Bronx as a bespectacled guide in a crinkled jacket and tie pointed out notable attractions: Yankee Stadium, the Bronx Zoo and the Art Deco buildings along the Grand Concourse.

description: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time and Hamilton led the pack at the Drama Desk Awards, which were announced Sunday night. Curious Incident scooped up six prizes, including those for outstanding play, outstanding actor (Alex Sharp) and outstanding director of a play (Marianne Elliott). Hamilton won seven, including those for outstanding musical and outstanding director of a musical (Thomas Kail); its creator, Lin-Manuel Miranda, won for music, lyrics and book.

description: CREWE, England  After 88 years and more than 3,000 matches, Harold Finch thought he had seen everything, but Sunday was a rare event.

title: Review: The Western Wind Performs LAmfiparnaso at a Distance
description: At its premiere in Modena, Italy, in 1594, Orazio Vecchis LAmfiparnaso must have been a barrel of laughs. The characters in this madrigal comedy are a mix of stock figures from commedia dellarte, supplemented by caricatures with foreign manners and silly accents: a preening Spaniard, a wily servant from Bergamo and that mainstay of Italian Renaissance thigh-slapping hilarity, Jews babbling among themselves in synagogue. There are also serious scenes of true love tested and a happy ending, all skillfully woven into a sequence of five-part madrigals.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 8:15 A.M. (Sundance) ORLANDO (1993) A beautiful young nobleman (Tilda Swinton, above) adored by an aging Queen Elizabeth I (Quentin Crisp) falls asleep one night in the 17th century and wakes up five days later as a woman. Same person, no difference at all, she says, unflustered. Just a different sex. She continues to learn about life through the centuries up until the present, pondering the differences between men and women  as well as their similarities  in this adaptation by Sally Potter of Virginia Woolfs 1928 novel. Charlotte Valandrey plays Sasha, a wanton Muscovite princess with whom the male Orlando falls in love. Billy Zane is the American with whom Orlandos female version has a more enduring if less sexually demanding relationship. This ravishing and witty spectacle invades the mind through eyes that are dazzled without ever being anesthetized, Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. Orlando could well become a classic of a very special kind, not mainstream perhaps, but a model for independent filmmakers who follow their own irrational muses, sometimes to unmourned obscurity, occasionally to glory. More than anything else, he added: Orlando is Ms. Swintons triumph. With the firmest but lightest of touches, she has spun gossamer.

title: Scientists Who Cheat
description: Cheating in scientific and academic papers is a longstanding problem, but it is hard to read recent headlines and not conclude that it has gotten worse. Falsified or erroneous results have forced authors and editors to retract papers from journals that let themselves be duped into publishing them. Researchers at some of the nations most prestigious universities have been implicated. There are ways to minimize this kind of fraud, but it will require changing the process, from how scientists share their data to how their peers review it and who is allowed to enforce academic standards.

title: That 1914 Feeling
description: U.S. officials are generally cautious about intervening in European policy debates. The European Union is, after all, an economic superpower in its own right  far too big and rich for America to have much direct influence  led by sophisticated people who should be able to manage their own affairs. So its startling to learn that Jacob Lew, the Treasury secretary, recently warned Europeans that they had better settle the Greek situation soon, lest there be a destructive accident.

title: Whos Willing to Fight for Iraq?
description: Defense Secretary Ashton Carters recent assessment of Iraqi security forces was impolitic and true, and rarely voiced by senior officials. After the devastating loss of the Iraqi city of Ramadi to the Islamic State in May, he told CNN that while Iraqi troops vastly outnumbered the brutal extremists, they just showed no will to fight.

title: Surviving Child Sexual Abuse
description: Last month came the news that Josh Duggar, now-former executive director of the Family Research Councils lobbying arm and eldest son on the TLC reality show 19 Kids and Counting, had apologized and said he had acted inexcusably. As In Touch Weekly magazine put it: Josh Duggar was investigated for multiple sex offenses  including forcible fondling  against five minors. Some of the alleged offenses investigated were felonies. Those minors apparently included his sisters. Duggar was around 14 years old when the reported assaults took place.

title: New York City Task Force to Investigate Three-Quarter Homes
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Sunday he had formed an emergency task force to investigate so-called three-quarter houses in New York City for potentially exploiting addicts and homeless people by taking kickbacks on Medicaid fees for drug treatment while forcing them to live in squalid, illegal conditions.

description: LONDON  The British government said on Monday it would extend a trading plan to sell down its stake in the Lloyds Banking Group and said it would offer some of its holdings to retail investors in the next year.

title: Justices Get Out More, but Calendars Arent Open to Just Anyone
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Last Friday afternoon, in an enormous tent in Radcliffe Yard at Harvard, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg gave a public interview before an adoring audience of about 1,300 people. She discussed her triumphs as a litigator, dodged oblique questions about gay rights and described an opera that premieres next month called Scalia/Ginsburg.

description: CHICAGO  The only complaint Mike Conklin ever received from his time helicoptering President Bill Clinton around in Marine One came from the White House chief usher, who politely asked if there were some way to quit strafing the flowers with wind from the rotors.

description: NEW PALTZ, N.Y.  Having sat in one too many hot cars in his life, Shiva Vencat decided on the kind of vacation home he would build here 15 years ago, up a winding road at the foot of the Shawangunk Mountains.

title: Price Tag on a Brooklyn Park Reaches $225 Million, and Thats Only the Beginning
description: Is a neighborhood park in Brooklyn worth a half-billion dollars? That may be the ultimate cost of Bushwick Inlet Park, which youve probably never heard of. This time of year, its full of children from around the city playing soccer. But its not much to look at.

title: What Are Some Words of Wisdom That Guide Your Life?
description: In difficult times or in just trying to choose between several equally good options, many people find guidance in expressions or sayings, like one day at a time or dont sweat the small stuff. Then there are more personal credos, like the words of a wise family member or even a hero from a book or movie that come to mind in times of uncertainty.

title: Reagan: The Life, by H. W. Brands
description: For a man who lived most of his life on camera, Ronald Reagan eludes focus. There was, and remains, a gauziness to the picture; Reagan retained, throughout his political career, the remoteness of a screen idol, though he never achieved that status as a movie actor. He was ubiquitous for decades and, as president, left a lasting imprint on Americas political culture. Yet he was all the same an unknowable man  even to those nearest him. In White House meetings, he was mostly silent, often leaving his aides to guess at (and feud over) his views. In his personal relationships, he was unfailingly warm but rarely intimate. He doesnt let anybody get too close, one observer said. Theres a wall around him. That the observer was his wife, Nancy, should give pause to any politician or pundit who claims to know what Reagan would do if he were here today. (It should, but it wont.)

title: Loving Day, by Mat Johnson
description: A house divided against itself cannot stand, Abraham Lincoln declared in his 1858 speech presaging the Civil War. Such a house sits at the heart of Mat Johnsons ribald, incisive novel Loving Day. Bequeathed to the narrator, Warren Duffy, by his deceased father, its a roofless, ramshackle mansion in a black neighborhood in Philadelphia: I look at the buckling floors. I look at the cracks in all the walls, the evidence of a foundation crumbling beneath us. I smell the char of the fire, the sweet reek of mold, the insult of mouse urine. I see a million things that have to be fixed, restored, corrected, each one impossible and each task mandatory for me to escape again.

title: How to Find That Vintage Cast-Iron Pan

title: Morning Agenda: Intel Takeover of Altera Is Expected
description: INTEL TAKEOVER OF ALTERA IS EXPECTED | Just days after  Avago Technologies agreed to buy Broadcom for about $37 billion, the semiconductor industry is on the verge of yet another takeover deal, this time between Intel and Altera,  Michael J. de la Merced and Quentin Hardy write in DealBook. Intel is in talks to buy the chip maker Altera for more than $15 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday. Intel is expected to pay about $54 a share for Altera, whose specialized chip designs would help Intel expand beyond chips for personal computers, this person said. An agreement could be announced this week, but the person said the talks are continuing and might still collapse. Shares in Altera rose 4 percent on Friday, to $48.85, after  The New York Post reported that the two companies were close to an agreement.

title: The Finnish Disease
description: A followup to my post inspired by troubles in Finland: its worth emphasizing just how bad Finlands performance has been. For Finns, the great depression they remember is the slump at the beginning of the 1990s, driven by a combination of a bursting housing bubble and the collapse of the Soviet Union next door. The result was a very nasty slump, and a delayed recovery. But this time, although the slump in per capita GDP never got quite as deep, has been far more persistent:

title: Medical Marijuana Feeds Familiar Hopes of Renewal Around New York State

title: Review: Stan VanDerBeek at Andrea Rosen Gallery
description: Projected on four walls of a small space, Stan VanDerBeeks experimental 16-millimeter films (transferred to video) form one of the best shows in Chelsea right now. They also create a pulsing environment that increases our understanding of this pioneering, experience-oriented artist, who died at 57 in 1984.

title: Lindsey Graham on the Issues
description: Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina announced Monday that he plans to seek the Republican nomination for president. In his three terms, he has focused on military and foreign affairs and developed a reputation for working together with Senate Democrats. Here are some of Mr. Grahams stands on important issues.

title: Lively Morgue Tumblr 520
description: Lively Morgue Tumblr 520

title: What Lindsey Graham Would Need to Do to Win
description: Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina on Monday joined the race for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination. Here is a look at what he will need to do to win.

title: Breast-Fed Children at Lower Risk of Leukemia
description: Children who are breast-fed as infants have a lower risk of developing childhood leukemia, a new study suggests.

title: American Pharoah Flies Around Track; Next Stop, Belmont
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  All week at Churchill Downs, a crowd has gathered at Barn 33 at 8:30 a.m. to watch American Pharoah head to the racetrack for light training in anticipation of his final workout ahead of the Belmont Stakes, where he will attempt to become the first Triple Crown winner since 1978.

title: FIFA Case Could Strengthen Justice Dept.s Global Power
description: Teddy Roosevelt was fond of the West African proverb to speak softly and carry a big stick; you will go far. The Justice Department is wielding one of its biggest sticks  the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, better known as RICO  to go after bribery and kickbacks that have been rife in international soccer for decades.

title: Inside the Rauschenberg Warehouse
description: The late artist Robert Rauschenbergs archive-in-progress in Mount Vernon, N.Y., reveals a stockpile of old neckties, Polaroids and letters from famous friends.

title: Walkabout: Americans Descend on Europe; Travel Start-Ups
description: Crowded With the dollar performing strongly against the euro, record numbers of American travelers are expected to converge on many of Europes most popular cultural attractions this summer. (The Wall Street Journal)

title: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
description: The good news is there are two big soccer games with global appeal this week. The bad news is that they are nearly on top of each other. The soccer editor Andrew Das, a shameless Ajax supporter, tells you what to watch.

title: Review: Soak Exposes Fears and Resolve on Debut Album
description: SOAK

title: Staying Out of Your Neighbors Business
description: Humans can be a competitive lot. The way we posture and position ourselves to stand out in a group seems to happen instinctively. After all, in the past we competed for resources and survival. Our lives depended on it. Today, we still compete, but for different reasons.

title: Times Critics Picks: What to Do This Week
description: Looking to break out of your cultural rut?

title: American Journalist Is Freed by Yemens Houthi Rebels
description: CAIRO  Houthi rebels in Yemen on Monday released an American freelance journalist who had been in their custody for about two weeks, the State Department and the journalists family reported.

title: Paul Salomons Imbalance Puzzles
description: Our challenge this week is an original by Paul Salomon, who teaches math and mathematical art at the John Burroughs School in St. Louis. The puzzle appears in the recently released Playing with Math by Sue VanHattum. Before getting to Pauls puzzle, Id love to say a bit about Sues new book, which was published by Natural Math.

title: Supreme Court Overturns Conviction in Online Threats Case, Citing Intent
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday made it harder to prosecute people for threats made on Facebook and other social media, reversing the conviction of a Pennsylvania man who directed brutally violent language against his estranged wife.

title: Hillary Clinton Still Strong in Iowa Poll, Though Negative News Is a Concern
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton continues to command a sizable lead in a poll released on Monday of Iowa Democrats, who will cast the first votes of the presidential nominating race early next year. At the same time, Democrats are worried that revelations about Mrs. Clinton could hurt her in the general election.

title: 1915: German Airship Bombs London
description: LONDON  The Admiralty issues the following statement as a continuation of its announcement made early this morning [June 1] with regard to last nights raid by a German airship over the Metropolitan area: Late last night about ninety bombs, mostly of an incendiary description, were dropped from a hostile aircraft in various localities not far distant from each other. A certain number of fires were caused by the bursting of these bombs. Only three of these fires were large enough to require the services of fire-engines. All the fires were promptly and effectively dealt with. The New York Herald, European Edition, June 2, 1915

title: Fifty Shades Author to Offer Greys Perspective
description: E.L. James is giving fans of her best-selling erotica series Fifty Shades of Grey a little something to tide them over before the next installment of the movie franchise.

title: A Nose for Fashion
description: The fashion designer Carolina Herrera and her daughter Carolina Herrera de Bez have teamed up on Herrera Confidential, a collection of six new fragrances. With a bit of synesthetic whimsy, the senior Herrera has created made-to-order dresses tailored to each scent: A sumptuous cashmere ensemble matches with warm amber, a lustrous silk cocktail dress with citrusy neroli. The most opulent of the offerings, Oud Couture, has been paired with a midnight-blue gown embellished with crystal embroidery.

title: More Opponents Stand in the Way of the Triple Crown . . .
description: American Pharoah could set a record for most horses beaten on the way to the Triple Crown.

title: Data Shows Large Rise in List Prices at Hospitals
description: The prices that hospitals ask customers to pay for a series of common procedures have increased by more than 10 percent between 2011 and 2013  more than double the rate of inflation.

title: Alvin Aileys Linda Celeste Sims and Her Pas de Cuisinart
description: When Linda Celeste Sims arrives in a hotel room  a common occurrence in the nine months she spends on the road each year as a lead dancer with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater  she unpacks her hot plate, pot, saut pan and Cuisinart food processor. For china, utensils and napkins, she calls room service; her suitcase is only so big.

title: New York Triathletes Mourn JackRabbits Loss of Independence
description: Soon after the Running Specialty Group bought JackRabbit Sports in March, the changes began behind the scenes. Some employee positions were eliminated immediately, and a popular commission program for sales employees was discontinued.

title: Refining a Familiar Form: Mariano Riveras Son Improves His Pitching and His Prospects
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.  It was a simple county park, with no scoreboard and a chain-link fence demarcating the outfield perimeter, where children scrambled after foul balls and aluminum pings echoed toward an ice-cream vendor across the parking lot.

title: Muslim Woman Denied Job Over Head Scarf Wins in Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday revived an employment discrimination lawsuit against Abercrombie & Fitch, which had refused to hire a Muslim woman because she wore a head scarf. The company said the scarf clashed with its dress code, which called for a classic East Coast collegiate style.

title: Jeb Bush Faces Challenge in Winning Over Brothers Team
description: WASHINGTON  When George W. Bush first ran for president, he liked to say he had inherited half of his fathers friends and all of his enemies. For Jeb Bush, now preparing his own bid for the White House, that may ring familiar.

title: Game of Thrones Q. and A.: Birgitte Hjort Sorensen on Playing a Wildling Mother
description: This post contains spoilers related to Sundays episode of Game of Thrones.

title: A New Album With Artsy Bona Fides (and an Assist from Leonard Cohen)
description: Ive always been interested in social psychology and why certain groups of people do things while others dont, says the singer Jihae of Illusion of You, her forthcoming fourth record, out this week. The overall theme of the album is based on individual illusions about self-identity as well as the societal illusions that create divisions between cultures, religion, class and gender.

title: Petrobras Seeks to Sell a 100-Year Bond
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Petrobras, Brazils troubled petroleum giant, is returning to the global capital markets with plans to sell a 100-year bond issue.

title: Time Warner Cable C.F.O. Leaves Company
description: Arthur T. Minson Jr., who helped guide Time Warner Cable through the collapse of the $45 billion takeover attempt by Comcast, then the $56 billion proposed sale to Charter Communications, is leaving his position as chief financial officer of the company to work as president and chief operating officer of WeWork, a company that rents shared office space.

title: Climate Model Suggests Everest Glaciers Could Nearly Disappear
description: By the end of this century, the landscape around Mount Everest may drastically change. As the planet continues to warm, the Everest region of Nepal could lose most of its glaciers, according to a study published in the journal The Cryosphere.

title: Disneys Top Financial Officer to Step Down
description: LOS ANGELES  Disneys chief financial officer, James A. Rasulo, will step down on June 30, a departure that had been expected after his removal from consideration as next chief executive.

title: Japanese Companies Attack Neglected Diseases
description: Several Japanese drug companies have joined a new project to find medicines to treat two neglected parasitic diseases, Chagas and leishmaniasis.

title: Grimaldis and L&B Spumoni Gardens Offer Slices by the Stop
description: To Sample: A Slice Here, a Scoop There

title: Two Ways to Be Happy
description: If youve read any self-help books, youve probably heard the adage that even if you cant control what happens to you, you can control how you feel about it. Now theres scientific evidence that the latter really does help  managing how you react to setbacks can make you feel better about life, maybe even more than avoiding those setbacks altogether.

title: Paris Bridges Love Locks Are Taken Down
description: PARIS  The padlocks that weigh heavily on the sides of the Pont des Arts tell stories dear to the lovers who affixed them to the celebrated bridges iron grillwork.

title: Caitlyn Jenner, Formerly Bruce, Introduces Herself in Vanity Fair
description: In April, Bruce Jenner spoke about her transition to being a woman in a television special that drew nearly 17 million viewers.

title: French Captive in Yemen Appeals for Help
description: Isabelle Prime, a Frenchwoman being held hostage in Yemen, asked President Franois Hollande to bring her home.

title: Graham Announces Presidential Bid
description: Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, returned to his hometown, Central, S.C., on Monday to open his campaign for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination.

title: Hillary Clinton to Rally in New York, Then Tour Early Voting States
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton will hold the first major rally of her presidential campaign on June 13 on Roosevelt Island in New York City, before embarking on a five-day swing through the four states with the earliest Democratic nominating contests, her campaign said on Monday.

title: Work and Play in Paris's Silicon Sentier
description: The area of central Paris around rue du Sentier, once home to part of the garment district, is now home to a hive of innovation.

title: A Step Toward Justice for Rana Plaza Victims
description: Police in Bangladesh filed murder charges on Monday against 41 people involved in the collapse of a garment factory building that killed more than 1,100 people in 2013. Though it took more than two years, these charges represent progress in a country that has historically done too little to help factory workers and hold factory owners responsible for crimes.

title: Met Opera Sets Lineup for Free HD Screenings
description: The Jets and the Sharks will return to the West Side  and the music of Leonard Bernstein and dance of Jerome Robbins will return to Lincoln Center  when the Metropolitan Opera opens its Summer HD Festival on Aug. 28 with a free screening of the 1961 film West Side Story. Ten nights of free opera screenings will follow on the plaza in front of the Met.

title: Little Sister Lauds Lindsey Graham, the Bachelor, for Raising Her
description: CENTRAL, S.C.  If elected, Senator Lindsey Graham would be the first bachelor to win the White House since Grover Cleveland. But that does not mean he will be on the campaign trail without any family members in tow.

title: The Upper Crust in a Tectonic Plate Collision
description: Q. The recent earthquakes in Nepal made me wonder: When tectonic plates collide, what determines which one winds up on top?

title: Chicago Schools Chief Resigns Amid Federal Investigation
description: CHICAGO  The chief executive of the public school system here, Barbara Byrd-Bennett, who has been the subject of a federal investigation into possible misconduct, has resigned, the district announced Monday.

title: Patz Prosecutor Takes On Ex-Congressman in Staten Island District Attorneys Race
description: Joan Illuzzi, a longtime Manhattan prosecutor who handled the Etan Patz case, has resigned her post to run for Staten Island district attorney as a Republican, setting the stage for a contest between a pair of unusually high-profile candidates.

title: Ben Bernanke Says Fed Cant Get Caught Up in Inequality Debate
description: Ben S. Bernanke, the former Federal Reserve chairman, has given short shrift to those who doubt the economic impact of his bond-buying campaigns in helping to bring the American economy out of the Great Recession.

title: Outlander Q. and A.: Tobias Menzies on Playing the Brutal Black Jack
description: Shock and horror are legitimate feelings to experience when youre watching a story, said Ron Moore in a recent interview about the Season 1 finale of Starzs Outlander. And it was hard not to feel both emotions while watching To Ransom a Mans Soul, in which we see in flashback the brutalization of Jamie, the shows male hero, by the villain Black Jack Randall. As I wrote in my episode recap, because of the way it addressed sexual assault, it was an important episode of television because it takes the time to fully explore what recovery actually looks like and understands that its by no means simple or straightforward.

title: Chip Deals in Search of Greater Pricing Power
description: Revenue synergies can be an elusive goal in mergers. Yet three big acquisitions in the chipmaking sector  the latest Intels $17 billion swoop on Altera  are promising plenty of them. Some acquirers may manage to work magic on their top lines, but its optimistic to think all of them will.

title: Djokovic vs. Nadal: A Quarterfinal That Feels Like a Final
description: PARIS  As most had hoped and everybody had expected, there was no altering the collision course.

title: No Food Fights for Large African Herbivores
description: How is it possible that so many large herbivores coexist in Africa? That incredible diversity is possible because each species has a distinct diet, a new study concludes. Little is known about the specific plants that elephants, impalas, zebras and other large herbivores eat. With a technique called DNA metabarcoding, researchers at Princeton University analyzed the feces of seven species, matching gene sequences they found to a reference library of plant DNA. All of the species consumed different diets, the scientists found, even those similar in size, digestive physiology and location. The findings, which appear in the Proceedings of the National Academy of the Sciences, may help researchers maintain wildlife diversity in the African savannas.

title: Washingtons Wine Surge
description: Washingtons winemaking production has more than doubled in the last decade, and one reason is the drought.

title: Drought Is Bearing Fruit for Washington Wineries
description: YAKIMA, Wash.  American wine, for all the hype and hyperbole in recent years about Idaho rieslings or Pennsylvania pinot noirs, is still overwhelmingly a California thing. Even in an off year, wineries there produce more than 20 times as much wine as the vineyards here in Washington State, the perennial No. 2 in the rankings.

title: A Likely Path for Senate Approval of a Surveillance Bill
description: WASHINGTON  After Senator Rand Paul forced the temporary expiration of some of the governments surveillance powers on Sunday night, the Senate voted overwhelmingly to take up a bill approved by the House that would renew some of those powers but also shift the storage of telephone records from the government to the phone companies.

title: Gazans Hopes for Rebuilding After War Give Way to Deeper Despair
description: GAZA CITY  On a street here crammed with glittery clothing and electronic shops, Mahmoud Matar flipped through the receipt book for his appliance store, much of it blank: His lone sale that day was a $7 kettle. It was clear whom he blamed for his poor sales: Gazas Islamist Hamas government.

title: Supreme Court Ruling Little Help to Struggling Homeowners
description: Justice Clarence Thomas and his Supreme Court colleagues decided on Monday that the bankruptcy code would continue to be of little help to underwater homeowners, though he suggested that he perhaps wished it could be otherwise.

title: Londons Newest Private Club Will Always Be at Least 51% British
description: London has a long history of private clubs, with perhaps more members-only establishments per capita than any other city in the world. That latest is the South Kensington Club, which officially opens today and has wellness as its focus. Luca Del Bono, the owner and a co-founder of Quintessentially concierge service, says he got the idea while living in New York, where hed often go to the Russian Turkish Baths in the East Village. At the time, Londoners were too prudish. Fifteen years ago, an English man would not even admit they would have a massage, he recalls. But nowadays people are so conscious about being healthy and fit. He describes South Kensington Club as a members club with a gym, a bathhouse and a saltwater Watsu pool.

title: English Abbeys Caffeinated Wine Gains Popularity and Scrutiny
description: BUCKFAST, England  Sticky, sweet and flavored like spiced wine, with a hint of violet and a jolt of caffeine, the alcoholic drink produced here for the last century by Benedictine monks is the heart of a thriving enterprise.

title: Dozens of Museum Leaders Sign Protest Letter Over Exclusion of Gulf Labor Activists
description: Dozens of curators and museum officials from around the world have signed a letter opposing recent decisions by the United Arab Emirates to prevent three people who have publicly criticized labor practices there from entering the country.

title: Microsoft Sets Date for Windows 10
description: Microsoft has finally said when Windows 10, one of its biggest products in years, will be available: July 29.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Taxidermys Best in Show
description: Competitors vie for the top spot at the World Taxidermy Championships, held in Springfield, Mo., and billed as The Greatest Taxidermy Show on Earth.

title: Inside The World Taxidermy Championships
description: Competitors from 48 states and as far away as New Zealand came to submit their best specimens.

title: Masters of Taxidermy Seek to Replicate More Than an Animals Appearance
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo.  They entered through the convention hall lobby  a mounted menagerie of dead mammals, birds and fish whose owners paused in the natural light to primp them to perfection before the show. A man in a camouflage cap tweezed a pheasants plumage into place. Another man, wielding a blower-vacuum, fluffed the mane of a lion suspended midpounce over a warthog, and a woman brushed what looked like a perfectly coifed weasel.

title: Washingtons Wine Surge
description: Washingtons winemaking production has more than doubled in the last decade, and one reason is the drought.

title: Critics Choice Television Awards
description: Red-carpet looks from the fifth annual awards show at the Beverly Hilton Hotel in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: A Trio of Classic Cocktail Recipes, Made New Again With Trendy Aejo Tequila
description: Tequila is growing up and expanding its boundaries  no longer a merecheap foundation for obliterating, sugary-sweet cocktails.Darker, premium golden-amber-hued aejos, hailing from the rainy highlands and arid valleys outside of Guadalajara, Mexico and aged in wooden barrels for at least 12 months, garner attention all on their own for their sophisticated flavor. This spring gives rise to a new wave of pricier, ultra-aged extra aejos(casked in wood from three to seven years), like Patrns rare and limited Extra Aejo 7 Aos, which are best enjoyed sipped (pass on the snifter and opt for Riedels Vinum Tequila glass  a Champagne-style flute), not mixed into a margarita.

title: Four Militants Killed in Gun Battle With Indian Troops
description: NEW DELHI  A gun battle in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir, in an area close to the disputed border with Pakistan, left four militant fighters dead, the Indian Army said on Monday in a statement.

title: Pictures of the Day: The United States and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the United States, Indonesia, Japan and Burundi.

title: June 1, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from the United States, Thailand, Burundi and Indonesia.

title: In Performance | Germn Jaramillo
description: A Spanish-language scene with Mr. Jaramillo, who plays Fidel Castro in Hierba Mala Nunca Muere, a farce by Juan Claudio Lechn at Repertorio Espaol.

title: U.A.B. Set to Reinstate Football After Outcry
description: The mood six months ago at the University of Alabama at Birmingham was one of shock, sadness and anger when President Ray L. Watts announced that the university would be the first in nearly two decades to drop its top-tier football program, blaming the rising costs of the sport.

title: Review: A Ship of Fools, Each Stuck in Isolation
description: Ship of Fools, by the Israeli team of Niv Sheinfeld (choreographer) and Oren Laor (director), begins with its three characters separated into lanes like lap swimmers. These lanes are metaphors for the boundaries between selves, and this 2011 dance-theater work, which had its New York premiere at Abrons Arts Center over the weekend, is a kind of play about whether these people can break out of their solipsistic prisons, understand one another and be understood.

title: Review: Maria Schneider Orchestras The Thompson Fields, Connections to the Natural World
description: MARIA SCHNEIDER ORCHESTRA

title: Review: Girlpool, in Before the World Was Big, Grows Up and Loud
description: GIRLPOOL

title: What Judy Blumes Books Meant
description: People have intense feelings about Judy Blume. Fans, readers, booksellers  even other authors and celebrities  often dissolve into tears upon meeting her, confessing that books like Forever ...  and Are You There, God? Its Me, Margaret got them through adolescence; taught them about sex, love and friendship; and provided their first glimpse of adulthood. Ms. Blume has come to expect overwrought reactions.

title: Hillary Clinton Lawyer Accuses Wisconsin of Trying to Suppress the Vote
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons top campaign lawyer has filed a second voter-access lawsuit accusing a Republican-led state of trying to suppress the vote  this time in Wisconsin, home to Scott Walker, the governor and likely Republican 2016 presidential candidate.

title: Review: The Shepherds Life, by James Rebanks, an English Sheep Farmer
description: James Rebankss captivating new book about his familys small sheep farm in England is also a book about continuity and roots and a sense of belonging in an age thats increasingly about mobility and self-invention. Its a book about a way of life essentially unchanged for centuries in an era thats all about change and flux. And its a book about a farming family whose history has played out in the fields, hills and villages between the Lake District and the Pennines for at least six centuries.

title: On Eve of Tony Awards, Broadway Box Office Dips
description: After a big Memorial Day weekend brought a strong end to a record-breaking season, Broadways box office sales sagged a bit last week.

title: A Simple Sanctuary
description: Finding a place to stay in the Hamptons during the summer can be a greater headache than the traffic, hence the anticipated reopening of the Chequit on Shelter Island. Built in 1872 as a dining hall for a local Methodist group, it has been transformed into a quaint boutique hotel with bright, airy rooms overlooking the harbor. Theres also a new restaurant, Red Maple  named after the towering tree in the center of the outdoor terrace  that serves up small plates such as smoked bluefish rillettes and oysters from nearby Montauk.

title: Obama Plans to Nominate Roberta Jacobson to Be Ambassador to Mexico
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will nominate Roberta S. Jacobson, the top State Department official for Latin America and his point person in negotiations to re-establish diplomatic ties with Cuba, to be the United States ambassador to Mexico, the White House said Monday.

title: Review: Ever After, a Slipperless Cinderella Tale, at the Paper Mill Playhouse
description: MILLBURN, N.J.  The Cinderella story received a realistic reboot in the 1998 movie Ever After, in which Drew Barrymore portrayed the heroine as a spunky, take-charge girl who wins her prince without benefit of any supernatural intervention, or even a glass slipper. The popular film has now become  surprise!  a storybook-pretty if bland stage musical, making its premiere at the Paper Mill Playhouse, with Margo Seibert supplying the requisite spunk in the central role, Christine Ebersole taking over from Anjelica Huston as the wicked stepmother, and the experienced Kathleen Marshall directing and supplying the dances.

title: Bribery Inquiry Drawing Closer to FIFAs President, Sepp Blatter
description: Federal authorities believe that Sepp Blatters top lieutenant at FIFA made $10 million in bank transactions that are central elements of the bribery scandal engulfing international soccer, United States officials and others briefed on the case said Monday. The revelation puts the money trail closer to Mr. Blatter, FIFAs president, than had been previously known.

title: Review: Jinkx Monsoon Is Back, and Pregnant, in The Vaudevillians: Bringing Up Baby
description: Poor Kitty Witless. Its a little embarrassing not being quite sure who fathered your unborn child, but she also seems hazy on whether the conception took place in this century or the last.

title: Past and Present Collide in Pittsburgh
description: The Carnegie Museum of Art enlisted writers to reflect on the archives of the pioneering African-American photographer Charles (Teenie) Harris to better understand Pittsburgh today.

title: Saddened by the Love Locks Lost
description: Hundreds of people from around the world responded to the news that Paris was removing the many love locks from the Pont des Arts by posting photographs of themselves at the bridge and lamenting the lost locks.

title: The Court and Online Threats
description: If you post violent thoughts about someone on Facebook, does it matter what you intended to convey when you wrote the words?

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Ahmed Zayat, American Pharoahs Owner, Is Named in $10 Million Libel Suit
description: The lawyer for the man who alleges that Ahmed Zayat has not paid a $2 million gambling debt filed a $10 million libel suit on Monday against Zayat, the owner of American Pharoah.

title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: The Chip Industry Consolidates
description: Recent months have seen a flurry of deals in the semiconductor sector, a business that has become prohibitively expensive for all but the biggest players.

title: Review: New Amsterdam Singers Perform a Text-Inspired Concert
description: Concert programmers often try to create thematic links between seemingly disparate works. But the New Amsterdam Singers event on Thursday at St. Ignatius of Antioch Episcopal Church on the Upper West Side was united by only what was described in the program as unusually appealing texts.

title: Red-Tailed Hawk Is Winning White House Turf Battle
description: WASHINGTON  A newcomer has arrived at the White House, provoking fierce turf battles and carrying out more than one lethal confrontation in broad daylight. But this is no political power struggle; it is nature.

title: Hundreds Missing After Chinese Cruise Ship Sinks on Yangtze
description: BEIJING  Most of the 458 people aboard a chartered cruise ship in China were still missing on Tuesday morning, more than a dozen hours after the vessel sank during a torrential rainstorm along the central Yangtze River, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency.

title: Rikers Island Health Care Provider May Lose Deal With New York
description: A private health care company that has been criticized for doing such a poor job at the Rikers Island jail complex that its medical performance contributed to several inmate deaths is expected to lose its contract with New York City, according to two high-ranking city officials.

title: An Art Festival in Bushwick, Tim Burton Movies at Lincoln Center
description: Bushwicks art scene can seem impenetrable from the outside.

title: Becoming Caitlyn Jenner
description: The transformation throughout the years it took for Bruce Jenner to become Caitlyn Jenner.

title: Tanith Lee, Fantasy and Horror Novelist, Dies at 67
description: Tanith Lee, who could not read until she was 8 but started writing when she was 9 and went on to compose more than 90 science fiction, fantasy and horror novels, died on May 24 at her home in East Sussex, England. She was 67.

title: Reflections on Stress and Long Hours on Wall Street
description: Earlier this year, a 22-year-old first-year analyst at the Goldman Sachs office in San Francisco was feeling overwhelmed by the all-nighters and 100-hour workweeks.

title: Justices Curb Bankruptcy Filers Ability to Have Second Mortgages Canceled
description: Handing banks a victory, the Supreme Court ruled that financially struggling homeowners who file for bankruptcy may not expect to have their second mortgage loans canceled, even if they owe more on their homes than the properties are worth.

title: Presidential Hopefuls on the N.S.A.
description: Here is where some of the 2016 presidential hopefuls stand on the governments vast surveillance authority.

title: African Countries Are Urged to Investigate Reports of Abuse by Peacekeepers
description: GENEVA  The top human rights official at the United Nations has urged several African members to intensify their efforts at prosecuting what he described as longstanding allegations of egregious abuses, including summary killings, by troops they had sent to keep the peace in the Central African Republic, one of the continents most dysfunctional and chaotic countries.

title: Missouri Reports Wide Racial Disparity in Traffic Stops
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Police officers in Missouri were 75 percent more likely to stop black drivers than white drivers last year, and 73 percent more likely to search black drivers, according to a report released Monday by Chris Koster, the states attorney general.

title: Americans and Turks Discuss ISIS Threat
description: WASHINGTON  American and Turkish officials are discussing a joint effort to clear Islamic State fighters away from Turkeys southern border, a senior State Department official said on Monday.

title: Irans Nuclear Stockpile Grows, Complicating Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON  With only one month left before a deadline to complete a nuclear deal with Iran, international inspectors have reported that Tehrans stockpile of nuclear fuel increased about 20 percent over the last 18 months of negotiations, partially undercutting the Obama administrations contention that the Iranian program had been frozen during that period.

title: FIFA Film: An Epic Fantasy
description: First came an international roundup of several of its top officials on federal corruption charges, including a hotel sweep down the street from its headquarters. Close behind came the pageant of its autocratic presidents re-election on a platform of: Eh, just a few bad apples.

title: Gunplay Rises in New York, Reviving Issue for de Blasio
description: Shootings in New York City have been rising for two straight years, the first time that has happened since the end of the 1990s, when the city was still in the early years of a remarkable downturn in crime.

title: Seeking Rate Increases, Insurers Use Guesswork
description: In a sign of the tumult in the health insurance industry under the Affordable Care Act, companies are seeking wildly differing rate increases in premiums for 2016, with some as high as 85 percent, according to information released on Monday by the federal government for the 37 states using HealthCare.gov as their exchange.

title: The Safety Net That Ruth Built
description: In March 1920, soon after being purchased by the Yankees, Babe Ruth sought a disability insurance policy from what was then called the Hartford Accident and Indemnity Company.

title: In Debate Over Patriot Act, Lawmakers Weigh Risks vs. Liberty
description: WASHINGTON  Just one senator voted against the Patriot Act, calling it a violation of civil liberties when it passed in the frightening, angry days after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. Nearly 14 years later, 77 senators voted to advance a bill ratcheting back its expansive scope.

title: European Leaders Assemble for Urgent Meeting on Greek Crisis
description: ATHENS  As the Greek government faces a looming debt payment, top European leaders met in Berlin on Monday night to reach a consensus over what to do about Greece, signaling the urgent need to unlock emergency financing for the cash-starved country and avoid a devastating default.

title: Betsy Palmer, 88, Dies; From TV Panelist to Friday the 13th Villainess
description: Betsy Palmer, an actress bound to be remembered by different generations for different career incarnations  as a performer on live television, as a panelist on game shows and as one of Hollywoods more bloodthirsty villainesses  died on Friday in hospice care near her home in Danbury, Conn. She was 88.

title: Bluff Called,Mitch McConnell Misplays His Hand in Phone Data Fight
description: WASHINGTON  For Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican entering his sixth month in his dream job of majority leader, the congressional struggle over National Security Agency surveillance powers produced a lose-lose-lose result.

title: Warriors Andrew Bogut Seems Content With Role Defined for Him
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Andrew Bogut, the starting center for the Golden State Warriors, was watching the Cleveland Cavaliers play the Atlanta Hawks in the Eastern Conference finals on television last week when a conversation among the analysts caught his attention.

title: South Korea: 2 Die of MERS Virus
description: Two South Koreans have died of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, the government said Tuesday, the countrys first confirmed deaths from the virus. The two patients  a woman, 58, and a man, 71  died Monday, the Health Ministry said in a statement. Both were being treated for respiratory ailments in a hospital last month when they had contact with the nations first MERS patient, a 68-year-old man who tested positive after a trip to the Middle East. South Korea has so far detected 25 MERS cases  mostly found among the hospitals staff, patients and visitors  and more than 680 people have been placed in isolation after having contact with those infected. The syndrome has killed hundreds of people in the Middle East.

title: Takata Says It Will No Longer Make Side Inflater Linked to Airbag Defect
description: As it prepared for a congressional hearing on Tuesday, the Japanese auto supplier Takata vowed on Monday to stop producing the driver-side inflaters that have been tied to a defect in its airbags. But the company said it would continue using an airbag propellant that experts said was dangerous.

title: Sub
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Anyone hungry? Pull up a chair and tuck in, because Bruce Haight is catering todays Wordplay gathering, which is darned nice of him, if you ask me.

title: Consumer Group Better Markets Hires Away Top House Aide
description: Consumer advocates often bemoan Washingtons revolving door between government and industry, but one group is taking a page out of that playbook to make a seemingly counterintuitive hire.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A majority of the Giants off-season workouts are voluntary, although in the N.F.L., where contracts are not guaranteed, attendance is expected and most players comply.

title: A New Suite of Pure Hair Products
description: Since Susanne Kaufmann first launched her holistic skincare line over 10 years ago in her Austrian spa, her hand-packaged creams and cleansers have gained a cult following for their hippie essence: built with natural ingredients and perfumed with non-allergenic scents. Her new haircare collection  a suite of seven products to wash, condition and repair free-flowing strands  is equally pure. Our focus was purely to encourage the natural beauty of the hair from within, hair that is strong and grows well, without any extra help or wild promises, Kaufmann says. Just let that hair grow and give it what it needs, and the result will be hair just as it should be. The range uses silk and sugar-based cleansing systems and is free from synthetic additives, silicone and chemical agents. Next, Kaufmann plans to introduce styling products.

title: Robert McKinleys Beach-Chic Style at Home in Chelsea
description: This piece of wood, I can see having for the rest of my life, says Robert McKinley, rubbing his hand along the edge of an ash wood table in the Chelsea apartment he shares with his fiance, Kate Nauta. Maybe it will be a bench or something else one day, says the 38-year-old designer, hotelier, D.J., artist and creative director. I try to reuse wood as much as possible. The slab of wood began its life as the leftovers of a project: McKinley brought the scrap home while designing the hotel Ruschmeyers in Montauk. Now, it sits atop matte black powder-coated tubular steel legs in the couples third-floor brownstone space, where they like to entertain. He makes fabulous pasta, says Nauta, a model, actor and singer who just returned from the Bahamas, where she recorded her first album with Lenny Kravitz as producer.

title: Rock Posters With a Mod Touch
description: The Portland, Ore.-based artist Dan Stiles is known for his bright colors, clean lines and witty abstractions. Over the course of his two decades as a graphic designer, hes worked with some of the worlds most recognizable corporations (IBM, Old Navy, the X Games), reimagined book jackets by beloved 20th-century authors (Anthony Burgess, Bohumil Hrabal) and even created unique soda packaging in honor of the Presidents commitment to farm-to-table eating. In his new book, One Thing Leads to Another ($25, PowerHouse) Stiless work is given a career-spanning retrospective, with full-color pages that showcase his eye-popping, overprinted style.

title: Vladimir Putin Hides the Truth

He continues to insist that Russian soldiers and weapons are not involved in the conflict in the eastern sector of the country, despite evidence to the contrary from NATO, the United States and independent journalists.

title: Finding a Slave Ship, Uncovering History
description: The trans-Atlantic slave trade that sent 12.5 million human beings in chains from Africa to the Americas  killing about two million along the way  has been described by the historian David Brion Davis as one of historys greatest crimes against humanity. It was driven not by hatred, but by greed. The colonizers  including Spaniards, Portuguese, Dutch, British, French, Danes, Swedes, Brazilians, and North Americans  wanted cheap labor for sugar, tobacco, coffee, indigo and other goods demanded by the aristocracy.

Raised in Piedmont, an affluent suburb of Oakland, Kim was in college during the rise of Facebook, and he watched in amazement as tech start-ups transformed the world around him. After graduating in 2006, he found work in the industry, at Zynga, Monster.com and LinkedIn.

title: The Making of Zombie Wars, by Aleksandar Hemon
description: The Summer of Love rolled into town and left behind an S.T.D. otherwise known as 1968. The Vietnam War ratcheted up the body count. Racial strife led to nationwide riots. The murders of Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert Kennedy must have made the end times seem at bloody hand. Cue Nixon and that silent majority. Forty-seven years later we still live in the eras apocalyptic shadow, those events a zombie horde in ever-present pursuit  race issues, ill-considered wars, the Russians  that infects us with the undead past. Oh, and you can also blame 1968 for that unfortunate metaphor, because in October of that year George A. Romeros Night of the Living Dead introduced us to a new kind of zombie: slow yet relentless, brainless yet hungry, endlessly symbolic yet always supercool. These flesh eaters have fed well on our culture, evolving from B-movie ghouls to bankable, if thankless, stars of film and screen, book and video game, to the point where they should probably unionize. We are living in peak zombie. Now, into this fray tiptoes Aleksandar Hemon with his latest novel, The Making of Zombie Wars.

title: Girl at War, by Sara Novic
description: You dont need to experience something to remember it, a former child soldier remarks in the final pages of Sara Novics outstanding first novel, Girl at War. title: How the Civil War Changed the Constitution
description: The most obvious constitutional result of the Civil War was the adoption of three landmark constitutional amendments. The 13th ended slavery forever in the United States, while the 14th made all persons born in the United States (including the former slaves) citizens of the nation and prohibited the states from denying anyone the privileges and immunities of American citizenship, due process or law, or equal protection of the law. Finally, the 15th Amendment, ratified in 1870, prohibited the states from denying the franchise to anyone based on race, color, or previous condition of servitude.

title: The Migrant and Refugee Crisis
Morning Agenda: Reflections on Wall Street Culture
description: REFLECTIONS ON WALL STREET CULTURE | Last week, Thomas J. Hughes, a 29-year-old banker at Moelis & Company, was found dead with drugs in his system after falling from a building in Manhattan. In April, Sarvshreshth Gupta, a 24-year-old first-year analyst at Goldman Sachs, was found dead in San Francisco after telling his father about suffering from intense stress. The official cause of death has not yet been determined in either case, but a recent string of deaths among young Wall Street workers have prompted financial firms to re-evaluate their work policies impact on staff members,  Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. Its difficult to definitively link a death to a firms work conditions, and Mr. Sorkin notes that studies have suggested that financial service employees are at higher risk than those in many other industries. Still, the string of deaths on Wall Street appears to rise above the level of simple coincidence, he writes.
