A coalition of architects, preservationists and landscape designers, joined recently by the Municipal Art Society, had been trying for months to stop the plan.

title: Stssy Celebrates 35 Years and More
description: Plus: The Ace Hotel has teamed up with Tokyobike; Salvatore Ferragamos make-your-own moccasin and more shopping news.

title: Public Enemy No. 9
description: When Luis Surez runs out onto the field for Barcelona in Saturdays Champions League final against Juventus, there will be no shortage of players with a score to settle with him on the other side.

title: Zac Posen Resort 2016
description: Looks from the collection.

title: Pakistans Pace of Executions Alarms Rights Groups
description: ISLAMABAD  Human rights groups expressed concern over the fast pace with which Pakistani authorities are executing death row prisoners, as the total number of executions for the year reached at least 135 this week, higher than for any full year in a decade.

title: The Liberalism of Adult Autonomy
description: Reflecting both on Caitlyn n Bruce Jenner andthe Gallup data that inspired my own sojourn into polygamy, Damon Linker argues that social conservatives (in particular, his friend and mine Rod Dreher) are wrong to portray the rise of social liberalism as a matter of individualism unbound from all moral restraint. Rather, it represents the triumph of one distinctive moral code, the morality of rights, over another, the morality of ends:

title: Appealing to Union, Hillary Clinton Calls Teachers Scapegoats
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton made an appeal for an endorsement from the American Federation of Teachers this week, suggesting in a private meeting with union officials that critics have turned teachers into scapegoats for all of societys problems.

title: Ali Smith Wins Baileys Womens Prize for Fiction
description: Ali Smith won the Baileys Womens Prize for Fiction on Wednesday at a ceremony in London, for How to Be Both, an innovatively structured novel about a young girl in modern-day England and a painter in Renaissance Italy.

title: As Republican Debates Near, Candidates Vie to Make Cut
description: Carly Fiorina is on the clock, a nine-week clock to be exact. That is when the first Republican debate of the 2016 election will happen. And if she does not get her poll numbers up, she will not make the cut.

title: Did the American Civil War Ever End?
description: When did the Civil War end? Many have answered never. As late as 1949, in an address at Harvard, the writer Ralph Ellison said that the war is still in the balance, and only our enchantment by the spell of the possible, our endless optimism, has led us to assume that it ever really ended.

title: What Do You Know? A Civil War Pop Quiz.
description: If you havent noticed, Americans have been commemorating the sesquicentennial of the Civil War for the past four years. There have been large-scale public events, battle re-enactments and lecture series. There have been books, articles and blog posts. The New York Times started Disunion in October 2010 and its columns have detailed events large and small; people famous and obscure; and causes won, lost, remembered and forgotten between 1861 and 1865.

title: French Telecom Executives Remarks on Israel Incite Furor
description: JERUSALEM  A growing global pro-Palestinian movement to boycott Israel instantly created a national furor on Thursday after the top executive of Orange, a leading French telecommunications company, said he would withdraw from the Israeli market if he could.

title: Sharing Data, but Not Happily
description: Should consumers be able to control how companies collect and use their personal data?

title: New York Festival of Song Announces New Season
description: The New York Festival of Song once again has a busy, diverse season ahead, with works by Rachmaninoff, John Lennon and Paul McCartney, and the contemporary composer David T. Little.

title: Fracking Has Not Had Big Effect on Water Supply, E.P.A. Says While Noting Risks
description: WASHINGTON  A landmark Environmental Protection Agency report on the impact of hydraulic fracturing has found no evidence that the contentious technique of oil and gas extraction has had a widespread effect on the nations water supply, the agency said Thursday.

title: Review: Alexander Calders Intimate, Encompassing Multum in Parvo
description: If you require further proof of the greatness of Alexander Calder, this exceptional show should do the trick. Intimate and encompassing, it is like a drawing retrospective in three dimensions: a selection of nearly 50 small mobiles and stabiles, a few less than two inches tall, that this American sculptor executed between the mid-1930s and around 1970.

title: Review: Harry Dodge Meditates on Identity With The Cybernetic Fold
description: Harry Dodge is a transgender artist, and although his current solo show  his second for this gallery  doesnt specifically address his own trajectory or biography, it meditates seriously, and deliriously, on the fluid nature of identity and how technology alters bodies and consciousness.

title: 3-D Film About Twin Towers High-Wire Walk to Open New York Film Fest
description: Continuing a recent tradition of using its prestigious opening-night slot to highlight an Oscar aspirant from a mainstream studio, the New York Film Festival said on Thursday that it would open its 53rd installment in late September with the world premiere of The Walk, a 3-D dramatic thriller directed by Robert Zemeckis.

title: When Ownership Changed in 2007, So Did the Blackhawks
description: The most common way to turn around a terrible sports franchise is to acquire better players or bring in a new coach. But in the case of the Chicago Blackhawks, the most important change may have been the passing of team ownership from a father to a son.

title: Dish Network Joins Deal Mania With Bid for T-Mobile
description: Merger mania has taken over the media business.

title: Chlo Resort 2016
description: Looks from the collection.

title: Religious Leaders Urge U.S. to Fund Abortions for Rape Victims in Conflicts Abroad
description: WASHINGTON  A starkly worded ad began appearing this week at bus stops near the White House. Next to a silhouette of President Obamas back reads the words: Dont walk away from women and girls raped in conflict. Act now.

title: Belmont Stakes 2015: Predictions and Analysis
description: The horses for the 147th running of the Belmont Stakes are listed in order of post position with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. The morning-line odds were set by Eric Donovan of Belmont Park.

title: Corsican Wines Speak a Language of Their Own
description: PATRIMONIO, France  Antoine Arena was a promising law student in Paris in 1975 when the Corsican independence movement took a violent turn.

title: Review: Deborah Kass Takes Mug Shots of the Art World
description: Considering Deborah Kasss smart and funny show of screen-printed, black-and-white images apparently copied  and much enlarged  from police mug shots, the casual gallery visitor might wonder: Who are these people? What crimes did they commit? Those who know their Pop Art history will recognize Ms. Kasss Americas Most Wanted, 1998-1999 as a late-1990s update of Andy Warhols 1964 work 13 Most Wanted Men, which featured the most wanted criminals of 1962. Seven of Ms. Kasss works, each seven-and-a-half-feet wide, show their subjects in profile and from the front with a fake police identification placard in the lower left corner. Three more are single head shots.

title: Flu-Driven Mass Slaughter of Midwest Poultry Conveys the Scale of Our Meat Habit
description: Heres a brief look behind headlines from the Midwest about the scope of the poultry slaughter necessitated by the spread, since last December, of the H5N2 strain of bird flu.

title: Review: Tom Burckhardt Juggles the Geometric and Organic
description: Tom Burckhardts ingeniously thin-skinned paintings may be too appealing to be taken as seriously as they deserve. Brilliant-colored collagelike abstractions, they segue effortlessly between organic and geometric forms that somewhat cartoonishly intimate figures, buildings and landscapes, and resonate with the similarly small, ambiguous paintings of Howard Hodgkin and Thomas Nozkowski.

title: Every Virus a Person Has Had Can Be Seen in a Drop of Blood, Researchers Find
description: Using less than a drop of blood, a new test can reveal nearly every virus a person has ever been exposed to, scientists reported on Thursday.

title: Global Warming Hiatus Challenged by NOAA Research
description: Scientists have long labored to explain what appeared to be a slowdown in global warming that began at the start of this century as, at the same time, heat-trapping emissions of carbon dioxide were soaring. The slowdown, sometimes inaccurately described as a halt or hiatus, became a major talking point for people critical of climate science.

title: Ad Backing Martin OMalley Jabs at Hillary Clinton and Jeb Bush
description: A new TV ad from the super PAC supporting former Gov. Martin OMalley of Maryland is titled Wall Streets Public Enemy No. 1. But it seems the intended target of the ad is Hillary Rodham Clinton and Jeb Bush.

title: Burials From Germanwings Flight Are Delayed by Paperwork Errors
description: PARIS  More than two months after a Germanwings co-pilot deliberately crashed his airliner into the French Alps, the families of the 150 people who perished in the disaster had, at long last, been preparing to put their loved ones to rest.

title: SunGard Files to Go Public After a Decade Owned by Private Equity
description: One of the last megadeals from the buyout boom is headed back to the public markets.

title: FIFA Paid Ireland Not to Protest Costly Hand Ball
description: The chief executive of Irelands soccer association said Thursday that FIFA had quietly paid compensation to his federation after a controversial hand ball by Frances Thierry Henry prevented Ireland from qualifying for the 2010 World Cup.

title: Recent Reporting on College: A Reading List for High School Students
description: Most Junes we mark the end of the school year by rounding up commencement-speech advice and suggesting ideas for teaching and learning from it.

title: About Last Night
description: In the Villa Aurelia, a 17th-century wonder surrounded by acres of gardens, the 2015 McKim Medal Laureates were feted under twinkling Italian stars.

title: Crawling Back From the Ledge
description: The thing about marrying the boy you fell in love with at 18 is that it can be hard to see him as anything other than the lanky, nervous teenager you kissed by your locker after class when you thought no one was looking.

title: Serena Williams and Lucie Safarova Reach French Open Final
description: PARIS  Lucie Safarova triumphed over her nerves Thursday, Serena Williams over her health.

title: Bowled Over
description: I have a job and a boss that I love. I keep a bowl of chocolates on my desk for everyone to enjoy. My boss has given me gift cards to thank me for keeping it full. Yesterday, she went to the doctor. Before she returned, her husband, who also works in the building, took me aside and said his wifes tests indicated that she should no longer eat sweets, or she will face the same early death as her mother. He also told me not to tell her we spoke. When she returned, my boss said she was in top shape. What to do?

title: What Were Reading Now
description: President Obama announced a plan to address the troubling decline in honeybee populations by making seven million acres of federal land more bee-friendly. But environmentalists say that by not addressing the pervasive use of toxic pesticides, the presidents measures dont go nearly far enough.

title: Tourists in South Korea on MERS Scare
description: Tourists in South Korea on Thursday described their feelings about the outbreak of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome in the country.

title: Obama to Meet With Iraqi Prime Minister to Discuss ISIS Advance
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will meet on Monday with Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi of Iraq to discuss the military campaign against the Islamic State, White House officials said on Thursday, as the militant group continues to make gains despite an American-led counteroffensive.

title: S.E.C. Charges Man in Bulgaria in Fake Takeover Offer for Avon
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday charged a Bulgarian man with misusing an important federal database for filing securities documents to submit false takeover bids for two companies, Avon Products and Rocky Mountain Chocolate Factory.

title: A $136 Million Powerball Ticket, Stashed in a Staten Island Plumbers Basement
description: Fortunately for Anthony Perosi, his truck broke down.

title: Governors Ball, Now in Its Fifth Season, Hits Its Stride
description: WHEN Big Boi was touring as a solo act in 2011, he played a brand-new festival on Governors Island in New York Harbor. The sound was banging  the crowd was bananas, he reminisces. Most fondly, he recalls he had to take a ferry to get there.

title: Rick Perry Announces Presidential Bid
description: The former governor of Texas, Rick Perry, formally announced in a rally on Thursday that he will be seeking the Republican nomination for president in 2016.

title: Viewfinder: Maryam Sahinyan
description: A look at the subjects photographed by Maryam Sahinyan in her 20th-century Turkish portrait studio.

title: Colbert Picks Jon Batiste as Late Show Bandleader
description: Now that Stephen Colbert has started to give audiences a sense of what he really sounds like (at least when hes not playing his blowhard pundit character from The Colbert Report), hes letting viewers know what his version of The Late Show will sound like, too.

title: 1913: Atomic Bombs End a World War
description: This feature looks at some of the earliest mentions of famous names or terms in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

title: A Chandelier That Stands the Tests of Time
description: I like instruments that try to quantify the ephemeral; a barometer traces air pressure, or an astrolabe charts the stars, and this measures the passing of time, says the artist Alison Berger, gesturing to a printout from the book Pocket Watches: From the Pendant Watch to the Tourbillon. The anatomy of the once-everyday trinket, and her training as an architect and as a glassblower, informed her latest creation, the Clock Chandelier. One gear moves slowly and the other moves quickly  large and small, fast and slow, she says, a rhythm articulated in the spacing of the chandeliers lightbulbs and candles suspended from three interlocking bronze and steel rings. Berger, who has made so-called heirlooms for the upcoming generation (think cereal bowls, in lieu of egg cups) for Herms and has constructed a new faade for a Comme des Garons store, considered each detail: The candlelit lanterns can be unhooked for cleaning and the rings fit together using pins, as they would in a timepiece. The chandelier looks open and endless from one view, but on the other side it is more compressed, Berger says  a metaphor, she explains, for the feeling of, Oh my god, its already 5 oclock.

title: Universal Pictures Named in Wrongful Death Lawsuit
description: LOS ANGELES  The off-screen drama surrounding the coming music biopic about the rap group N.W.A., Straight Outta Compton, increased this week when the studio behind the film, Universal Pictures, was named in a related wrongful death lawsuit.

title: Ralph Lauren Resort 2016
description: Looks from the collection.

title: Two Lose Jobs at Brooklyn Group Home Where Rape Suspects Lived
description: Two workers at a group home for boys in Brooklyn have been fired after an investigation revealed that they were falsifying logbooks intended to keep track of residents, a person familiar with the case said on Thursday.

title: Dinosaur Fossil Is From a Close Relative of Triceratops
description: A newly described horned dinosaur with peculiar ornamentation was a close relative of Triceratops, paleontologists have found. The dinosaur had a longer nose horn than Triceratops, and two small horns above its eyes. But its most distinctive feature was a radiating frill, a set of large, pentagonal plates like a crown atop its head. Researchers at the Royal Tyrrell Museum of Palaeontology in Canada named their find Regaliceratops peterhewsi. They first stumbled on the bones sticking out of a cliff along the Oldman River, in southeastern Alberta, about a decade ago. Like other horned dinosaurs, Regaliceratops probably evolved during the late Cretaceous, 65 million to 100 million years ago. Its nearly complete skull is described in the journal Current Biology.

title: Okonomi
description: Japanese breakfast served daily in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: At Okonomi, Dont Look for French Toast
description: The egg lies in a cup like a clouded eye. At the edges, ruffles of white have half-set, wispily afloat in a sauce of sake and soy. The center is mere veil, the yolk a faint glow beneath, firmer than the white but still ready to run. You dont eat it, you pour it  into your bowl of rice, as you would milk into oatmeal, and stir.

title: The Duffel Bag, Updated
description: Perfect for weekend, these carryalls are roomy enough for shoes and clothes but still fit under the seat in front of you.

title: Beware a Bluff From Dishs Poker-Playing Boss
description: A poker pro like Dish Networks chief executive, Charles Ergen, knows it is possible to win without the best cards. His hand may be getting weaker, however, as the cable and telecommunications industries consolidate rapidly around him. Mr. Ergen would be making a bold bet by merging his $35 billion satellite operator with similarly sized wireless provider T-Mobile US. Investors may want to guard against a bluff.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Love & Mercy
description: Bill Pohlad narrates a sequence from his film about Brian Wilson, featuring Paul Dano.

title: After Midnight
description: This exhibition at the Queens Museum examines Indian modern art from 1947 through the 1970s, and contemporary art from 1997 to the present.

title: Rick Perrys Close Bond With Lone Survivor Marcus Luttrell
description: Former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas made clear on Thursday that his passion for the military will be front and center during his second bid for the White House.

title: Love & Mercy (With Movie Trailer): Bill Pohlad Narrates a Scene
description: The filmmaker Bill Pohlad tells the story of the musician Brian Wilson at two stages in his life in Love & Mercy. The drama shows the Beach Boys singer-songwriter as a young man (played by Paul Dano) preparing the album Pet Sounds in the studio. And a parallel narrative follows the musician two decades later (and played by John Cusack), struggling to repair his life and meeting Melinda Ledbetter, the woman he would fall for.

title: Living With Cancer: Keep On Cooking
description: Julia put a glass jar of turkey-tail mushrooms on the restaurant table. Drinking home-brewed tea helps her combat the side effects of treatment. The day before a blood test  which would reveal whether or not an experimental drug was working  I placed one delicate bit on the center of my palm. The ridged striations and concentric ruffles reminded me of the tiny angel-wing shells that Leslies partner had collected on Sanibel Island for our cancer support group.

title: Rehearsing to Break a Leg at the Tonys
description: A look at preparations onstage and off for Sundays Broadway awards celebration.

title: Indian Artists Look Westward, and Homeward, at the Queens Museum
description: In 1997, Jane Farver, the farsighted and much-loved American curator who died in April in Venice, put together an influential exhibition called Out of India: Contemporary Art of the South Asian Diaspora at the Queens Museum.

title: Inaugural Seattle Art Fair Announces Lineup of Galleries
description: First-time art fairs often struggle for recognition, for an audience and for participation by the kinds of galleries that might actually draw collectors and a crowd. But the new Seattle Art Fair, to take place at the end of July, is not your average first-time fair.

title: Abacus Bank Found Not Guilty of Mortgage Fraud and Other Charges
description: A jury found Abacus Federal Savings Bank and two of its senior officers not guilty of grand larceny and other charges on Thursday after a four-month trial, rejecting the Manhattan district attorneys attempt to prove that the bank systematically lied for years to the Federal National Mortgage Association about the qualifications of its mortgage applicants.

title: Dish and T-Mobile: Last of the Telecoms Mega-Deals?
description: If it seems like the telecommunications industry has been playing a game of musical chairs, the music might be about to stop. Thats because Dish Network, the satellite-TV company, is in talks to buy T-Mobile US, the wireless phone company, in what would probably be the last mega-deal in the industry for a while.

title: Ouest on the Upper West Side Will Close
description: Ouest, Tom Valentis reliable Upper West Side restaurant for the last 14 years, will be closing, though no date has been set. I told the staff not to take any reservations after June 13 because I wasnt sure how much longer wed be open, whether it would be another week or two, or whatever, Mr. Valenti said in a phone conversation on Thursday.

title: Viagra for Women Is Backed by an F.D.A. Panel
description: After an intense lobbying campaign, a federal advisory panel recommended approval of what would become the first drug to treat a lack of sexual desire in women.

title: A Starlit Dinner in Rome
description: Last night, the American Academy in Rome honored Carlo Petrini, the founder of the Slow Food Movement, and the filmmaker Paolo Sorrentino at a dinner chaired by Ginevra Elkann. The McKim Medal Laureates were feted (by the likes of chef Alice Waters and Ts editor in chief, Deborah Needleman) under twinkling Italian stars at the Villa Aurelia, a 17th-century wonder surrounded by acres of gardens, for their contributions to the arts and humanities  and received medals designed by Cy Twombly. The photographer Gianni Cipriano captured the evening for T.

title: Gucci Resort 2016
description: Looks from the collection.

title: Christian Siriano Resort 2016
description: Looks from the collection.

title: Zac Zac Posen Resort 2016
description: Looks from the collection.

title: The People in American Pharoahs Corner
description: Images along American Pharoahs journey to try to become horse racings first Triple Crown winner since Affirmed in 1978.

title: Ahmed Zayats Journey: Bankruptcy and Big Bets
description: Before his name was on the lips of horse lovers, American Pharoah was known simply as Hip No. 85 and was drawing attention two summers ago for all the wrong reasons. He was a large, lovely bay yearling with a tiny scrape on the back of a front ankle that was beginning to swell. His sales price was dropping each time prospective buyers watched him walk amid the barns at the Fasig-Tipton Saratoga Sale in upstate New York.

title: Stacking Up the Presidential Fields
description: The Republican party has 16 major presidential candidates this cycle  three times the number of Democrats and more than any other field in recent history.

title: In ISIS, the Taliban Face an Insurgent Threat of Their Own
description: JALALABAD, Afghanistan  For nearly as long as the Taliban have been at war, Maulvi Abbas has been in the middle of it, leading a small squad of insurgent fighters in Nangarhar Province and demonstrating a certain talent for survival and success.

title: American Pharoah Trains at Belmont
description: Bob Baffert, the trainer of the Triple Crown contender American Pharoah, said he was aware of the looming pressure but was trying to take it all in stride.

title: Inside The Times: News and Opinion Strictly Separate at The Times
description: Andrew Rosenthal, The Timess editorial page editor, talks about the strict separation between Times news coverage and opinion writing.

title: Questions on Spectrum Animate T-Mobile-Dish Merger Talks
description: At the center of the merger talks between T-Mobile and Dish Networks is the value of spectrum, the airwaves that carry communications signals.

title: A Brooklyn BartenderInspired by Guatemala
description: Ivy Mix has been a competitive equestrian. She has run with the bulls in Pamplona, Spain. She has smuggled mezcal over the Guatemalan border.

title: Burundi Postpones Elections Amid Violence
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  After weeks of unrest that left dozens of protesters dead and drove tens of thousands of people to flee the country, the government of Burundi has postponed parliamentary and presidential elections that were scheduled for this month.

title: Review: Notes of a Native Song Is Stews Homage to James Baldwin
description: The singer and songwriter Stew pays homage to the great African-American writer and activist James Baldwin in Notes of a Native Song, a song cycle adorned with some casual commentary and video  or, as Stew puts it in a program note, just a bunch of songs with banter in between.

title: Task Force Formed to Investigate Northern Colorado Shootings
description: DENVER  The random shootings of a bicyclist killed on a county road and a woman shot in the neck as she drove home from work have stirred unease across suburban communities in northern Colorado and prompted the local police, county sheriffs and the F.B.I. to form a task force to investigate.

title: Pictures of the Day: Myanmar and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Myanmar, China, Greece and Syria.

title: Review: New York Philharmonic Gives Mozart His Due
description: The New York Philharmonic, soon to vacate Avery Fisher Hall for the summer, is stealing a march on the Mostly Mozart Festival, which moves in next month. As the festival continues to evolve in directions that have less and less to do with its namesake, the Philharmonic, perhaps sensing an opportunity, offers a Mozart program of its own this week: the Prague Symphony and the Piano Concertos No. 20, in D minor, and No. 21, in C, with Jeffrey Kahane as guest conductor and soloist.

title: June 4, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Myanmar, China, Greece and Syria.

title: Review: Cedar Lake Ballet Taking Its Final Bows
description: As ballet companies across the country struggle to build audiences, especially young audiences, the troupe with one of the youngest, most adoring fan bases is closing. Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet was founded 12 years ago by Nancy Laurie, a Walmart heiress who, through an unusual single-patron model, financed most of the enterprise  until recently, when she decided to stop. Suddenly, the company was preparing to vacate its Chelsea theater; its next New York show would be its last.

title: Paddle8, Art Auction Site, Sees Growth
description: Its still an open question whether high-end art buying on the Internet will take off. But one online auction site, Paddle8, says it is enjoying a bit of a breakthrough. Its highest price points are rising, regularly breaking $100,000, according to Kate Brambilla, a senior director of business development. And as both buyers and consignors become more comfortable with the Web, the site is seeing a rising trend of single-owner sales  those where a single collector is willing to consign a group of works to the auction house for sale at once.

title: When Low Turnout Is to a Partys Benefit
description: Equal-population congressional districts help Democrats win with fewer voters. They outperform their share of the popular vote in House elections because they tend to fare best in the districts with large numbers of ineligible voters.

title: MoMA Acquires Hundreds of August Sander Photographs
description: A procession of faces from another era is coming to the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Frick Collection Plans Show on the Flemish Painter Anthony van Dyck
description: The Frick Collection has decided its time for a new look at Anthony van Dyck.

title: The Other Basque Country
description: Spain may be the more vocal segment of the region that straddles the two countries, but in France, it also has a singular identity.

title: Narciso Rodriguez Resort 2016
description: Looks from the collection.

title: What Jeb Bushs Official Announcement Will Mean
description: Be the first to know, says the website teasing the great day (6.15.15) when apparently Jeb Bush is going to announce something big.

title: This Weeks Movies | June 5, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Entourage, Spy and Testament of Youth.

title: Review: William Styrons My Generation, Musings of a Pacing Lion
description: William Styrons literary reputation was in limbo, if not apocalyptic decline, well before his death in 2006. His big novels  Lie Down in Darkness (1951), The Confessions of Nat Turner (1967) and Sophies Choice (1979)  can seem like elegiac museum pieces, or mass-market paperbacks left too long in the sun.

title: A Good Stamp Is Hard to Find
description: English majors, say hooray: Flannery OConnor is on a postage stamp. It comes out Friday and costs 93 cents.

title: Tony Voters Speak, in a Royal We
description: Three actresses play the graphic novelist Alison Bechdel at different stages of her life in the Tony-nominated musical Fun Home, and this year three of us worked the phones  and the cocktail-party circuit  to predict who might win Broadways top prizes at Sunday nights ceremony.

title: Review: Testament of Youth Recalls the Great War With Little Nostalgia
description: Testament of Youth, James Kents stately screen adaptation of the British author Vera Brittains 1933 World War I memoir, evokes the march of history with a balance and restraint exhibited by few movies with such grand ambitions. Most similar films strain at the seams with bombast and sentimentality. This one, with a screenplay by Juliette Towhidi (Calendar Girls), is consciously old-fashioned  or should I say traditional?  while maintaining a sober perspective.

title: The Tony Awards Broadcast: Broadways Chance to Woo America
description: THE funeral home jingle is an upbeat crowd-pleaser in a show that more often prompts tears. Three winsome children, emerging from hiding in a coffin, pretend to record a TV spot for their family business, and the comic lyrics and antic dance moves invariably provoke rousing applause from the rapt audiences that are now packing into Circle in the Square Theater to see Fun Home.

title: Review: Mark Morris and Haydn Join to Brighten Houston Ballet Program
description: HOUSTON  Why hasnt Mark Morris set more dances to works by Joseph Haydn? An important part of this famously musical choreographers talent has been applied to pieces by composers from the late 17th century to the late 18th  notably Purcell, Bach, Handel, Gluck and Mozart. Haydn (1732-1809) isnt just a central composer of that period; he also often exemplifies the same qualities as Mr. Morris: high spirits, terrific humor, a strong inclination to the pastoral and a keen instinct for structural experimentation. Last week, the Houston Ballet gave the premiere of Mr. Morriss The Letter V  choreographed to Haydns Symphony No. 88 in G (1787). (Some Haydn symphonies were once known by letters of the alphabet; V was assigned to this one  hence this ballets title.)

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Review: In United Passions, a Fictionalized FIFA, Underwritten by the Soccer Group
description: It turns out there is such a thing as bad publicity after all. Just ask Sepp Blatter.

title: Hacking Linked to China Exposes Millions of U.S. Workers
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Thursday announced what appeared to be one of the largest breaches of federal employees data, involving at least four million current and former government workers in an intrusion that officials said apparently originated in China.

title: Review: Wild Horses, a Film by and Starring Robert Duvall
description: Could Robert Duvalls incoherent melodrama Wild Horses have been salvaged by a skillful editor? Probably not. Mr. Duvalls first directorial effort since Assassination Tango in 2003, this film is the story of Scott Briggs (Mr. Duvall, now 84), a hard-bitten Texan rancher deep into his twilight years. It has majestic man-on-horse-under-the-Southwestern-sky cinematography, and in its best scene, Scotts three grown sons get drunk in a roughneck bar and stumble into a brawl with some cowboys. But such moments are too scattered to make this jumble of a film come together.

title: 12 Hours Before Yangtze Disaster, Tourists Enjoyed a Morning on Land
description: CHIBI, China  The tourist park here beside the Yangtze River was bustling on Monday with cruise ship passengers on a port of call. They strolled through the lush grounds, laughing and taking pictures. Some sat next to a lake and a line of toy cannons pointed over the water.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Were trying something new: a quick nightly rundown of the days top stories. What do you think? Let us know at briefing@nytimes.com.

title: One Year: A Century of Birthdays
description: Ilvy Njiokiktjien got a glimpse into Dutch culture when she photographed birthday celebrations for people from 1 to 100 years old.

title: In Greek Debt Puzzle, the Game Theorists Have It
description: That Yanis Varoufakis, the rakish Greek finance minister, would meet with senior European officials wearing a leather motorcycle jacket and open-collar shirt would probably have fascinated John F. Nash Jr., the Nobel prize -winning mathematician, game theorist and Princeton professor who was thrown from a taxi and killed last month.

title: TKTKTKTKTK
description: TKTKTKTKTK

title: Review: Emmet Gowins Poignant Pairings at the Morgan Library
description: When a museum invites an artist to make an exhibition by selecting works from its permanent collection, the outcome rarely disappoints. Something magical often ensues from artist and institution joining forces and, forsaking the usual rigors of art-making or exhibition-shaping, going slightly off the grid.

title: Review: Insidious: Chapter 3 Keeps a Franchise Rolling
description: In 2011, James Wans Insidious, the tale of a family terrorized by malign spirits, was the little horror movie that could: On a budget of $1.5 million, it made almost $100 million worldwide. Its sequel, in 2013, cost about $5 million and took in around $162 million. How did these modest pictures, virtually devoid of gore, nudity and cursing, prove so profitable? With decent actors, for one thing. And with simple but cohesive plots, tidy production values, effective Boo! moments and a sense of humor. What more could a 14-year-old at the mall on a Friday night ask for?

title: Movie Listings for June 5-11
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Pop, Rock & Cabaret for June 5-11
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: The Nightmare, Rodney Aschers Look at Sleep Paralysis
description: In Room 237, the director Rodney Ascher invited armchair experts to share their theories about secret meanings in Stanley Kubricks movie version of The Shining. Annotated clips allowed viewers to play along.

title: Movie Review: Spy
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Spy.

title: Comedy Listings for June 5-11
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for June 5-11
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Classical & Opera Listings for June 5-11
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Review: Entourage
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Entourage.

title: Dance Listings for June 5-11
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Theater Listings for June 5-11
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: The Tallest Man on Earths Solo Act Gets a Backing Band
description: The Tallest Man on Earth  the (inaccurate) stage name of the songwriter Kristian Matsson  rarely stands still when he performs. In his sold-out concert at the Beacon Theater on Wednesday, he used every inch of his long guitar cord to roam the stage: darting around, crouching, stretching, hip-twitching, perching briefly and jittering away, but always ending up back at the microphone when he had more words to sing.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for June 5-11
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
description: 96 YEARS AGO

title: Spare Times for June 5-11
description: Museums and Sites

title: Spare Times for Children for June 5-11
description: Science Fair

title: Boston Officials Move Quickly to Share Video in Terrorism Suspects Shooting
description: BOSTON  Immediately after the police and the F.B.I. on Tuesday shot and killed a black Muslim man who had been under surveillance for possible terrorism, law enforcement officials moved quickly to share information with civic and religious leaders, hoping to quell any potential unrest.

title: Power Lunch Proceeds at Four Seasons Despite Abuse Case Against Co-Owner
description: It looked like any other lunch hour at the Four Seasons: Power brokers here, A-listers there. There were boldface- name types like Henry A. Kissinger, the former secretary of state, and Henry R. Kravis, the private equity billionaire. There was small talk at the bar.

title: Movie Review: Testament of Youth
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Testament of Youth.

title: Review: Love & Mercy Gets Inside Brian Wilsons Head
description: The first thing you see in Love & Mercy is an extreme close-up of Brian Wilsons ear. Its a startling image, and it holds out a twofold promise: that the film will take viewers inside its protagonists head and that it will pay particular attention to the role that sound played in his life.

title: Black Caucus Is Wooed for Trade Pact Votes
description: WASHINGTON  About a week ago, Representative Cedric Richmond of Louisiana, a passionate champion for the poor in New Orleans and the lone Democrat in the states congressional delegation, received a phone call from President Obama, pleading for his vote to enhance the presidents trade negotiation powers.

title: Petco Takes Full Responsibility for Retrievers Death, but Says Heat Was Not the Cause
description: The sad question of what happened to Colby, the golden retriever, has gripped dog lovers for days.

title: Review: Hungry Hearts, a Drama About Love and Obsession
description: Saverio Costanzos Hungry Hearts begins promisingly with a meet-cute scene that compresses the progress of relationship intimacy into just a few minutes. Jude (Adam Driver) and Mina (Alba Rohrwacher) find themselves locked in the bathroom of a Chinese restaurant, where they are forced to share close quarters, endure unpleasant odors and get to know each other.

title: Ted Cruz Wonders About Jeb Bushs Viability
description: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has said he will not take shots at his Republican rivals for the presidency, but on Thursday he questioned descriptions of Jeb Bush as a front-runner and wondered whether Mr. Bush could win an early state in the nominating contests.

title: Review: In We Are Still Here, Ghostly Inhabitants Can Be the Toughest to Evict
description: Trying to make a fresh start after their college-age son, Bobby, dies, Anne and Paul Sacchetti (Barbara Crampton, Re-Animator and Andrew Sensenig, Upstream Color) make a move in bleakest winter. Like many judgment-impaired horror movie couples, they leave the city, presumably Boston, where they must have friends and perhaps livelihoods, for creepy Aylesbury, Mass., a village of strangers. Their new home? A charmless, isolated, hideously decorated handyman special built in 1859 for the short-lived town undertaker.

title: Gawker Media Employees Vote to Form a Union, and the Bosses Approve
description: Employees at Gawker Media, the company that publishes websites like Gawker and Jezebel, voted by a substantial margin on Wednesday to form a union, a first for a prominent digital media outlet.

title: N.I.H. Finds Contamination at Pharmacy
description: WASHINGTON  The National Institutes of Health said on Thursday that it had suspended operations at a specialized pharmacy that is part of its clinical center in Bethesda, Md., after fluid used in experimental studies was found to be contaminated with fungus.

title: Ben Carsons Speaking Career Turned Lucrative Fast, Filing Shows
description: A speech at the National Prayer Breakfast in 2013 that started rumblings about a Ben Carson presidential campaign also began a lucrative speaking career.

title: Third Trial Is Set for Mubarak in Killing of Egyptian Protesters
description: CAIRO  A judge on Thursday ordered former President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt to again stand trial on murder charges in the killing of protesters during the 2011 uprising against his 30-year rule.

title: Senator Seeks Inquiry Into Visa Program Used at Disney
description: Senator Bill Nelson of Florida, a Democrat, called on Thursday for the Department of Homeland Security to investigate a temporary visa program for highly skilled immigrants after a report in The New York Times that technology employees at Walt Disney World in Orlando and other companies lost their jobs to immigrants and had to train their replacements.

title: Review: In Charlies Country, a Refugee in His Homeland
description: In Australian cinema, the wilderness has long served as a rebuke to the primacy of Western civilization. With Twelve Canoes and now Charlies Country, the Dutch-Australian director Rolf de Heer has portrayed the lived experience of Aboriginals that are often treated as part of an exotic landscape. Using a combination of bleak realism, fatalistic humor and a healthy dose of sentimentality, Mr. de Heer traces the downward spiral of a man who has become a refugee in his own homeland.

title: Review: Freedom Stars Cuba Gooding Jr. as a Slave Fleeing to Canada
description: Freedom takes a compelling chapter in American history  the flight of slaves from Southern bondage to Canada via the Underground Railroad  and flattens its drama. The film pursues twin narratives: one, starting in 1856, presents the trek of a slave, Samuel Woodward (Cuba Gooding Jr.), and his family from the Richmond, Va., area to points north; the other, beginning in 1748, follows the fact-based story of John Newton (Bernhard Forcher), an English slave trader voyaging from Gambia to Charleston, S.C.

title: Review: Doomsdays, a Jaunt Into Strangers Homes in the Catskills
description: Nowhere in particular is only a throwaway line in Doomsdays, but it couldnt be more essential to our understanding of its two main characters. Its where theyre from, where theyre going and where their heads are at, these vagabonds who invade empty vacation homes in the Catskills and squat until forced to move on.

title: Margaret Juntwait, the Voice of the Met on Radio, Dies at 58
description: A teacher who heard Margaret Juntwait talking had some advice: You should consider a career in radio. She did not pay much attention. She was preoccupied with studying for a sixth-grade math test.

title: Saudi Arabia and Israel Share a Common Opposition
description: WASHINGTON  A new merging of strategic interests between Saudi Arabia and Israel was on display on Thursday as two former officials from those countries appeared on the same stage to discuss their concerns about Irans actions across the Middle East.

title: Hillary Clinton Says G.O.P. Rivals Try to Stop Young and Minority Voters
description: HOUSTON  Hillary Rodham Clinton on Thursday accused Republicans including her potential rivals Jeb Bush, Scott Walker and Rick Perry of deliberately trying to stop young people and minorities  both vital Democratic constituencies  from exercising their right to vote, as she presented an ambitious agenda to make it easier for those groups and other Americans to participate in elections.

title: Hardening of Positions Undercuts Ukraine Peace Accord
description: SHYROKYNE, Ukraine  The trenches near this battered town in southeastern Ukraine slice surreally for miles across fields of sunflowers, in places running in three lines separated by a mile or two of mined ground, Ukrainian commanders say.

title: Pat Perez, a Late Bloomer at 39, Finds Success Both on and Off the Course
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  No way did a young Pat Perez picture himself where he popped up Thursday, strolling the exquisitely manicured golf course that Jack Nicklaus built and grabbing, albeit briefly, a share of the lead in the first round of the 40th Memorial Tournament.

title: Bevo Francis Dies at 82; Scored 116 and 113 Points in College Basketball Games
description: In 1954, Bevo Francis scored 113 points in a single college basketball game, setting an N.C.A.A. record that stood for nearly six decades. But he may be remembered as much for a game that was wiped from the books, when he piled up 116.

title: What You Need to Know About MERS
description: Q. What is MERS?

title: One Day, Italys Gianluigi Buffon Wants to Call the Shots, Not Stop Them
description: TURIN, Italy  It is hardly surprising that Gianluigi Buffon, the longtime goalkeeper for Juventus and the Italian national team, thinks often about the future.

title: Hand to God Play Sued by Abbott and Costello Heirs Over Use of Whos on First?
description: The Broadway play Hand to God has ridden its foul-mouthed humor, as well as a wry use of Bud Abbott and Lou Costellos Whos on first? baseball routine, to five Tony nominations.

title: Review: In Patch Town, Animated Toys Work the Factory Line
description: Give Patch Town credit for seeking a fresh niche: Its not as though we have a glut of musical fairy tales inspired by Eastern European folklore in which vivified toys revolt against an unscrupulous corporate overlord.

title: Edward Snowden: The World Says No to Surveillance
description: MOSCOW  TWO years ago today, three journalists and I worked nervously in a Hong Kong hotel room, waiting to see how the world would react to the revelation that the National Security Agency had been making records of nearly every phone call in the United States. In the days that followed, those journalists and others published documents revealing that democratic governments had been monitoring the private activities of ordinary citizens who had done nothing wrong.

title: Yemen: Civilians Bombed, Officials Say
description: Airstrikes carried out by a military alliance led by Saudi Arabia have killed at least 50 people in the northern Yemeni province of Saada, officials and the director of a hospital said Thursday. The victims of the bombings, in two separate districts, were mostly civilians, according to Dr. Muhammed Abdulwahab Hajar, the director of the Republican Hospital in Saada. Since the beginning of its offensive against Yemens Houthi rebels in late March, the Saudi-led coalition has been accused of killing hundreds of people in airstrikes that have at times failed to distinguish between military targets and civilian facilities, according to human rights groups. Saudi officials, who say their offensive is aimed at restoring to power Yemens ousted president, Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, have accused the Houthis of fighting from populated areas. Dr. Hajar said airstrikes on one village on Wednesday killed at least 42 people, including many who were killed in nine homes that were destroyed by the bombing.

title: Fed Deflects Outside Aid to Investigate Data Leaks
description: A review of the Federal Reserves response to recent leaks about its bond-buying plans raises new questions about the central banks efforts to police interactions with investors who can profit handsomely from inside information.

title: Portrait of Suspect in Boston Is Disputed
description: BOSTON  Usaamah Rahims family walked through a parking lot near a CVS here on Thursday and came to a stop near where Mr. Rahim was killed two days earlier by law enforcement officers.

title: Barnyard Buddies Curl Up at Belmont
description: People watching American Pharoah take his exercise at Belmont Park on Thursday morning could not help noticing that he had a friend with him. It happened to be a 6-year-old gelding named Smokey, who has been serving as general companion and calmer of nerves for American Pharoah during the horses potentially stress-filled attempt to become the first Triple Crown winner since 1978.

title: A Stunning Link to New Yorks Past Makes a Long-Awaited Return
description: At age 10, Maaret Klaber tried to find a spot alongside the Harlem River to watch a swim race around Manhattan. It was weeds over my head there, she said on Wednesday. Also, sinkholes with cars halfway in. But, Ms. Klaber said, you could tell there was a path there.

title: Problems Accompany W.N.B.A.s New Success
description: After the Phoenix Mercury swept the Chicago Sky in the W.N.B.A. finals last September, the league had reason to fondly reflect on the 2014 season.

title: Unions Subdued, Scott Walker Turns to Tenure at Wisconsin Colleges
description: CHICAGO  Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, who began building a national profile four years ago by sharply cutting collective bargaining rights for most government workers, has turned his sights to a different element of the public sector: state universities.

title: Will Holt, Who Wrote Lemon Tree and for the Musical Stage, Dies at 86
description: Will Holt, a songwriter whose lyrics for the 1970 musical The Me Nobody Knows were nominated for a Tony Award, and whose Latin-tinged folk song Lemon Tree became a musical signpost of the 1960s, covered by myriad artists and finding its way into advertising and the literature of the Vietnam War, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 86.

title: An Italian Mayor Makes His First Trip to Manhattan, and Likes What He Tastes
description: Little is the operative word these days in Little Italy. The Manhattan neighborhood south of Houston and west of the Bowery is now nearly bereft of the Italian immigrants who once packed tenements and opened so many restaurants serving marinara-drenched tastes of home that in its heyday Mulberry Street was a veritable Via Veneto.

title: Between the Lines
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  First, lets get this out of the way: Ive gone on record that I dont like RE- words in my puzzles, especially when it seems like it might be a made-up word whose express purpose is to get a constructor out of a tight corner.

title: Judge OrdersShabaka Shakur Freed From Prison After 27 Years
description: Shabaka Shakurs 27 years behind bars came to an official end on Thursday in State Supreme Court on Staten Island.

title: Review: Anna Sperber Plays With Light, Movement and Architecture in Ruptured Horizon
description: Ruptured Horizon isnt the first time Anna Sperber, a Brooklyn choreographer, has shown a fascination for the light and architecture of a space and then turned it into a frame for a non-narrative dance. How does movement alter a room? How does it make a space expand and recede?

title: French Firm Latest Target of Palestinian-Led Movement to Boycott Israel
description: While many Israelis were enraged by comments from the chief executive of the French telecommunications company Orange, who told journalists in Egypt that he would like to cut ties to an Israeli cellphone service provider that operates in the occupied West Bank, pro-Palestinian activists working to isolate Israel argued that the statement was insufficient.

title: American Legion Band Maestro Kept Baton Moving at 96
description: Irwin Meyer, 96, was an old Navy man who used to take his evening constitutional down to Sheepshead Bay from his apartment on East 21st Street in south Brooklyn.

title: Bronx Boy, 7, Killed After Car Crashes Into Restaurant
description: A 7-year-old boy was killed and his father and sister were injured when a car crashed into a fast-food restaurant in the Bronx late Thursday afternoon, the police said. The driver, identified by the authorities as Kwasi Oduro, 73, fled but was quickly caught.

title: A Michigan Lawyer Coaches His Way to the N.H.L.
description: In the summer of 1999, Tom Brennan was at a sizable disadvantage when he started looking for someone to coach his sons varsity hockey team at Lansing Catholic High School in Michigan. The position paid very little and the program had not been competitive in 25 years.

title: Silver Addresses Playoff Themes and a Dramatic Void
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Kicking off his second championship series since replacing David Stern as the N.B.A.s commissioner last year, Adam Silver expressed excitement over the matchup of LeBron Jamess Cleveland Cavaliers and Stephen Currys Golden State Warriors in his annual news conference before Game 1.

title: Have Wary Police Brought an End to the Drop in Crime?
Niese Is Having Trouble, but the Mets Have a Prospect
description: PHOENIX  Jon Niese, the only left-handed pitcher in the Mets rotation, went through his normal routine here Thursday in anticipation of his next start, on Friday.

title: L.I.R.R. Outlines Changes to Ease the Wait for a Stampede of Fans Heading Home
description: Just in time for Saturdays Belmont Stakes, the Long Island Rail Road formally unveiled a series of measures on Thursday designed to prevent thousands of fans who attend the race from having to wait hours afterward to get on a train and go home.

title: Charles Laughton, Man of Many Outsize Portraits, in The Hunchback
description: There are actors who are so singular in their appearance, inventive in their mannerism and outsize in their eccentricities that they might be called creatures. Peter Lorre was one. Charles Laughton was another  and perhaps the greatest in his dedication to his art.

title: Big Test for American Pharoahs Jockey, Too
description: American Pharoah will be only part of the equation in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday as he attempts to become the 12th Triple Crown champion and the first since Affirmed in 1978. Much will depend on the split-second decisions made by the jockey Victor Espinoza and his counterparts in a grueling mile-and-a-half contest that tests the mental acuity of riders as much as it does the stamina of horses.

title: Tony Award Nominees: In Performance
description: For the second annual In Performance Live concert, The Times invited six Tony Award nominees to sing at a lunchtime performance at 54 Below. The actors got one chance to get it right.

title: At Home With a Brooklyn Restaurant Designer, Nominated for a James Beard Award
description: If there can be said to be a Brooklyn look in the restaurant world today, Matthew Maddy is at least partially responsible for it. Many of the boroughs most beloved and stylish eateries sport warm, eclectic and detail-rich interiors created by the designer-builder-entrepreneur: the tile-adorned cocktail den Weather Up, name-checked on Girls; the Fort Greene institution No. 7; Grand Army, a new project whose partners include the owners of Mile End and Rucola and which opens to the public this week; and the casually elegant Colonia Verde, for which Maddy is nominated for the James Beard Foundation Award for Outstanding Restaurant Design, to be awarded tonight. (He has also been involved with places in Manhattan, London, Oakland and beyond.) But to hear Maddy tell it, his design signature is really about not having one. My aesthetic is just having an opinion and knowing what I like, he says. Its not a principled school of thought. All the restaurants involve such different people and cultures and communities.

title: Duro Olowu, Inspired by the World
description: The Nigerian-born, British-educated lawyer-turned-fashion-designer merges riotous prints with daring shapes for collections that transcend trends  and global boundaries.

title: Word of the Day | prefatory
description: prefatory  \pre-f-tor-e\  adjective

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 11:48 A.M. (Comedy Central) NATIONAL LAMPOONS ANIMAL HOUSE (1978) Delta House, the misfit fraternity at Faber College, is put on double secret probation by Dean Vernon Wormer (John Vernon) in an attempt to boot it off campus. In response, the fraternity members (Tim Matheson, John Belushi, above, and others) concoct a series of stratagems to improve their grades while making mischief. At its best, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, the movie isnt strictly satirical, because it doesnt need to be. The filmmakers have simply supplied the appropriate panty-girdles, crew-neck sweaters, frat-house initiation rites and rituals of the toga party, and let all that idiocy speak  very eloquently, and with a lot of comic fervor  for itself.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: 2015 N.B.A. Finals: With Overtime Surge, Stephen Curry and Warriors Squeak by Cavs
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The Golden State Warriors had the best home-court advantage in the N.B.A., the seasons most valuable player and 40 years of bottled enthusiasm uncorked for the chance at another championship.

title: Mets Record a Victory and, Possibly, a Key Loss
description: PHOENIX  Daniel Murphy hit a chopper toward shortstop in the third inning and sprinted out of the box, his legs churning, his jersey flapping. It was a routine baseball play, the kind that happen every day, the kind a youth coach might show his team as an example of how even All-Stars hustle. But Murphy eased up as he neared first base.

title: Corrections: June 5, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: One Year: A Century of Birthdays
description: For Ilvy Njiokiktjien, a stint as the Dutch national photographer turned into a never-ending party. Given the task in 2013 of exploring the theme of Family, she wondered about the moments that united extended clans. I thought of times when you see your relatives: funerals and birthdays, she said. The latter seemed more fun, and appropriate.

title: One Year: A Century of Birthdays
description: For Ilvy Njiokiktjien, a stint as the Dutch national photographer turned into a never-ending party. Given the task in 2013 of exploring the theme of Family, she wondered about the moments that united extended clans. I thought of times when you see your relatives: funerals and birthdays, she said. The latter seemed more fun, and appropriate.

title: Nestl Pulls Maggi Noodles From Shelves Across India
description: NEW DELHI  Nestls unit in India said on Friday that it would withdraw its popular Maggi brand of instant noodles from stores across the nation, after mounting concerns over reports that some samples contained high levels of lead.

title: Calling on Chancellor Tisch to Punish the East Ramapo School Board
description: To the Editor:

title: Lowering the Basket for W.N.B.A. Games
description: To the Editor:

title: Layoffs at Disney, and Immigrant Replacements
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Problem With Powerful Women
description: WHEN Hillary Rodham Clinton conceded the Democratic presidential nomination to Barack Obama, she hit all the right notes. In her speech, seven years ago this Sunday, she urged everyone who had supported her to shine their affection on him.

title: Growing Almonds and the California Drought
description: To the Editor:

title: Lone Star Stumble
description: Remember the Texas economic miracle? In 2012, it was one of the three main arguments from then-Gov. Rick Perry about why he should be president, along with his strong support from the religious right and something else I cant remember (sorry, couldnt help myself). More broadly, conservatives have long held Texas up as a supposed demonstration that low taxes on the rich and harsh treatment of the poor are the keys to prosperity.

title: New Regulations for Philanthropy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hillary Clinton, Voting Rights and the 2016 Election
description: A basic fact often gets lost in the propaganda that swirls around voting laws in this country: between one-quarter and one-third of all eligible voters  more than 50 million Americans  are not registered.

title: Dont Back Down on Russian Sanctions
description: Russias invasion and annexation of Crimea, an egregious violation of Ukraines sovereignty, prompted a strong response from the United States. President Obama used his executive authority to impose sanctions on Russia and Congress voted to ban the purchase of Russian-made rocket engines, which have been used to launch military and intelligence satellites since 2000. The White House also lobbied the European Union to enact economic sanctions.

title: The Separation Strategy on Iraq
description: In 2006, Joe Biden, Les Gelb and many others proposed plans to decentralize power in Iraq. Biden, then a United States senator from Delaware, Gelb and others recognized that Iraqi society was fracturing into sectarian blocs. They believed that governing institutions should reflect the fundamental loyalties on the ground. According to the Biden plan, the central Iraqi government would still have performed a few important tasks, but many other powers would have been devolved to regional governments in the Sunni, Shiite and Kurdish areas.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Chinese Leaders, in Stilted Talk, Urge Empathy for Families of Cruise Ship Victims
description: In Chinese Leaders, in Stilted Talk, Urge Empathy for Families of Cruise Ship Victims, Edward Wong and David Barboza write about one of the worst maritime accidents in Asia in decades.

title: Test Yourself | Saying Farewell to a Childhood Classic
description: Below, several paragraphs from a May 27 article, Goodbye F.A.O. Schwarz: Toy Lovers Prepare for Stores Closing.

title: OPEC, Keeping Quotas Intact, Adjusts to Oils New Normal
description: VIENNA  The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to keep the oil pumping, with no change in its production quotas, at the groups meeting here on Friday.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: June 5
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images from the scene of a fatal Brooklyn shooting and the sky portal at One World Observatory.

title: Settlement Awards Free Rent for Tenants Living in Construction
description: In a rare and major victory for tenants that could sound alarm bells for developers, state prosecutors have ordered that rents be waived for 11 residents of a building on the Upper West Side, after their landlord improperly tried to convert their building into a condominium.

title: Midtowns Vanishing Historic Architecture
description: The Rizzoli bookstore on West 57th Street. An automobile showroom designed by Frank Lloyd Wright on Park Avenue. And the Bancroft Building, a 19th-century red-and-white-striped limestone office building on West 29th Street. All three of these structures were gutted or leveled within the past two years, despite attempts to preserve them.

title: Re: Continental Divide
description: In our May 24 cover story, Suzy Hansen profiled the new finance minister of Greece, Yanis Varoufakis, whose defiance in financial negotiations with his European counterparts over austerity measures threatens the notion of a united Europe. Varoufakis stated that he would rather resign than lead Greeks further into economic ruin. Its not good for Europe, he told Hansen, and its not good for Greece.

title: Dronestagrams View
description: Smartphones have sneaked a camera into every pocket and purse, but there is much they can never witness. The drone, though, sees and shares all. On the social network Dronestagram, users upload images and videos theyve captured in midair, soaring over cathedrals and waterfalls and fireworks from a vantage point we once described as birds  or Gods  eye. (Dronestagram is not to be confused with @dronestagram, an Instagram account that shows the sites of attacks by U.S. military drones.) This photograph was shared by Grant Sheehan, who flew his drone over the Kereru Sheep Station in Hawkes Bay, New Zealand. In the gaze of its ovine inhabitants, we glimpse their dim recognition that a new sort of shepherd has arisen.

title: A Life in a Password
description: In a triumph of rotten timing, I began dating my first girlfriend in my final weeks of high school, just before I was to leave India for college in the United States. It was 1999, but it already feels like an unrecognizable age. We had no Skype, and phone calls would have broken the bank. Personal email addresses, however, were newly popular in India, and she had a Hotmail ID. We walked to a cybercafe, near my house in Chennai, to sign me up for a MailExcite account. In my password, I included her date of birth.

title: Self-Googling in 1997
description: On a spring afternoon in 1997 in Vienna, I googled myself for the first time. Technically speaking, of course, I didnt. Google didnt exist yet. Altavistas search engine was the best one around then.

title: Snail Mail and the Safety of Distance
description: In the fall of 1994, eight years after emigrating from Leningrad to the United States, I started using email on a regular basis. But when I wrote to my friends and parents back home, I avoided this new mode of correspondence, continuing to exchange letters with them. The reasons were not technological but emotional.

title: Hit Send, Then Pray
description: We lived on a hill in a mountainous region of Maharashtra, India. The 200 16- and 17-year-old boarding-school students were from nearly every corner of the world. The Internet connection was unreliable, as was the power plant generating electricity for the entire school. Communicating with our families was a matter of calculating probabilities: The longer it took to write an email, the higher the chance of losing your Internet connection.

title: Making and Unmaking the Digital World
description: The center of the virtual world, economically and culturally, may still be the United States, but the work of creating that world leaves a real and growing footprint overseas. American technology giants have established data centers in about two dozen countries, and electronics manufacturers draw on materials fraught with ethical and environmental concerns. Those include the so-called conflict minerals  tin, tantalum and tungsten (and also gold)  as well as rare earth metals that are available almost exclusively from China. At the same time, the rapid cycle of obsolescence and replacement that feeds the expansion also produces a lot of garbage  nearly 42 million metric tons of toxic e-waste in 2014, less than a sixth of which made it into the regulated recycling stream, with much of the rest being broken down by workers at dumps throughout the developing world. Following are a few scenes from the digital life cycle.

title: Strong Job Growth Data Eases Concerns After Winter Dip in Economy
description: You could almost hear the sighs of relief.

title: Le Selfie
description: In the 19th century, language scholars coined a new word  wanderwort  to describe old words that wandered global trade routes from one language to the next. Back then the word referred to spices and other exotic goods: Cumin can be traced linguistically to ancient Sumerian, ginger began its journey in Sanskrit and coffee and orange started in Arabic. The wanderwrter of the information age travel more quickly, of course, and now even the French, ever resistant to vulgar Anglicisms, have accepted email and le selfie, which in 2016 will make its debut in Frances Larousse dictionary. Here we collect some of the other adjustments that high-tech terminology has made to languages around the world.

title: Video of Mexican Prison Riot Highlights a Crisis as Elections Near
description: MEXICO CITY  With little interference from guards, the inmates rampage.

title: Turn-Ons: Peppermints, Cool Breezes. Turnoffs: Mares Who Move Too Fast.
description: VERSAILLES, Ky.  One by one, the stallions marched into the brick-and-stone breeding shed for a date that, if successful, would cost the mares owners anywhere from $5,000 to $100,000. Most of the stallions  including Bellamy Road, whose nickname around the barn is Bam Bam  knew exactly why they were there and consummated the relationship within minutes.

title: Recession, Politics and Policy Stretch Arizona School Budgets
description: PHOENIX  In the rural Saddle Mountain Unified School District 50 miles west of Phoenix, three new libraries have been locked since last year. In a neighboring county, an elementary school closed last month because there was no money to keep it open, even after the district agreed to shift to a four-day week.

title: Would You Be Willing to Pay for Facebook or Google in Exchange for Your Privacy?
description: Almost everywhere else in life, we have to pay for the goods and services we use. Except on the Internet, where the business model is flipped. In return for giving us free email and social media accounts on Facebook, Google and Instagram, companies collect data on us and sell it to advertisers.

title: High Inflation Makes Ukraines Troubled Situation Worse
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Olesia Verchenko looked over a selection of blackened avocados at a supermarket here recently.

title: Vodafone Confirms Talks on a Liberty Global Deal
description: LONDON  The British telecommunications company Vodafone said on Friday that it was in early-stage talks with Liberty Global, the European cable and wireless operator controlled by John C. Malone, over exchanging assets between the companies.

title: German Stance on Russia Complicates Long-Cultivated Tie as G-7 Meets
description: BERLIN  When seven world leaders meet this weekend in Germany, their agenda will include maintaining pressure on Russia over Ukraine, a policy on which the host countrys chancellor, Angela Merkel, has proved a reliable ally for President Obama.

title: Todays Travel News and Tips
description: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: The French Side of Basque Country
description: At the end of October, summer had returned to the Basque Country. Swimmers joined the surfers along the coast. A strong sun turned the Atlantic Ocean from green to blue. On a late Sunday morning, in the French fishing village of Ciboure, townspeople poured out of Lglise St.-Vincent, a 16th-century church with an octagonal tower. Some stopped to chat by a tall gray cross speckled with lichen. Little girls in poufy dresses ran in circles, squealing. A young man tended to his stooped grandfather, who negotiated old flagstone with a cane. Freshly coifed women with short-handled pocket books lingered in the courtyard. Bonne journe, called the priest to his congregation as they headed off into the narrow streets on their way home for lunch.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: 191st Street Tunnel, Now in Technicolor
description: Good morning on this cloud-covered Friday.

title: Lloyds Bank Fined $180 Million Over Handling of Insurance Complaints
description: LONDON  British regulators on Friday said they had imposed a fine of about $180 million on the Lloyds Banking Group over its handling of customer complaints about a contentious loan insurance product that has cost the industry billions of dollars. As a result, the bank said it would cut its 2015 bonus pool.

title: To Caitlyn, From a Caitlin
description: LOS ANGELES  Hello, Caitlyn! It is my pleasure indeed to #callyouCaitlyn, as everyone #callsmeCaitlin. Yes, I, too, am a Caitli(y)n, and Im so pleased to welcome you to the sisterhood. Youre in excellent company! Like Caitlin Lowe, another American Olympian, Caitlin FitzGerald, a talented actress currently on Masters of Sex, and Caitlin Macnamara, who became Caitlin Thomas when she married the poet Dylan Thomas.

title: What to Be Afraid Of
description: Some time ago, a friend of mine was hit by a bus in New York, one of almost 5,000 pedestrians killed in traffic every year. I also lost a nephew to gun violence  one of more than 11,000 Americans slain by firearms in this country. And I fell out of a tree that I was trying to prune in my backyard. I was O.K. But the guy next to me in the trauma ward was paralyzed from his fall. He was taking down his Christmas lights.

title: When Its a Crime to Withdraw Money From Your Bank
description: Dennis Hastert has not been indicted on a charge of sexual abuse, nor has he been indicted on a charge of paying money he was not legally allowed to pay. The indictment of Mr. Hastert, a former House speaker, released last week, lays out two counts: taking money out of the bank the wrong way, and then lying to the F.B.I. about what he did with the money.

title: Today in Politics: Campaign Trail Makes Room for Long Fly Balls and Weekend
description: Good Friday morning from Washington. Though the ever-growing Republican field will make for a hectic late summer, for now, theres room to mix work and play, as, for example, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey proved deft with a softball bat, and as a group of Republican candidates prepared for a day of roast pork and motorcycles.

title: Closing the Broccoli Gap
description: Ten years ago, New York Citys Department of Health and Mental Hygiene invented Health Bucks, a program designed to help the citys poor to eat more vegetables and fruit. City agencies and community groups distributed Health Bucks in high-poverty areas. If you spent $5 in food stamps at a farmers market, the Health Bucks program would give you a coupon for $2, which you could use or save.

title: North Korean Defector Opens Up About Long-Held Secret: His Homosexuality
description: SEOUL, South Korea  WHEN the North Korean defector Jang Yeong-jin arrived in South Korea in 1997, officials debriefed him for five months but still hesitated to release him. They had one crucial question unanswered: Why did Mr. Jang decide to risk crossing the heavily armed border between the two Koreas?

title: Selling E-Commerce While Avoiding Amazon
description: For all of the noise and hype  drones! one-hour delivery! get more toilet paper painlessly!  e-commerce is showing the first signs of maturing as a business. Figures from the research firm eMarketer show the rate of domestic growth falling from 16.5 percent in 2013 to 14.2 percent this year to 11.6 percent in 2018. By that point, e-commerce in the United States will still be less than 10 percent of all retail. The death of the physical store, so widely anticipated in the last few years, is nowhere in sight.

title: Ukraine Repels Separatists in Fierce Fighting, Poroshenko Says
description: KIEV, Ukraine  In what amounted to a multidimensional confidence-building campaign, President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine tried on Friday to rally international support for his country and to maintain pressure on President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, including economic sanctions.

title: Morning Agenda: Merger Mania in Media Sector
description: MERGER MANIA IN MEDIA SECTOR | Faced with a future controlled by digital and mobile, media companies are on the hunt for acquisitions as they bet that a larger scale will help them survive the disruption to their sector,  Emily Steel and David Gelles write in DealBook. Dish Network and T-Mobile are the latest to seek a merger, according to people briefed on the discussions, in a year that has already seen deals in the global media and entertainment sector reach $155.3 billion. Whats driving the frantic pace of acquisitions is the rapidly changing habits of consumers, who are increasingly shunning cable television subscriptions in favor of streaming services. Netflix and digital is pressuring the entire system, said Anthony DiClemente, a Nomura media analyst. If Dish does acquire T-Mobile, one person briefed on the negotiations said that instead of trying to bundle a Dish satellite television subscription with a T-Mobile wireless package, the new company would focus on creating a network that can stream mobile video to smartphones and tablets.

title: South Korea Reports Nine New Cases in MERS Virus Outbreak
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Nine new cases of Middle East respiratory syndrome were discovered in South Korea on Saturday, five of them stemming from transmissions at one of the countrys largest and best hospitals, as officials struggled to contain the virus that has so far infected 50 people, killing four.

title: Pressure from Chinese Authorities Forces Ex-Detained Feminist to Shutter Organization
description: A womens rights organization linked to two of the five Chinese feminists whose detention in March set off an international outcry ceased operations after pressure from the authorities led most of its staff members to quit and funding dried up.

title: Woman Says Dennis Hastert Abused Her Brother in High School
description: YORKVILLE, Ill.  As an enthusiastic young teacher and wrestling coach at the high school here, former House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert reliably had one student at his side, former classmates say. Stephen Reinboldt, a smart, slender, likable student who rose to become class president, was the wrestling teams equipment manager. For four years, he arrived at practice early and stayed late, traveled with Mr. Hastert to overnight tournaments, even when only one wrestler was competing, and went for long rides in the coachs sports car, sometimes driving it.

title: 68 Migrants Are Found Locked Inside Trucks at British Port
description: LONDON  Sixty-eight migrants, including two pregnant women and 15 children, have been found locked inside four trucks at a port in southeast England, the authorities said on Friday.

title: Europes Shared Responsibility for Migrants
description: The European Commissions proposal last week of a system of quotas to distribute migrants among the European Unions 28 member states is a welcome step toward a permanent, more equitable process for dealing with the waves of migrants seeking safety and opportunity in Europe.

title: Jesse Andrews Learns on the Fly to Write Me and Earl and the Dying Girl
