description: When he set out to be a filmmaker, Jesse Andrews had to be convinced that spending $200 on screenplay-writing software was a good investment. He admits he didnt know the first thing about writing a script. On the other hand, he was already the author of a best-selling novel, had drawn the attention of A-team Hollywood and had a production company waiting to film the movie adaptation he was just sitting down to write.

title: Video Reviews of Spy, Entourage and Testament of Youth
description: In this weeks video, Times Critics share their thoughts on Spy, Entourage and Testament of Youth. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Teenagers in The Times | May 2015
description: As regular readers know, this monthly feature is a roundup of recent articles about young people that have appeared in The Times. This month, however, writing by teenagers popped all over the paper.

title: Norway Will Divest From Coal in Push Against Climate Change
description: Norways $890 billion government pension fund, considered the largest sovereign wealth fund in the world, will sell off many of its investments related to coal, making it the biggest institution yet to join a growing international movement to abandon at least some fossil fuel stocks.

title: Mary Schapiro and Richard Kovacevich to Join Hedge Fund
description: Hudson Executive Capital had already set out to not be the typical activist hedge fund. Its stated mission is to be constructive in dealing with corporate boards, rather than taking combative stances of the likes of William A. Ackman and Carl C. Icahn.

title: Seven Leading Architects Defend the Worlds Most Hated Buildings
description: Can the fields top minds change the way we think about a doomed housing project in Naples or the most abhorred skyscraper in Paris? Allow them to try.

title: Polite in His Own Way
description: Dear Diary:

title: The French Open: From Court to Catwalk
description: It must be Paris. Playing in the French capital, which in a couple of weeks will host the fall mens wear and the couture shows, seems to have had a trickle-down effect on the French Open. As the tournament draws to a close this weekend, amid all the surprises thus far  upsets of Eugenie Bouchard, Maria Sharapova, Rafael Nadal  the most surprising thing of all has been the clothes.

title: The Jobs Recovery Is Going Strong
description: The recovery in the job market that became more robust in late 2014 and early 2015 wobbled a little in the spring. The message from the May numbers released Friday morning was this: Dont worry. Everything is just fine.

title: Rubios on the Road Have Drawn Unwanted Attention
description: Senator Marco Rubio has been in a hurry to get to the top, rising from state legislator to United States senator in the span of a decade and now running for president at age 44.

title: Daily Report: Rising Resistance Among American Consumers to Data-Mining Practices
description: Should consumers be able to control how companies collect and use their personal data?

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Hobart, Tasmania

title: Updating the Macs Software
description: Q. Should I always install updates of Mac OS X and individual applications? Ive heard that over time, they can really slow down ones computer. How do you know which are important?

title: Jason Derulo Glides Across Genres
description: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss Jason Derulos new album.

title: Chinese Workers Lift Sunken Ship
description: On Friday morning, crews using cranes and machinery righted the Oriental Star, which capsized in the Yangtze River on Monday.

title: View the Rubio Traffic Infractions
description: County records show Senator Marco Rubio and his wife, Jeanette, have been cited for numerous driving incidents over the years.

title: Penguins With Parent Problems No. 6: Dance Like Nobodys Watching
description: Whats this? A Random Penguin! Let it brighten your day. You can read more about the Penguins here.

title: 1965: U.S. Astronauts Will Reach Moon Before 70
description: HOUSTON  Apollo program chief Joseph Shea predicted yesterday [June 5] that the United States would put two men on the moon comfortably before the end of the decade. Mr. Sheas project is the $20-billion program that is building and testing a three-man spaceship for the man-to-the-moon shot, Americas No.1 goal in space. His prediction, made at a news conference, was the most optimistic that any U.S. space official has made recently concerning Americas chances of getting men to the moon before 1970.

title: Our Sense of Resignation About Data Collection
description: When it comes to data privacy, Americans seem to have given up.

title: U.S. Was Warned of System Open to Cyberattacks
description: WASHINGTON  The inspector general at the Office of Personnel Management, which keeps the records and security clearance information for millions of current and retired federal employees, issued a report in November that essentially described the agencys computer security system as a Chinese hackers dream.

title: Demand and Expectations Grow for Green Retirement Communities
description: A DIE-HARD community gardener and composter, David Conrad, 77, wanted to age in a retirement community that complemented his love of all things green. So seven years ago, he and his wife, Sally, moved to earth-friendly Wake Robin in Shelburne, Vt.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are found in Alphabet City, the Financial District, and Kensington, Brooklyn.

title: Millionaires Who Are Frugal When They Dont Have to Be
description: BOB WEIDNER likes to play a game when he goes to a high-end outlet store like Brooks Brothers or Ralph Lauren: How many things can he buy and not spend more than $100? On his last visit, the answer was seven.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties are four-bedroom homes in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and New Canaan, Conn.

title: 1940: French Planes Hit Nazi Targets
description: The French Ministry of Air last night [June 4] issued the following communiqu describing the French air raids over Germany and northern France during the last thirty-six hours: The activity of the French aviation has been unusually intense. Our bombing squadrons have attacked military objectives at Mannheim, Ulm, Ludwigshafen and Munich. The Badische Anilin factory was set on fire. These flames, rising to a great height, were plainly visible from the French frontier.

title: More Bodies Are Found as Yangtze Ship Is Lifted
description: BEIJING  Grieving relatives of the hundreds of people who died in the Yangtze River cruise ship disaster expressed growing frustration on Friday at the lack of answers from officials over why the boat capsized during a storm and at the governments attempts to muzzle their outrage.

title: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: Short-Term Health Insurance Attracts Many Despite Drawbacks
description: TEMPORARY, bare-bones insurance plans that dont meet the requirements of the Affordable Care Act are still attracting consumers, online insurance brokers report. But health experts caution consumers to be wary of the plans.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: And Down the Stretch They Come! (All Rights Reserved)
description: Whether he is calling an ordinary horse race or a Triple Crown event, Larry Collmus is never tempted to say, near the end, And down the stretch they come! Collmus, who will announce Saturdays Belmont Stakes on NBC, said: When I hear it from another announcer, I say: Thats awful. You cant say that. Its Dave Johnsons line.

title: Our Souls at Night, by Kent Haruf
description: Kent Haruf, who died in November at the age of 71, was best known for his justly praised novel Plainsong (1999). Haruf set all of his books in the fictional small town of Holt, Colo., integrating his bare-bones descriptions of the high plains so strikingly and crucially into his plots that setting is generally the first thing people mention about his work. But this emphasis can make Haruf sound parochial. In fact, his great subject was the struggle of decency against small-mindedness, and his rare gift was to make sheer decency a moving subject.

title: Inventing Reagan
description: A quarter-century after Ronald Reagan left the White House, he remains a beacon  and a mystery  to many Americans. This week, Jeff Shesol reviews a new biography by H.W. Brands, the latest attempt to capture the 40th president on the page.

title: Paris, He Said, by Christine Sneed
description: If the American dream is a steady income, a home of ones own and the promise of a better future for the kids, then the American Fantasy might be summed up in one word: Paris. (Paree!) A Parisian vision of romance, indulgence and beauty has resided in the less responsible quarter of our national psyche since Ben Franklin spent nine years there, wined and dined, wooing and wooed. Franklin, Hemingway, Stein  and Carrie Bradshaw, too. The imagined Parisian life is a heady one, so when the aspiring painter Jayne Marks, the central figure in Christine Sneeds intricate new novel, Paris, He Said, is offered an all-expenses-paid existence in the City of Light by Laurent Moller, a handsome, elegant, older gallery owner who also happens to be her lover, how can she possibly turn him down?

title: Words Without Music, by Philip Glass
description: Given that all the events of a long, rich and full artistic life can scarcely be squeezed into a moderate-size book, how does one choose, at age 78, what to put into a memoir and what to leave out? The Promethean composer Philip Glass provokes this question in his lively and colorful new book, Words Without Music, in which he offers stories from his life in varyingly detailed magnification. Whatever you think of him as a composer  self-imitator or icon of postmodern symphony and opera  Glass is one of the most articulate composers around. Insight and practical common sense pervade his new book, and reading it reminded me of hearing him speak: Hes ever thoughtful and loquacious, but he doesnt answer any questions he doesnt want to.

title: Billy Martin: Baseballs Flawed Genius, by Bill Pennington
description: They were both All-Star Yankee infielders, won five championships apiece in their playing days, and have yet to be elected to baseballs Hall of Fame (though one of them is surely on his way). Derek Jeter and Billy Martin share this much  and little else. Jeter was the games ice-cold ambassador. Martin, who may be the only manager to have thrown dirt at an umpire, was anything but. Jeters self-effacing persona positioned his success front and center. Martins histrionics nudged his achievements offstage, madness overshadowing the method. In Billy Martin: Baseballs Flawed Genius, the New York Times sportswriter Bill Pennington gives long-overdue flesh to the caricature.

title: Jonas Salk: A Life, by Charlotte DeCroes Jacobs
description: Nobody could recall a medical press conference quite like this one. On April 12, 1955, families huddled around radios, as if listening to the World Series or a championship fight. Crowds watched on television sets lining department store windows. Work stopped in offices and factories as word spread and tearful celebrations erupted. Polio Is Conquered, the headlines screamed. The vaccine developed by Jonas Salk, a 40-year-old University of Pittsburgh researcher, had been judged safe and effective following the largest public health experiment in our history.

title: The Edge of the World, by Michael Pye
description: Michael Pyes new book is bristling, wide-ranging and big-themed. Its the sort of historical work whose thesis is virtually impossible to prove, but its also a reminder that history isnt an exact science. At its most meaningful, history involves a good deal of art and storytelling. Pyes book is full of both.

title: Spectacle: The Astonishing Life of Ota Benga, by Pamela Newkirk
description: The internment of exotic peoples in expositions and world fairs was no rare event in the 19th century, when Europeans swarmed Africa and other colonial lands in search of subhumans to display. Bodies, typically brown and black, were exhibited by scientists as well as impresarios like P.T. Barnum. In fact, Barnums first success was an 1830s attraction featuring Joice Heth, fictitiously billed as the 161-year-old mammy of George Washington.

title: How I Shed My Skin, by Jim Grimsley
description: Several years ago, the actress Nichelle Nichols, who played Lieutenant Uhura on Star Trek, recounted the story of meeting Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. She told King that she planned to leave Star Trek, and he persuaded her to stay. Stop! You cannot! she recalled him saying. You are the first nonstereotypical role in television. ... For the first time, not only our little children and people can look on and see themselves, but people who dont look like us ... from all over the world, for the first time, the first time on television, they can see us, as we should be.

title: The Thrilling Adventures of Lovelace and Babbage, by Sydney Padua
description: In the late 1970s, a French computer scientist under contract to the United States Defense Department developed Ada, a programming language for military computer systems. Today the language is widely used in safety critical settings: in the military, in banks and nuclear power plants, in medical devices and air traffic control. Ada was named for the woman who has been called the worlds first computer programmer, Augusta Ada Byron King, Countess of Lovelace (1815-52), daughter of Lord Byron.

title: The Given World, by Marian Palaia
description: The story of Riley, the heroine of The Given World  Marian Palaias ardent, ambitious debut novel  might sound familiar at first. It has all the elements of a particular kind of post-60s American coming-of-age story: Farm kid leaves home for the big city (in Rileys case, rural Montana is abandoned for San Francisco) and dives headlong into adulthood, with all of its requisite heartbreak. Drugs are ingested, Janis Joplin is played on a jukebox, and many drives are taken through the countryside on motorcycles or a beat-up Mustang. But The Given World contains what feels like 12 times the usual dose of tragedy within its pages, because Riley and her generation come of age poisoned by the Vietnam War. They are its secondhand casualties; the war has upended their world and rewritten its rules of gravity, so that they fall hard and fall often.

title: The Anchoress, by Robyn Cadwallader
description: Earlier this year, three British-born Muslim girls, ages 15 and 16, ran away from London to Syria to join ISIS. What could possibly have attracted them to a sect of fundamentalist thugs who use religion to justify violence and misogyny? Might the rebellious, hormonal storm of their age be partly to blame? Robyn Cadwallader, probably didnt have ISIS in mind when she sat down to write The Anchoress, her affecting novel about a teenage girl walled up in a village in 1255 England, but the parallels are there if one chooses to consider them.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Coup de Foudre, by Ken Kalfus
description: You can always count on a murderer for a fancy prose style, as Nabokovs Humbert Humbert admitted, and in his spectacular novella Coup de Foudre, Ken Kalfus has created an equally articulate monster. First appearing in Harpers and collected now with his latest short stories, Coup de Foudre is a thinly  or possibly barely  veiled account of the Dominique Strauss-Kahn affair, in which Strauss-Kahn was accused of sexually assaulting a housekeeper at a New York City hotel. The criminal charges, which led to the disclosure of a hidden world of sex parties and erotic compulsion, came to nothing. But Strauss-Kahn eventually paid a hefty fine after a civil action, and his reputation was ruined, perhaps because of the question that was impossible to ignore: What made him do it? What would cause the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, wealthy and successful beyond measure, to risk everything in such a fashion?

title: Orhans Inheritance, by Aline Ohanesian
description: Orhan Turkoglu, the protagonist of Aline Ohanesians first novel, stands to gain a lot when his 93-year-old grandfather, Kemal, dies in 1990. But although the old mans will grants him the familys thriving rug business, their home in Anatolia is, to everyones surprise, left to a stranger, a woman named Seda Melkonian, now 90 and living in a nursing home in Los Angeles. Wasting little time, Orhan is soon boarding a flight to California, intent on confronting this mystery woman. Who is she, and what was she to Kemal?

title: Robert Goddards The Ways of the World, and More
description: In the company of fictional detectives who emerged from their wartime experiences shellshocked and haunted, former Lt. James (Max) Maxted, the dashing protagonist of Robert Goddards historical espionage thriller THE WAYS OF THE WORLD (Mysterious Press, $25), is a refreshing throwback to an earlier romantic tradition of heroes. Max was an ace fighter pilot with the Royal Flying Corps in World War I, and having had what the British call a good war, hes not content to settle down on his familys ancestral estate now that its over. But Maxs dreams of starting a flying school are dashed when his diplomat father, Sir Henry Maxted, falls to his death while in Paris as a member of the British delegation laboring over the Treaty of Versailles.

title: Inside the List
description: Save the Ducklings: Chuck Palahniuk  who remains best known for the 1996 novel Fight Club, despite a string of subsequent hits  has another hardcover best seller with his first story collection, Make Something Up, new at No.8. Theres no mistaking Palahniuks sense of plotting. Heres how Robert Brink of the website The Hundreds sums up the collection: So this one kid, hes pledging for a frat and drops acid, the Hello Kitty kind, right before hes about to be a contestant on The Price Is Right. And this other guy, he slaps his prostate-cancer-ridden, morphine-pickled father square in the face with a pie as hes dying in his hospital bed. And then theres these high school kids who begin to lobotomize themselves with cardiac defibrillators because they discovered the key to true happiness. Yep, thats Palahniuk. Even casual fans, though, may be interested to know that Make Something Up is not the only new book Palahniuk is promoting  hes also written his first graphic novel, and its a sequel bearing the straightforward title Fight Club 2. In an interview with The Wrap, he explained he needed some distance before he felt ready to revisit this story. If I followed it up too soon, he said, my whole career would be writing progressively less interesting sequels to Fight Club. He chose the comics format, he said, because if it was written as a novel or a film, itd be compared to previous versions. ... Certain things work in comics because theres a slight aspect of unreality. Given his reputation for disturbing readers, Palahniuk was asked, what makes him personally squeamish? I saw a headline about animal abuse recently, he replied. Man Runs Over Ducklings With Lawnmower. That kind of stuff.

title: A Quiet Benefit of Interactive Journalism
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Stuff We Liked
description: Here are the things on the web that delighted us this week:

title: Families in Fiction
description: EARLY WARNINGBy Jane Smiley476 pp. Knopf, $26.95.

title: Walmart Board Elects New Chairman
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark.  Walmarts board elected a new chairman on Friday, only the third chairman in the retail giants history. The post again passed on to a member of the founding Walton family.

title: California Farmers Dig Deeper for Water, Sipping Their Neighbors Dry
description: Early one morning in late April, Parvinder Hundal stood beside a hole in the ground at the edge of his almond farm near Tulare in the Central Valley of California. The hole, which was about the size of a volleyball and was encased in a shallow block of concrete, was the opening of a well, one that went hundreds of feet into the earth. He had paid $100,000 to have it drilled, but it wasnt producing water. Mr. Hundal was hoping that if he cleaned out the well, the water would start flowing again.

title: Even Low-Level Air Pollution May Cause Harm
description: Even low levels of air pollution may not be safe, a new study suggests.

title: Tsipras Declares Creditors Debt Proposal for Greece Absurd
description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras declared on Friday that his government would not accept a new bailout plan proposed this week by Greeces creditors, telling a cheering assembly of the Greek Parliament in Athens that he would not allow the creditors to humiliate the country.

title: Every Lash of a Whip Adds to Urgency for Its Critics
description: Present it so that the horse understands.

title: Carryalls That Carry it All
description: Finding a bag to tote gear for the sports-minded newlyweds.

title: Divided S.E.C. Reaches Compromise in Computer Sciences Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has long sought to make an example out of the Computer Sciences Corporation, a large technology company with government contracts around the world. And on Friday, the S.E.C. seized the opportunity, bringing civil charges against eight former employees and executives and extracting a $190 million penalty from the company for manipulating financial results.

title: Paperback Row
description: FORCING THE SPRING: Inside the Fight for Marriage Equality, by Jo Becker. (Penguin, $18.) Becker, an investigative reporter for The New York Times, offers a riveting fly-on-the-wall account of the five years of legal battles over Proposition 8, Californias ban on same-sex marriage, culminating in the Supreme Court case that led to its repeal.

title: Meeting Caitlyn, Saying Bye to Bruce  and Pronoun Confusion
description: What do you call a he who once was a she, or vice-versa? For grammar freaks and logolepts, Caitlyn Jennifer (formerly Bruce) Jenners very public transformation from man to woman provides an undreamed-of opportunity  and need  to create new go-to pronouns for people whose gender identification is fluid  or who reject pronouns like he, him, she and her on grounds that they are sexist or overly narrow.

title: Editors Choice
description: DAUGHTERS OF THE SAMURAI: A Journey From East to West and Back, by Janice P. Nimura. (Norton, $26.95.) In 1871, three clueless Japanese girls were sent to America, to learn how to educate their countrywomen in modern ways.

title: George Soros Bankrolls Democrats Fight in Voting Rights Cases
description: A Democratic legal fight against restrictive voting laws enacted in recent years by Republican-controlled state governments is being largely paid for by a single liberal benefactor: the billionaire philanthropist George Soros.

title: Champions League Final Is Latest Moment in Spotlight for Olympiastadion
description: A legendary track performance in front of Hitler. A record-breaking baseball game. The most famous head-butt in sports. Guns N Roses and the N.F.L. Europe.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Reagan: The Life
description: This week, Jeff Shesol discusses H. W. Brandss new biography of Ronald Reagan; Alexandra Alter has notes from the publishing world; Charlotte DeCroes Jacobs talks about her new biography of Jonas Salk; questions from readers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Profits of Drug Trade Drive Economic Boom in Myanmar
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Visitors flying into this buzzing tropical metropolis step into a modern glass-and-steel airport that symbolizes both Myanmars aspirations to rejoin the wider world after years of isolation and the countrys troubled past.

title: Phone Data Labyrinth Hinders Investigation of Amtrak Derailment
description: WASHINGTON  When Christopher A. Hart, the chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, appeared before a congressional panel this week to discuss the investigation into last months deadly Amtrak derailment in Philadelphia, lawmakers wanted to know one thing: Was the trains engineer using his phone at the time of the accident?

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Reagan: The Life
description: This week, Jeff Shesol and Charlotte DeCroes Jacobs.

title: Vietnamese Bluefish
description: Melissa Clark cooks bluefish fillets in a robust, peppery sweet sauce.

title: Dont Fear the Bluefish
description: Bluefish are feisty, both on the line and on the plate.

title: Stadium of Dreams, and Nightmares
description: Olympiastadion in Berlin has been the site of numerous famous, and infamous, sports events.

title: Hannibal Season 3 Premiere Recap: Let It Be a Fairy Tale
description: Season 3, Episode 1: Antipasto

title: Trailer: Bridge of Spies
description: A preview of Bridge of Spies, the new film from Steven Spielberg starring Tom Hanks.

title: Latin Lover, a Sendup of Italian Screen Heartthrobs
description: Saverio Crispo (Francesco Scianna), a dashing fictional film idol, has been dead for 10 years but still exerts a powerful magnetism. In the Italian comedy Latin Lover, the women in his life gather in his hometown for a memorial service and reunion attended by his two wives, Ramona (Marisa Paredes) and Rita (Virna Lisi, in her final screen appearance) and assorted offspring. He left behind five daughters from relationships in different countries. The film, directed by Cristina Comenici, opened the Film Society of Lincoln Center series Open Roads: New Italian Cinema 2015 and has one more screening on Monday at the Walter Reade Theater.

title: Wildcat! Wraps Up Forward Ferguson at JACK in Brooklyn
description: The performance space JACK is easy to miss, blending into a nondescript block of Clinton Hill, Brooklyn. What happens inside leaves a stronger impression. Directed by Alec Duffy, this three-year-old organization, the recipient of an Obie Award, makes room for rowdy, resourceful, politically conscious live art.

title: Adjusting to a World That Wont Laugh With You
description: It is often said that we are living in a golden age of comedy, when new varieties of funny sprout from every screen and nightclub stage. We are lucky to be around in the era of Hannibal Buress and Amy Schumer, of Jane the Virgin and black-ish, of Broad City and Louie, of Amy Poehler and Tig Notaro and a Saturday Night Live cast that may have finally broken that shows 40-year cycle of tokenism and dude-centrism. Every week, on cable and the networks, YouTube and Twitter, boundaries are breached, categories scrambled and stereotypes shattered as hot-button topics are transformed into grist for fresh riffs, gags and flights of goofiness.

title: Joan of Arc at the Stake, Brahms on a Barge and a Russian Day Treat
description: June is traditionally a less busy time for classical music in New York, though the New York Philharmonic has a big week with its staged performances of Honeggers Joan of Arc at the Stake (7:30 p.m., Wednesday through Friday, 8 p.m. Saturday, nyphil.org.) But Bargemusic, everyones favorite floating recital hall in Brooklyn, never slows down. An enticing concert takes place Sunday afternoon.

title: Bridge of Spies Trailer: A First Look at the Steven Spielberg-Coen Brothers Film
description: When word came that Steven Spielberg would be making his next film from a Coen brothers script, movie fans wondered what that collaboration would look like. Now the first trailer for their project, Bridge of Spies, offers some answers.

title: In Love Finds You in Charm, an Amish Woman Ponders a Bigger World
description: Second-tier cable channels looking to build an audience need anchors. A solid series can be one, of course, but so can a movie franchise, whether its the Hallmark Channels Good Witch collection or Syfys Sharknado invasion. The UP channel tries for movie-franchise momentum on Sunday night at 7 with Love Finds You in Charm, its second film adapted from the romance-novel series.

title: In Albert Oehlen: Home and Garden, a Restless, Foraging Painter
description: With an oeuvre encompassing fabric paintings, collage portraiture and pint-size pieces on paper, Albert Oehlen has been called the most unpredictable German painter working today. Starting Wednesday, a selection of his self-portraits from the 1980s, his Computer Paintings and Switch Paintings from the 1990s and more recent works, including appropriated advertising signage, will be on view at the New Museum. Billed as his first major New York exhibition, the show, Albert Oehlen: Home and Garden, was organized by Massimiliano Gioni, the museums artistic director.

title: Henry Threadgill and Jenny Hval Release New Albums
description: Henry Threadgill Zooid

title: Giorgio Moroder, the Cat in the Stache, Comes Back
description: LOS ANGELES  Giorgio Moroders living room proudly displays souvenirs from a career as a disco pioneer and pop hitmaker  a career that Mr. Moroder, who recently turned 75, is about to resume.

title: Climate Change May Drive Fish and Coral From Equator, Studies Say
description: As the climate warms, fish may flee the Equator for cooler waters with more oxygen, according to a new study in the journal Science.

title: Stock Buybacks That Hurt Shareholders
description: Were in a stock buyback binge. Companies are tripping over themselves to repurchase their own shares this year, and most investors see this as a bonanza.

title: Book Review Podcast: Reagan: The Life
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Jeff Shesol reviews H.W. Brandss new biography of Ronald Reagan. Mr. Shesol writes:

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Libido, Lice and Drinking to Excess
description: Take the Quiz

title: House Value Jumping? Save Your Home Improvement Receipts
description: A tax time bomb is ticking for an increasing number of people who have been lucky enough to see big gains in the values of their homes.

title: German Child Care Workers Strike Brings Debate on Priorities
description: HAMBURG, Germany  At 8:05 a.m. at a day care center in northern Hamburg, Alexandra Kllings 4-year-old son clung to her leg, crying. A breakfast of bread, butter, cheese, ham and milk waited, but no teachers came to coax Mika gently away from his mother and over to his place at the low table.

title: LeBron James Misses, and a Sense of Destiny Evaporates
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  In those final, frantic seconds of regulation that must have felt like the interminable eight-day wait for the start of the N.B.A. finals, Andre Iguodala was alone against the best basketball player on the planet.

title: White Lies on Mortgage Applications Are Costly to Lenders
description: Mortgage lenders have good reason to require borrowers to specify whether they intend to live in a house they are financing.

title: French Open 2015: Stan Wawrinka Beats Jo-Wilfried Tsonga to Advance to Final
description: PARIS  Stan Wawrinka had made it into his first French Open final at age 30, and the first question that came his way at his news conference involved Roger Federer.

title: Safety AgencyAdmits Missing Clues to G.M. Ignition Defects
description: Ever since General Motors began recalling cars with a defective ignition switch that has been linked to at least 109 deaths, Mary T. Barra, its chief executive, has repeatedly apologized for the automakers failings in what became the gravest safety crisis in its history.

title: Escalating Demands at Work Hurt Employees and Companies
description: Earlier this week, I had a call with the chief executive of a $5 billion company who has traveled four to five days a week for many years. She sounded utterly exhausted. When times get tough, she told me, the only way Ive ever known is to muscle through. I just cant do it anymore. Ive hit bottom. The problem is that Ive been numb for so long, Im honestly not sure if I can find my way back to a sane life.

title: A Tireless Witness to Lost Worlds
description: The photographer Edward S. Curtis spent 30 years on his remarkably ambitious project of photographing all the remaining Indian tribes in North America.

title: Russias Expanded Garage Museum Aims to Be a Global Art Player
description: MOSCOW  Members of the relatively small modern art clan in Moscow still vividly recall the opening party for the Garage Center for Contemporary Culture seven years ago. Amy Winehouse stumbled around onstage, the caterer was imported from London, and the worlds of global art, fashion and fabulous Russian wealth converged here as never before.

title: Johnny Depp for Dior, a Bath & Body Works Fragrance Renaissance and Barbie in Flats
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: Photographer Edward S. Curtiss Southwest
description: A wind knifed high across the desert, bounded up and over the mesa top and side-winded through the alleys of Acoma Pueblo, pummeling us. We shuffled toward the centuries-old San Estevan del Rey Mission Church, whose portals lay mercifully open. Acoma, also known as Sky City, sits atop a 367-foot-high sandstone bluff in western New Mexico, and is utterly exposed to the elements. A bunch of us had come up from the Sky City Cultural Center, 30 tourists clinging to one anothers sleeves, angling our torsos into the wind. At one point I was almost horizontal as I clenched an older womans hand, hanging on for dear life.

title: The Faces of 85 and Up
description: Men and women age 85 and above are one of the citys fastest-growing groups, but they are almost invisible. It is a time of love, pain and abrupt change. Six New Yorkers share their stories.

title: Corruption in FIFA? Its Auditors Saw None
description: Despite longstanding suspicion of corruption, world soccers governing body has received a clean bill of financial health for 16 consecutive years from KPMG, one of the worlds top auditing, accounting and consulting firms.

title: 85 and Up
description: Articles in this series looked at the lives of a group of New Yorkers age 85 and older, and how they navigate life at the upper end of old age in this city.

title: France Says It Opposes Boycotting Israel
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  France is firmly opposed to a boycott of Israel, the French foreign minister said Friday, after the partly state-owned French telecommunications company Orange said it would seek to withdraw its brand from the Israeli market.

title: A Group Portrait of New Yorks Oldest Old
description: It was an average week in an aging city. Frederick Jones, 88, fell in the kitchen of his Crown Heights apartment and went to sleep on the floor, resting until he felt strong enough to pull himself up. Ping Wong, 90, told her daughter that she could not make their annual spring trip to Atlantic City  the drive was too long, her back and joints too sore. Helen Moses, 90, decorated an enameled copper pin for the man who lives two doors down in their Bronx nursing home. He held her hand in a loving squeeze.

title: James Rebanks, Man of Sheep, Man of Letters
description: MATTERDALE, England  James Rebanks picked up a newborn lamb by the scruff of its neck and set it on its feet. It stood, shaking and weak. Were going to lose that one, he said. He got back onto the quad bike that he uses to patrol his farm, 300 acres of hilly land near this parish in the Lake District, where his family has farmed for about 600 years. Sometimes it happens, he said stoically.

title: On Location | Greenwich Village
description: A lofted sleeping area in a remodeled one-bedroom apartment in Greenwich Village provides space for a family of four.

title: Frenchman in Vegetative State Can Be Taken Off Life Support, Court Rules
description: PARIS  A 38-year-old Frenchman who is in a vegetative state after being paralyzed in a car accident seven years ago can legally be taken off life support, the European Court of Human Rights ruled on Friday.

title: Pakistan Says Court Has Freed 8 of 10 Accused in Attack on Malala Yousafzai
description: LONDON  Pakistani officials said Friday that a court had released eight of the 10 men accused of conspiring in the shooting of the schoolgirl activist Malala Yousafzai, in an admission that brought new scrutiny of Pakistans faltering efforts to try Islamist militants in the courts.

title: Heres How Ancient Romans Got Wild Animals Onto the Colosseum Floor
description: ROME  The archaeological ruins of the Colosseum in Rome may be majestic, but they only give a vague sense of the marvel-inducing pageantry that ancient visitors would have experienced attending a spectacle at the ancient arena inaugurated in 80 A.D.

title: New York Philharmonic Names Opening Acts for Parks Concerts
description: Some of the New York Philharmonics free parks concerts later this month will feature local warm-up acts  and, for the gastronomically inclined, food trucks.

title: Disney Layoffs and Immigrant Replacements Draw Deluge of Comments
description: An article in The Times, about American employees of Disney who said they lost their jobs to immigrants from an Indian outsourcing firm and had to train their replacements attracted a torrent of online reaction. The singer and actress Bette Midler reposted the article on Twitter and exhorted her followers, But be sure to read the comments. Whew.

title: Are We Helping Our Kids or Nagging Them?
description: Its a parents job to teach our children: to do the right thing, use the right words, learn and practice the skills theyll need to handle life at school and out in the world. But some mornings  after a seemingly endless stream of corrections intended to help my daughter  I end up feeling as if I am sending my unlucky child off to school with the extra burden of never getting anything right.

title: Jeffrey Peek Named an Executive Vice Chairman at Bank of America
description: Jeffrey M. Peek, who once lost a race to become the chief executive of Merrill Lynch, is coming home, in a way.

title: Park Avenue Penthouse With Views for $32.6 Million
description: A raw, full-floor penthouse at 737 Park Avenue, an Art Deco brick-and-limestone building acquired by Macklowe Properties and the CIM Group in 2011 and converted from 104 rental apartments into 56 luxury condominiums by Handel Architects, sold for $32,658,763.13 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Republican Candidates Assail Hillary Clinton on Voting Rights
description: Three Republican presidential hopefuls struck back at Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday after she accused them of trying to curtail voting rights.

title: The Cherries on Top: Three Desserts for Summer
description: Even if strawberries and rhubarb are in, to me it never feels as if summer has begun until there are cherries. Cherries herald the beginning of the stone fruit season, and for a brief period they have star billing before apricots, peaches, nectarines and plums arrive.

title: A Three-Dimensional, LED-Lit Dance Costume that Exposes the Performer  Or Hides Her
description: There are more than seven different ways to wear the artist Elizabeth Tolsons new performance-art dress, which features a stunning three-dimensional, expandable LED-lit attachment. At the debut of In the Presence of Myself, a performance premiering this weekend at Bushwicks Open Studios, the dancer Emily Smith will demonstrate them all. Tolson built the costumes focal point by crafting rings with plastic boning. When Smith pushes the exoskeleton out, the viewer is forced to see how it juts out, like a tiered wedding cake; but when she pulls it back in, it collapses flat against the body. Tolson also tucked a hundred lights inside the sack dresss silver and white sheer cotton, and the layers of fabric diffuse the battery-powered LEDs and illuminate Smith with a fuzzy white-yellow glow. I wanted the lights to shine toward the body instead of out, Tolson says.

title: Mishearings
description: A FEW weeks ago, when I heard my assistant Kate say to me, I am going to choir practice, I was surprised. I have never, in the 30 years we have worked together, heard her express the slightest interest in singing. But I thought, who knows? Perhaps this is a part of herself she has kept quiet about; perhaps it is a new interest; perhaps her son is in a choir; perhaps .

title: Lincoln Chafee Draws Life Lessons From Having Worked With Horses
description: As he embarks on the campaign trail to begin his long-shot bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, Lincoln Chafee, the former governor of Rhode Island, draws on a transformative experience that gives him a sense of confidence: his previous life as a farrier.

title: Catholic Archdiocese in Minnesota Charged Over Sex Abuse by Priest
description: CHICAGO  Prosecutors in Minnesota filed criminal charges on Friday against the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of St. Paul and Minneapolis, accusing church leaders of mishandling repeated complaints of sexual misconduct against a priest and failing to follow through on pledges to protect children and root out pedophile clergymen.

title: Gagosian Expands With Third London Gallery
description: Gagosian Gallery is starting a third space in London. A 18,000-square-foot gallery at 20 Grosvenor Hill, in the heart of Mayfair, it will open with an exhibition by the American abstract painter Cy Twombly on Oct. 8, just before the Frieze London art fair.

title: Small Steps Beat Big Leap for Vodafone and Liberty Global
description: It is good to talk. And Vodafone, the $100 billion British mobile giant, is right to open formal, if noncommittal, lines of communication about asset swaps with Liberty Global, Europes leading cable group.

title: A Greenwich Village Loft for a Family of Four
description: When Yaron Schwartzman and Alexandra Polier were hunting for a two- or three-bedroom apartment in Greenwich Village a couple of years ago, their real estate agent suggested they look at a large one-bedroom instead. They were dubious, to say the least.

title: Friday Night Music: Im With Her
description: Busy day in Oxford, city of ancient halls, dreaming spires, and countless sellers of selfie sticks. So no substance until tomorrow. But here are three incredibly talented ladies having a very good time:

title: Romanian President Calls for Premier to Resign Amid Graft Inquiry
description: BUCHAREST, Romania  Romanias president called for the resignation of the countrys prime minister, Victor Ponta, after the countrys anticorruption agency opened criminal investigations into whether he was involved in forgery, money-laundering and other crimes when he was still a practicing lawyer.

title: Some Germanwings Victims Remains to Be Returned on Schedule
description: PARIS  The remains of some of the 150 people who died in the crash of a Germanwings jet in the French Alps will be returned to relatives early next week, Lufthansa, the airlines parent company, said Friday evening. The announcement brings to an end more than two days of uncertainty for the families after the transfer was suspended because of last-minute paperwork errors.

title: Gay Pride Week in Tel Aviv-Jaffa
description: The city of Tel Aviv-Jaffa is expecting a crowd of 180,000 revelers from all over on June 12 for its annual Gay Pride Parade, which will focus for the first time on Israels transgender people.

title: How a Carried Interest Tax Could Raise $180 Billion
description: When Hillary Rodham Clinton opened her campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination in Iowa, the first substantive issue she raised was a safe one: carried interest. Theres something wrong when hedge fund managers pay lower tax rates than nurses or the truckers that I saw on I-80 as I was driving here, she said.

title: Me, Myself and Mx.
description: Sometimes cultural shifts rumble at a glacial pace. Sometimes they gather momentum so quickly that our language can only surge ahead in an effort to catch up. Think selfie, or vape, or normcore.

title: Walmart, Lagging in Online Sales, Is Strengthening E-Commerce
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark.  In the world of brick and mortar, Walmart is a titan, ringing up more than $1 billion of sales a day.

title: When the Warriors Lost Home-Court Advantage to the Ice Follies
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The Golden State Warriors are in the N.B.A. finals for the first time since 1975, playing Games 1 and 2 in the same arena they called home 40 years ago.

title: Finding Love Online, and Off
description: After meeting at a wedding, two online specialists kept looking for ways to meet up without the interference of a screen.

title: The French Opens Courtwalk
description: Tennis players wore eye-catching and creative outfits.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Strange Vision Solved!
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to figure out why a previously healthy 31-year-old woman suddenly began having strokes. I thought this was a particularly tough case  all the more so since I had never heard of the disease she was ultimately diagnosed with. Apparently I was not alone. Only a few dozen of the 400 plus readers who wrote in were able to make this difficult diagnosis.

title: Versace Resort 2016
description: Looks from the collection.

title: Review: Linda Lavin, Scratching Out Fresh Starts, at 54 Below
description: Cabaret may be a sideline for that human whirlwind Linda Lavin, but you can be sure that she takes a nightclub performance as seriously as any Broadway role. Her latest show, Starting Over, which opened on Thursday at 54 Below, is a fully developed concept in which Ms. Lavin, 77, tells her story mostly in song. As the title suggests, this is not a conventional summing up with a beginning, a middle and an end, but a repeated cycle of new beginnings, the latest of which is her seemingly blissful 10-year marriage to Steve Bakunas, the drummer in her band.

title: Review: American Classical Orchestra Takes on Friedrich Witt
description: Heres a conversation starter: Whats easier to bear? A boring performance of a boring piece or a boring performance of a masterpiece? On Thursday at Alice Tully Hall, the period-instrument American Classical Orchestra, under the direction of Thomas Crawford, offered both in a lackluster season finale. The program opened with a humdrum performance of Friedrich Witts justifiably overlooked Symphony in A and ended with a slack reading of Beethovens Pastoral Symphony.

title: My First Time in a Strip Club
description: Editors note: Austin Meyer is the winner of Nicholas Kristofs 2015 Win-a-Trip contest. He will receive his masters in journalism from Stanford University later this month.

title: Digital Experts Head Offline for Love
description: Michael Noland-Conlow first saw Kristen Titus in December 2011 as she stood on a balcony inside the Renaissance hotel in downtown Pittsburgh.

title: Review: Pairing Beethoven With George Walker at Mannes College
description: The unimaginatively named Mannes Beethoven Institute has in recent years reached far beyond Beethoven, pairing his works with those by contemporary composers. Stephen Hartke and Peter Lieberson were recently featured; for this years lineup, music by the New Jersey-based composer George Walker is in the spotlight.

title: Greek Premier Addresses Parliament
description: The Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, addressed parliament on Friday after the country postponed a repayment of its bailout.

title: The Week in Political Pictures
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton is honored in Texas, Senator Lindsey Graham joins the presidential race and more.

title: Review: J. Edgar Klezmer: Songs From My Grandmothers F.B.I. Files Tells All at Here Arts Center
description: The klezmer bandleader Eve Sicular is hardly a fan of J. Edgar Hoover, the F.B.I.s first director, whose Cold War hunt for Communists put her grandmother in his sights. But he did keep meticulous records, and she cant help being grateful for that.

title: Review: John Zorns Spirit of Restless Invention Flows Forth
description: On the title page of the score of The Aristos, John Zorns 2014 piano trio of ten metaphysical ambiguities, the composer quotes T. S. Eliot: We shall not cease from exploration/And the end of all our exploring/Will be to arrive where we started/And know the place for the first time.

title: Making the Invisible Visible
description: Dave Greer documents the infrastructure of the Internet.

title: The Internet I.R.L.
description: If youve ever wondered how the Internet works or, perhaps, what it actually looks like, your first impulse was probably to Google it (or maybe you looked on Wikipedia). For Dave Greer, a Philadelphia-based photographer, it all started with a building  specifically, the sale of a building.

title: Review: Metropolitan Playhouse Tackles Labor History in Injunction Granted
description: This year, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York recommended raising New York Citys minimum wage to $11.50, with a minimum of $10.50 elsewhere in the state. Lawmakers rejected the proposal, which is not really a surprise if you know the history that inspired Injunction Granted. A 1936 play created by the Living Newspaper Unit of the W.P.A.s Federal Theater Project, it has been given a devoted if rickety revival by the Metropolitan Playhouse.

title: Grim Reality: Czech TV Makes Game of Nazi Era
description: PRAGUE  We have seen toddlers in tiaras, been left Naked and Afraid and met more real housewives than a postman.

title: In Grim Rape Statistics, Signs of Progress
description: Last week, as Mayor Bill de Blasio worked to quell anxieties over rising instances of violence in the city, a young woman in Lower Manhattan found herself victim of the kind of terrifying crime that now seems almost to belong to another era in New York. Early on Monday in Chinatown, the police said, three teenage boys attacked a woman they had just met at an Internet cafe. Investigators said two raped and robbed her before the group headed to her apartment with the keys they had stolen from her. Video from surveillance cameras at the cafe and at a deli where she later sought help, which ultimately led to arrests, showed her battered and bloodied.

title: De Blasio, on Radio, Starts Conversation With His Constituents
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio sat cross-legged at a small table in his office, scribbling notes like a debate competitor. He pantomimed a drinking motion, and an aide returned with tea. He nodded vigorously at speakers who could not see him, flattering their inquiries with care.

title: Sail, Paddle or Row?
description: Participants in The Race to Alaska will race in boats without motors for 750 miles from Port Townsend, Wash., to Ketchikan, Alaska.

title: Human-Powered Vessels Race to Alaska
description: Race to Alaska organizers, in putting up a $10,000 prize for the first vessel to cross the finish line in Ketchikan, 750 miles away, said they wanted to see what human imagination and muscle could do.

title: A Race to Alaska: No Motors, but No Limits on Imagination
description: PORT TOWNSEND, Wash.  Scott Veirs and Thomas Nielsen have a little wooden plank mounted on their boat, just in front of the seat where they plan to take turns, for days on end, pedaling a bike-chain-driven propeller shaft all the way to Alaska.

title: Popcast: Jason Derulo Glides Across Genres
description: [Listen in iTunes | Download the MP3]

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
Disabled In Action Singers
description: New York Times photographer James Estrin chronicles the Disabled In Action Singers over several decades.

title: Thakoon Resort 2016
description: Looks from the collection.

title: Bill Cunningham | Fringe Movement
description: The fringe skirt adds motion to fashion and is in contrast to the movement to put women into a functional uniform.

title: Bill Cunningham | Fringe Movement
description: The fringe skirt adds motion to fashion and is in contrast to the movement to put women into a functional uniform. The current iteration of fringe started with Michael Kors skirts last October and is now a genuine fashion expression. Its even made it onto evening dresses. But fringe has some tangled problems: One womans heels were trapped by her dresss strands.

title: In Afghanistan With ISIS and the Taliban: Reporters Notebook
description: There are not many places in the world where journalists  not to mention government officials  might still rely on passing shepherds to bring them reports of political significance. But that is how one of the early descriptions of an Islamic State training base in western Afghanistan first surfaced back in January.

title: Evening Hours | Silver Linings
description: The unseasonal rain and cold didnt slow the parties down.

title: Tariq Aziz, Top Aide and Fervent Ally of Saddam Hussein, Dies at 79
description: Tariq Aziz, the Iraqi foreign minister and deputy prime minister who for decades was the most public face of Saddam Husseins government on the world stage, died on Friday in Nasiriya, Iraq, where he had been imprisoned. He was 79.

title: The Tony Red Carpet
description: Over the last few years, fashion at the Tony Awards has been mixed.

title: Paul Molitors Attention to Detail Has Twins Off to Fast Start
description: BOSTON  The first impression Paul Molitor made on Trevor Plouffe was profound. It was a decade ago in Beloit, Wis., and Plouffe, now the third baseman and cleanup hitter for the Minnesota Twins, was 19 years old. Molitor, a Hall of Famer with 3,319 career hits, was a roving instructor in the Twins farm system.

title: Pictures of the Day: China and Elsewhere
description: Photos from China, Turkey, Syria and Burundi.

title: The Tony Awards Get Dressed Up
description: A little after 5 p.m. on Thursday afternoon, Beth Malone stood in the Manhattan offices of the fashion public relations company KCD trying not to appear out of place. It was a losing battle.

title: Why Is U.S. Womens Soccer Still Fighting to Exist?
description: With two minutes to go in stoppage time in the quarterfinal match of the Womens World Cup 2011, Brazil was leading the United States 2-1. As the U.S. offense advanced for its last possible possession, the crowd in Dresden chanted U-S-A! But on ESPN, the announcer Ian Darke was already calling it. It will go down as the U.S.A.s worst performance ever in the Womens World Cup, he told his viewers: going home a top-eight loser in the quarters.

title: Blackhawks Build a Juggernaut With Talent on Ice and in Front Office
description: CHICAGO  When the Chicago Blackhawks and the Anaheim Ducks met in Game 7 of the Western Conference finals, the Blackhawks owner, Rocky Wirtz, had an idea about where besides Chicago he would find a jittery audience: Rockefeller Center, home of NBC, the N.H.L.s broadcast partner.

title: Relying on Butterfly Wings to Survive
description: With flowers in bursts of orange and red, flame azaleas attract several types of pollinators. But these azaleas must rely almost entirely on butterflies to reproduce, researchers have found.

title: June 5, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from China, Turkey, Syria and Burundi.

title: Patrick Lynch, Police Union Chief Who Fought de Blasio, Wins a 5th Term
description: Beating back his first challenge in a decade, Patrick J. Lynch, the irascible police union boss, was re-elected on Friday as the president of the New York City Patrolmens Benevolent Association.

title: Elizabeth Reaser Is Game for Anything, Onstage and Off
description: Elizabeth Reaser sat down carefully.

title: LightSail, a Private Spacecraft, Goes Unexpectedly Quiet
description: Since it launched last month, LightSail, a little, privately financed spacecraft meant to demonstrate the potentially revolutionary technology of using sunlight for propulsion, has been alive, dead and revived.

title: A Tokyo Treasure
description: The Okura, almost surreal in its beauty and a favorite of stars for decades, will be demolished to make way for glass towers.

title: The End of a Treasure in Tokyo
description: On the bus ride from Narita Airport to the Hotel Okura in Tokyo last April, I noticed something peculiar and touching  rows upon rows of trees, gently propped up with wooden braces. What care these limbs get! What attention is paid to the crooked and the lame! I saw many such struts for many such trees throughout Japan  in parks, in cities, on sidewalks, on highways.

title: Carmakers Zoom Away From Retro
description: Like aging rockers, car designers fell into the habit of trotting out their greatest hits, producing faithful copies of beloved classics, including the Volkswagen Beetle, Ford Mustang and Mini Cooper. Now that movement, called retro design, is giving way to a forward-looking approach.

title: Alice Goffmans Heralded Book on Crime Is Disputed
description: Since her book On the Run: Fugitive Life in an American City was published last year, Alice Goffman has achieved a measure of fame that is rarely visited on a young sociologist.

title: Voting With My (Ugly) Feet?
description: Well, now I can never go to Cannes.

title: These Dads Are Writing Their Own Tickets
description: In 1988, Ben Fountain, then a 30-year-old lawyer in North Dallas, decided to quit his practice to stay at home with his child and learn how to write fiction. His wife, also a lawyer, made enough money to support the family and hire a nanny. Mr. Fountain used the six hours a day she was on call to write before picking up the caregiving slack and household maintenance in the afternoon.

title: Henrietta Binghams Jazz Age Life
Mom and Dad Have Their Own Set of Finals
description: Jodi Gold, a Manhattan child psychiatrist and the mother of three children ages 6, 9 and 11, is accustomed to the perennial juggle. But at this time of year, all she can do is triage.

title: Coffee and Haircuts: The New Classic
description: Barber shops are offering drinks with their usual offerings.

title: Kyrie Irving Out of N.B.A. Finals With Broken Kneecap, Cavaliers Say
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  With Kyrie Irving officially gone for the remainder of the finals, the Cleveland Cavaliers must figure out a way to compete with a powerful Golden State Warriors team that may have been too much for them even when they were at full strength.

title: You Want a Cappuccino With That Haircut?
description: Every couple of weeks, Andrew Livingston, 22, a co-founder of a Brooklyn men's wear company, stops on his way home from work for a drink  either a glass of pale ale or an espresso  in a setting where he typically finds like-minded guys.

title: A Crisis at the Edge of Physics
description: DO physicists need empirical evidence to confirm their theories?

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: How Uzo Aduba, Actor, Spends Her Sundays
description: Uzo Aduba, who won an Emmy Award last year for her portrayal of Suzanne Warren (Crazy Eyes) on Netflixs Orange Is the New Black, finally feels like a New Yorker. Born to Nigerian immigrants, she grew up in Massachusetts and moved to the city after college to pursue theater. She was instantly enamored of New York and its rhythms. It felt bigger than life, she said. But it was not until she mastered the subway system that Ms. Aduba, 34, felt like part of the fabric. The actor, who lives in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, said that because she no longer consults the subway map she stands out less. But with the third season of Orange available for binge-watching on June 12, blending in may prove more difficult.

title: A Lesson for New York City Ballet: The Past Is Always Present
description: George Balanchine once said: Put 16 women on the stage, and its everybody  its the world. Put 16 men on, and its always nobody. His 1972 Stravinsky Symphony in Three Movements begins with 16 women, and his 1934 Tchaikovsky Serenade with 17 women. When we watch those ballets, we can still believe him. (Symphony in Three was danced early in the New York City Ballet season that ends this weekend. It and Serenade return to repertory next May.)

title: Halt and Catch Fire, on AMC, Switches Gears in Its New Season
description: Early in the new season of Halt and Catch Fire, AMCs drama about daddy issues, 1980s home dcor and the beginnings of the computer industry, the action takes place mostly in a beat-up Dallas house furnished with water guns and pizza crusts. Its the headquarters of Mutiny, a nascent company offering early versions of online gaming and chat rooms, whose corporate structure consists of two more or less mature women trying to wrangle a herd of childish young men  Prodigy crossed with Animal House.

title: Water for Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Britains Health Service Aided Struggling Computer Sciences
description: Britains National Health Service has long provided free and universal health care to the countrys residents.

title: Christopher Dodd Stays On as Top Hollywood Lobbyist
description: LOS ANGELES  Despite a tenure marred by a major legislative setback and a slow response to the Sony computer attack, Christopher J. Dodd, the leader of Hollywoods top lobbying organization, was given a three-year contract extension on Friday.

title: Review: Holly Herndon, With Laptops, at the Wick
description: Depending on your point of view, Holly Herndons work might seem incomplete, only partway toward the heart of a lot of interesting things. Or it might seem complete in its semidetached, casually obsessive relationship with all of them.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Were trying something new: a quick nightly rundown of the days top stories. What do you think? Let us know at briefing@nytimes.com.

title: Review: Yoshiko Chuma, in a Journey Across Borders
description: Just as pi stretches on indefinitely, so might Yoshiko Chumas =3.14 ... Nothing, or Everything. At the outset of this multimedia work, which opened on Thursday at La MaMa, the performer Nick Vaughan explains that the dance has been in rehearsal for 10 days, or three years, or continuously since 1976, the year that Ms. Chuma, a veteran choreographer and activist, arrived in New York from her native Japan. It is a work perpetually in progress.

title: The Value of a Mindless Summer Job
Magnum Chooses the Decisive, and Transforming, Photo
description: Magnum asked some 50 of its members to choose one image that changed everything, eliciting a range of responses, some unexpected.

title: Philharmonic Chooses Anna Thorvaldsdottir for Emerging Composer Program
description: Anna Thorvaldsdottir, an Icelandic composer known for richly textured works that are often inspired by nature, was named Friday as the New York Philharmonics second Kravis Emerging Composer  an honor that comes with $50,000 and a commission to write for the orchestra.

title: Cabinet of Wonders
description: Beyond the shady exterior of Eclectic Collectibles and Antiques lives a kooky, pell-mell paradise: a forest of ephemera, an inchoate collision of the beautiful and revolting thats open every day until midnight.

title: Eclectic Collectibles and Antiques in Williamsburg Is a Cabinet of Wonders
description: Music lures pedestrians into Eclectic Collectibles and Antiques at 285 Metropolitan Avenue. Oldies, specifically. I Guess Thats Why They Call It the Blues (Elton John, from 1983) blared from the entrance on a recent sunny afternoon. The nondescript storefront would be easy to miss if not for the music and a menacing antique car parked at the curb: a tar-black 1940 Buick Super that evokes pinstripe suits, Tommy guns and Sonny Corleones assassination in The Godfather.

title: A Defender of Stonewall, and Himself
description: The monthly meeting of the Stonewall Rebellion Veterans Association was drifting into disorder last weekend when its director, Williamson L. Henderson, called for order by banging his gavel, which, to be technical, was really a kitchen tool.

title: An App That Lets You Find and Share Articles
description: When you scroll through your Facebook feed, there are particular kinds of posts that youre looking for, even if you dont realize it. It could be that you favor items like your cousin Carlys wedding pictures, an update on Nathans trip to Thailand or the interesting articles that you know your friend Anna is liable to share.

title: Player Ratings: Netherlands (3) vs. United States (4)
description: For the United States national team, the past year has been marred by a sudden sting of defensive collapses. In Friday nights exhibition in Amsterdam, the team turned the tables for a change. With three goals in the final 20 minutes, including one in the 88th minute and a 90th-minute winner, the Americans erased a two-goal deficit and stunned the Netherlands, 4-3, in a friendly in Amsterdam.

title: Meth Finds a New Market in New York
description: The waiting room of Gay Men of African Descent, a service agency near Downtown Brooklyn, is almost always quiet and empty. Artful photographs of naked men under tinted lights hang on the walls without an audience. Magazines for people who are H.I.V. positive sit untouched in a swirl on a carved African pedestal.

title: A Manhattan Fortuneteller Cost Him Fortune After Fortune
description: Everyone knows that when a man loves a woman, he cant keep his mind on nothing else. Hell spend his very last dime. Give up all his comfort, sleep out in the rain.

title: Nepal: More Victims Reported in Helicopter Crash
description: An American military helicopter that crashed last month in the mountains east of Kathmandu, the capital, was carrying five more passengers than had previously been reported, the Nepalese Army said Friday. Eight people  six United States Marines and two Nepalese soldiers  were initially reported to have been killed during a relief mission in the aftermath of a devastating earthquake in April. But Nepals Army said in a statement Friday that five additional passengers, all Nepalese civilians, had also been on the flight and had been killed. It has not been determined why the helicopter went down on May 12. The wreckage was found on a ridge at an altitude of 11,200 feet, the army statement said, close to the epicenter of a second major earthquake.

title: A Money Horse
description: The rich could get much richer if American Pharoah, who has banked $3,730,300 for Zayat Stables can earn the winners share of $800,000.

title: Drawn to Estela but Not by a 50 Best List
description: When the Worlds 50 Best Restaurants announced its 2015 rankings last week, the only new American restaurant among upstarts from India, Dubai, South Korea and Russia  and perennial American contenders like Per Se and Le Bernardin  was Estela, a small, beverage-driven restaurant from Thomas Carter, the former beverage director of Blue Hill at Stone Barns, and Ignacio Mattos, a chef mentored by Alice Waters. While Estela is new to the list, coming in at No. 90  naturally, the 50 Best list goes to 100  it is not new to New York City, having occupied a space on East Houston Street in NoLIta for a couple of years.

title: The Tale of the Red Queen, Communist Double Agent
description: Q. Wasnt there a woman early in the Cold War known as the Red Queen?

title: Pistons Hire Agent Arn Tellem as a Front Office Executive
description: Arn Tellem, one of the most influential and powerful agents in professional sports, has agreed to become the vice chairman of Palace Sports and Entertainment, the company that owns the Detroit Pistons.

title: The Camera as Time Machine
description: David Battel, who has been taking black-and-white pictures in Midtown Manhattan for over 20 years, pays homage to luminaries like Garry Winogrand.

title: Street Photographer at Port Authority Captures Another Era
description: For more than 20 years, the street photographer David Battel has stalked Midtown with a Leica in tow. Most days, he arrives at the height of rush hour and aims his lens at those pounding the pavement, a heterogeneous pool of commuters, tourists, artists, students and scraggly folks who flow into and out of Manhattan.

title: Real Estate Magnate Pushes for a Casino in North Jersey
description: Jeff Gural, the New York real estate tycoon, had cleaned up well.

title: U.S. Says Russia Failed to Correct Violation of Landmark 1987 Arms Control Deal
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department reported on Friday that Russia had failed to correct a violation of a landmark arms control accord between Washington and Moscow that prohibits intermediate-range ground-launched missiles.

title: Arthur Goldhammer
description: Arthur Goldhammer is best known as a translator of French literature, having translated more than 100 works ranging from classics by Alexis de Tocqueville and Albert Camus to last years best-selling Capital in the 21st Century, by Thomas Piketty.

title: Lehman to Pay Barclays $1.3 Billion to Settle Suit
description: One of the longest-running legal fights from the financial crisis, rooted in the dismantling of Lehman Brothers, is near an end.

title: Pulses Are Zooming, and Opinions Are Flying
description: Conspiracy theorists, soothsayers and experts of all stripes feel truly at home in few places. The racetrack is one of these premier locales. The times when this assemblage of dreamers balances anxiety and gloom, hope and despair with the fervor of true believers are rarer still. The eve of a Triple Crown bid is such a time.

title: Long Island Sees a Crisis as It Floats to the Surface
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  The dead turtles, about 100 of them, started washing ashore near here in late April. Then came the dead fish, in numbers no one had seen before. By this week, tens of thousands of fish carcasses had bobbed to the surface of the Peconic River, which runs along the southern border of this town, and in adjoining Flanders Bay, washing ashore in putrid drifts.

title: Health Care Expansion Is Rejected in Florida
description: MIAMI  In another rebuke of the Obama administrations efforts to expand health care to the uninsured, Floridas Republican-led House of Representatives soundly rejected a plan on Friday that state officials said would have covered as many as 650,000 residents.

title: Serena Williamss Grand Slam March
description: On Saturday at the French Open, Serena Williams will go for her 20th Grand Slam singles title and third in a row. She is second on the Open era career list, behind Steffi Grafs 22. Williamss opponent, 13th-seeded Lucie Safarova, will be playing her first Grand Slam singles final, though she won the womens doubles title at the Australian Open this year. A look at some of the numbers in Williamss remarkable 18-year career at Grand Slam events:

title: Days Before Election in Turkey, Blasts at Rally Kill 2
description: ISTANBUL  A huge opposition political rally in the predominantly Kurdish city of Diyarbakir on Friday ended with smoke, panic and defiance as two explosions killed two people and wounded more than 100 others, a senior government minister said.

title: 2 Defendants in Manhattan Biker Assault Await Verdict From Judge
description: The prosecution and defense summed up their cases on Friday in the trial of an undercover New York police detective and another man accused of being among several motorcyclists who beat up a driver during a raucous biker rally in September 2013.

title: Bergdahl Seeks Removal of General in Desertion Case
description: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl has asked a military appellate court to disqualify the general in charge of the desertion case against him. Eugene R. Fidell, Sergeant Bergdahls lawyer, said the general, Mark A. Milley, who has been nominated to be the Armys chief of staff, should be removed because of his personal interest in being confirmed by the Senate. Sergeant Bergdahl, who disappeared from his post in Afghanistan in 2009 and was held by the Taliban for five years before being released last year in a prisoner swap, filed the request on Friday in the United States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces.

title: Israels Allies in U.S. Challenge Boycott
description: South Carolina has become the first state to enact legislation aimed at thwarting an international pro-Palestinian economic and disinvestment campaign intended to penalize Israel. Illinois will soon become the second, and advocates say plans are underway for similar laws in 18 more states.

title: Womens World Cup 2015: Door Opens for 24 Teams
description: Opening Day

title: Tapping Your Inner Wolf
description: MEN often face pressure to measure up as alpha males, to wolf up as it were. Alpha male connotes the man who at every moment demonstrates that hes in total control in the home, and who away from home can become snarling and aggressive.

title: Leonid Plyushch, Soviet Dissident Punished in an Asylum, Dies
description: Leonid Plyushch, a Ukrainian mathematician who became a leading political dissident in the Soviet era, prompting the Kremlin to commit him to a mental asylum for a nightmarish three years of drugs and deprivation in the early 1970s, died on Thursday near Paris.

title: Supreme Court Justices: Be More Open
description: To the Editor:

title: In Defense of Prosecutions of Drug Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: Gender Bias at Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Edward Snowden and U.S. Surveillance
description: To the Editor:

title: A Political Brand of Sominex
description: When I have trouble falling asleep, I do lists. Like running through the names of all the presidents, along with several factoids for each one. I was rather proud of this talent until friends sent me a video clip of Ellen DeGeneres interviewing a 5-year-old girl who could do it better.

title: Review: The Twentieth-Century Way Explores a Moment in Gay History
description: Some underemployed actors answer phones. Some babysit or bar-tend or teach English as a second language. And some entrap and arrest gay men on charges of social vagrancy.

title: Crime and Confusion in a Safer New York City
description: The New York City tabloids, TV news and other elements of the citys early-warning system for the apocalypse have noted a steady rise in shootings and homicides. To some this smells like the beginning of the end of many years of falling crime, and with it, presumably, the mayors credibility as a leader who can keep the city safe.

title: A Triple Crown Possibility Keeps Registers Ringing Around Belmont Park
description: The spectators who crowd into Belmont Park for the final leg of the Triple Crown like to dress for the occasion. They don pastel sun dresses and straw fedoras.

title: Magic Object
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Well, I was right, wasnt I? I warned you to enjoy the Friday puzzle because, in all likelihood, the Saturday would be tougher. Today, we reflect (sorry) on the difficulty level of this puzzle by Jason Flinn.

title: A Detainee Describes More C.I.A. Torture
description: Anyone who had the time to read the summary of the 6,700-page report by Senate investigators on the federal governments program of torturing detainees captured after the Sept. 11 attacks knew, or at least suspected, that there was more to the sickening story.

title: Scott Walkers Effort to Weaken College Tenure
description: Gov. Scott Walkers proposal for weakening tenure at Wisconsins highly respected state university system and undermining the facultys role in campus governance will appeal to conservative voters whose support he needs to win the Republican presidential nomination.

title: New York Grants Subsidy to Widow After Lawsuit Over Rent-Freeze Eligibility
description: New York City officials said on Friday that they were reversing a decision that significantly raised the rent for a 93-year-old widow who was in danger of being evicted, and that they would review the cases of other older and disabled tenants in the same predicament.

title: Caught Between Fresh Horses and Triple Crown Tradition
description: When eight thoroughbreds break from the post at Belmont Park on Saturday, American Pharoah will be the only one who has run in all three legs of the Triple Crown.

title: Daryl Hall Renovates Venue, for Music, Food and TV
description: In the 1970s and 80s, Daryl Hall and his musical partner, John Oates, built a catalog of recordings that included six No. 1 hits, among them Rich Girl, Private Eyes and Out of Touch. The duo, who still attract sellout crowds on tour, were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame last year.

title: Hospitals Back Providers Applying for New York State Marijuana Licenses
description: New Yorks new medical marijuana program has drawn the interest of several major hospitals, which have formed alliances with aspiring growers to try to make the drug accessible to their patients.

title: Judge Rules Second Version of New York Teachers Exam Is Also Racially Biased
description: A federal judge on Friday found that an exam for New York teaching candidates was racially discriminatory because it did not measure skills necessary to do the job, the latest step in a court battle over teacher qualifications that has spanned nearly 20 years.

title: The Belmont Draw
description: Post positions for Saturdays 147th running of the Belmont Stakes.

title: Ruth Feldman, 80, Dies; Quiz Kid Told What It Was Like in a Book
description: The question was reasonably obscure  What was the last opera in Wagners Ring cycle?  but Ruthie Duskin knew the answer.

title: Look, Ma, No Hands!
description: On Wednesday morning, during Googles annual meeting, a shareholder named John M. Simpson stood up to question the companys top executives about its self-driving car program. They were not friendly questions.

title: Yankees Survive a Six-Run Rally by the Angels
description: It was a harmless infield pop-up in the languorous conclusion of a blowout game.

title: Daniel Murphy Heads to D.L. on Day of Losses for Mets
description: PHOENIX  When the Mets clubhouse opened Friday, Daniel Murphys jersey and pants hung in his locker, as if he would be playing that night. Perhaps it was the product of wishful thinking. But when a players health is involved, not much has gone right for the Mets this season, and this was nothing more than a tease.

title: Review: At Winston in Mount Kisco, the Play of Sweetness and Spice
description: The Moroccan duck breast is delicious: a fan of perfectly cooked rose-colored slices, with a top layer offering an intriguing interplay of sharp and sweet.

title: Bringing In the Righty. And the Lefty.
description: Nearly 20 years ago Greg Harris, a journeyman reliever, finally fulfilled his dream to pitch with each hand in a major league game. In the ninth inning of a loss to the Cincinnati Reds on Sept. 28, 1995, Harris, then with the Montreal Expos, came into the game as a right-hander and retired Reggie Sanders on his first pitch. He switched to his left arm to walk Hal Morris and retire Eddie Taubensee, then was back to his right to induce a groundout from Bret Boone.
