title: Isiah Thomas Era Opens With Liberty Defeating Atlanta
description: Once thought to be in a state of permanent exile from Madison Square Garden, Isiah Thomas returned Friday night in his new capacity as president of the W.N.B.A.s Liberty.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: He cant be rushed when hes making champions like American Pharoah.

title: Review: Guys and Dolls in East Haddam Revives the World and Patois of Damon Runyons New York
description: Whats playing at the Goodspeed? Ill tell you whats playing at the Goodspeed. Story of a high-rolling gambler who wins way more than he bargained for when a mission doll upsets his game. Yes, Sky Masterson and Sarah Brown are back, along with their pals Nathan Detroit, Miss Adelaide (dont call her Ms.!) and the whole gang of charming lowlifes who inhabit the Broadway of Guys and Dolls.

title: A Review of Sayulita, Mexican Cuisine With a Twist
description: Some restaurants just grab you the moment you walk through the door. Named after a surfing village near Puerto Vallarta, Sayulita has a bright, beachy vibe, with distressed furniture and whitewashed pine booths, photos of oceanfront scenes and a Volkswagen Microbus, and Christmas lights draped festively across a mirror. Waitresses in jeans and gingham shirts complete the symphony of charm that the owner, Bill Driggs, has orchestrated.

title: Review: All the Living Rooms a Stage in Madison Revival of 27 Play by George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber
description: That theatrical adage Dying is easy; comedy is hard is aptly demonstrated by the Shakespeare Theater of New Jerseys current revival of The Royal Family in Madison.

title: Corrections: June 6, 2015
description: NEW YORK

title: Restaurant Review: Talde Jersey City
description: Celebrity chef restaurants get a lot of buzz but do not always live up to the hype. Talde Jersey City, the casual Asian-American spot from former Top Chef contestant-turned-entrepreneur Dale Talde, 36, has definitely gotten a lot of buzz.

title: Review: In The New Sincerity, Worldviews Are Constantly Changing
description: What a minefield the world of political protest can be  almost as treacherous as interpersonal relationships, especially ones involving sex.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (MAX) BLADE RUNNER (1982) Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford) is a blade runner  an agent tasked with eliminating, or retiring, rogue robots, or replicants. Deckard struggles with emotional connections to one replicant as he dangerously engages with others. Ridley Scott directed this gritty and ethereal noir. Science-fiction devotees may find Blade Runner a wonderfully meticulous movie and marvel at the comprehensiveness of its vision, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. Even those without a taste for gadgetry cannot fail to appreciate the degree of effort that has gone into constructing a film so ambitious and idiosyncratic.

title: A Heartfelt Letter Home
description: Its impossible to be anonymous when the owner of a restaurant greets you with a smile and a big hug. This happened to me recently at Caf Mendoza in Commack. The person doing the hugging was Hugo Garcia, the owner of the almost four-month-old restaurant. Mr. Garcia, along with his business partner, Fabio Machado, also owns Caf Buenos Aires and Bistro Cassis in Huntington as well as Bistro Citron in Roslyn and Manhattan.

title: With First-Round Difficulties Forgotten, Blackhawks Corey Crawford Rights Himself for the Finals
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The mood was light around Corey Crawfords locker stall on Friday. He laughed along with the banter and joked with Chicago television reporters about their fresh Florida suntans.

title: Views Differ on Shape of Macroeconomics
description: The doctrine of expansionary austerity  the claim that slashing spending would actually boost demand and employment, because it would have such positive effects on confidence that this would outweigh the direct drag  was immensely popular among policymakers in 2010, as the great turn toward austerity began. But the statistical underpinnings of the doctrine fell apart under scrutiny: the methods Alberto Alesina used to identify changes in fiscal policy did not, it turned out, do a very good job, and more careful work found that historically austerity has in fact been contractionary after all. Moreover, the experience of austerity programs seemed to confirm what Keynesians new and old had warned from the beginning  that the negative effects of austerity are much larger under conditions where they cannot be offset by conventional monetary policy.

title: I Am a Bigamist
description: Among the many popular misconceptions about grief and its trajectory, one that particularly rankles widowed people is the assumption that if youve found a new love relationship, youve moved on from your grief. How very tidy.

title: The Truth About AI (Silly)
description: Izabella Kaminska, at a meeting about the future of artificial intelligence, muses/jokes that the AI might already be here, but choosing not to show itself. Shes not watching the right TV shows! Thats the premise of the terrific Person of Interest. Heres Root (Amy Acker), a hacker temporarily confined to a mental health facility but still in contact with the Machine:

title: Escape to Bro-topia
description: WASHOUGAL, WASH.  People talk about chucking their jobs. They say they will leave behind the madness of the city and hit the road.

title: Mr. Market Speaks
description: Way back, when it wasnt entirely silly to say that there was a real debate about the impact of fiscal and monetary policy in a liquidity trap, there were really two big issues on which academics like me and those who claimed to be wise about such matters but didnt do models differed. One was inflation; the other was interest rates, where there were many dire warnings about the impact of budget deficits, but basic macroeconomics said otherwise.

title: Why Am I A Keynesian?
description: Noah Smith sort-of approvingly quotes Russ Roberts, who views all macroeconomic positions as stalking horses for political goals, and declares in particular that

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took viewers from a remote Indian village to a block party in Bamako, the capital of Mali.

title: A New Look at Cuba
description: Youve booked a flight from Miami and have your approved travel visa in hand. Youre ready to see Cuba. Now what?

title: If Hastert Was Extorted, He Could Deduct Some Losses From His Taxes
description: When I was researching my article about Dennis Hasterts indictment on charges that he improperly withdrew large sums of money from a bank, one question I had was whether any tax was owed on the payments Mr. Hastert was said to have made.

title: Hubris, and Sputnik, Doomed the Edsel
description: The Ford Motor Company in the late 1950s gambled about $250 million (roughly $2.1 billion today) to create what The New York Times called the first new brand name to be introduced by one of the Big Three car companies (General Motors, Ford and Chrysler) since 1938. The car was the Edsel, a name that remains a synonym for a failed product.

title: Taliban Overrun Remote District in Northeastern Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Hundreds of Taliban fighters overwhelmed a remote district in northeastern Afghanistan on Saturday in an area where the governments influence has waned considerably over the past two years, provincial officials said.

title: A Noisy Gym Next Door
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Electoral Paths for Hillary Clinton
description: Should Hillary Rodham Clinton win the Democratic nomination for president in 2016, she would most likely follow the path that Barack Obama took to victory in 2008 and 2012.

title: Inside SEAL Team 6
description: Officially, SEAL Team 6 does not exist. The unit performs some of the militarys most dangerous missions, those considered too risky for conventional troops.

title: SEAL Team 6: A Secret History of Quiet Killings and Blurred Lines
description: They have plotted deadly missions from secret bases in the badlands of Somalia. In Afghanistan, they have engaged in combat so intimate that they have emerged soaked in blood that was not their own. On clandestine raids in the dead of the night, their weapons of choice have ranged from customized carbines to primeval tomahawks.

title: Obama Delivers Eulogy for Beau Biden
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who began his life on the national stage more than four decades ago under the dark cloud of a family tragedy, laid his elder son, Beau, to rest on Saturday, marking yet another moment of grief in a long political career shaped by it.

title: Third Time Is a Chore as Serena Williams Wins French Open Title
description: PARIS  Serena Williams was too ill to get out of bed for most of Friday. She was too tightly wound to close out what would have been a routine straight-set victory against Lucie Safarova on Saturday.

title: Novak Djokovic Tops Andy Murray to Reach French Open Final
description: PARIS  After Novak Djokovic outclassed his first five opponents, including the ultimate clay-court master, Rafael Nadal, he finally had to overcome stiff resistance at this French Open.

title: A Storied Trainer and a Witness to History
description: OLD BROOKVILLE, N.Y.  At the end of a long and winding road shaded by trees sit two brick houses owned by a father and son who have often resided at the top of the thoroughbred industry. A sign with jockey silks and the name Nerud points the way.

title: Scott Walker Riding With Joni Ernst in Iowa as Rivals Give Chase
description: When Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin throws his leg across his beloved Harley-Davidson Road King for a celebration of motorcycles and Iowa pork on Saturday, the political symbolism will be as thick as the smoke from the roasting pits.

title: Northside Festival Features Lunas Return and Other Indie Rock
description: The Northside Festival, Brooklyns emulation of South by Southwest, continues to expand. Its core is still the indie-rock clubs of Williamsburg and Greenpoint and the local bands that play them. But its also attracting headliners with bigger names. Its opening-night concert, Thursday at McCarren Park, features the return  for its first New York show after a 10-year hiatus  of Luna, a band that carried the Velvet Underground legacy of drone-rock and deadpan insight from 1991-2004. There are also big showcases at 50 Kent Street  a.k.a. Live at the Inlet  with Neko Case and Rhye on Friday, Best Coast and Built to Spill on Saturday, and Run the Jewels and Sleigh Bells on Sunday. The Nigerian Afrobeat band Femi Kuti and the Positive Force visits Brooklyn Bowl on Thursday. But in a festival with hundreds of bands, leave time for lesser-knowns like Jacco Gardner, a Dutch psychedelic-pop revivalist, on Thursday at Rough Trade, or the Minimalist composer Delia Gonzalez next Sunday at Manhattan Inn. (northsidefestival.com.)

title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  If the byline on todays Puns & Anagrams puzzle looks different to you, its not a meta clue, nor is it a mistake. Constructor Mark Diehl makes his P&A debut today. Ill let Will Shortz explain:

title: Liz Rodbell on Taking the Time to Recognize Success
description: This interview with Liz Rodbell, president of Lord & Taylor and Hudsons Bay department stores, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Pope Francis Urges a Divided Bosnia to Heal, Declaring War Never Again!
description: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina  Coming to a country whose national anthem has no lyrics because its bickering ethnic groups cannot agree on them, Pope Francis on Saturday called for greater religious reconciliation and an end to the sectarian conflicts that still threaten Bosnia and proliferate around the world in a kind of third world war being fought piecemeal.

title: The High Cost of Investing Like a Daredevil
description: Live in the moment: If youre skiing, surfing or scuba diving, thats the way to go. But if youre investing, that approach can lead to disaster.

title: Divine Intervention Is a Hope, Not a Horse, in the Belmont
description: Just a few dozen furlongs from Belmont Park lies the grave site of Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, the rebbe of the Lubavitcher group of Hasidic Jews. Since Schneerson died in 1994, Jews from all over the world have made a pilgrimage to Montefiore Cemetery to pay homage to the charismatic rebbe.

title: Task for Obama at Group of 7 Is to Reinforce Isolation of Russia
description: WASHINGTON  One year after President Obama rallied core allies to join the United States in punishing Russia for its bellicose ways, he will use a gathering on Sunday of the worlds largest industrialized democracies to urge them to stand strong, and together, in isolating the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin.

title: No Wine (Really, Not One Bottle) Before Its Time
description: The Haggler dislikes wine and finds all the trappings of wine connoisseurship  ordering, sipping, opining, ordering some more, opining some more  very tiresome. Everything the Haggler knows about wine could be written on the top of a bottle cork. With a Sharpie.

title: A Stooper at Belmont Chases the Jackpot
description: This is my main turf, Frankie Abbate, 52, said, weaving his way through a sea of bettors in the grandstand area of Belmont Racetrack on Friday just after the seventh race.

title: A First for Snapchat
description: DES MOINES  The fast-growing social media platform Snapchat just landed its first political ad.

title: Oakland Is Home to Championship Teams, All of Them Looking to Leave
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  There are times at this ugly concrete complex next to the freeway when you wonder why anyone would rather be anywhere else.

title: Red Sox Pitching Change Is Paying Off
description: BOSTON  It was hard to play much worse than the Boston Red Sox did while losing on Thursday at Fenway Park. They blew a four-run lead, made three errors and ran the bases poorly, and their $95 million free-agent switch-hitter, Pablo Sandoval, went 0 for 4 while batting left-handed against left-handed pitchers. The forgiving American League East standings, at least, give the Red Sox hope. And as badly as they looked at the end of their four-game series with Minnesota, their pitchers did string together four quality starts. A group that looked overmatched early has settled down under a new pitching coach, Carl Willis.

title: A Military Mind-Set Keeps a Yankee Prepared Amid Limited Action
description: Four months ago Garrett Jones arrived at Blackman High School in Murfreesboro, Tenn., with a small team of former Navy SEALs.

title: Susan Axelrod of Finra: An Eye in the Sky Keeping Watch on Wall Street
description: Susan Axelrod is the executive vice president for regulatory operations at the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, or Finra, in New York.

title: 300 More Bodies Found in China Ship Disaster
description: BEIJING  Chinese soldiers and paramilitary police officers have recovered nearly 300 more bodies from the cruise ship that capsized last week, and officials said Saturday that they would continue searching the muddy waters of the Yangtze for the more than 40 people who remained missing.

title: At Site of Highs for Tiger Woods, One of a Different Sort: 85
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  In 2000, Zac Blair managed to get Tiger Woodss autograph in the Valhalla clubhouse during the week of the P.G.A. Championship, which Woods won on his way to holding all four major titles concurrently.

title: Saudi Arabia Shoots Down Missile Fired From Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  Saudi Arabia shot down a Scud ballistic missile fired from Yemen early Saturday by forces loyal to Yemens Houthi rebels, according to a statement by the official Saudi news agency. It was the first time Yemeni factions had used the weapon, signaling an escalation of the conflict and providing new evidence that a Saudi effort to pacify the rebels is faltering.

title: Finding the Right Balance
description: WE all fall down. But while a tumble for a toddler is a learning experience, and a stumble for an adult is usually just embarrassing, for older people it can be a serious, even fatal, incident.

title: Differences in Depression Extremes
description: Depression levels vary across red and blue states.

title: The F.C.C. Should Help the Poor Get Online
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission has proposed expanding a telephone subsidy program to help the poor gain access to high-speed Internet service. A few Republican lawmakers  notably John Thune of South Dakota in the Senate and Fred Upton of Michigan in the House  have complained of fraud in the existing program. The complaints are overblown and are no reason to undermine an excellent idea.

title: Differences in Depression Treatments
description: Depression treatments vary across blue and red states.

title: From Paris, With Tough Love
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Culture of Atheism
description: To the Editor:

title: Heroin Doesnt Have to Be a Killer
description: BALTIMORE

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Running Against Hillary
description: BEFORE anything else is said, they deserve the thanks of a grateful nation. Bernie Sanders, Martin OMalley, even Lincoln Chafee: They are stepping up where others quailed, laying their bodies on democracys altar, saving their partys nominating contest from resembling a presidential re-election in Kazakhstan.

title: What Makes a Woman?
description: Do women and men have different brains?

title: Hillary the Tormentor
description: LATELY Ive been running into people even more put off by the Clintons than the nefarious operatives in the vast right wing conspiracy ever were.

title: The Case for a Carbon Tax
description: In a welcome development, businesses are asking world leaders to do more to address climate change. This week, the top executives of six large European oil and gas companies called for a tax on carbon emissions.

title: How to Pose Like a Man
description: THE cover my publisher chose for my new novel, The Unfortunate Importance of Beauty, was indeed very beautiful, but more feminine than I would have ideally liked. It was mostly white, but all the way at the top were the gorgeous chin and red lips of a young woman. Not wanting to be a difficult author, I decided not to ask my editor to find a new cover. (She had already been kind enough to change it once.) Instead, I decided to counteract the cover by other means, starting with my author photo.

title: Hackers Can Be Fought Without Violating Americans Rights
description: The scope and sophistication of recent cyberattacks on American government, business and personal accounts are chilling. The latest, a breach of federal personnel records that could affect more than four million current and former employees, is a reminder that enhancing the nations cyberdefenses has to be an urgent priority.

title: Talking Red State Blues
description: WHEN you mull over the differences between states that vote for Republicans in presidential elections and states that vote for Democrats, what do you think about? Perhaps religion: People in red states are far more likely to believe in God. Or maybe media consumption: More people in blue states like NPR.

title: The Deadly Combination of Heat and Humidity
description: THE most deadly weather-related disasters arent necessarily caused by floods, droughts or hurricanes. They can be caused by heat waves, like the sweltering blanket thats taken over 2,500 lives in India in recent weeks.

title: Why I Defaulted on My Student Loans
description: ONE late summer afternoon when I was 17, I went with my mother to the local bank, a long-defunct institution whose name I cannot remember, to apply for my first student loan. My mother co-signed. When we finished, the banker, a balding man in his late 50s, congratulated us, as if I had just won some kind of award rather than signed away my young life.

title: Ruben Tejada Is Making the Most of Another Chance With Mets
description: PHOENIX  Ruben Tejada was sitting at his locker Thursday, examining the tattoo that circled his left wrist like a bracelet, when he was asked what the five ornately drawn letters signified.

title: Break Serve? For Most Players, Its a Struggle to Break Even
description: PARIS  Fifty years ago this spring, Fred Stolle of Australia won the French International Tennis Championship by defeating his countryman Tony Roche in the final. Stolle and Roy Emerson, another Aussie, won the doubles crown as well.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Blatter Deserves Anything But Praise

title: Young, Seeking Change Over Ideology, Power Right Wing in Poland
description: WARSAW  Sitting quietly in the bustle of the campus cafe, Daria Zysk paused to find just the right words to explain why she had voted for a presidential candidate whose partys right-wing policies did not match her own views.

title: Imagining the Lives of Others
description: What could be more exhilarating than experiencing the world through the perspective of another person? In Remembrance of Things Past, Marcel Prousts narrator says that the only true voyage of discovery is not to visit other lands but to possess other eyes, to behold the universe through the eyes of another, of a hundred others, to behold the hundred universes that each of them beholds. This is one of the central projects of the humanities; its certainly part of the pleasure we get from art and literature.

title: Discordant NotesOver Need to Practice on a U.S. Open Course
description: Robert Trent Jones Jr., the architect of the public links-style course hosting this months United States Open, likens the circus descending on Chambers Bay Golf Course in less than two weeks to a symphony.

title: Face of Soccer in Canada, on Field and on Stamps
description: EDMONTON, Alberta  GCanada had just been eliminated from the 2011 Womens World Cup. Its captain, Christine Sinclair, sat on the turf, crying, angry, desolate. Her nose had been broken earlier in the tournament in Germany. Now, after a 4-0 rout by France in group play, her spirit felt broken as well.

title: On Paper, U.S. Women Have Enough
description: Can we win?

title: A Long-Awaited Coronation
description: Belmont Park began filling up early on Saturday with spectators, trainers and riders in preparation for the Belmont Stakes, which American Pharoah won to complete his Triple Crown bid.

title: Ben Carsons Nascent Campaign Faces Personnel Turmoil
description: BOONE, Iowa  Ben Carson, a retired neurosurgeon and Tea Party folk hero, has emerged as one of the most talked-about Republican candidates for president in 2016, buoyed by the strength of his outsiders appeal and captivating life story.

title: With Power Tools and a Ruse, 2 Killers Escape New York Prison
description: DANNEMORA, N.Y.  Two convicted murderers serving life sentences in adjoining cells staged an elaborate escape from New Yorks largest state-run prison between Friday night and Saturday morning, fooling guards with makeshift dummies made out of sweatshirts and using power tools to drill out of their cells and past the prisons 30-foot-tall walls, officials said.

title: Presidential Hopefuls Descend on Iowa, Courting Favor With Joni Ernst
description: DES MOINES  Arriving at the kickoff of her inaugural Roast and Ride event here, fresh off a two-hour ride up from Red Oak on her 2009 Soft Tail Deluxe Harley-Davidson Saturday morning, Senator Joni Ernst of Iowa grinned as a friend pressed a Monster Energy drink into her hand.

title: Barcelona Overwhelms Juventus to Win Fifth Champions League Title
description: BERLIN  It is not discussed often, but there is a deep and rich tradition of manager celebrations in high-level soccer, a veritable catalog of sideline revelry. On various occasions  and with varying degrees of dignity  men in suits have danced a jig, pretended to use a lasso and hydroplaned on their knees as if their coaching box had morphed into a water ride. Just a few months ago, one man in charge even ripped his trousers in a particularly robust fit of exuberant histrionics.

title: Things to Do in Westchester, June 7 to 13, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, June 7 to 13, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, June 7 to 13, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Irving Mondschein, Decathlete, Coach and Track Patriarch, Dies at 91
description: Irving Mondschein, a national champion in the decathlon and high jump in the 1940s, a college and Olympic coach and the patriarch of three generations of track and field stars, died on Friday in Hershey, Pa. He was 91.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, June 7 to 13, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: The Call of the Race
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  That sound you hear is that of my brain unclenching after the Friday and Saturday puzzles.

title: Surprising Saudi Rises as a Prince Among Princes
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Until about four months ago, Prince Mohammed bin Salman, 29, was just another Saudi royal who dabbled in stocks and real estate.

title: Tenure Firmly in Place, but Colleges Grow Wary of Lasting Commitments
description: Gov. Scott Walkers move to weaken tenure in the Wisconsin public university system is bold  and, at least for a while, it is likely to remain an outlier.

title: Transgender Childrens Books Fill a Void and Break a Taboo
description: Sam Martin was browsing in a Boston record store 23 years ago when an unusual photography book caught his eye. Mr. Martin flipped through its pages, which featured portraits and interviews with women who had become men, and started to cry.

title: American Pharoah Wins Belmont Stakes and Triple Crown
description: As American Pharoah came out of the far turn and squared his shoulders to let his rider Victor Espinoza stare down the long withering stretch of Belmont Park, a sense of inevitability surged through this mammoth old grandstand. The fans in a capacity crowd strained on the tips of their toes and let out a roar from deep in their souls. It was going to end, finally  this 37-year search for a great racehorse.

title: Courts Budget Intensifies Kansas Dispute Over Powers
description: The fight between Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas and the states judicial branch has escalated, with the governor last week signing into law a bill that could strip state courts of their funding.

title: Spanish Tuna Fishing Melds to Japans Taste, Reshaping a 3,000-Year-Old Technique
description: BARBATE, Spain  The fishing boats, swaying in the narrow strait that connects the Atlantic to the Mediterranean, maneuvered one recent morning around an intricate architecture of nets they had laid as a trap. Then the fishermen lifted just one section from the water, heavy with their prize.

title: Dennis Hastert Rushed to Make Money as Payouts Grew
description: WASHINGTON  After a relatively slow start to his career as a consultant and lobbyist, J. Dennis Hastert, the former speaker of the House of Representatives, became very busy in 2010. He was traveling to spots including Singapore and Montreal, meeting with clients about ventures as varied as futures trading and Formula One racing.

title: Americans Dominate Boys Play in Paris
description: PARIS  When North Carolinas Tommy Paul beat San Diegos Taylor Harry Fritz, 7-6 (2), 2-6, 6-2, Saturday in the first all-American boys final at the French Open, it formally ended a tournament in which the future of United States mens tennis had already been declared the unanimous winner.

title: Painkillers Resist Abuse, but Experts Still Worry
description: Anthony DiTullio would pop a painkiller in his mouth but not just swallow it, as intended. He would chew it for 30 minutes, grinding through its protective coating and waxy unpleasantness, because the only pain he was treating was addiction.

title: Hillary Clinton Traces Friendly Path, Troubling Party
description: WASHINGTON  Hillary Rodham Clinton appears to be dispensing with the nationwide electoral strategy that won her husband two terms in the White House and brought white working-class voters and great stretches of what is now red-state America back to Democrats.

title: Putin Urges Western Pressure on Ukraine in Peace Effort
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia called on the United States and Europe on Saturday to pressure the Ukrainian government to comply with a cease-fire accord, saying that Russia would do what it could to influence separatists in the eastern Ukrainian regions of Donetsk and Luhansk but held no sway in Kiev, the capital.

title: As G.O.P. Courts Iowa, Party Debates Relevance of State
description: BOONE, Iowa  Wearing a black leather vest with a bald eagle on the back, black motorcycle boots and snug jeans, Senator Joni Ernst, a freshman Republican from Iowa, began her inaugural pig roast and motorcycle ride fund-raiser Saturday by easing her 2009 Softail Deluxe out of the Big Barn Harley Store in Des Moines.

title: Gathering With Hopes of Witnessing a Coronation
description: Belmont Park began filling up early on Saturday with spectators, trainers and riders in preparation for the Belmont Stakes, where American Pharoah completed for the Triple Crown.

title: Adjustments Ease Crowd at Racetrack
description: The blueprint demanded a revamped train station, intentionally depressed ticket sales and a pillar of pop-rock music, circa 1998.

title: Ronnie Gilbert, Bold-Voiced Singer With the Weavers, Is Dead at 88
description: Ronnie Gilbert, whose crystalline, bold contralto provided distaff ballast for the Weavers, the seminal quartet that helped propel folk music to wide popularity and establish its power as an agent of social change, died on Saturday in Mill Valley, Calif. She was 88.

title: Kyrie Irving Is the Latest Casualty in a High-Stakes Game
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The kid had all the moves and a clever dribble. He was lightning quick to the seams of the defense. You could see his cockiness and conviction in the way he carried himself against older boys with more developed bodies. Yes, that kid, Kyrie Irving, was going places.

title: An Elusive Trophy, Gleaming Through the Smudges of Hands and Lips
description: For 37 long years, as the sterling silver Triple Crown trophy waited for a permanent home, those handling it almost always did so wearing white cotton gloves.

title: After Series of Setbacks, Spacecraft Prepares to Unfurl Sail
description: A small experimental spacecraft that uses a shiny sail to reflect sunlight to propel itself came back to life Saturday afternoon after a series of near-death experiences. In a rush to finish the mission before anything else goes wrong, the team behind the craft prepared to deploy the sail on Sunday afternoon.

title: Get New York Times WhatsApp Alerts on Popes Latin America Trip
description: Our Vatican correspondent, Jim Yardley, will be traveling with Pope Francis during his trip to Latin America in early July. He will be on the papal plane and will provide a behind-the-scenes look as Francis visits Ecuador, Bolivia and Paraguay.

title: The Belmont, From Every Angle
description: A 360-degree view of American Pharoah winning the Belmont Stakes and the Triple Crown.

title: MERS Cases Rise in South Korea, Health Officials Say
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The number of South Koreans infected with Middle East respiratory syndrome increased to 87 on Monday after the government identified additional cases. It also said Monday that an 80-year-old man had died, bringing the number of deaths linked to the virus in South Korea to six.

title: Fan Expected to Survive Injury From Shattered Bat at Fenway
description: A woman who was struck in the head by a broken bat at Fenway Park on Friday night was in serious condition Saturday at a hospital in Boston, her family said in a statement.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: If you run a campaign trying to appeal to 60 to 70 percent of the electorate, youre not going to run a very compelling campaign for the voters you need.

title: Korean Robot Makers Walk Off With $2 Million Prize
description: POMONA, Calif.  A team of roboticists from the Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology claimed a $2 million prize on Saturday that was offered by a Pentagon research agency for developing a mobile robot capable of operating in hazardous environments.

title: Frustration Turns to Elation for Victor Espinoza
description: Before Victor Espinoza hopped aboard American Pharoah, carrying saddlebags full of his previous disappointment, and attempted to run toward history, he tried to lose himself in his routine.

title: Lightning Pull Even With Blackhawks in Back-and-Forth Game
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Tampa Bay Lightnings lack of experience had already been baked into the Stanley Cup finals, a ready-made reason for them to acquit themselves well but ultimately lose to the Chicago Blackhawks.

title: Angels Starter Is Out Early, and the Yankees Cruise
description: As Los Angeles Angels Manager Mike Scioscia made a premature stroll out to the mound Saturday night, Garrett Richards could not look. He kept his neck craned and stared toward the video board in center field, where some ghastly first-inning numbers were being displayed for all to see: six runs and five hits allowed, and only two outs.

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Catch up on the weeks top stories.

title: New York Prison Escape Stirs Painful Memories for Victims Father
description: Phillip Tarsia is still haunted by the death of his son, Deputy Sheriff Kevin Tarsia, at the hands of David Sweat, one of two convicted murderers who fled into a rural expanse of northern New York after staging an elaborate escape from a prison that was discovered on Saturday.

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Were trying something new: a quick rundown of the weeks top stories. What do you think? Let us know at briefing@nytimes.com.

title: Julia Bartlett, Alexander Stratoudakis
description: Julia Van Rensselaer Bartlett and Alexander Jay Stratoudakis were married Saturday. The Rev. Dr. Amy E. Richter officiated at St. Annes Episcopal Church in Annapolis, Md., where she is the rector. The Rev. Stuart A. Kenworthy, also an Episcopal priest, took part.

title: Janani Ramachandran, William Yates
description: Janani Ramachandran and William Peter Yates were married Saturday at the Mandarin Oriental hotel in Washington. The officiant was Betsey A. Stevenson, a friend of the couple who received authorization from the District of Columbia Superior Court.

title: Lauren Dahlin,  Peter Bacon
description: Lauren Nicole Dahlin and Peter Gamble Bacon were married Saturday by Wanda Chiles, a justice of the peace, at the Pinewood Lake Association in Trumbull, Conn.

title: Tricia Starr, Robert Dudley
description: Tricia Harper Starr and Robert Hamilton Dudley were married Saturday at the Roaring Fork Club in Basalt, Colo. The Rev. Jill Pidcock, a minister who was ordained through the the former Esoteric Truth Center in Colorado, officiated.

title: Molly Boskey, Charles Pascal
description: Molly Elizabeth Boskey and Charles Carleton Pascal were married Saturday at the Wequassett Resort and Golf Club in Harwich, Mass., by Jonathan T. Marston, who received permission from Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Colleen White,  Carson Brown
description: Colleen Faith White, a daughter of Susan Y. White and Jeffrey White of Westport, Conn., was married Thursday to Carson Thomas Brown, a son of Leslie E. Brown and Cameron S. Brown of Cape Elizabeth, Me. The Rev. Thomas Collins, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Marys Church in Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: Elizabeth Cimarelli,  Michael DeLoach
description: Elizabeth Anne Cimarelli and Michael Keith DeLoach were married Saturday at the Hill, an events space in Hudson, N.Y. The officiant was Mary Ellen Morganteen, the brides aunt, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion.

title: Gertrude Conklin,  Tom Meberg
description: Gertrude Conklin and Tom Meberg were married Saturday by the Rev. Beate Storck at Trinity Lutheran Church in Tenafly, N.J.

title: Heather Schroder, Lukas Morawski
description: Heather Marie Schroder and Lukas Campbell Morawski were married Saturday by the Rev. Dr. Gordon McClellan, a Presbyterian minister, at the First Congregational Church in Manchester, Vt.

title: Stephanie Smith, Eric Schulte
description: Stephanie Smith and Eric William Schulte were married Saturday at Joias, a villa in Christ Church Parish, Barbados. The Rev. Ricky Kirton, a minister of the Church of the Nazarene, officiated.

title: Lucy Wertheim, Alexander Palmer
Helen Johnston, Bryan Gant
description: Helen Danielson Johnston and Bryan Daniel Gant were married Saturday at the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme in Old Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Steven R. Jungkeit, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

title: Angela Shih, Albert Li
description: Dr. Angela Young Shih and Dr. Albert Cheng-Chia Li were married Saturday at St. Rose of Lima Church in Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. M. Christen Beirne, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Stephanie Witkin and Matthew Shapiro
description: Stephanie Brett Witkin and Matthew Benjamin Shapiro were married Saturday evening at the St. Regis Bal Harbour Resort in Bal Harbour, Fla. Rabbi Gary Glickstein officiated.

title: Sarah Troup, Timothy Geisenheimer
description: Sarah Elizabeth Troup and Timothy Adam Geisenheimer were married Saturday in Madison, Conn. Virginia C. Raff, a justice of the peace, officiated at the summer house of the grooms family.

title: Michael Foley and Christopher Lukacs
description: Michael Christopher Foley and Christopher Anton Lukacs were married Saturday evening at the Three Village Inn in Stony Brook, N.Y. Martin Penny, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Monica Rober,  Patrick McHugh
description: Monica Louise Rober, a daughter of Gail Rober and Gregory Rober of Lynnfield, Mass., was married Saturday to Patrick Justin McHugh, the son of Pamela J. McHugh of Rockville, Md., and the late Richard J. McHugh. Guy H. Cecil III, a Universal Life minister, officiated at Pinstripes, a restaurant in Washington.

title: Ellinor Quay, Michael Coyne
description: Dr. Ellinor Ramsay Quay and Michael Atkinson Coyne were married Saturday at St. Michaels Parish in Litchfield, Conn. The Rev. Dr. E. Bevan Stanley, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Brita Bergh,  Henrik Dahlback
description: Brita Maria Bergh and Henrik Claes Gustaf Dahlback were married Saturday at the Muse Event Center in Minneapolis. The Rev. Carrie S. Scheller, a Lutheran minister, officiated.

title: Jennifer Hoffman, Andrew Werner
description: Jennifer Lauren Hoffman and Andrew Edward Werner were married Saturday evening at the National Aquarium in Baltimore. Rabbi Steven Fink officiated.

title: Lindsay Lachky,  Michael Kenworthy
description: Lindsay Ann Lachky, a daughter of Cathy M. Lachky and Robert C. Lachky of St. Louis, was married Saturday to Michael Scott Kenworthy, a son of Maria A. Kenworthy and Paul R. Kenworthy, both of Minneapolis. The Rev. Michael P. Hilbert, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Jena Levy,  Andrew Sussman
description: Jena Paige Levy, a daughter of Shelley Wittman Levy and Benjamin M. Levy of Tenafly, N.J., was married in Pearl River, N.Y., Saturday evening to Andrew Cory Sussman, a son of April Baskin Sussman and Dr. Robert Sussman of West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Melissa L. Buyer officiated at the Hilton Pearl River hotel.

title: Charles Bergman, Stuart Levy
description: Charles Cabe Bergman and Stuart Alan Levy were married Saturday at the home of Elizabeth G. Sachs and Samuel Sachs II in Bedford, N.Y. James G. Croghan, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Benita Hussain and Noah Cohen-Cline
description: Benita Del Hussain and Noah Baruch Cohen-Cline are to be married Sunday at the Prospect Park Picnic House in Brooklyn. Saisha M. Grayson, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, is to officiate, with Marcus P. Berley, also a Universal Life minister, in a ceremony that will incorporate Jewish and Bengali-Muslim traditions.

title: Honor McGee and Jay Lundy Jr.
description: Honor Serena Wadsworth McGee, the daughter of Celia B. McGee and Henry W. McGee III of New York, was married Saturday evening to Jay Russell Lundy Jr., a son of Calesti B. Lundy and Mr. Lundy Sr. of Fort Pierce, Fla. Judge Patti B. Saris of the Federal District Court in Boston officiated at Winvian Farm in Morris, Conn.

title: Kirsten Reach, Eugene Rutigliano
description: Kirsten Elizabeth Reach, a daughter of Anna D. Reach and Robert F. Reach of Gambier, Ohio, was married Saturday to Eugene Anthony Rutigliano, the son of Karen Burns Rutigliano and Anthony J. Rutigliano of Randolph, N.J. The Rev. Cam Miller, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Spirit in Gambier.

title: A Match Made in Anatomy Lab
description: Amy Li, the daughter of Li Ping Li and You Xiang Li of Brooklyn, was married Saturday to Dr. Jacob Eric Lemieux, the son of Monica I. Blum and Robert P. Lemieux of Manhattan. Judge Paul A. Crotty of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York officiated at the Prince George Ballroom in Manhattan.

title: Jackelyn Tannenholtz,  Joshua Gerber
description: Jackelyn Lisa Tannenholtz and Joshua Colman Gerber are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Jeffrey J. Sirkman at Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn.

title: Janice Cane, Brian Wolly
description: Janice Rochelle Cane and Brian Jeffrey Wolly are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Jack Luxemburg at the Loews Hotel in Philadelphia. Rabbi Eliott Perlstein is to take part in the ceremony.

title: David Barquist, Douglas Schaller
description: David Lawrence Barquist and Douglas Gene Schaller were married Saturday at St. Peters Church in Philadelphia. The Rev. Ledlie I. Laughlin, an Episcopal priest and the rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Cook,  Anna Prow
description: Elizabeth Ann Cook and Anna Drucilla Prow were married Saturday at Zigbone Farm Retreat Center in Sabillasville, Md. Rabbi Annie Bornstein officiated.

title: Stephanie Alessi, Michael Kraft
description: Stephanie Ann Alessi, a daughter of Florence M. Alessi and Dr. Carl F. Alessi of Lincoln, Me., is to be married Sunday to Michael J. Kraft, a son of Ruth B. Kraft and Dr. Robert L. Kraft of North Hills, N.Y. Michael G. Thieling, a Universal Life minister, is to officiate in the courtyard of the Delancey Street Foundation, a social services organization in San Francisco.

title: Allison Kumata, Conrad Shang
description: Dr. Allison Ming-Yu Hiroko Kumata and Conrad Yuan-Kang Shang were married Saturday at Hans Fahden Vineyards in Calistoga, Calif. The Rev. Blane W. Ellsworth, a minister of the Fellowship of Kindness, led a nondenominational ceremony.

title: Marisa Maleck and Thomas Johnson Jr.
description: Marisa Christina Maleck, a daughter of Maria F. Rodriguez-Maleck and Paul M. Maleck of West Springfield, Mass., was married Saturday to Thomas Michael Johnson Jr., a son of Marie R. Johnson and Thomas M. Johnson Sr. of Park Ridge, N.J. The Rev. Patrick Riffle, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Peter's on Capitol Hill in Washington.

title: Time Stands Still at 79th and Lexington
description: Alexandra Shackelford Jones, a daughter of Nancy S. Jones and James A. Jones III of Manakin-Sabot, Va., was married Saturday to Nicholas Yates Thorne, a son of Margaret Y. Thorne and Nathan C. Thorne of New York. The Rev. John E. Miller, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Marys Episcopal Church in Richmond, Va.

title: Andrea Cohan, Tanya Liszniansky
description: Andrea Michelle Cohan, a daughter of Sherri Cohan and Jack G. Cohan of Solon, Ohio, was married Saturday evening to Tanya Maria Liszniansky, the daughter of Suzanne Liszniansky and Emil Liszniansky of Vermilion, Ohio. Rabbi Debra Kolodny officiated in Malibu Lake, Calif., at the home of Ms. Cohans aunt, Julie Locks Sherman.

title: Anna Kendrick, Alexander Geppert
description: Anna Kathryn Kendrick and Alexander Christian Tillmann Geppert were married Saturday in Boston. The Rev. Stephen G. Kendrick, the brides father, performed the ceremony at First Church, a Unitarian Universalist church where he is the senior minister. The Rev. Kevin G. Grove, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Carolyn Cost, Bryan Hart
description: Carolyn Anne Cost and Bryan Charles Hart were married Saturday by Msgr. Frank Del Prete, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Marys-in-Tuxedo in Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

title: Michelle Zemel, Julia Diamond
description: Michelle Zemel and Julia Ellen Diamond were married Saturday in Grand Park, a public park in Los Angeles, in a ceremony led by Eugenia Han, who became a minister affiliated with American Marriage Ministries to officiate.

title: At the Table, Michael Perlmans Play About Loose Tongues and Frayed Friendships
description: After the Tony Awards wrap up on Sunday, how will you spend your evenings? Very few Broadway shows are opening between now and the usual fall flurry, but keep in mind that there are no lulls in downtown theater.

title: With Power Tools and a Ruse, 2 Killers Flee New York Prison
description: DANNEMORA, N.Y.  The State Police and other law enforcement agencies were continuing on Sunday to hunt for two fugitive murderers in the wilderness and rural communities of northern New York, a day after the two men escaped from the maximum-security state prison here.

title: Mets Dillon Gee Unhappy With Move Back to the Bullpen
description: PHOENIX  When Dillon Gee arrived at Chase Field on Saturday, Mets Manager Terry Collins summoned him to his office to apologize. Gee was not entirely sure why. The apology could have been for the frequent trade rumors, or the shifting of Gee between the bullpen and the rotation, or the general sense from the Mets that he was unwanted.

title: Corrections: June 7, 2015
description: NATIONAL

title: Dennis Hastert, From Public Servant to Rainmaker
description: Documents provided to The New York Times offer an inside look at how J. Dennis Hastert, the former speaker of the House, attempted to start his career in the private sector at the same time that he began to make payments that have drawn scrutiny from criminal investigators.

title: Dennis Hastert, From Public Servant to Rainmaker
description: Documents provided to The New York Times offer an inside look at how J. Dennis Hastert, the former speaker of the House, attempted to start his career in the private sector at the same time that he began to make payments that have drawn scrutiny from criminal investigators.

title: Scenes From Belmont Park
description: American Pharoah became the first horse since 1978 to sweep the Triple Crown.

title: Affirmeds Owner and Jockey Share in a Celebration, 37 Years After Their Own
description: In the crazy euphoria of a historic racing moment, Patrice Wolfson stood in her box at Belmont Park on Saturday evening, soaking up the emotion and, like the rest of us, trying to digest what had just happened: American Pharoah, dominating almost from the start, had become the first horse in 37 years to win the Triple Crown.

title: 1915: Turks Resistance in Gallipoli Slowly Waning
description: LONDON  A telegram from Athens says that the general attack begun on Friday in the Gallipoli Peninsula is making splendid progress. The resistance of the Turks is visibly weakening on account of their enormous losses. The Allies, adds the despatch [sic], have occupied three rows of trenches where dead and wounded Turks are heaped together in masses.

title: Whats Your Teenager Doing This Summer? In Defense of Nothing
description: Another school year has come to an end. And heres what summertime looks like for Americas luckiest teenagers: a full-time internship, learn-to-code camp or college classes (to show you can do college work before you apply to college), plus an SAT prep class and a college-essay-writing intensive, plus, as summer draws to a close, sports camp or music lessons in prep for the fall competitions. Or maybe all of the above.

title: Remittances at the Click of a Smartphone Button
description: LONDON  When Stellah Vardling was getting ready recently for her birthday party, she did what many 22-year-olds would have done. She asked her family for money to help pay for the party.

title: Deutsche Bank Co-Chief Executives Resign
description: FRANKFURT  Even as other European banks reduced their presence on Wall Street in the face of new regulations and legal challenges, Deutsche Bank has been the exception.

title: Over Beer, Obama and Merkel Mend Ties and Double Down on Russia
description: KRN, Germany  President Obama sought to smooth over tensions with a crucial ally, bonding on Sunday with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany over beer, sausages and their shared determination to confront Russia over its aggression in Ukraine, as he declared her a great friend and partner during a summit meeting of world leaders.

title: Erdogans Governing Party in Turkey Loses Parliamentary Majority
description: ISTANBUL  Turkish voters delivered a rebuke on Sunday to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan as his party lost its majority in Parliament in a historic election that thwarted his ambition to rewrite Turkeys Constitution and further bolster his clout.

title: A Triumph of Racing, and Broadcasting, That Was Worth the Wait
description: The prerace programming for the Belmont Stakes on Saturday on NBC lasted nearly two and a half hours. Despite the quality of the broadcast, it felt too long, but perhaps that was appropriate given the 37-year wait for a Triple Crown winner.

title: A Muslim Lawyer Refuses to Choose Between a Career and a Head Scarf
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y.  The apprehension usually hits the night before a job interview or a big court case, as Zahra Cheema, a young lawyer, looks at the colorful head scarves and flowing abayas in her closet and silently wonders: Should I try to make myself look less Muslim?

title: European Leaders Voice Frustration With Greece in Debt Crisis
description: GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany  World leaders on Sunday increased the pressure on Europe to resolve the crisis over Greek debt, hours after one of the chief European negotiators expressed exasperation with the way the Greek leader was handling the talks.

title: Spy and Melissa McCarthy Prove More Popular Than the Boys of Entourage
description: LOS ANGELES  In another gender-war weekend at the box office, the women of Spy humiliated the men of Entourage.

title: French Open 2015: Stan Wawrinka Defeats Novak Djokovic for Title
description: PARIS  A memorable French Open mens final full of long rallies and bold strokes had just ended, and Gustavo Kuerten appeared on the red clay to hand out the trophies.

title: Notoriety and Scorn Shadow Clinton Prison
description: Clinton Correctional Facility, the state prison where two men serving murder sentences were discovered missing on Saturday morning, is a tough place to do hard time.

title: Protections for Late Investors Can Inflate Start-Up Valuations
description: Warning: Some unicorns may be smaller than they appear.

title: State Bills Tackle Drive-Thrus, Pop Tarts and Horse Tripping
description: State legislatures are often called the countrys laboratories of democracy, but as the 2015 legislative season comes to an end, some bills have inspired more laughter than respect.

title: States Confront Wide Budget Gaps Even After Years of Recovery
description: CHICAGO  In Illinois, fights over the state budget and its $3 billion shortfall have hit such an impasse that Gov. Bruce Rauner, a Republican, issued a dire warning last week that a major, major restructuring of the government was around the corner.

title: A Beat Calls Puerto Ricans to Their African Roots
description: Jose Ortiz stood on the steps of the Andrew Freedman Home on the Grand Concourse, a gorgeous Bronx palazzo bathed in sunshine, his barrel drum by his side. Before him, on the lawn, a circle of people gathered, passing a calabash or sage leaves as they blessed one another. As the faint scent of gardenia and lavender wafted through the air, Mr. Ortiz straddled his drum and played.

title: Seeing a Different Type of Clinton Campaign
description: In 2008, when Hillary Rodham Clinton was waging a campaign for Democratic superdelegates  party officials who could choose to back whichever candidate they wanted, regardless of whether that person had won their state  Bill Clinton worked the phones aggressively on her behalf.

title: Egypt: Lifes Sentence
description: Hend Nafea was sentenced to life in prison for protesting against Egypts military government. In this piece  filmed a day after the sentencing  she maintains her innocence.

title: Syria: Brides of Peace
description: The sisters Kinda and Lubna Zaour walked through the main souk in Damascus dressed as brides, a symbol of love and peace. They were arrested almost immediately.

title: Bahrain: Our Oath
description: Dr. Nada Dhaif helped create a medical tent to treat injured protesters in Bahrains Pearl Roundabout  and was sentenced to 15 years in jail.

title: Yemen: When Is the Time?
description: In this conservative country  dubbed the worst in the world for women  the revolution offered feminists like Belquis Al Lahabi a faint glimmer of hope.

title: Libya: Wake Up, Benghazi!
description: On June 25, 2014, Salwa Bugaighis was shot dead in her home by unknown militants, marking a new milestone in the countrys descent toward anarchy: the first female political assassination.

title: Stripped, Beaten, Humiliated and Barred From Her Own Trial in Egypt
description: During the early days of the revolution against President Hosni Mubarak, a sense of shared purpose and community made Tahrir Square feel like the safest place in Cairo, for women and men. But that collapsed almost the moment Mr. Mubarak left office, on Feb. 11, 2011. Sexual assault and the harassment of women in public, an epidemic problem in Egypt for decades, became alarmingly common again.

title: The Brutal Silencing of a Woman at the Forefront of Libyas Rebellion
description: Scores or perhaps hundreds of killings remain unsolved in Benghazi, Libya, since the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi nearly four years ago. But no victim has symbolized the crushed hopes of the Libyan uprising more than Salwa Bugaighis.

title: A Quickly Stifled Attempt to Ease Suffering in Bahrain
description: The roundup of health workers who treated injured protesters set the tone for the furious and uncompromising reaction by Bahrains government to a popular uprising in 2011.

title: In Yemen, a Brief Moment Before Women Were Pushed Aside Again
description: CAIRO  When protesters in Yemen succeeded in ousting President Ali Abdullah Saleh in 2012, their success stirred hopes for change in a place that had suffered mightily from poverty and corruption for decades under his autocratic rule.

title: Making Herself Heard, Before and After Tunisias Uprising
description: TUNIS  In December 2010 a fruit-vendor in Tunisia, Mohamed Bouazizi, set himself alight in a protest against the police who stopped him from setting up his stall and earning a daily wage. His act of self-immolation  he died three weeks later  triggered a popular uprising around the country, where thousands of Tunisians seized on Mr. Bouazizis singular act and took to the streets to stand against state oppression and government corruption.

title: Brides of Syria Were Joined in Opposition to Violence
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The blurry pictures circulating on social media showed several women in white, dressed as brides, standing shoulder to shoulder in a covered market in the old city of Damascus. The banners they carried were ostensibly innocuous, calling for the end of all military operations.

title: Tunisia: Keeping the Promise
description: Even before the revolution, Ghazala Mhamdi was leading the fight for jobs, freedom and human rights; then the veteran activist ran for Parliament.

title: Lindsey Graham and Scott Walker Stick to Domestic Issues on Sunday Shows
description: The large and growing field of Republican presidential candidates is largely in agreement on foreign policy, so the hopefuls are looking to domestic and social issues as a way to differentiate themselves.

title: Up for Auction: Lucian Freuds Letters to a Poet
description: Lucian Freuds colorful, affectionate letters to the poet Stephen Spender, written when the painter was a teenager, will soon be up for auction at Sothebys in London.

title: Tempers Are Hot, but So Are the Yankees
description: Before their 6-2 win over the Los Angeles Angels at Yankee Stadium on Sunday, Yankees players posed for pictures, many of them selfies, with season-ticket-holding fans.

title: John Lennons Love Me Do Guitar Found, and Is Up for Sale
description: John Lennons 1962 Gibson guitar is a blip in the history of the Beatles. He played it for early hits like Love Me Do,  but it disappeared in 1963 and was quickly replaced. End of story.

title: G.E. Nears Deal on Major Step in Retreat From Banking
description: General Electric is near a deal to sell the bulk of a division that finances leveraged buyouts to a major Canadian pension fund, people briefed on the matter said on Sunday, as the industrial giant seeks to shed most of its GE Capital finance arm.

title: The Art of the Rolling Stones Sticky Fingers
description: With the rerelease of the 1971 album, the designer Craig Braun is eager to share the story of what VH1 called the best album cover ever and that tongue logo.

title: Amid the Mud and Straw, Workers on the Backstretch Savor a Special Day
description: At the distant edge of the horse-and-track village called Belmont Park, even the sparrows were excited. Their evening chatter all but shouted out the faint strains of New York, New York, wafting over the stables and barns and ramshackle dorms where the horse people exist.

title: Review: Charlie Parkers Yardbird Uses Opera to Tell a Jazz Story
description: PHILADELPHIA  Writing an opera about a famous person who lived a well-documented life is difficult enough. Writing an opera about a famous musician is even harder, especially a figure like the towering jazz saxophonist and composer Charlie Parker, a pioneer of bebop, an artist whose music still defines the art form and remains as astounding as ever. How can a composer make Parker the subject of an opera without putting Parkers music into the score?

title: Review: With Evolution, Dr. Lonnie Smith Channels an Old Wisdom
description: Dr. Lonnie Smith plays the Hammond organ and works more or less within the style and sound of East Coast and Rust Belt organ jazz from the 1960s and 70s. Thats his professional biography, anyway. He started in Buffalo, moved to New York City and worked with George Benson, then began a half-century of swing and funk and blues, from his early records on Blue Note through his octet album of a few years ago, In the Beginning.

title: MERS Outbreak in South Korea
description: As seen from the North.

title: Review: Book of Numbers, by Joshua Cohen, Is Narrative as Rich as the Web
description: Alive with talk and dense with data, Joshua Cohens novel Book of Numbers reads as if Philip Roths work were fired into David Foster Wallaces inside the Hadron particle collider.

title: Art of the Rolling Stones: Behind That Zipper and That Tongue
description: As the Rolling Stones prepared recently to rerelease Sticky Fingers, their classic 1971 album featuring hits like Wild Horses and Brown Sugar, the manufacturing process hit a snag: The functional zipper from Andy Warhols bulging blue jean album cover, recreated for some new deluxe editions, was taking longer than expected to produce, Universal Music announced, pushing back the release to Tuesday.

title: Review: Settlement House, a Tribute to Henry Streets 100-Year History
description: It has been 100 years since the Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side opened its neighborhood playhouse, a little theater that became a home to Martha Graham, John Cage and Alwin Nikolais. On Saturday, Settlement House, a choreographic installation organized by Will Rawls, celebrated the playhouses centennial by performing there and next door at the Abrons Arts Center. A program note introduced the guiding questions: whether one can actually dance about architecture and whether and how architecture might be made to dance.

title: Review: In Odd Mom Out, Competition Among Manhattans Wealthy
description: After complaining about the commute between Southampton and Capri, a Park Avenue socialite asks Jill Weber (Jill Kargman) a question: Where do you guys summer again? Jill defiantly replies, We summer on 61st between Second and Third.

title: Turkeys Ruling Party Loses Parliamentary Majority
description: The election results were a significant setback for President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

title: Shaded Answers
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  This is a different way to present the common-word-goes-after-theme-entry theme, and it is made easy with a revealer at 38 Across and the shaded or circled entries in the puzzle.

title: Benefits Grow for Public University Presidents, Survey Finds
description: Even with college costs and student debt in the national spotlight, the pay packages  and especially the benefits  of public university presidents continue to grow. The median salary for public university presidents was $428,250 in the 2014 fiscal year, up about 7 percent from the previous year, according to an annual survey by The Chronicle of Higher Education.

title: Publisher to Put Asterisk on Primates of Park Avenue
description: Primates of Park Avenue, a memoir on the secluded lives of Upper East Side wives, set off a rush of skeptical commentary over what appeared to be the outr rituals, like wife bonuses, of New Yorks wealthy elite.

title: Mets Bats Back Jacob deGrom in Win Over Diamondbacks
description: PHOENIX  Curtis Granderson hurried around the bases and straight for the dugout, his head down, as if he were worried the umpire would call his home run back. His manager, Terry Collins, greeted him with a firm and grateful handshake, and Granderson plopped down on the bench and let out a sigh.

title: At CatCon, Breaking a Stereotype in Ears and Whiskers
description: LOS ANGELES  They arrived wearing whiskers and ears. They purred over new litter fragrances, and pawed through the cat clothes. Hissing? Well, the line was long for that keynote speech: Photographing Cats  It Looks Easy, but Its Not.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of June 8
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: After Silences and Setbacks, the LightSail Spacecraft Is Revived, Deploying Its Solar Sail
description: After malfunctions, silences and other unexpected twists, a small experimental spacecraft testing the possibility of harnessing sunlight for propulsion finally did what it was designed to do on Sunday: It unfurled a large, shiny sheet of Mylar.

title: Discovery of Missing Prints Fails to Save Boston Library Leaders Job
description: BOSTON  If the word vindicated had a picture in the dictionary, it might be the face of Amy Ryan.

title: Sepp Blatter, FIFAs Fallen Chief, Is Held Up as Hero at Home
description: VISP, Switzerland  His reputation may be deeply tarnished in the world of soccer, and beyond. A widening swirl of corruption allegations points to deep rot in the organization he has run. And after 17 years atop one of sports most powerful groups, his downfall was a shattering crash heard the globe over.

title: A Map for Tiger Woods: Jack Nicklauss Late Career
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  The 39-year-old legend could not win a golf tournament for trying, giving rise to amateur diagnoses that the infirmities in his game were incurable. On Sunday, Jack Nicklaus remembered that 1979 season, the first winless year of his Hall of Fame career.

title: Bronx Cocktail
description: Dear Diary:

title: The 2015 Tony Awards
description: The 69th annual Tony Awards on Sunday night turned out the biggest stars of Broadway.

title: HackerOne Connects Hackers With Companies, and Hopes for a Win-Win
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In 2011, two Dutch hackers in their early 20s made a target list of 100 high-tech companies they would try to hack. Soon, they had found security vulnerabilities in Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft, Twitter and 95 other companies systems.

title: Passing Up Event at Home, David Lingmerth Wins the Memorial
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  David Lingmerth reluctantly passed on the European Tour stop in his native Sweden this year, as he had the previous two. While his compatriot Alex Noren won by four strokes Sunday at PGA Sweden National, Lingmerth was more than 4,000 miles away, locking horns with the 2013 United States Open champion, Justin Rose, in the Memorial Tournament at Muirfield Village Golf Club.

title: Monsanto Renews Its Pursuit of Syngenta, With $2 Billion Fee
description: Monsanto on Sunday made a new attempt to acquire Syngenta, the Swiss agricultural chemical manufacturer. But rather than increase the price it is willing to pay, Monsanto instead offered to pay Syngenta $2 billion if Monsanto cannot obtain the regulatory approvals necessary to complete the deal.

title: Ex-Official Says Chris Christie Broke Grand Jury Law
description: The players at the center of the George Washington Bridge lane-closing scandal are not finished causing headaches for Gov. Chris Christie.

title: Russia Uses Money and Ideology to Fight Western Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON  The war in Ukraine that has pitted Russia against the West is being waged not just with tanks, artillery and troops. Increasingly, Moscow has brought to bear different kinds of weapons, according to American and European officials: money, ideology and disinformation.

title: Lightning Owner Wants to Build to Last, in Tampa and on Ice
description: TAMPA, Fla.  As a money manager, Jeff Vinik made hundreds of millions of dollars by taking big bets on undervalued assets. But when he turned 50, he wanted to do something else. He did not play golf and could visit only so many museums.

title: Wide Net Cast for Escaped Killers; They Could Be Anywhere
description: DANNEMORA, N.Y.  The plot was more Shawshank Redemption than CSI: two hardened inmates using power tools, handmade decoys and their hands to chisel and crawl their way out of a maximum-security prison in a subterranean escape.

title: New York City Ballet Announces Promotions in Dancer Ranks
description: New York City Ballet has a new pair of principal dancers: Lauren Lovette and Anthony Huxley, who had been soloists with the company, were promoted on Sunday afternoon by Peter Martins, its ballet master in chief.

title: A Convicted Murderers Escape Alarms Investigators From His Past
description: NORTH TONAWANDA, N.Y.  The disappearance of the businessman was initially handled as a missing person case. Then a detective noticed specks of blood near a cellar door and a fisherman found a human torso in the Niagara River.

title: Obama Administration Criticizes Egypt in Report to Congress
description: CAIRO  Egypt is moving away from democracy, stifling freedom of expression, arresting thousands for political dissent and failing to hold the security forces accountable for arbitrary or unlawful killings, the Obama administration has determined in a formal report to Congress.

title: At Center of FIFA Scandal, a Divisive Politician in Jack Warner
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad and Tobago  The prime minister of this Caribbean republic walked out of a session of Parliament on Friday, angrily chastising a fellow politician and former ally, Jack Warner, who finds himself and his two sons at the center of soccers widespread corruption scandal.

title: Straight Outta Compton Film Plays a Role in Suge Knight Murder Case
description: LOS ANGELES  In an editing room here, filmmakers are wrestling with a final cut of Straight Outta Compton, Universal Pictures new movie about the outlaw rap group N.W.A.

title: Review: Card and Gift, Set in a Seldom-Patronized Shop
description: Small-town blues were once a dominant melody line in American drama. Their sound was probably most pervasive during the mid-20th-century, when the tear-splotched plays of William Inge ruled Broadway.

title: After American Pharoahs Runaway, Pondering Whether to Quit While Ahead
description: Everyone knows there is no cheering in the press box, and crying is frowned upon as well. Both rules were violated as American Pharoah thundered down the stretch and into the record books, setting off a cathartic celebration at Belmont Park and beyond among those who appreciate racehorses.

title: De Blasio Prods New York State on Housing Laws
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio went to church on Sunday to talk about housing.

title: High Hopes for John Cryan,Deutsche Banks New Chief, Known for His Pragmatism
description: John Cryan, a former finance chief at UBS who Deutsche Bank said on Sunday would become the banks new chief executive, brings many qualities to the table, colleagues say.

title: Community Remembers Reporter Shot in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  When Charnice Milton was a little girl, she used the newspaper to overcome a speech impediment. Her mother, Francine Milton, encouraged her to strengthen her voice by reading the articles out loud.

title: Obamas Slap in Britains Face
description: London  Two weeks ago, we went to Washington to argue for the immediate release of Shaker Aamer, a detainee at Guantnamo Bay. Mr. Aamers wife and four children live in London but he has yet to meet his youngest child, Faris, who is now 13.

title: Apples Conference, G.M.s Annual Meeting, and a Trade Vote in Europe
description: Apple is set to kick off its annual conference for software developers on Monday. The company is expected to show new and improved versions of OS X, its Mac operating system, and iOS, the mobile software system powering iPhones and iPads. The company will also introduce a new streaming music service that it developed with Beats Electronics, the company it acquired last year for $3 billion. Absent from the unveilings will be a long-anticipated upgrade for the Apple TV set-top box, which was pulled from the conference because of issues related to content and technology. Brian X. Chen

title: Henry Carr, Olympic Sprinter and a Football Giant, Dies at 73
description: Henry Carr, a sprinter who captured two gold medals in the 1964 Tokyo Olympics and later played defensive back for the Giants, died on May 29 in Griffin, Ga. He was 73.

title: Silicon Valley Recap: Schrdingers Cat
description: Season 2, Episode 9: Binding Arbitration

title: Game of Thrones Season 5 Episode 9 Recap: Dragon Dance
description: Season 5, Episode 9, The Dance of Dragons

title: Testing the Mettle of a Team, and Its Star: Alex Morgan
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba  For a woman who has not played a competitive soccer game in about two months, Alex Morgan has managed to remain a brilliant ray of sunshine on the eve of the Womens World Cup. So what if a bone bruise in her left knee has sidelined her since early April, leaving the United States womens team without its best goal scorer ahead of a tournament it is desperate to win.

title: Why Did That Horrible Thing Happen on Game of Thrones?
description: This post includes spoilers for Sundays episode of Game of Thrones.

title: Cleveland, City of Champions (at Least in Indoor Soccer of the 90s)
description: Like anyone else around Cleveland, George Hoffman has gotten used to all the chatter about the citys sports championship drought, about the fact that no major local team has won a trophy since 1964, about how LeBron James and the Cavaliers this month could end 51 years of fan suffering.

title: Popular Demand
description: An early version of Lycos trumpeted itself as Your Personal Internet Guide. It offered email and links to topics. Go Get It! exhorted the search command button. Indeed we have.

title: David Wildsteins Statement
description: David Wildsteins statement, in a civil case separate from the federal prosecution in the bridge case, offers the first insider confirmation of a long-rumored tale of New Jersey political corruption.

title: Veep Recap: This Mouse Will Roar
description: Season 4, Episode 9: Testimony

title: Outsiders Art Is Saluted at Columbia, Then Lost Anew
description: He was an outsider who flitted at the fringes of one of the countrys most elite universities, a Brooklyn-bred, Bronx-dwelling candy peddler who charmed and enthralled generations of Columbia University students with the greeting: Hey boys, I got paintings here! Or, I got those Hoishey bars.

title: The 50th M.L.B. Draft Unfolds With a Surprise Factor
description: Unlike the made-for-television drafts in the N.B.A. and the N.F.L., there is still some mystery that surrounds Major League Baseballs draft despite this being the 50th anniversary of the event. So when Rob Manfred, M.L.B.s commissioner, walks to the dais Monday night to announce who the Arizona Diamondbacks have taken with the No. 1 pick, the selection will be a surprise to nearly everyone other than Manfred, the team and the player selected.

title: Questions Begin at Third Draft Slot as Top Prospects Perform at Combine
description: BUFFALO  They were pushed, prodded, measured, weighed and otherwise subjected to a kind of scrutiny familiar to anyone who has inspected produce before buying.

title: Sunday at the Womens World Cup
description: SUNDAYS RESULTS

title: Tony Award Winners
description: Musical: Fun Home

title: As if Karlie Kloss Could Be Any More Likable
description: In this new series for T, notables from the worlds of fashion, art, design and entertainment illustrate their responses to a brief questionnaire, revealing their favorite things, darkest secrets  and how they see themselves and the world around them.

title: The Many Pals of Peaches
description: For more than two decades, the performance artist and musician Merrill Nisker, better known as Peaches, has sought to upend gender norms, smash stereotypes and tackle taboos. In her new book, What Else Is in the Teaches of Peaches ($28, Akashic), the Berlin-based, Canada-born provocateur has teamed up with her longtime tour photographer Holger Talinski to look back at a brazen career that has captured the attention of outsider artists and massive pop stars alike, ranging from Michael Stipe to PJ Harvey to Iggy Pop. Holger shows the exhaustion, the work, the relaxation, the elation, the parties, the quiet moments and the family visits, writes Peaches in the foreword. It is amazing for me to look back at these photos and understand how much I have packed into these years.

title: The Misery and Magic of Childhood
description: For Ts ongoing series, the artist Janaina Tschpe finds expression for Stephen Burts reflection on the wonderful, terrible weirdness of being a kid.

title: Behind Scott Walker, a Longstanding Conservative Alliance Against Unions
description: MADISON, Wis.  Less than a week after he was elected governor of Wisconsin in 2010, Scott Walker went to Milwaukee at the invitation of his political patron, Michael W. Grebe.

title: Global Diabetes Rates Are Rising as Obesity Spreads
description: WASHINGTON  The global diabetes rate has risen by nearly half over the past two decades, according to a new study, as obesity and the health problems it spawns have taken hold across the developing world.

title: Going to the Ends of the Earth to Get the Most Out of Music
description: In the music industrys hunt for royalties, no digital nook or cranny is too small to scour for income  even for the biggest hits.

title: Word of the Day | rendezvous
description: rendezvous  \rn-di-v, -da-\  noun and verb

title: Tony Awards: Fun Home Wins Best Musical and Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time Best Play
description: Fun Home, a poignant and raw exploration of family, memory, sexuality and suicide, on Sunday completed a long journey from the margins to the mainstream as it won the Tony Award for best new musical.

title: Critics Notebook: The Tonys Show Celebrates the Stage Without Any Real Theater
description: In a season when Broadway drew bigger audiences and more dollars than ever, the Tony Awards broadcast on CBS on Sunday night resembled many an expensive musical: a big, bland, well-tooled entertainment machine. No one said or did anything excessively moving or embarrassing, if you dont count the person who picked the lavender shorts suit Alan Cumming wore in the shows opening. Pity the people who have to find moments suitable for YouTube clips on Monday morning.

title: N.B.A. Finals: Matthew Dellavedova Shines in Cavaliers Taut Win
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  For better or worse, Matthew Dellavedova has a knack for making himself the story.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 12:10 P.M. (HBO2) THOUGHT CRIMES: THE CASE OF THE CANNIBAL COP (2015) This documentary, directed by Erin Lee Carr, follows Gilberto Valle, left, the New York City cannibal cop who was convicted of conspiring to kidnap, torture, kill and eat women. The film questions whether someone can be found guilty of what Mr. Valles lawyer called thought prosecution, that is, thoughts without actions. The film, though, is no knee-jerk defense of Mr. Valles right to talk about trussing up women like livestock and making centerpieces out of their heads, Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times. Ms. Carr (whose father was David Carr, the media columnist for The New York Times, who died in February) sprinkles the film with excerpts from Mr. Valles chats, which are appalling even if they are merely fantasies. She also gives voice to all sides in the debate over the implications of the case, not just the free-speech one.

title: Liam Cunningham on Sundays Sad Game of Thrones Moment
description: Davos Seaworth feels your pain.
