description: NEW YORK

title: Profit as an Incentive for Israeli-Palestinian Peace
description: JERUSALEM  Supporters of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict generally start with a moral argument: Both peoples deserve the rights of self-determination and sovereignty; one should not rule over the other. Lately, President Obama and liberal American Jewish leaders also frame their case in security terms, saying Israel cannot survive as a Jewish democracy without ending its occupation of Palestinian territories.

title: Tough-Talking El Bronco Wins Mexican Governors Race
description: MEXICO CITY  A cussing rancher known as El Bronco, who made the first serious run for governor as an independent candidate in Mexico, trounced his competition in midterm elections, according to preliminary official results on Monday, in a race closely watched as a sign of voter frustration with entrenched, established parties often seen as ineffectual and corrupt.

title: Magnum Chooses the Decisive, and Transforming, Photo
description: Why do photographers get attached to a particular image from their archives? Is it the image itself or the moment leading up to it? Was it the effort to obtain it? Did the photo capture a historic moment or a turning point in the photographers life? Or was it simply about discovering new gear?

title: Magnum Chooses the Decisive, and Transforming, Photo

Did the photo capture a historic moment or a turning point in the photographers life? Or was it simply about discovering new gear?

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Fighting the Derp
description: When it comes to economics  and other subjects, but Ill focus on what I know best  we live in an age of derp and cheap cynicism. And there are powerful forces behind both tendencies. But those forces can be fought, and the place to start fighting is within yourself.

title: The Thrill of Political Hating
description: THE 2016 presidential race is already upon us. Do you find that prospect exciting or exhausting? If you chose the latter, Im willing to wager its in part because of the destructive rhetoric that threatens to accompany the election. At least half of American adults felt that the last presidential campaign was too negative.

title: Sneaky Ways to Raise Drug Profits
description: Two devious tactics by manufacturers of brand-name drugs to delay competition from cheaper generic drugs were appropriately slapped down recently by federal and state officials. That should help consumers, insurers and anyone else who foots the bill for prescription medicines. Generic copies, which can enter the market when patents on a brand-name drug expire, typically cost much less than branded versions and are just as safe and effective.

title: Disability Payments to Veterans
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Dads Are Doing Best of All
description: One of the most persistent statistical bludgeons of people who want to blame black people for any injustice or inequity they encounter is this: According to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (C.D.C.), in 2013 in nearly 72 percent of births to non-Hispanic black women, the mothers were unmarried.

title: G.O.P. Assault on Environmental Laws
description: President Obama has announced or will soon propose important protections for clean water, clean air, threatened species and threatened landscapes. Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, and other Republicans in Congress are trying hard not to let that happen  counterattacking with a legislative blitz not seen since Newt Gingrich and his Contract With America Republicans swept into office after the 1994 midterm elections bent on crippling many of the environmental statutes enacted under Presidents Johnson and Nixon. Bill Clinton threatened or used vetoes to block that assault. Mr. Obama should be prepared to do the same.

title: Floridas Foolish Medicaid Lawsuit
description: Floridas governor, Rick Scott, got a well-deserved brushoff from federal health officials in  May after he accused the government of trying to coerce his state into expanding its Medicaid program, even though the Supreme Court has ruled that such expansion is purely voluntary.

title: Test Yourself | A Surprised Lottery Winner
description: Below, several paragraphs from a June 4 article, A $136 Million Powerball Ticket, Stashed in a Staten Island Plumbers Basement.

title: Apollo Global in Talks to Acquire Saint-Gobains Glass-Packaging Unit
description: LONDON  The French conglomerate Saint-Gobain said on Monday that it had begun exclusive talks to sell its glass-packaging unit Verallia to the private equity firm Apollo Global Management for about $3.3 billion.

title: 6 Qs About the News | With Belmont Stakes Win, American Pharoah Takes the Triple Crown
description: In American Pharoah Wins Belmont Stakes and Triple Crown, Joe Drape writes about Saturdays history-making race.

title: Evangelicals Open Door to Debate on Gay Rights
description: LA MIRADA, Calif.  As a young, gay Christian activist, Matthew Vines considered it a victory just to get into a room at a conservative Christian university here with four influential evangelicals who disagreed with him over what the Bible says about homosexuality.

title: Untested Developer Picked Wrong Time, Wrong Place and Wrong Neighbors
description: Standing beside one of the two waterfalls he had built into his duplex condominium on West 15th Street in Manhattan, Colin Rath smiled. The waterfalls feed a narrow koi pond that runs the length of the living room and was scooped out in the shape of a scale replica of the Yangtze River in China.

title: Carl Heasties Campaign Spending Blurs Line Between Political and Personal
description: On the eve of the 39th birthday of Carl E. Heastie, then a little-known assemblyman from the Bronx, his campaign paid a $270 tab for food at Happy Valley, a Manhattan nightclub that did not sell food but was popular for its throbbing dance floor and caged go-go dancers in 2006.

title: Seeking More Bookings, Airlines Limit Sites That Show Their Fares
description: When Josh Marion had to book a last-minute business trip to New York, he knew the plane ticket wouldnt be cheap.

title: What Are Your Thoughts on Repaying Student Loans?
description: New York Times readers recently shared what they wish they had known about student loans before taking on debt to pay for their college education. While none said they felt college was a mistake, many painted a troubling picture of clueless teenagers, frazzled parents and college administrators who may not always take students by the shoulders and question their debt levels.

title: Kurds Celebrate Election Success
description: There was celebration in the streets of Turkey over gains by the Peoples Democratic Party, which aligned with liberals and secular Turks opposed to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

title: Recovery of Bodies Brings Confirmed Toll in Yangtze Sinking to 434
description: HONG KONG  The confirmed death toll from the capsizing last week of a Yangtze River cruise ship rose to 434 on Monday morning as crews recovered more bodies, according to Chinas state-run news agency, Xinhua.

title: In Performance: Ruthie Ann Miles of The King and I
description: This weeks video features a song from Ruthie Ann Miles, who won the Tony Award on Sunday for best featured actress in a musical for her role as Lady Thiang in Lincoln Center Theaters revival of The King and I. Here she sings the ballad Something Wonderful with Ted Sperling, the shows music director, on piano. The King and I, which won the Tony for best musical revival, is at Lincoln Centers Vivian Beaumont Theater.

title: The Sunken Cathedral, by Kate Walbert
description: Kate Walberts new novel, her fourth, begins and ends amid high winds and storm surge, a lethal deluge that the books characters  post-9/11, post-Sandy New Yorkers  endure with nervous resignation. Walbert is in her element. Shes an anatomist of disaster, or, more precisely, of its psychic toll, of the myriad subtle ways calamities  natural, man-made, self-inflicted  reverberate through lives and across generations. Her style is understated, elegiac, her perspective oblique. In her books, war and social crisis typically lurk just off the page; what shes after is quieter, more elusive stuff: the collateral damage of haunted minds and thwarted ambition. Her characters, you might say, are afflicted by history.

title: The Architects Apprentice, by Elif Shafak
description: If you happen to be born in an Indian village in the 16th century and end up on a ship sailing for the court of the Ottoman ruler Suleiman the Magnificent accompanied by a pet albino elephant named Chota, you had better be quick  on your feet and in your mind.

title: The Meursault Investigation, by Kamel Daoud
description: When I was 15, a shy and bookish sophomore at a high school in Morocco, my French class was assigned Albert Camuss The Stranger. I remember being intrigued by the fact that the story was set in neighboring Algeria. I remember the novels indelible first line: Mother died today. I remember what an odd hero Meursault seemed to me, unabashed and remorseless, a man who shows no emotion at his mothers funeral. And I still remember how distressing it was to come upon the crucial scene in which Meursault, walking on a beach under the midday sun, shoots a nameless Arab. Our class discussed Meursault, his mother, his fight with the priest, existentialism and the absurd. All the while, I had to quiet the voice inside me that kept asking, But what about the Arab?

title: Fears, Not Facts, Support G.M.O.-Free Food
description: Despite myriad assurances from scientists that foods containing genetically modified ingredients are safe to eat, consumers are likely to see more and more products labeled G.M.O.-free in the not-too-distant future. As happened with the explosion of gluten-free products, food companies are quick to cash in on what they believe consumers want regardless of whether it is scientifically justified.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: The Circle That Gives Fruit Flies Direction
description: When researchers found a group of brain cells in the fruit fly that function like a compass, they were very satisfied. They had found what they were looking for.

title: Ask Well: Catching Disease From a Toilet Seat
description: Question:

title: Justice Department Takes Down Barriers in Retirement Homes
description: When the dispute started four years ago, residents and their children figured it would be easily resolved.

title: New York Today: Dusting Off a Forgotten Gem
description: Good morning on this mottled Monday.

title: Attack on Nurse Stirs Discussion of a Medical Strike in China
description: The reports in Chinese news outlets on Monday about an attack on a nurse in a hospital in the southwestern city of Kunming were brief and virtually identical, suggesting they were coordinated by the authorities  often a sign of a politically delicate issue. They described how on Sunday, around 12:30 p.m., a man stabbed the nurse at the First Affiliated Hospital of Kunming Medical University, seriously wounding her.

title: I Saw a Turtle, My Father Saw Food
description: The turtles didnt stay on the beach that year. Maybe it had something to do with the stadium lights that lit up the nearby golf course so military officers could swing their clubs through the night. Or the big white domes that protected satellite dishes but looked like Epcot moons. Wed lived on MacDill Air Force Base near Tampa for a year, not far from the beach. Id already seen two turtles whod wandered from the surf  one in a sand trap and one by the side of the road. Then on one September day, I arrived home from school, and the loggerhead was there on the sidewalk leading to our mobile home, baking in the Florida sun.

title: NBC Announces 12-Year Deal to Televise the British Open
description: Nearly two years ago, the NBC Sports Group was stung when it lost the rights to televise the United States Open to Fox.

title: Show Us Your Dad Bod
description: Much has been made of a college students essay on the Dad Bod  the not so perfect male physique that women often find attractive. Clemson University student Mackenzie Pearson first wrote about the dad bod on the college website the Odyssey.

title: Today in Politics: Trips Abroad Pull Focus to Foreign Policy
description: Good Monday morning from Washington. The Republican candidates have a busy week lined up, and the Iowa caucuses have added some technology to their traditions. But the week begins with President Obama in Europe, a Bush heading there and the politics of foreign affairs taking a step into the spotlight.

title: The Search for the Best Estimate of the Transgender Population
description: The recent debate over public restroom access for transgender people has prompted some questions on just how big an issue this is  how many people are affected by such rules? The size of the transgender population is tricky to estimate, for reasons we discussed almost a year ago, in the article below:

title: Syngenta Rejects Second Takeover Approach From Monsanto
description: LONDON  The agricultural and chemical giant Syngenta said on Monday that it had rejected a second takeover approach from Monsanto, its American rival.

title: Morning Agenda: Shake-Up at Deutsche Bank
description: SHAKE-UP AT DEUTSCHE BANK | Now that Deutsche Banks co-chief executives, Anshu Jain and Jrgen Fitschen, have resigned, the company is likely to re-examine its status as the last European bank left standing on Wall Street,  Jack Ewing writes in DealBook. Mr. Jain, 52, will resign at the end of the month after three years as co-chief executive and will be replaced by John Cryan, 54, a former high-ranking executive of the Swiss bank UBS. Jrgen Fitschen, 66, the other co-chief executive, will remain another year but will leave before his contract would have run out in 2017.

title: ScienceTake | A Compass in a Flys Brain
description: In a very small region of a fruit flys very small brain, a circle of neurons helps the fly know where it is pointed.

title: Torture and Other Rights Abuses Are Widespread in Eritrea, U.N. Panel Says
description: GENEVA  President Isaias Afwerki of Eritrea has imposed a reign of fear through systematic and extreme abuses of the population that may amount to crimes against humanity, a panel of United Nations investigators said on Monday.

title: Musings on Inequality and Growth
description: Ive been using the case of research on inequality and growth as an example of an issue where liberals need to be careful not to let wishful thinking drive their conclusions; it would fit perfectly with our world view if inequality were not just a bad thing but also bad for the economy, which is a reason to bend over backwards to avoid accepting that conclusion too easily. But what do we really know?

title: Trinidad Discusses Ex-FIFA Leader Warner
description: Trinidad and Tobagos justice minister said on Sunday that there was a presumption of innocence in the case involving the former FIFA vice president Jack Warner, but that it should go to trial.

title: Debating Bible Verses on Homosexuality
description: Two evangelical authors offer conflicting interpretations about the Bibles well-known passages about homosexuality.

title: Mondays Travel News and Tips
description: A VINTAGE TRAIN TRIP, CHICAGO TO DENVER

title: Ai Weiwei Trades Politics for Subtlety in First Solo Exhibition in China
description: Barred since 2011 from traveling outside his home country, the artist Ai Weiwei has become a master of what might be called remote exhibition-making  using 3-D computer models, Skype, and a team of curators and assistants to create large-scale installations around the world from his studio in Beijing. But no virtual simulation was needed for the artists newest exhibition, which opened last weekend at the Galleria Continua and at the Tang Contemporary Art Center in the trendy 798 Art District of Beijing.

title: Families of Drone Strike Victims in Yemen File Suit in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  The families of an anti-Qaeda cleric and a police officer killed in an American drone strike in Yemen filed suit in federal court in Washington on Sunday night, asking the court to declare that the strike was unlawful.

title: How High Can Pakistans Air Force Women Fly?
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Flight Lt. Ayesha Farooq, Pakistans only combat-ready female air force pilot, has become both an international celebrity and a symbol of a new Pakistan, where women are breaking barriers and taking on roles traditionally closed to them. Yet Pakistan is also known as a country where womens place in society yo-yos up and down. For example, in the 1990s it entrusted the leadership of the entire nation to Benazir Bhutto while still resisting girls education and advances in womens rights.

title: Give to Those at the Bottom? Sure, as Long as They Stay There
description: When it comes to reducing inequality, Americans may be open to bolder solutions for reining in those at the top than for ones boosting people at the bottom.

title: I Do Not Think That Derp Means What You Think It Means
description: Continuing on the theme of derp in policy discourse: Vox coincidentally has a post about Hillary Clintons proposal for automatic voter registration noting that signing up less informed voters isnt necessarily a bad thing, because informed voters mainly seem to be informed about the party line. In effect, they know which derp theyre supposed to repeat.

title: Daily Report: All Eyes on Apple
description: Apple is set to kick off its annual conference for software developers on Monday. The company is expected to show new and improved versions of OS X, its Mac operating system, and iOS, the mobile software system powering iPhones and iPads. The company will also introduce a new streaming music service that it developed with Beats Electronics, the company it acquired last year for $3 billion.

title: When Fashion Met the Tonys, Who Won?
description: There were lots of winners at Sunday nights Tony Awards, chief among them The King and I, The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time and Fun Home. But was fashion among them?

title: 1915: Presidents Reply on Lusitania
description: LONDON  Mr. Wilsons new Note to Germany has been approved by the Cabinet and was to have been despatched to Berlin today [June 5]. It is understood that the communication is vigorous in tone and that it denies the allegations contained in Germanys last Note that the Lusitania was armed or carrying explosives. According to the Daily Telegraphs New York correspondent, it is hardly expected that Berlin will answer the new Note until Count Bernstorffs envoy reaches Germany, so there is a prospect of two or three weeks elapsing before a reply is received.

title: N.B.A. Finals: In Overtime, Missed Shots and Foul Calls Were the Key
description: For the first time in N.B.A. finals history, Games 1 and 2 went to overtime. Once again, fans were treated to five tense, vital minutes between two of the best teams in basketball, the Golden State Warriors and the Cleveland Cavaliers.

description: Theres a red lipstick for every occasion.

title: Tony Awards Red Carpet
description: Looks from the award ceremony.

title: Ukraine Crisis and Advance of ISIS Dominate Agenda for Group of 7
description: KRN, Germany  President Obama would have preferred to spend the summit meeting of the leaders of the seven leading industrial nations fully focused on big issues that he hopes will define his legacy, including confronting climate change and expanding global trade.

title: Texas Police on Pool Party Incident
description: Greg Conley, the chief of police in McKinney, Tex., said Sunday that a police officer had been placed on leave after video surfaced showing him pushing a girl during a pool party on Friday.

title: Anshu Jains Painful Lessons for New Deutsche Boss
description: Deutsche Banks new chief executive needs to learn some painful lessons from Anshu Jain.

title: The Story of Alice: Lewis Carroll and the Secret History of Wonderland
description: Lewis Carroll loved puns, like those about the tortoise who taught us, or the lessons that lessen the need for any more of them. He especially loved puns that could be found hiding in one word, like wonderland: a place full of wonders and a place where you wonder what is happening to you. These meanings are not only different, they can be read as opposites, as Robert Douglas-Fairhurst reminds us, quoting a Victorian evocation of a person who, being in a chronic state of wonder, is surprised at nothing. Sentimental memories of the Alice books often stress the first, dazzled meaning, but a fresh reading of Carroll is likely to leave us much closer to the second, which Douglas-Fairhurst neatly formulates as being puzzled at what we do not know. This is how the flowers talk in Through the Looking-Glass: I wonder how you do it, a rose says to Alice, referring to her odd human ability to move about. Youre always wondering, an irritated tiger-lily says.

title: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
description: The European leagues are done but the soccer never stops. The soccer editor Andrew Das tells you what to watch.

title: Supreme Court Backs White House on Jerusalem Passport Dispute
description: WASHINGTON  In an important separation-of-powers case, the Supreme Court on Monday struck down a law that would have allowed American parents of children born in Jerusalem to obtain passports saying the children were born in Israel. The president, rather than Congress, must determine national policy on the status of Jerusalem, the majority said.

title: Berlin, Leery of One Bush, Prepares to Meet Jeb
description: BERLIN  They marvel at the enduring influence of a single family in American politics. They recall the painful blunders of his brother. And they confess that the last name  Bush  summons instant unease.

title: Fracking Associated With Smaller Babies
description: A new study has found an association between hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, and smaller babies.

title: With Move Across London, U.S. Embassy Cant Please Everyone
description: LONDON  One neighbor, a countess named Anca Vidaeff, staged a hunger strike to protest it. Another neighbor, the chairwoman of a local residents group, said it made people very, very nervous about bomb threats and suggested it find a new home.

title: Iceland to Lift Capital Controls Imposed After Financial Crisis
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  After Iceland imposed capital controls during the global financial crisis, the move helped stabilize the countrys banking system, putting the economy on a path to recovery.

title: A Rappers Ode to Uber, Chengdu Gangster Style
description: For Western technology companies in China, popularity can be a dangerous thing.

title: Uber Spends Heavily to Establish Itself in China
description: HONG KONG  Uber is spending money at a breakneck rate to crack the China market  even paying its drivers more than the fares they collect.

title: Digital Vintage
description: Ever wonder what the iPhones grandparents looked like? Chances are Lonnie Mimms has one in the massive collection of vintage computers he keeps outside of Atlanta.

title: Walkabout: OHare Delays; Disney at the Airport
description: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.

title: Ex-South Carolina Officer Is Indicted in Shooting Death of Black Man
description: A former police officer in North Charleston, S.C., was indicted Monday by a grand jury on a murder charge in connection with the April shooting death of Walter L. Scott, which was recorded by a passer-by and became a resonating symbol in the national debate about police behavior.

title: North American Butterflies
description: From a series for T in which the artist Leanne Shapton makes new artworks from pictures in old books.

title: A Raid on ISIS Yields a Trove of Intelligence
description: WASHINGTON  American intelligence agencies have extracted valuable information about the Islamic States leadership structure, financial operations and security measures by analyzing materials seized during a Delta Force commando raid last month that killed a leader of the terrorist group in eastern Syria, according to United States officials.

title: A Climate Campaigner (Bill McKibben) and Climate Change Critic (Anthony Watts) Meet in a Bar.
description: Having been on the run overseas since the weekend, Im only now catching up with Anthony Wattss attack on Tom Peterson, one of the authors of  a recent National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration climate paper. The exchange, in which Watts accuses Peterson of prostituting himself and hints at fraud, occurred just before* hed posted on his friendly meeting with climate campaigner Bill McKibben, described below.

title: Video Captures Texas Pool Party Incident
description: From 2015: A video shows a police officer detaining a girl on Friday and pulling a gun on other teenagers after a disturbance at a neighborhood pool party in McKinney, Tex.

title: Prospect of Instability Looms as Turkish Voters Deny Erdogan a Majority
description: ISTANBUL  In choosing a Parliament without a majority party, Turkish voters have curtailed the ambitions of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan to claim new powers in an election hailed as a triumph of Turkish democracy.

title: At Least Four Men Killed at Sea
description: Despite dozens of witnesses, the murders went unreported and remain a mystery.

description: This post contains spoilers for Sundays episode of Game of Thrones.

title: Fette Saus Joe Carroll Writes Feeding the Fire, a Worthy Barbecue Primer
description: Summer arrives and with it the usual glut of cookbooks about grilling and barbecue: largely culinary lesson plans written for dudes in shorts, the dad-bod set, those interested in the intersection of smoke and deliciousness.

title: Col. George Sichermans Calendar Reform Problem
description: This weeks puzzle was suggested by Col. George Sicherman, a well-known recreational mathematician weve had by before (check out Dice and Pool). Today we present another one of the Colonels original creations: a mystifying election day challenge. Lets try our hand at

title: Judd Apatow: By the Book
description: The screenwriter, director and author of Sick in the Head: Conversations About Life and Comedy, owns a lot of books. I have actually convinced myself that buying books is the same as reading.

description: See images and maps of the N.Y. prison escape.

title: The Wrong Place and Time to Have a Money Conversation
description: A few weeks ago, I got home late after a long trip. Id been traveling a lot recently and didnt sleep well that night. The next morning, I woke up and felt like Id been hit by a truck.

description: KRN, Germany  It is a tale of beer summitry gone awry.

title: Volcker Sees Hidden Peril in State Budgets
description: Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman widely credited with taming inflation in the 1980s, has found what he considers a new economic scourge to battle: shoddy state budgets that he contends push costs into the future for other generations of taxpayers to pay.

title: 1965: GIs Will Fight in Ground War
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department disclosed today [June 8] that U.S. forces in Vietnam have been authorized to fight alongside South Vietnamese troops  a move expected to produce full-scale battle between Americans and the Communist guerrillas. The departments press officer, Robert J. McCloskey, emphasized that U.S. combat assistance was conditional on a request from the South Vietnamese government. But it seemed certain to most observers that U.S. troops were being fully committed to a direct ground war campaign against the Viet Cong.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 9, 1965

title: When Pain Persists After Breast Cancer Surgery
description: I could hear the anxiety in my sisters voice. A week after her double mastectomy and breast reconstruction for breast cancer, she had developed a burning sensation under her right arm where her surgeon had removed several dozen lymph nodes for a postoperative biopsy. The throbbing and itching were so intense it felt like poison ivy lit by a blowtorch.

title: Is Overcrowding a Legitimate Threat?
South Korea MERS Cases Rise as Hong Kong Increases Alert Level
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The number of South Koreans infected with Middle East respiratory syndrome increased to 87 on Monday after the government identified additional cases. It also said that an 80-year-old man had died, bringing the number of deaths linked to the virus in South Korea to six.

description: President Obama said that the group remains strongly united in its support for Ukraine, and will maintain sanctions on Russia in hopes of halting that countrys aggressions.

title: First Draft Focus: Bush Family Reunion in Maine

description: The Stifel Financial Corporation on Monday embarked on yet another acquisition in a yearslong buying spree, this time seeking to purchase Barclays American wealth management business.

title: Melissa McCarthy and Summer Heroines Have Shattered a Glass Ceiling
description: Ross Douthat: Frank, its a pleasure to be back with you again for our first full summer movie season together. And happily, the season of blockbusters is giving us something to talk about besides superhero and disaster flicks: So far, its been dominated by  women. And I dont mean women in a Megan Fox-in-Transformers or Liv Tyler-in-Armageddon sort of way; I mean women as the prime movers of their movies, the reason to show up and watch.

title: A Senate Lunch Tradition Draws on the Flavors of Home
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Dan Coats, Republican of Indiana, falls several grins short of a giddy man. He lopes through the halls of the Capitol as if he has just emerged from a weighty briefing at the Select Committee on Intelligence.

description: War Machine, a satirical comedy starring Brad Pitt, will make its global debut on Netflix and in select theaters next year, the streaming service announced Monday.

title: 1915: Secretary of State Resigns
description: NEW YORK  Mr. William Jennings Bryan has resigned as Secretary of State. While no reason is given in Washington for the sensational move by Mr. Bryan, it is generally believed that the resignation is due to his opposition to the firm character of President Wilsons Note to Germany, which he, as a leader of the peace at any price element in the Democratic party, would not indorse. Friends asserted that the statesman from Nebraska felt that he, because of his influence in obtaining the Presidential nomination for Mr. Wilson, should have the leading voice in the Cabinet.

title: Obama Is Optimistic Justices Will Let Health Care Law Stand
description: WASHINGTON  A decision by the Supreme Court to strike down health care subsidies in federally run marketplaces would be a contorted reading of the Affordable Care Act that would disrupt coverage for millions of people, President Obama said on Monday.

description: Q. If you can put your hands in the water while washing dishes, is it really hot enough to kill germs? And if not, whats the point of using all that energy?

description: The Supreme Court ruled against three death row inmates who had sought to bar the use of an execution drug they said risked causing excruciating pain.

So Germany Coach Silvia Neid admits freely that she was in the dark when they were put in her first-round group for the Womens World Cup.

description: Apple announced a new streaming service, a news-reader app, and improvements to Siri, Apple Pay and its operating systems.

I have cared for Kevin in both senses of the word for years now, but he still has his previous providers fingerprints all over him: he takes medications I never use and has health-maintainance routines I find somewhat perplexing.

description: The Supreme Court is getting closer to making is long-awaited ruling on same-sex marriage and, whatever the outcome, the political response is expected to be vocal along party lines.

description: Sharpen your Valyrian steel  pencils.

description: The L.A. neighborhood has more than a dozen trendy new restaurants and boutiques selling home goods and fashions from up-and-coming designers.

description: Hollywood royalty and fashion-world darlings flew in to Italy to commemorate the propertys birthday.

description: EDINBURGH  Nicola Sturgeon, Scotlands feminist first minister, was inspired to run for office by Margaret Thatcher  not because Mrs. Thatcher was Britains first female prime minister, but because Ms. Sturgeon hated her politics and the unemployment her policies brought to Scotland.

title: Arrests and Riot Gear After Scuffles at Summer Jam
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A total of 61 people were arrested on Sunday night at MetLife Stadium during Hot 97s Summer Jam, the annual hip-hop concert presented by WQHT-FM, the New Jersey State Police said on Monday. Ten officers sustained minor injuries during scuffles at an entrance gate as some attendees tried to force their way inside by climbing fences or pushing past security, the police said.

title: Most Parents Got Top Choices for Pre-K, Mayor de Blasio Says
description: In a hopeful sign for the second year of his prekindergarten push, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Monday that parents of about 57,000 children in New York City were offered seats in one of their top three choices for programs in the fall.

title: The Institute of Culinary Education Gets a New, Bigger Home
description: To Study: Culinary School Moves To Battery Park City

title: Activists for Change: Six Short Films and Teaching Resources on Womens Roles in the Arab Spring
description: When students see news about war and unrest in the Middle East and North Africa, they typically see images of men. But when the Arab Spring revolutions began to sweep across the region in 2011, women were very much on the front lines  protesting, leading and even dying. What are their stories?

title: The Grocery to Serve Its Final Meal
description: Sharon Pachter and Charles Kiely, the owners of the Grocery in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, have announced that they will close the restaurant once the tables are cleared on June 27.

title: Dov Charney and American Apparel Tussle Over Lawyers Fees
description: The nasty fight between Dov Charney and the company he founded, American Apparel, over his firing in 2014 has been an endless source of fascination for many months.

title: Families of Nepalese Killed in Marine Helicopter Crash Ask for Compensation
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  Relatives of some of the five Nepalese civilians killed in a Marine helicopter crash expressed anger Sunday at what they said was the slow pace of the investigation into the deaths, and demanded compensation from the governments of Nepal and the United States.

title: Surveillance Video of Boston Shooting
description: Close-circuit video of last weeks fatal shooting of a terror suspect, Usaamah Rahim, by a Boston police officer and an F.B.I. agent was released during a press conference today.

title: Review: In Muse, the Publisher Jonathan Galassi Writes What He Knows
description: Jonathan Galassis keenly observed debut novel, Muse, is a carefully constructed literary echo chamber, haunted by the ghosts of two classics and peopled with some thinly veiled portraits of well-known publishing figures. As in Philip Roths The Ghost Writer, a young man with literary aspirations  in this case, an editor instead of a writer  finds himself torn between two rival father figures. As in Henry Jamess The Aspern Papers, an editor obsessed with a famous poet goes to Venice in search of some answers about the poet and the poets lover and has a surprising encounter that will affect both his career and his apprehension of himself.

title: Review: Only Suspense at Summer Jam Was Outside the Stadium
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It seems that every year of late, the annual Summer Jam presented by the radio station Hot 97 has to find new purpose. In the 1990s and into the mid-2000s, it was the New York hip-hop concert of record. Now it is a showcase for the genres scattered regional identities and Hot 97s decreasingly steady footing as an arbiter of its future. Summer Jam was once the essential proving ground; now its a hit-or-miss revue.

title: Sonia Rykiel Resort 2016
description: Looks from the collection.

title: With Chairmanship, McCain Seizes Chance to Reshape Pentagon Agenda
description: WASHINGTON  John McCain has had many dreams.

title: Alexander Melamid Begins Artenol, an Art Magazine
description: As the artist-provocateur Alexander Melamid sees it, modern art is deathly ill, but he thinks he has the cure. It is Artenol, his new quarterly magazine, described on its website as a purgative for an ailing art world, a palliative for afflicted aesthetes.

title: Pensions in Greece Feel the Pinch of Debt Negotiations
description: ATHENS  Vasiliki Meliou did not want to retire at 53, but she had little choice, she said, after the state-owned bank she worked for was sold three years ago.

title: Final Salvos Against Polio
description: The documentary Every Last Child begins the way Hill Street Blues used to: A police commander says a few words to his men before they roll out into a hostile city. Their job is to protect polio teams going house to house in neighborhoods where Taliban assassins cruise on motorbikes.

title: Square Unveils Mobile Wallet-Friendly Credit Card Reader
description: It will take years for smartphone-based wallets, like those offered by Apple and Google, to have a chance to truly catch on with mainstream consumers. But with the help of payments processors, mobile wallets may catch on a bit faster.

title: Reaction to Slagers Indictment
description: Prosecutor Scarlett Wilson, Rodney Scott and the Scott familys lawyer spoke after Michael T. Slager, a former police officer in South Carolina, was indicted in the fatal shooting of Walter L. Scott.

title: Chris Christie Tries to Take On Hillary
description: Despite a homey backdrop  front porch, American flag, pots of red geraniums  New Jersey Governor Chris Christie sounded like a street fighter Sunday morning on CBSs Face the Nation. This time the notoriously aggressive governor was taking on every Republicans favorite target  Hillary Clinton. Mrs. Clinton, the Democratic frontrunner in the looming presidential primaries, had the nerve to blast Republicans like Mr. Christie for trying to keep people from voting in this country. As she put it pointedly: What part of democracy are they afraid of? (Note to Clinton camp: Are there bumper stickers yet?)

title: Pictures of the Day: Germany and Elsewhere
description: Germany and More  Pictures of the Day

title: June 8, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Germany, Ukraine, Turkey and New York.

title: With Backpacks and Exposed Skin, European Officials Roil Iranians
description: TEHRAN  The woman wore form-fitting clothes and a scarf wrapped around her head that revealed a few of her blond tresses. The men carried backpacks to official meetings. Nothing all that unusual in most places, but enough to touch off a firestorm of criticism this weekend from Iranian lawmakers, who accused their visitors of flouting Islamic law by, as one put it, wearing extremely weird clothing.

title: Former Soccer Player Sues Illinois, Saying Concussion Was Mishandled
description: A former womens soccer player at Illinois has filed a lawsuit against the university, alleging that her concussion was mishandled and her career ruined after the team ignored protocol. The suit, filed Monday afternoon in Champaign County Circuit Court, seeks damages of at least $50,000, though the amount could be far greater.

title: Six Elderly New Yorkers Provide Lessons on Aging: What One Reporter Learned
description: Since the start of the year, Ive been reporting on six New Yorkers over the age of 85, but the guiding voice in my head has often been that of a much younger man, Karl Pillemer, one of several gerontologists I interviewed at the start of the project. When Dr. Pillemer started in the field, he viewed old age the way many of us do, as a problem to be solved. Peoples bodies broke down, their minds lost function, they drained billions out of the health care system. I was busy rewriting the Book of Job, he said. It made for grim work.

title: N.Y. Police on Manhunt for Convicts
description: Maj. Charles Guess of the New York State Police said the hunt has intensified for two convicted murderers who escaped from a maximum security prison over the weekend.

title: Turkey's Hung Parliament at a Glance
description: Voters denied an outright majority to the ruling party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. A multiparty coalition will need at least 276 votes in the 550-seat Parliament. Here are the four parties in contention.

title: Video Feature: The Apple Collector
description: Lonnie Mimms has been a collector all his life. Even now, Mr. Mimms, 52, has a selection of hippopotamus figures displayed under track lighting in his bedroom. But vintage computers are his real obsession, namely ones made by Apple.

description: ANTONIO SNCHEZ

title: Review: In Love Life, Tamia Enacts Seduction and Conservatism
description: TAMIA

title: Review: Predatory Headlights, a Bright Double Album From Tenement
description: TENEMENT

title: In Performance | Ruthie Ann Miles
description: Ms. Miles, who won a Tony Award for her performance in the revival of The King and I, sings Something Wonderful, a ballad from the musical. The show is on Broadway at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

title: Review: City Ballet Debuts in Season Finale
description: Debuts occur all the time at New York City Ballet, where dancers, no matter their rank, get chances to shine in parts of all sizes. And then along came Miriam Miller.

title: Kalief Browder, Held at Rikers Island for 3 Years Without Trial, Commits Suicide
description: Kalief Browder was sent to Rikers Island when he was 16 years old, accused of stealing a backpack. Though he never stood trial or was found guilty of any crime, he spent three years at the New York City jail complex, nearly two of them in solitary confinement.

title: Maiyet Resort 2016
description: Looks from the collection.

title: Home and Work: Tony Oursler
description: A look at where the pioneering video artist lives and creates.

title: Lanvin Resort 2016
description: Looks from the collection.

title: Modi Under Fire for Calling Bangladeshs Leader Tough, Despite Being a Woman
description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India was ridiculed Monday on social networks for comments he made over the weekend during a state visit to Bangladesh, where he praised its prime minister for fighting terrorism despite being a woman.

title: Street Style at the Governors Ball
description: Summer festival style on display Randalls Island at the Governors Ball.

title: The Evidence Points to a Better Way to Fight Insomnia
description: One weekend afternoon a couple of years ago, while turning a page of the book I was reading to my daughters, I fell asleep. Thats when I knew it was time to do something about my insomnia.

title: Fifty Years of Chic at Hotel Il Pellicano
description: Hotel Il Pellicano has a 50-year history of attracting a certain jet set  Hollywood royalty, fashion-world darlings, very beautiful and important humans  to its cliffside pool on the Tuscan coastline. And its impossibly chic creative director Marie-Louise Sci, whose father, Roberto, bought the hotel in 1979, summoned regulars like the actor Josh Hartnett and his girlfriend, Tamsin Egerton, to celebrate the propertys birthday over the weekend. All gleefully flew in, heeding the suggested dress code: Missoni meets Slim Aarons (who photographed Il Pellicanos socialite scene for more than 25 years). The crowd, co-hosted by Ts editor in chief Deborah Needleman, was as festive as the grounds, dressed up with colorful prints, strung with twinkling lights and toasted with fireworks after a fiery sun set below the perimeters cypress trees.

title: With New Study, New Mothers Seeking IUDs Are No Longer Urged to Wait
description: After childbirth, some new mothers wishing to avoid another pregnancy ask their doctors to provide reversible contraception, like an intrauterine device. But normally, new mothers are told to return for contraception six weeks after giving birth  after fully half of them have already resumed sexual relations.

title: Review: Smile at Us, Oh Lord Depicts a Jewish Odyssey
description: Buried deep in the show, the old joke got a warm, rolling laugh on Friday night from the crowd at City Center.

title: Street Style at the Governors Ball
description: The Governors Ball music festival, one of the biggest outdoor pop music events in New York City, drew more than 60 performers to its four stages this year. Over the course of three days, music lovers flocked to Randalls Island to hear Drake, Florence and the Machine, the Black Keys and many more. Many attendees donned their coolest outfits for the shows.

title: U.N. General Assembly Report on Children and Armed Conflict
description: A report on the impact of armed conflict on children and violations against children in conflict zones in 2014.

title: First Draft Focus: Obamas Trip to Germany
description: President Obama attended the summit meeting of the Group of 7 in the Bavarian Alps.

title: Jeb Bush Shakes Up Campaign Staff, Week Before Campaign Becomes Official
description: Jeb Bush shuffled his political team on Monday, moving to address persistent questions surrounding his presidential candidacy a week before he plans to announce his formal entry into the race.

title: Longtime Assistants Relish Ride With American Pharoah
description: The assistant trainer Jimmy Barnes watched the race that changed everything from behind the winners circle. He was calm and introspective, thinking about his father, Laverne, who had died 15 years earlier, almost to the day. He watched his family, including his wife, Dana, who works alongside him in Bob Bafferts barn, cheer and cry and cheer some more.

title: Fun Home Finds That Winning a Tony Is the Best Way to Market a Musical
description: The Tony Award for best new musical is always a boon for the winning show. But for Fun Home, which claimed this years prize on Sunday night, the award is likely to be a major turning point, allowing the production to reach new markets, and new audiences, that might have been initially put off by its searing exploration of sexuality and suicide.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Municipal Art Society President to Step Down for New Lincoln Center Role
description: In the wake of David Geffens $100 million gift toward the $500 million transformation of Avery Fisher Hall, many have wondered how Lincoln Center and the New York Philharmonic would go about trying to raise the rest of such a daunting budget.

title: I.O.C. Adds Four Events to Roster of 2018 Winter Games
description: You can never have enough curling. That was one of the messages from the International Olympic Committee on Monday when it approved the addition of several events for the 2018 Winter Games in Pyeongchang, South Korea.

title: The Supreme Courts Jerusalem Passport Case
description: To whom does Jerusalem belong?

title: Looking for Robots That Will Cooperate, Not Terminate
description: POMONA, Calif.  A robot that evoked a human form paused in front of a door leading to a simulated nuclear power plant accident and inexplicably stood motionless. Suddenly, from the grandstands overlooking the scene, a group of schoolchildren began to chant: Go Robot! Go Robot! Go Robot!

title: Smithsonian Displays Ancient Artwork From City Threatened by ISIS
description: To highlight the cultural destruction threatening the ancient crossroads city of Palmyra, in the Syria desert, the Smithsonian Institution is putting an intricately carved funerary bust acquired in 1908 on long-term display, officials said on Monday.

title: Calpers to Cut Ties With Many Fund Managers to Save on Fees
description: For years, the California Public Employees Retirement System, the countrys biggest state pension fund, paid Wall Street billions of dollars to help finance the retirement plans of teachers, firefighters, police and other state employees.

title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Our nightly rundown will catch you up quickly on the days top stories.

title: Vince Musi at Look3
description: When the National Geographic photographer Vince Musi learned not to say no to assignments, he redefined his approach  and relationship  to photography.

title: A Wide Musical Lineup at Governors Ball, With Women Leading the Way
description: The fifth annual Governors Ball festival, on Randalls Island, featured strong and strange music by women, who were outnumbered by men.

title: Review: Governors Ball Is Ruled by Women
description: Women brought the strongest and strangest music to the fifth annual Governors Ball festival, held Friday through Sunday on Randalls Island. They were worldly and otherworldly, heroic and vulnerable, proudly pop-savvy or defining their own kinds of fringe. Of course, they were outnumbered by men, who held most of the headlining slots.

title: Atlantic Broadband Deal Shows Small Operators Seek Growth, Too
description: As the big get bigger in the cable business, the small are trying to get a little bit bigger, too.

title: Government to Forgive Student Loans at Corinthian Colleges
description: In a move against what he called the ethics of payday lending in higher education, Secretary of Education Arne Duncan announced Monday that the Education Department would forgive the federal loans of tens of thousands of students who attended Corinthian Colleges, a for-profit college company that closed andfiled for bankruptcylast month,amid widespread charges of fraud.

title: Cuomo Finds Prison Emergency Is Also an Opportunity
description: Less than 48 hours after a whirlwind visit to the Clinton Correctional Facility, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was ready for a full-fledged media blitz.

title: Review: Locrian Chamber Players at Riverside Church
description: Classical music has too many rules for its own good, but the enterprising Locrian Chamber Players have two laudable ones. No. 1: Program notes are available only on the way out of its performance space, a room in Riverside Churchs tower, which yields views of the Hudson River and Grants Tomb. No. 2: Compositions from the past decade are the only ones on its programs.

title: Review: New Jersey Symphony Orchestra
description: Bergen Performing Arts Center, Englewood, N.J.

title: Review: Lisa Moore at DiMenna Center
description: Carnegie Hall offers free cough drops to the audience. Kettle Corn New Music offers free beer and popcorn. A contemporary-music series now in its third year, Kettle Corn has joined other concert series trying to make performances a less finicky affair. Led by the artistic directors Alex Weiser and Chris Rogerson, it does so much less awkwardly and far more engagingly than most.

title: An Earthlings Guide to Black Holes
description: Welcome to the place of no return  a region in space where the gravitational pull is so strong that not even light can escape it. This is a black hole.

title: Dennis Hastert Hires Thomas C. Green as His Lawyer
description: J. Dennis Hastert is scheduled to be arraigned in federal court in Chicago on Tuesday, and he has hired a powerful and experienced Washington lawyer to represent him.

title: Music and a Melee at Hot 97s Summer Jam
description: The annual hip-hop concert was hampered by a modest lineup onstage and a face-off between the police and would-be concertgoers outside MetLife Stadium.

title: Cleveland Leaders Bypass Prosecutors to Seek Charge in Tamir Rice Case
description: WASHINGTON  Community leaders in Cleveland, distrustful of the criminal justice system, said Monday that they would not wait for prosecutors to decide whether to file charges against the police officers involved in the fatal shooting of 12-year-old Tamir Rice last year. Instead, they will invoke a seldom-used Ohio law and go directly to a judge to request murder charges against the officers.

title: Smells Like Hawaii (and Benzyl Acetate): Revealing the Chemicals in Glades Fragrances
description: SC Johnson, the maker of Glade air fresheners, has decided to tell consumers more about the chemicals they are breathing.

title: American Apparel Avoids Fight Over Board
description: American Apparel said on Monday that it had averted a proxy fight with an ally of its estranged founder and former chief executive, Dov Charney, as the retailer unveiled a turnaround plan meant to get it back on a growth track toward $1 billion in annual sales.

title: The Global Refugee Crisis, Region by Region
description: In the latest crisis, tens of thousands are racing to Hungary before a border fence is finished.

title: Jack Livings Wins PEN Prize for Debut Fiction
description: Jack Livings won the $25,000 PEN/Robert W. Bingham Prize for Debut Fiction on Monday night, for The Dog, a collection of stories set in China, where Mr. Livings lived for a time during the 1990s.

title: Shot Clock Cut for Men in College Basketball
description: In an effort to speed up games, the shot clock in mens college basketball will be reduced to 30 seconds from 35, one of several changes for the coming season that the N.C.A.A. announced Monday on Twitter.

title: Mayor de Blasio Tells New Jersey to Reject Deal With Exxon
description: New Jerseys proposed $225 million pollution settlement with Exxon Mobil Corporation has a prominent and new opponent: the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, which has asked that the deal be rejected, saying it appears wholly inadequate.

title: Tuberculosis Case Prompts Search for Patients Fellow Airline Passengers
description: Health officials are trying to identify people who may have come into contact with a woman who flew from India to Chicago in April and had a type of tuberculosis that is highly resistant to drug treatment.

title: Regulator Said to Have Pressed for Exit of Deutsche Chiefs
description: When the two executives who lead Deutsche Bank, Germanys largest bank, unexpectedly announced their resignations on Sunday, pressure from angry shareholders was widely seen as the chief factor.

title: Critical of FIFA, Publishers Flee
description: Fallout from the FIFA soccer scandal has begun to affect journalism in the Cayman Islands.

title: Earthquake Prods Nepal Parties to Make Constitution Deal
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  After almost a decade of friction over central constitutional issues, Nepals major political parties reached an accord on Monday night, agreeing to a federal model with eight provinces that would allow them to form a government involving all major parties and rebuild the quake-ravaged nation.

title: Kentucky Governor Raises Minimum Wage With Executive Order
description: WASHINGTON  Gov. Steven L. Beshear of Kentucky signed an executive order on Monday raising the hourly minimum wage for certain state employees to $10.10. The change, which angered state Republicans and drew praise from the governors fellow Democrats, affects almost 800 employees, including those making the current hourly minimum of $7.25.

title: Mergers Might Not Signal Optimism
description: A boom in mergers and acquisitions usually signals confidence in the economy, and recent headline-grabbing deals evoke images of chief executives and directors cheering about their business prospects and overall growth.

title: MERS Viruss Path: One Man, Many South Korean Hospitals
description: SEOUL, South Korea  At first, doctors thought the 68-year-old man might have simple pneumonia. He coughed and wheezed his way through four hospitals before officials figured out, nine days later, that he had something far more serious and contagious.

title: At 50, Major League Draft Has Sharpened Its Focus
description: Brendan Rodgers had been to New York once before this month, to play at Citi Field in a summer showcase for top high school players. He has also played at Wrigley Field in Chicago and Petco Park in San Diego.

title: Bronx Man Dies After Police Use Taser Stun Gun on Him
description: A man brandishing a pair of scissors died on Monday after being shocked with a Taser stun gun during an encounter with police officers inside his Bronx apartment, the authorities said.

title: Democracy Wins in Turkey
description: Turkish voters reasserted their commitment to democracy in Sundays parliamentary elections. More than 86 percent of them cast ballots, a level of participation far above the 57 percent turnout posted by Americans in 2012. The Turks made clear they would not allow President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, an increasingly authoritarian leader, to amass even more power, denying him a parliamentary majority while voting in significant numbers for a party representing the Kurdish minority.

title: Israel and Hamas Are Kept Off a Grim List
description: Under unusual pressure from Israel and the United States, the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, opted not to include either Israel or Hamas on a list of armies and guerrilla groups that kill and maim children in conflicts worldwide, despite the recommendations of one of his senior envoys, diplomats say.

title: LeBron James Has Nothing to Prove, but Hes Proving It Anyway
description: CLEVELAND  After the 11 makes and the 24 misses, after the 16 rebounds and the 11 assists and the 39 points, each of them hard won, LeBron James plopped down on a dais at Oracle Arena on Sunday night and reflected on the Cleveland Cavaliers first step in the N.B.A. finals toward a championship.

title: Shortstops Loom Large at Top of Draft as Teams Pass on Pitchers
description: SECAUCUS, N.J.  Dansby Swanson, a slick-fielding Vanderbilt shortstop with a line-drive swing, was selected No. 1 in the major league baseball draft by the Arizona Diamondbacks on Monday, a night that was notable for the arms selected for future major league infields but not for pitching mounds.

title: Iran: Hearing Is Held in Reporters Trial
description: An Iranian revolutionary court convened the second hearing on Monday in the espionage trial of Jason Rezaian, the Washington Posts Tehran correspondent, who was arrested and imprisoned nearly a year ago. Irans official Islamic Republic News Agency reported briefly on the second hearing, which was closed to the public; it said that a third hearing was planned but that a date had not been announced. The secretive prosecution of Mr. Rezaian, 39, a California native who holds dual citizenship in Iran and the United States, has become an increasingly contentious point between the two countries, along with the imprisonment of at least two other Americans in Iran and the disappearance of another eight years ago. Mr. Rezaians brother, Ali Rezaian, said the Iranian defense lawyer for Mr. Rezaian, Leila Ahsan, was filing a complaint against the Mehr News Agency, a semiofficial news service in Iran that had reported what it said were details from the first hearing on May 26, in violation of a court-ordered ban.

title: World Trade Center Parachutists Go on Trial
description: One of the three sky divers who parachuted off the 1 World Trade Center tower on a September 2013 night left a note for his mother before the covert jump. Sorry mom, for what its worth, the jumper, Andrew Rossig, wrote. But I had to write some history.

title: New Prosecutor Is Selected for Patz Retrial
description: A senior Manhattan prosecutor who handled the fraud trial of Brooke Astors son has been given the task of retrying a former store clerk accused of murdering 6-year-old Etan Patz, officials in the Manhattan district attorneys office said on Monday.

title: Alan Bond, Yachting Hero and Convict, Dies at 77
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Alan Bond, who bankrolled Australias historic victory in the 1983 Americas Cup yacht race, and who was also a brash billion-dollar dealmaker who was sent to jail for what at the time was the largest corporate fraud in Australian history, died on Friday in Perth, Australia. He was 77.

title: By a Nose
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Todays puzzle by Roy Leban runs because of a different, four-legged runner. In case you missed it, AMERICAN PHAROAH won the Triple Crown on Saturday, after leaving the other horses in the dust at the Belmont Stakes. He is the first horse to win the Triple Crown since AFFIRMED won in 1978. Thats quite a long dry spell.

title: Womens World Cup: U.S. Shows Unease; Hope Solo Puts a Stop to It
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba  The United States appeared nervous Monday when it opened the Womens World Cup, often tattered in defense, frequently inert and faltering in attack.

title: The Kings the Thing, Not the Play, for an Actor Who Would Be Lear
description: Eight years ago, the English actor Edward Petherbridge flew to New Zealand to play King Lear. Hed never seen himself as the Lear type.

title: Kendrick Lamar, Rapper Who Inspired a Teacher, Visits a High School That Embraces His Work
description: When Brian Mooneys students struggled in March to digest the literary themes and dense language in Toni Morrisons novel The Bluest Eye, Mr. Mooney sought inspiration from an unorthodox teacher of his own: the two-time Grammy winner and world-famous rapper Kendrick Lamar.

title: Dolores Spikes, Trailblazer as President of Southern University, Dies at 78
description: Dolores Spikes, who became the first woman to head a university system in the United States when, in 1988, she was named president of the Southern University and A & M College System in Louisiana, and who fought court-ordered desegregation of the states colleges to protect Southerns identity as a black institution, died on June 1 in Baton Rouge, La. She was 78.

title: Released After 27 Years, an Ex-Inmate Is Mindful of a Detectives Cases
description: Lanette Holmes had grown accustomed to waiting for her husband, Shabaka Shakur. He had spent the past 27 years in prison for a murder he insisted he did not commit, based largely on a confession that a judge ruled last week bore a reasonable probability of having been fabricated by a detective now accused of using rogue tactics to make his cases.

title: Monday at the Womens World Cup
description: MONDAYS RESULTS

title: Hints and Whispers Preceded Changes in Jeb Bushs Team
description: The final decision was made only in the last few days, but word of turmoil in Jeb Bushs organization, and a coming change, had been in the air for weeks.

title: Ben Bishop Helps Tampa Bay Lightning Pull Ahead in Stanley Cup Finals
description: CHICAGO  Ben Bishop lay face down, arms spread above his head, and he did not move. He might not have wanted to, either. He had spent much of the game Monday night staggering from side to side in the crease and lumbering from front to back. He seemed to favor his left side.

title: Inside Tony Ourslers House of ESP Cards (Among Other Ephemera)
description: Sorry  this place is a total wreck, says the video artist Tony Oursler of his Manhattan home and studio, which is in a constant state of precariousness: Touch one thing and three more take a tumble. But thats the fun of it! Youre in the midst of moviemaking magic, he continues, and its true. Ahead of the international photography festival Les Rencontres dArles, the sets and props for his upcoming immersive 3D film occupy part of the buildings first floor and a model theater fills the rest. (The basement serves as an editing room for Oursler and his team.)

title: Julio Le Parcs Kinetic Energy
description: The 86-year-old Op Art legend brings his kaleidoscopic vision to a collection of one-of-a-kind silk scarves for Hermes.

title: Word of the Day | condiment
description: condiment  \kn-d-mnt\  noun

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 9, 2015
description: Now the government is belatedly trying to mend the fence after the cow had already been stolen.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 1 P.M. (SYFY) THE PRESTIGE (2006) Robert Angier (Hugh Jackman) and Alfred Borden (Christian Bale) work together as assistants in magic performances before a tragedy turns them into lifelong enemies. As performing magicians, they seek vengeance on each other through obsessive one-upmanship. Rebecca Hall and Michael Caine play supporting roles as Angiers wife and his manager. The Prestige, directed by Christopher Nolan from a script he wrote with his brother Jonathan, is an intricate and elaborate machine designed for the simple purpose of diversion, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Set in a stylized late-Victorian world of dueling music-hall magicians and diabolically clever inventors, it has a satisfyingly puzzlelike structure, zipping around in time and scattering clues throughout its busy scenes and frames. Like Memento, also directed by Christopher Nolan and based on a story by his brother, The Prestige is a triumph of gimmickry, a movie generous enough with its showmanship and sleight of hand to quiet the temptation to grumble about its lack of substance.

title: Corrections: June 9, 2015
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Vince Musi at Look3
description: This years Look3 photo festival features the photographs of Vince Musi, who has been an integral part of the event as its M.C. since its beginning. The festival, which starts Wednesday evening in Charlottesville, Va., also features, Alec Soth, Larry Fink, Zanele Muholi and David Alan Harvey.

description: This years Look3 photo festival features the photographs of Vince Musi, who has been an integral part of the event as its M.C. since its beginning. The festival, which starts Wednesday evening in Charlottesville, Va., also features, Alec Soth, Larry Fink, Zanele Muholi and David Alan Harvey.

title: HSBC to Shed 50,000 Jobs in Overhaul of Global Business
description: LONDON  Like other global institutions, HSBC, Europes largest bank, has been under severe pressure since the 2008 financial crisis to cut costs, meet stringent new regulatory demands and satisfy restless shareholders.

title: When Its O.K. to Pay for a Story
description: St. Petersburg, Fla.  JOURNALISTS frown on paying sources. This decades-old principle stems from the belief that the tawdry practice corrupts the authenticity of information: If I pay you to tell me your story, you may distort its details to up the value.
