description: PARIS  Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund, was acquitted on Friday of aggravated pimping charges, concluding a case that made the private lives of public figures fair game for the French news media, even if the French themselves still seemed inclined to overlook dalliances by their political leaders.

title: Soil Contamination Found Near Huge Mine in Western China
description: Soil samples collected by Greenpeace East Asia researchers near Asias largest zinc and lead mine and smelting plant, in Yunnan Province, show severe heavy metal contamination, the organization says. The findings, it has reported, highlight the environmental and health hazards as industries react to tighter pollution constraints in eastern China by expanding operations in less developed areas in the west.

title: How to Write a Country Song
description: You dont have to be from the country to write a country song  but it helps, says Billy Joe Shaver, who started songwriting as a boy in Corsicana, Tex. Shaver, who is now 75 and lives in Waco, sings and plays guitar, but his lyrics are better known coming from the mouths of other performers. Willie Nelson, Kris Kristofferson, Johnny Cash, Waylon Jennings and Elvis Presley have all recorded his work. In the 1970s, Shaver wrote a number of anthems in the rougher, less-polished-than-Nashville subgenre called outlaw country.

title: Outside, Looking In
description: One day last November, at a stoplight on Route 34 in Derby, Conn., I noticed a truck idling in front of me. It was stout and white, with the requisite grime, and by outward appearance it could have been carrying anything: Portuguese rolls, hanging file folders or maybe replacement gas caps. But when the bumper sticker (Am I driving safely?) referred me to a government website, I became certain the truck was hauling human beings.

title: On the Brooklyn Bridge
description: Years before the Brooklyn Bridge was built, Walt Whitmans poem Crossing Brooklyn Ferry anticipated the fascination so many poets have had with it, its power to compel us toward contemplation. Charles Simics poem shows that the bridge  the crossing  maintains its original attractions to the observant sojourner. It reminds me too of what I love about cities: the seemingly familiar faces in the midst of a crowd, a way of being both alone and not alone in the wide world.

title: The 5.31.15 Issue
description: Andrew Solomon wrote about the stigma of antenatal depression, or depression during pregnancy, and looked into its treatment. How should doctors tend to pregnant women who suffer from mental illness? The answer is complicated.

title: Seven Reasons I Didnt Visit the Spectacular Historic Site on My Holiday
Today in Politics: In Tight Contest, Trade Deal Heads to the Bottom of the Ninth
description: Good Friday morning from Washington. The campaign trail leads for the moment through Utah and Mitt Romneys candidate summit meeting, but the primary action is in the House, which is scrambling to complete a vote over the trade deal that has aligned President Obama with Republicans and that sent him to a baseball diamond on Thursday to press for the votes he needs.

title: Morning Agenda: Twitter Chiefs Exit Sparks Deal Speculation
description: TWITTER CHIEFS EXIT SPARKS DEAL SPECULATION | To Twitter board members and friends of Dick Costolo, his plans to resign as Twitters chief executive was not a surprise,  Vindu Goel and Mike Isaac report in The New York Times. But  Michael J. de la Merced notes in DealBook that whenever a chief executive departs, it always raises the question of whether the company is now for sale  and Twitter is no exception. In fact, Twitter was the subject of takeover rumors as recently as last month, and a longtime Twitter investor, Chris Sacca, has mused over the last two weeks that Google might make a logical buyer.

title: Hong Kong Soccer Fans Boo Chinese National Anthem
description: Hong Kong won its first World Cup qualifying match in nearly eight years on Thursday, thrashing Bhutan 7-0. But ahead of the match at Mong Kok Stadium in Hong Kong, the sounds of jeers filled the air.

title: French Executive Apologizes to Netanyahu After His Remarks Prompt an Uproar
description: JERUSALEM  The chief executive of a French telecommunications company made an extraordinary personal pilgrimage to Israel on Friday to apologize to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, after the executives recent declaration that he wanted to disentangle from an Israeli mobile provider prompted a diplomatic uproar.

title: Vincent Bollors Long Bet on Solid-State Batteries for Electric Cars
description: He is the French billionaire who is the chairman and biggest shareholder of the media giant Vivendi.

title: Coping With Baltimores Murder Rate
description: Tiffany Fair and Tevon Chapman are struggling to keep their families safe as violent crime rises in Baltimore. They say the absence of police officers has made their neighborhood much more dangerous.

title: West Baltimores Police Presence Drops, and Murders Soar
description: BALTIMORE  From the steps of her New Bethlehem Baptist Church, the Rev. Lisa Weah looked down the block to the open-air drug market outside the bodega on the corner a few hundred feet away.

title: Electric Car Sharing Program Moves to London
description: A French billionaire seeks to emulate the success of Pariss short-term rental program.

title: In New Deals With Apple and Facebook, a Delicate Balance for The Times
description: A sentence in the announcement to Times employees about new partnerships with Apple and Facebook caught my eye: In crafting each of these deals, we are mindful of the need to maintain the healthy balance weve achieved between digital advertising and subscription revenue.

title: A Day With the Anderson Monarchs
description: Steve Bandura and his baseball team travel to New Jersey for a game.

title: Baseball and Black History
description: PHILADELPHIA  LAST summer, a 13-year-old named Mone Davis landed on the cover of Sports Illustrated, a national sensation after she pitched a shutout in the Little League World Series, where almost all of the other players are boys. Shes believed to be the only black girl ever to participate in the competition.

title: Negotiations in Close Quarters
description: Dear Diary:

title: Negotiations in Close Quarters
description: Dear Diary:

title: Oranges Boss Meets With Netanyahu
description: Stphane Richard, the chief executive of Orange, the French telecom giant, tells Israels prime minister that he regrets the furor caused by his statements about doing business in the country.

title: Doctor Faustus and Christopher Marlowe Return to New York
description: Christopher Marlowes plays are so rarely staged at New Yorks major theaters that this season is a banner one for that Elizabethan tragedian, whose work influenced Shakespeare but has since been spectacularly overshadowed by that of his contemporary. First came a production of Tamburlaine the Great, starring the mighty John Douglas Thompson. Now the Classic Stage Company follows up with a new version of Doctor Faustus, adapted by David Brindel and Andrei Belgrader and directed by Mr. Belgrader.

title: At Womens World Cup, Seeing Signs of Lionel Messi, Not Mia Hamm
description: Megan Rapinoe controlled the ball at the halfway line at the Womens World Cup and sped forward. When she finally encountered a defender, she effortlessly jinked past her and shot the ball into the net to seal a victory for the United States over Australia on Monday.

title: A New Manhattan Rental Designed to Feel Like a Resort
description: With Sky, a shimmering new rental building on the Far West Side, the Moinian family says it is not content to merely keep up with the Joneses.

title: The Second Coming of Sam Cooke
description: Those lucky enough to have caught the Leon Bridges set at SXSW in March would be forgiven for feeling like they had traveled back in time. The 25-year-old crooner from Fort Worth, Tex., who until recently was washing dishes to make ends meet, exudes 50s style and swagger in high-waisted pants and saddle shoes. His first album, Coming Home, out June 23, is a revelation: full of gently flowing songs about Jezebels and tender sweet loving.

title: Orange Is the New Black Season 3, Episode 2 Recap: Bedbugs
description: Season 3, Episode 2: Bed Bugs and Beyond

title: Red vs. Blue America on Marriage
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Q. and A.: Zhang Weiwei on Why China Will Succeed Under the Communist Party
description: When Zhang Weiwei was asked if it was true, as had been whispered among Chinese academics and officials, that President Xi Jinping had read his book The China Wave: Rise of a Civilizational State and recommended it to people such as the former World Bank president Robert Zoellick, he answered, Im glad he did.

title: 4 Tourists Plead Guilty to Obscenity for Posing Naked on Malaysian Peak
description: HONG KONG  Four Westerners who stripped atop Malaysias highest peak pleaded guilty on Friday to public obscenity and were due to be deported, their lawyer said.

title: Topman Design: Spring 2016 Menswear
description: London

title: Nothing to Hide and Nowhere to Hide It in Joshua Cohens Internet Novel
description: A strange thing happened when Joshua Cohen was deep into writing his new novel, Book of Numbers. It started to come true. He had already written most of the book, a dense, dizzying story about a struggling novelist named Joshua Cohen who is hired to ghostwrite the memoir of the shady billionaire founder of Tetration, a Google-like technology company whose revolutionary mission is to equalize ourselves with data and data with ourselves.

title: Before Official Announcement, Jeb Bush Shows Off Support Inside Florida
description: Former Gov. Jeb Bush unveiled a raft of endorsements from Republicans in Florida on Friday, demonstrating support in his home state ahead of next weeks expected announcement that he is running for president.

title: Republicans Put Net Neutrality in Jeopardy
description: Many Republican lawmakers hated regulations that the Federal Communications Commission approved earlier this year to prevent cable and phone companies from creating fast and slow lanes on the Internet. Now, they are trying to undermine those rules through an appropriations bill.

title: Criminal Psychics See a Clear Path to Profits in the Desperate
description: A detective paused between bites of a late lunch on Wednesday in a Midtown diner and said, Its not very often you see a customer in a psychic shop.

title: Wave of Protests Spreads to Scandal-Weary Honduras and Guatemala
description: MEXICO CITY  In Guatemala, angry citizens marched under pelting rain, undeterred. In Honduras, they carried torches at dusk. A wave of protests against corruption scandals that is sweeping across Latin America has reached Central America.

title: Daily Report: Under a New Chief, Twitter Has a Chance to Focus on Live Events
description: Here, in 140 characters or fewer, Farhad Manjoo writes in his State of the Art column, is some free advice for Twitters next chief executive: Focus on live events. People never tire of gabbing about whats going on right now. Twitter could be the best place for that. Do it fast.

title: Recording a Phones Screen on a Mac
1890: High Prices for Art Works
description: One and a half million francs  in exact figures 1,589,000 fr.  were realized by the sale of the fifty-three paintings of the Crabbe collection, at the Sedelmeyer Gallery, yesterday. The auction room of the spacious establishment in the rue de La Rochefoucauld was packed to its fullest. Corots enchanting Matin, which was sold in 1880 at the Hotel Drouot for 7,000 fr., and for which Senator Crabbe paid, three years ago, 42,000 fr., brought 63,000 fr.

title: South Korea Steps Up MERS Fight
description: Workers sprayed disinfectant in a South Korean market as new cases of Middle East respiratory syndrome continue to be identified.

title: Hannibal: 3 Steps to TVs Scariest Soundtrack
description: GLENDALE, CALIF.  Over two seasons, Hannibal has presented some of televisions most beautifully disturbing imagery. A totem pole made of corpses. A field of corpses harvested to grow mushrooms. A corpse sewn inside a horse.

title: 1915: Fierce Fighting in Gallipoli
description: Fierce fighting is reported from the Gallipoli Peninsula, with big successes for the Allies. According to despatches from Mitylene, a great battle began on Thursday in the Maidos sector, where the Allied troops delivered five furious attacks, and captured the heights dominating Maidos. They are now within two hours of the town, the occupation of which, telegraphs the Times Athens correspondent, was prevented by the fire of Fort Nagara and the coastal batteries, which bombarded the Allies with indirect fire.

title: Chinese Premier Urges Officials to Fight Events That Led 4 Children to Drink Pesticide
description: BEIJING  Li Keqiang, the Chinese premier, ordered officials across the country on Friday to avert the kind of events that led to the deaths of four children who drank pesticide this week, possibly to kill themselves, in an impoverished corner of the southwest.

title: Lawyer on Ex-I.M.F. Chiefs Acquittal
description: Henri Leclerc, the lawyer for Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund, spoke on Friday in Lille, France, after his client was cleared of pimping charges.

title: Fridays Travel News and Tips
description: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Abigail Gray Swartz Continues Her Artist-in-Residency
description: Im happy to share that Abigail Gray Swartz, whose work has appeared at the top of many essays in the past months, will be continuing to illustrate essays and other posts regularly through the summer. Follow her on Twitter and on Instagram: @graydaystudio. See more of her work on Etsy.

title: For Candidates Like Rick Santorum, the Line Can Be Long to Take Flight
description: PARK CITY, Utah  The 2016 presidential season may have started early  but expect it to go long.

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Berlin

title: With Candidates Staying Out, Iowa Straw Poll Dies
description: The Iowa Straw Poll, a Republican Party tradition since 1979 that was cherished by candidates vying to win the nations first nominating contest, is dead for the 2016 presidential cycle, party officials said Friday.

title: Untitled at the Whitney
description: At the museums new downtown restaurant, the chefs welcome the change of scenery.

title: Craig Green: Spring 2016 Menswear
description: London

title: Carly Fiorina Shows Us Just How Weird Americas Tax System Is
description: Last week, Carly Fiorinas presidential campaign made an offer to reporters that was tantalizing to me, but probably to few other people on the planet: If we came in person to her campaign headquarters in Virginia, we could review her state income tax returns.

title: Celebrating 50 Years of New York Philharmonic Outdoor Concerts
description: Those of us who are in the business are apt to forget the curious position of the New York Philharmonic in the citys life, the music critic Harold C. Schonberg wrote in The New York Times in 1965. By and large the citizens are proud of their great orchestra; and, by and large, the citizens have never heard it.

title: A Symphonic Staple
description: A look back at the New York Philharmonics free outdoor concerts in the citys parks.

title: Ayano Sudos Photographs Blur the Gender Line
description: Ayano Sudo was studying art in Paris as an exchange student in 2009 when she saw a German photographers recreations of Harajuku style, named for the teenage girls who doll themselves up as nurses, Lolitas and other characters, and congregate on Sundays near Harajuku railway station in Tokyo.

title: A Gaza Tunnel Millionaire Falls on Hard Times
description: GAZA CITY

title: Deutschland 83, a SundanceTV Series About an Earnest Stasi Spy
description: BERLIN  With its clunky rotary phones, vinyl-coated swivel chairs and wooden desks, the Stasi Museum, located in the former headquarters of the dreaded East German secret police, provided the perfect retro look for Deutschland 83, a new eight-part German television series set in the last throes of the Cold War. The show, which was filmed partly at the museum, makes its United States debut Wednesday on SundanceTV.

title: Ryn Weavers The Fool Is Deeply Personal Indie Pop
description: The singer-songwriter Ryn Weaver is a chronic over-sharer  to the max, she said. Once I feel like I can trust you, if its been like three minutes, Im like  she leaned in  promise you wont tell anyone.

title: Deluxe Cheesecake
description: Sam Sifton recreates Craig Claibornes classic cheesecake recipe.

title: A Swipe and Click Mortgage Service
description: Aspiring to become a one-stop-shopping network for home buying, Nationstar Mortgage Holdings this week unveiled a service designed to allow purchasers to simply swipe and click their way through the entire process.

title: Craig Claibornes Classic Cheesecake
description: There is perhaps no more New Yorkish a dessert than cheesecake, a dish best consumed with a hot coffee and a reading of the afternoon news. The dessert owes something to the cooking of Italy and the Baltic States, of course, but its smooth creaminess and contrasting crust are almost indigenous to the United States and particularly to the diners and coffee shops of New York City.

title: New Releases From Marta Snchez, Cloud Rat, Pete Rodriguez and More
description: Marta Snchez Quintet

title: Cathedrals, R&B With a Dash of 1980s Rock, at Le Poisson Rouge
description: Release, then clench. Release, then clench again. Everything about the Bay Area duo Cathedrals follows this simple, striking pattern. The singer Brodie Jenkins has a voice thats both pulpy and ethereal  she leans heavy into big words, her voice robust, then fading ever so dreamily. (Ms. Jenkins is a versatile singer  as a teenager, she was signed to a country music label as part of a family band.)

title: Jaws Opens Manhattan Parks Summer Outdoor Movies
description: Its almost summer, which means free outdoor movie screenings are popping up around Manhattan-area parks. On June 22, for example, the HBO Bryant Park Summer Film Festival, in Midtown, commences on Mondays; the Hudson RiverFlicks Big Hit Wednesdays series kicks off on July 8, on Pier 63 in Chelsea.

title: Alvin Ailey Company Says Goodbye to Three Dancers
description: Dancers dont last forever. The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater proves that this week as three artists bid farewell. Along with a married couple, Antonio Douthit-Boyd andKirven Douthit-Boyd, is Alicia Graf Mack, who returns from her leave of absence for three guest appearances. This transcendent, statuesque dancer sways her hips with the company a final time as the parasol-waving woman in the Wade in the Water section of Revelations onTuesday and Thursday and next Sunday night. Other highlights include the Douthit-Boyds in Chroma, Grace and Revelations onThursday, and in Night Creature on Saturday. They will soon take over the Center of Creative Arts in St. Louis, where theyll have some company. Ms. Mack, who recently gave birth to a son, will teach ballet and modern dance at Webster University and Washington University in St. Louis. Theres some solace: The next generation of Ailey is in good hands. (7:30 p.m., TuesdaythroughThursday; 8 p.m., FridayandSaturday; 2 p.m., Saturday; 3 p.m. and 7:30 p.m. next Sunday; David H. Koch Theater, 212-496-0600,davidkochtheater.com.)

title: Navigating the West Celebrates George Caleb Binghams Paintings
description: American 19th-century genre painting doesnt often get the museum spotlight, though it should. It has a lot to tell us about where weve been and who we are, and some of our best artists made their careers in it. So for more than one reason, Im looking forward to Navigating the West: George Caleb Bingham and the River, which arrives at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Wednesday.

title: Jennifer Beals and Matthew Modine Star in TNTs Proof, on Life, Death and Beyond
description: Parachuting off Mount Everest doesnt faze Ivan Turing, a tech wizard with a referential surname and a fondness for Steve Jobsian turtlenecks. But terminal adenocarcinoma has given him pause. Ive always hated unknowns, he tells Dr. Carolyn Tyler, a cardiothoracic surgeon with little patience for speculation and a wellspring of grief all her own. And now that Im facing the biggest one there is, I want to know what to expect. His offer: Hell give her control of his $10 billion estate if shell help him prove what, if anything, exists after the body flatlines.

title: Taking On Student Debt, and Refusing to Pay
description: Over the last couple of decades, we have been engaged in an enormous national experiment, taking impressionable and often ignorant teenagers and young adults and seeing just how much student loan debt they can handle.

title: Stalins Daughter, by Rosemary Sullivan
description: A young princess walks the corridors of an ancient palace, surrounded by adoring relatives, governesses and tutors. Her father is a beloved ruler of a vast country, and she is his only daughter and favorite child, his little sparrow, his little fly. She brings him presents of violets and strawberries, and he pets her, showering her in bristly kisses redolent of tobacco. She spends idyllic summers at the family dacha, where her fathers merry friends, whom she calls aunts and uncles, come on visits and regale her with stories and songs. The world she inhabits seems magical to her, that place of sunshine.

title: Backlands, by Victoria Shorr
description: Usually when reviewing a novel, you must be careful not to give away too much plot. But in the case of Victoria Shorrs Backlands, theres no such danger: Shorr herself reveals the bare bones of the story in the first few pages. Put simply, Backlands is the fictionalized account of a real-life one-eyed bandit called Lampio and his lover, Maria Bonita  famous Brazilian outlaws who took from the rich and gave to the poor. From the early 1920s to his capture in 1938, Lampio and his gang controlled much of the Serto, a huge and dusty swath of land in the northeast of the country, almost the size of Spain. More than once, they were cornered but managed to escape. For a long time, Lampio seemed invincible and his life, as Shorr puts it, was a tango, full of beauty and danger, mixed.

title: Literary Lives
description: ADELINEA Novel of Virginia WoolfBy Norah Vincent280 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $23.

title: The Dorito Effect, by Mark Schatzker
description: A few years ago I sat with a friend and looked at a menu, and we wondered why everything seemed to be flavored like a taco. Or Caesar salad or maple syrup. I couldnt quite say what about it bothered me, but I held a conviction that something was wrong in a thing  a Mexican snack, salad dressing, tree sap  being turned into a flavor.

title: Black or White? Womans Story Stirs Up a Furor
description: She has professed an affinity for black people since she was a teenager, when her parents adopted four black children. She chose a college where she could immerse herself in racial issues. She married a black man and built a reputation as an advocate for civil rights.

title: Bizarre Court Case Puts a Violinist, and Leipzig String Quartet, in an Unflattering Light
description: The violinist Stefan Arzberger had planned to play the music of Beethoven, Haydn and Mendelssohn with his colleagues in the Leipzig String Quartet later this month at Wigmore Hall in London, where he fondly recalls once sipping sherry with patrons after a concert.

title: Stuff We Liked
description: What stuff has our staff found for you this week on the web?

title: Fresh Ricotta Turns a Simple Pasta Dish Sublime
description: A recent trip to Sicily reminded me just how marvelous fresh ricotta can be. I had the chance to visit a family-run sheep dairy to observe a cheese master at work. The farm produces pecorino cheese, both young and aged, and ricotta too, which is essentially a by-product of the cheese-making process.

title: Folkways and Family in America
description: Occasionally in the debates about family structure in America, Ive had reason to point out the limits of the popularred family, blue family dichotomy, which portrays a post-sexual revolution America divided between a late-marrying, lower-divorce-rate model of family formation in liberal regions and an earlier-marrying, frequently-divorcing model in more conservative and religious states. This portrayal, particularly associated with the sociologists Naomi Cahn and June Carbone, definitely captures one distinctive reality of American life the fact that stable two-parent homes are more common among secular liberal Bobos in the BosWash corridor and elsewhere than they arein, say, certain regions in the Bible Belt. But its also important to recognize the exceptions to this pattern, from red social models (in the High Plains and Mormon Utah, in particular) that combine high marriage rates and birthrates and relative family stability to blue social models (inner city, Rust Belt, Southwestern) that are as unstable as anything Alabaman and Mississippian. (And thats without getting into the issue of abortion as a necessary prop for blue stability.)

title: Sherrie Levine Moves to David Zwirner
description: Sherrie Levine is switching galleries, but she wont be moving very far. After more than a decade and a half with the Paula Cooper Gallery, Ms. Levine will join the David Zwirner Gallery, just a couple blocks south in Chelsea.

title: Jeb Bushs Family Values
description: In many campaigns, one candidate or another is asked to answer for comments he or she made in the past. The answer is usually gibberish  that was a long time ago, or I was trying to say something else. This weeks entry is  not shockingly given how many times he has tripped over his own tongue lately  Jeb Bush.

title: The Art Basel Fair: A Tough Club to Crack
description: Galleries seeking to exhibit at Art Basel encounter an intense, juried competition. While the fair says it works to find new faces, prime selling space on the ground floor is dominated by a roster of established dealers.

title: Nine Rooms on Park Avenue for $28.5 Million
description: A sprawling, elegant apartment that once belonged to Roone Arledge, who ran ABC Sports and News, in the exclusive Rosario Candela-designed building 778 Park Avenue sold to a hedge fund manager and his wife, who also own Brooke Astors former co-op directly above it, for $28,500,000 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Explosion Destroys Ancient Cultural Heritage Site in Yemen Capital
description: A protected 2,500-year-old cultural heritage site in Yemens capital, Sana, was obliterated in an explosion early Friday, and witnesses and news reports said the cause was a missile or bomb from a Saudi warplane. The Saudi military denied responsibility.

title: From Tree to Greens, a U.S. Open Unlike Any Before
description: This is a story about countless blades of grass, a single tree and a freight train.

title: Interpol Halts Use of FIFA Funds for Anticorruption Program
description: LONDON  Interpol suspended an agreement with FIFA on Friday that had called for the international police agency to receive 20 million euros over 10 years to fight corruption in soccer, citing the American investigations that have ensnared soccers world governing body.

title: Asking Tough Questions to Understand The Wolfpack
description: The transfixing and troubling documentary The Wolfpack opens this week, telling the story of six young brothers who, until five years ago, had spent most of their lives locked up in their familys apartment on Manhattans Lower East Side.

title: U.S. Will Call All Chimps Endangered
description: All chimpanzees will be designated as endangered under the Endangered Species Act, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service announced Friday.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Treadmill Desks, Cholesterol Drugs and More
description: Take the Quiz

title: Los Angeles Confronts a Spike in Homelessness Amid Prosperity
description: LOS ANGELES  Construction cranes dot the sky from Century City to the Sunset Strip. Once-downtrodden blocks downtown and in Venice are bustling with restaurants, coffee shops, sparkling new condominiums, theaters and office construction. The unemployment rate has dropped to almost half its double-digit high of five years ago. Much of Los Angeles these days seems the portrait of prosperity.

title: MAN: Spring 2016 Menswear
description: London

title: Take Care, Mr. Elson
description: From Times Documentaries, a trailer for Take Care, Mr. Elson, the story of one mans hard path to health insurance in the age of the Affordable Care Act. Watch the full video at the link below.

title: Paperback Row
description: IDIOPATHY, by Sam Byers. (Faber & Faber, $15.) In this debut novel, three characters  a former couple, now estranged, and their mutual friend freshly sprung from rehab  clumsily reunite against the backdrop of a bovine epidemic coursing through England. As our reviewer, Joshua Cohen, put it, the characters worry that theyll be infected too, though the idiotic futility of their chatter suggests theyre terminal already.

title: Gawkers Moment of Truth
description: Im pretty sure we have a revolution coming, said Nick Denton, founder and chief executive of Gawker Media. Its not 100 percent guaranteed, but the existing corporate structure is looking pretty hollow.

title: The Friendly, Heavy Skies
description: Thousands of books have crossed my desk, but until recently none of them had weighed 14 pounds. That behemoth, with the faceless, almost cryptic title Airline Visual Identity 1945-1975, is a massive collection mostly of full-page posters advertising the glamour and reach of air travel in the postwar years.

title: What I Love | Edward Hibbert
description: The actor and literary agent lives in an alcove studio in the West Village.

title: Hope Fills the 7 Train for Mets Fans. The Next Stop: Reality.
description: I fielded the phone call in late afternoon: The Mets are in first place, the world champion San Francisco Giants are in town, and we have our blond Viking strikeout machine, Noah Syndergaard, on the mound.

title: How to Bake Pi, by Eugenia Cheng
description: To make mathematics palatable for the lay reader, the author must sweeten the pill. There are many ways to do this, but Eugenia Cheng is surely the first to have approached the task literally, writing a math book in which almost every chapter begins with a recipe for dessert.

title: Popcast: Tenements Bright Double Album
description: Ben Ratliff, Maria Sherman and Liz Pelly discuss the bands new album and punk music.

title: Move: Putting Americas Infrastructure Back in the Lead, by Rosabeth Moss Kanter
description: We seemed to be going in circles.

title: At Moscows New Garage Museum, a Work Set to Debut in a Thousand Years
description: This week in Moscow, all of the exhibitions and works have been installed for the globally buzzy opening of the Garage Museum of Contemporary Arts new Rem Koolhaas-designed building  including a Ping-Pong-based performance by Rirkrit Tiravanija called Tomorrow is the Question? and the selfie heaven of Yayoi Kusamas Infinity Theory, the artists first-ever show in Russia  except for one, leaving a blank cube in the wall where it will eventually be placed. But dont hold your breath for that: Taryn Simons Black Square XVII is made from nuclear waste, and it will take 1,000 years for the vitrification process to rid it of radioactive material. Itll be on view in 3015.

title: Roosevelt Island to Shine Under the Hillary Clinton Spotlight
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons decision to use Roosevelt Island, the two-mile sliver of land mashed between Queens and Manhattan, as the backdrop Saturday for her first major stump speech sent a small but noticeable ripple through the islands previously scheduled weekend plans.

title: Nasir Mazhar: Spring 2016 Menswear
description: London

title: It Starts With Trouble, by Clark Davis
description: Chased out of many a yard, the title character of William Goyens 1947 short story The White Rooster has torn his feathers and so tired himself that whatever he found to eat in random places was not enough to keep any flesh on his carcass. Yet he keeps foraging, foiling societys best efforts to extinguish him, and each new day finds him crowing, a carillon-like sound that bursts from his straggly throat. Even as he nears death, he is most vividly alive, in some courageous way.

title: An Unsung Architectural Oasis
description: Modernism pushes tumbleweed aside in Tucson, where finding individualistic architecture only requires wheels and a map.

title: Talks to Begin on Creating a Trade Zone Within Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG  Trade within Africa has long faced many barriers, from the physical to nonphysical: bad roads, air routes that still favor old colonial ties to Europe, corruption and poor governance. Even as African economies have grown in the last decade, trade between African nations has lagged behind their exchanges with the rest of the world.

title: Lon Blum: Prime Minister, Socialist, Zionist, by Pierre Birnbaum
description: Lon Blum, age 26, imagined Goethe writing a sequel to his renowned Faust. Blums protagonist, however, was not Goethes famous intellectual, who wagers with the Devil to experience everything possible. He was, instead, a socialist seeking justice  although impeded by Mephistopheles. Blums Faust passes reforms in Parliament, but reaction lands him in prison. Still, obstacles only make him resolute.

title: Game of Thrones Season 5 Finale: 9 Questions That Need Answers
description: Its Thrones Friday, which means the pop culture cabal takes one last whack at the show before Sundays Season 5 finale.

title: Orange Is the New Black Season 3 Episode 3 Recap: Darling Nicky
description: Season 3, Episode 3

title: Chinese Hackers Circumvent Popular Web Privacy Tools
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Chinese hackers have found a way around widely used privacy technology to target the creators and readers of web content that state censors have deemed hostile, according to new research.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Stalins Daughter
description: This week, Rosemary Sullivan talks about Stalins Daughter; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Eugenia Cheng discusses How to Bake Pi; Judd Apatow on his reading habits; questions from listeners; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Burk Uzzles American Puzzle
description: In between assignments, Burk Uzzle took to side streets and back roads to find serendipitous visual moments.

title: The Scene
description: Craig Green at London Collections Men.

title: Prison Worker Who Befriended Killers Is Accused of Providing Tools for Escape
description: DANNEMORA, N.Y.  More than a month before two killers escaped from a maximum-security prison in far northern New York State last weekend, a worker there who befriended them provided them with some of the tools to do the deed: hacksaw blades, chisels, a punch and a screwdriver bit, according to criminal complaints.

title: Inside the List
description: Blumes Day: In the summer of 1976, the Book Review took note of a new frankness in childrens literature, and cited as Exhibit A the novels of Judy Blume: She is a kind of heroine to the kids who read and reread her books, and a kind of Little League Grace Metalious to the mothers. Metalious, you may remember, was the author of Peyton Place  that decidedly Major League novel of suburban smut  and being seen as a junior version didnt hurt Blumes popularity any. Starting with Wifey in 1978 and continuing right up to In the Unlikely Event (new at No. 4 on the hardcover fiction list), all four of her adult novels have been best sellers. Thats more than you can say for her most celebrated childrens books, including Blubber and Are You There God? Its Me, Margaret, although its not their fault: The Times didnt introduce a childrens best-seller list until 2000. Had one existed in 1976, Blume would surely have been on it. She had some two million books in print that year, according to the Times article, which further observed that Blumes appeal lies in her ability to speak directly to her readers experience. Her characters are usually suburban kids, and not always nice ones. Blume recently told NPRs Weekend Edition that when she was an adolescent herself, she preferred grown-up literature. Starting at 12, really, and onward, I was reading adult books, she said. Everything that I was curious about, about the adult world, I learned from reading those books. Or I got from them, you know, some idea of what it was like to be grown-up. Which is what I was very, very curious about.

title: Popcast: Tenement, Punk and the DIY Scene
description: Predatory Headlights is the new album by Tenement, the punk trio from Appleton, Wis. Its an accomplishment. Its a double album, with 25 songs, and it took more than three years to make. It gives you an enlarged sense of what the primary songwriter, Amos Pitsch, is most trained at: tightly written riff songs with an almost classical pop sense, descended from pop-punk while transcending its clichs. But it also includes experimental compositions and arrangements involving strings and field recordings and an out-of-tune piano. Predatory Headlights is strong and strange and detailed and cohesive; if people are still listening to records from 2015 in 20 years, this might be one of them. Tenement started in 2006 and has spent a lot of its life on the DIY circuit, gigging in living rooms and basements. For quite a while, if you wanted a Tenement record, you had to buy one at a gig. It appears on bills and has recorded split EPs with far more noisy, simple straight-ahead hardcore bands, but it plays music that sounds as if it could have been almost popular at some point in the recent past. Where does Tenement fit into the current punk-hardcore-DIY scene?

title: Edward Hibbert on His West Village Studio
description: For years, the actor Edward Hibbert lived contentedly in a studio apartment in Hells Kitchen, an area that has become so chic we now call it Chez Hades, said Mr. Hibbert, 59, who is playing an uncannily prescient wedding planner in the Broadway musical It Shoulda Been You.

title: Cuomos Housing Game
description: If your Internet wanderings this week happened to land you on the web page for the governor of New York, you would have immediately found images of Andrew M. Cuomo scouring the bowels of the Clinton Correctional Facility, immersing his head in the pipes and looking like Tommy Lee Jones in The Fugitive.

title: Editors Choice
description: LOVING DAY, by Mat Johnson. (Spiegel & Grau, $26.) Johnsons hero is tragic not because of the stresses of his liminal racial status but because he, like most everyone else in the novel, is haunted by ghosts of painful pasts.

title: City Schoolchildren Take to a British Sport
description: More than 70 teams in and around New York City played this month in the eighth annual Rugby Cup, and a frequent contender is a Brooklyn middle school.

title: Brownsvilles Unlikely Rugby Dynasty
description: On a patch of turf on the sidelines of crowded athletic fields on Randalls Island, under the rattle of the Robert F. Kennedy Bridge, a dozen middle school students gathered around a burly man with a ponytail and a goatee. This was Ovidiu Grozav, coach of two flag rugby teams  one boys, one girls  from Intermediate School 392 in Brownsville, Brooklyn, and he was giving his boys a few words of encouragement before their first match.

title: In Tucson, an Unsung Architectural Oasis
description: People tend to come to Tucson to figure something out, Demion Clinco remarked one cool desert evening, beneath a sky so boundless it made all things seem possible. We were seated on the terrace of the 85-year-old Arizona Inn, drinking anachronistic cocktails. The cocktails produced an optimism of their own.

title: James Last, Bandleader Known for Happy Sound, Dies at 86
description: James Last, the internationally renowned German bandleader whose music was considered staggeringly accessible even by the standards of easy listening, died on Tuesday at his home in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 86.

title: J. Crews Cuts, Sarah Jessica Parker for Jordache and Mall Stats
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: J. Crews Cuts, Sarah Jessica Parker for Jordache and Mall Stats
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: Christopher Shannon: Spring 2016 Menswear
description: London

title: First Condos Soon for Sale at Barclays Center Site
description: By the time Barclays Center, the Brooklyn arena, opened in 2012 as a centerpiece to a massive redevelopment plan then called Atlantic Yards, the project had endured years of lawsuits, a financial downturn and no small measure of controversy. Thousands of new apartments, initially projected to be done by 2016, had not yet begun to materialize as timelines were pushed back again and again to as far off as 2035.

title: Coffee Drinks Stake a Claim at the Bar
description: The Espresso Fizz has the air of a classic cocktail, even though its made with espresso, not spirits, and was introduced to the coffee menu of the Manhattan restaurant Maialino earlier this year. Created by Ryan Clur, the head barista, its a shot of espresso floated over chilled tonic water thats flavored with orange bitters and an orange twist.

title: Before Crash, Germanwings Pilot Searched Web for Ways to Die
description: BERLIN  The day before he crashed an Airbus 320 carrying 149 passengers and crew members into the French Alps, Andreas Lubitz safely flew an empty jet from Dsseldorf, Germany, to Berlin, then returned home to his iPad to search terms including living will, suffering and dying.

title: Overcoming the Confidence Gap for Women
description: When I met Lynne Doughtie this week, I was struck by how different it felt sitting with her than with any male chief executive I had met over the years. Six weeks ago, Ms. Doughtie was elected United States chairwoman and chief executive of KPMG. When she takes over the role on July 1, she will become the first woman to serve in both of those roles for a Big Four accounting firm. Cathy Engelbert was chosen as chief executive of Deloitte in February.

title: Photo Diary: Craig Green Spring/Summer 2016
description: Scenes from London Collections Men, captured by Kasia Bobula.

title: Worlds Tallest Passive House Breaks Ground on Roosevelt Island
description: An apartment tower on Roosevelt Island that began construction this month will be the tallest passive-house high-rise in the world when it is completed in 2017, according to the Passive House Institute in Germany. And at about 270,000 square feet, it will also be the largest, said David Kramer, a principal with Hudson Companies, which is developing the building in partnership with Cornell Tech, the applied sciences campus of Cornell University, and the Related Companies.

title: Warriors Andre Iguodala Re-emerges in His Season of Sacrifice
description: With the intricately structured salary cap in the N.B.A., depth is a luxury most teams cannot afford. The value of having options beyond your superstars was on full display in Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals on Thursday night when Andre Iguodala led the Golden State Warriors to a road win that evened the series at two games apiece.

title: The New Beauty
description: Many civilians, and by that I mean people who dont breathe the hothouse air of the fashion industrial complex daily, have been struck of late by the rather odd looks  big noses, large foreheads, awkwardly coltish legs or squished mouths  of many of the current top models walking the runway and appearing in magazines such as this, and in its advertisements. The glamazon supermodels of yesteryear (Christy, Linda, Naomi), and todays Sports Illustrated or Victorias Secret models (Gisele Bndchen, Kate Upton), are much easier to understand, more obvious in their beauty (especially to the average straight guy). Those girls are air-brushed-seeming goddesses of human perfection, while the new models are fairly unconventional, far more individual.

title: The Partys Over  Over My Budget, That Is
description: Everyone knows that for couples and their families, planning and staging a wedding involves serious money.

title: Excerpts From Drawn & Quarterly 25
description: Comics by Kate Beaton, Jillian Tamaki and Genevive Castre.

title: New Internet Regulations Take Effect, and Web Users See No Change
description: Open Internet activists counted down to this Friday. After years of advocacy and months of legal procedure, the federal governments rules for strictly regulating the web tookeffect: The democracy of the Internet becameenforceable, with the government ready to protectthe principles of net neutrality and Internet service providers required to load every site at the same speed.

title: Tough Choices for Succession in the Family Business
description: SHARON MADISON was enjoying a successful career in marketing and advertising at Verizon Communications when she took a leave of absence to work for her familys business, United Building Maintenance. She joined her twin brother to help their father, who was ill. When their father died a few years later, she found herself running a company she had little interest in.

title: Drawn & Quarterly: Genevieve Castree
description: A selection of cartoons on sleeping.

title: Louisiana Court Blocks Release of Angola Three Inmate
description: NEW ORLEANS  A three-judge panel of the federal appeals court here ruled on Friday against the immediate release of Albert Woodfox, who has served nearly four decades in solitary confinement for the murder of a prison guard, deciding that he should stay in prison as the state appeals a federal order to free him.

title: Explosion in Old City of Sana
description: A Unesco world heritage site was damaged on Friday by a blast that witnesses said was caused by airstrikes in Yemens capital.

title: New Forms Aim to Clarify Mortgage Data for Borrowers
description: New rules and forms aimed at making mortgage information easier for borrowers to understand are scheduled to debut on Aug. 1.

title: Tell Us How the Crisis in Yemen Is Affecting You or Your Family
description: We want to hear from people in Yemen affected by the ongoing violence. Help us tell the story there.

title: In Belgiums Strawberry Fields, Perfections in the Picking
description: For many Belgians, Wpion has long been synonymous with strawberries. Carefully picked berries from this village, which has been in the strawberry growing business since the mid-17th century, are renowned for their fully ripe flavor. In Brussels, 50 miles to the northwest, Wpion berries fetch a premium price, roughly twice what the competition is going for.

title: Inside Ts Beauty Issue
description: Ts latest issue celebrates beauty in its many forms. To that end, weve rounded up 11 of the most striking models working today  from the youthful Amilna Estevao to the 44-year-old fashion icon Stella Tennant  who epitomize whats beautiful now. Ashley Brokaw already knows this. As the fashion industrys leading casting director, she is largely responsible for the latest trend of unusual, unconventional beauties. As on the runway, so in architecture: In a special portfolio, seven leading architects tell us why maligned buildings from Paris to upstate New York are deserving of a second look. Elsewhere, the writer Dan Chiasson sorts through the rusted bicycles and myriad neckties of Robert Rauschenberg, whose archive-in-progress in Mount Vernon, N.Y., is a colorful manifestation of the late artists penchant for turning ephemera into art; a trip to Havana, Cuba opens the door to a grand home and cultural meeting place 15 years in the making; Christine Smallwood extols the introduction of so-called outsider artists into major institutions; the novelist and horticulturist Umberto Pasti pens a rumination on the art of gardening; and Natasha Lyonne and John Baldessari cast a critical eye on a zombie gnome and soap made from nightingale droppings. See all stories from this issue >>

title: Lawskys Top Deputy to Succeed Him Temporarily
description: Anthony Albanese, chief of staff to Benjamin M. Lawsky, the New York State superintendent of financial services, will succeed his boss on an interim basis when Mr. Lawsky steps down next week.

title: Washington Dysfunction, With a Twist: Democrats Desert Their President
description: WASHINGTON  He made it personal. He appealed to their loyalty. He asked them to give him what every modern president has had. He argued the facts, disputed the politics, quarreled over the history and at times lashed out at those who still refused to stand with him.

title: Erroll Garner: Caravan
The Back-and-Forth on Trade
description: A sampling of the debate in Washington over President Obamas Trans-Pacific Partnership free-trade pact.

title: Founding Member of Pussy Riot Detained in Moscow
description: Nadezhda Tolokonnikova,a founding member of the activist groupPussy Riot, was detained along with another activist, Ekaterina Nenasheva, in Moscowon Friday, after setting up a brief protest performance in Bolotnaya Square, a central area where in 2012 thousands demonstrated in opposition to President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: Paying Off the Mortgage Is Becoming Harder for Older Workers
description: LIKE Archie Bunker, who celebrated paying off his home mortgage by burning his documents in a 1975 episode of All in the Family, many workers once routinely timed retirement to coincide with paying off a mortgage.

title: East Hampton Equestrian Compound for $55 Million
description: A 23-acre equestrian compound on the edge of East Hampton Village, anchored by an 18,000-square-foot stone, stucco and shingled house, is about to go on the market for $55 million. The annual real estate taxes on the property, which includes multiple barns, a 5,500-square-foot guesthouse, two cottages and nine buildable lots, are $118,523.76.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Stalins Daughter
description: This week, Rosemary Sullivan, Eugenia Cheng and Judd Apatow.

title: YouTube Takes On Amazon With New Gaming App
description: About a year ago Google tried to acquire Twitch, the popular video game streaming site, but lost out to Amazon. Now it will try to build its own gaming portal.

title: Longtime Bush Adviser Focuses on Jebs Messaging
description: In the last week, there have been numerous news accounts about reassignments and changes in the political team being put together by Jeb Bush.

title: New Message on Frisking From de Blasios City Hall Amid Criticism
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York swept into office on a pledge to rein in police excesses of the Bloomberg administration, vowing to reverse the zealous use of stop-and-frisk tactics. After less than a year, he declared that part of his work complete.

title: Harper Lee Letters Fail to Sell at Auction
description: A collection of Harper Lees private letters failed to sell at auction at Christies on Friday. The six letters, which were written between 1956 and 1961 or were undated, were estimated to be worth between $150,000 and $250,000. The bidding opened at $80,000 and stopped at $90,000.

title: California Cuts Farmers Share of Scant Water
description: LOS ANGELES  Farmers with rights to California water dating back more than a century will face sharp cutbacks, the first reduction in their water use since 1977, state officials announced Friday. The officials said that rights dating to 1903 would be restricted, and that such restrictions would grow as the summer months go on, with the state facing a prolonged drought that shows few signs of easing.

title: The Week in Political Pictures
description: The Group of 7 meets in the Bavarian Alps, seersucker has its day, and Congress plays ball.

description: How can you rely on someones opinion of a book if you dont know what that person reads, and what else she likes?

title: What You Should Know About the Trans-Pacific Partnership
description: You can be forgiven if you havent been particularly riveted by the series of slick parliamentary maneuvers that the Obama administration and his congressional Republican allies are using to try to secure support for the trade deal known as the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

title: Deflating Deflategate
description: BEFORE Deflategate, the National Football Leagues most recent controversy, there was Bountygate, in which New Orleans Saints officials were accused of offering bonuses to Saints players who injured members of opposing teams  a policy alleged to have been in place from 2009 to 2011. Initially, several Saints officials and players were penalized by the N.F.L.

description: Laurie Bennett and Skip La Plante rolled into the Manhattan Marriage Bureau one afternoon a few weeks ago looking like anything but your average newlyweds.

description: Photos from Yemen, South Korea, the West Bank and Kashmir.

title: Jason Whitlock Out as Head of ESPN Website Built for Him
description: Jason Whitlock was replaced Friday as the head of The Undefeated, ESPNs website about the intersection of race and sports, just weeks before its planned kickoff.

title: Joshua Newmans Lawyers in Plea Talks in Fraud Case
description: Federal prosecutors and lawyers for Joshua B. Newman, a serial entrepreneur accused of defrauding more than a dozen investors out of at least $2 million, are engaged in plea negotiations, according to a June 10 court filing.

title: The Red Cross and the Mystery of Its Haiti Aid
description: No one should miss this: an eye-popping report from Justin Elliott of Pro Publica and Laura Sullivan of NPR about Haiti and the Red Cross.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: A Kids Camp on Catamarans
description: In partnership with Broadreach, a summer adventure learning program, Exclusive Resorts is offering a new summer kids camp aboard private catamarans in the Caribbean. Each of the two sessions of the Voyagers Camp  Aug. 2 to 9 and Aug. 9 to 16  starts in St. Martin and will give boys and girls between the ages of 10 and 16 the opportunity to snorkel, water ski, wakeboard, paddleboard, hike and earn a PADI Open Water scuba certification or International Yachting Certification.

title: Labors Inner Sanctum
description: Photographs of union offices around the world.

title: Work Spaces
description: Noel Bowler, an Irish photographer, has spent four years photographing the empty interior spaces of labor-union offices in 14 countries. He began the project, titled Union, during his M.F.A. studies in photography at the University of Ulster in Belfast. Bowler said the project was a way of engaging with the debate and conversation about the changes in the workplace, through an examination of the spaces that influence decision-making.

title: The Scene
description: Alex Mullins at London Collections Men.

title: Photo Diary: Alex Mullins Spring/Summer 2016
description: Scenes from London Collections Men, captured by Joshua Woods.

title: 400 Million Lack Basic Health Services, Report Finds
description: At least 400 million people lack access to essential health services, the World Health Organization and World Bank said Friday in a new report that they described as a wake-up call about the challenges to achieving universal health coverage.

title: The Very Big Downgrade
description: A multimillionaire undergoes a midlife crisis in reverse.

title: Me, My Dad and American Pharoah
description: When American Pharoah crossed the finish line in the Belmont Stakes on June 6, becoming the first Triple Crown winner in 37 years, I cried.

title: Antonio Marras Resort 2016
description: Looks from the collection.

title: REIT Gambit Buys Sears Time but Little Else
description: The hedge fund manager Edward S. Lampert is getting about $2.6 billion more to burn. Sears, the flailing United States retailer that Mr. Lampert has led since 2013, wants shareholders to exercise rights to capitalize a real estate investment trust that will buy 235 stores. The danger is that Sears will waste the cash.

title: Guantnamo Detainees Conviction Is Thrown Out on Appeal
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Friday threw out the conspiracy conviction of a detainee at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, ruling that bringing the charge before a tribunal was unconstitutional because an international war crime was not alleged.

title: Prom Accessories: Corsages, Limousines and Liability Waivers
description: Adam Wergeles, a corporate lawyer in Los Angeles, spent hours, if not days, sweating over a legal document this spring. Taking black pen to paper, he x-ed out words, added others, made notations in the margin and sought counsel from another lawyer.

title: Bill Cunningham | Flames in the Garden
description: Some of the 600 guests at the Frick Collections lawn and garden party wore the vibrant orange color of a painting that was the focus of the festivities.

title: The Aspirational R.S.V.P.: Saying Yes When You Mean No
description: Lets call it the aspirational R.S.V.P.  when someone replies yes to an invitation, even though he knows, or is fairly certain, that he cant or wont attend.

title: Bill Cunningham | Flames in the Garden
description: The annual Fifth Avenue lawn and garden party at the Frick Collection was an exceptional experience made only more so by the rarity of the Fifth Avenue garden thats part of the Gilded Age home. A painting was the focus of the festivities: Flaming June (above) by Fredrick Leighton, a Victorian artist and contemporary of James McNeill Whistler. It was shown alongside the Fricks four Whistlers. Some of the 600 guests wore the vibrant orange color of the painting. All of the guests made a big effort to dress for the occasion. Many of the Frick family members were present.

title: How Jane M. Rogers, Staten Island Yankees Executive, Spends Her Sundays
description: When the Staten Island Yankees begin their season on Friday, Jane M. Rogers, the teams president and general manager, may reflect on the day she answered a want ad for a secretary 16 years ago. She was an at-home mother who had never seen a minor-league baseball game; the Yankees had not yet come to Staten Island. I had no idea it was going to develop into a career, Ms. Rogers, 59, said. Now she handles all team logistics and her husband, Michael, a retired sanitation worker, manages the stadium. The two live in Tottenville with a Shih Tzu named Rocket Rogers. I hate to be called the team mom, she said. Sometimes they say that but I dont like it. I feel like Im sitting here baking cookies for them, which I dont. JOHN LELAND

title: Evening Hours | The Heat Turns Up
description: Food tastings, dances and fund-raisers.

title: Review: San Francisco Symphony Stages Missa Solemnis With a Visual Component
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Walking into Davies Symphony Hall here on Thursday evening, the audience was met with a promisingly unusual sight. Hanging above the stage were four large screens, more or less rectangular and arranged as if theyd been torn from one another to form a rough cross at the center. Dozens of smaller squares trailed from the rectangles on both sides, as if exploding outward from the cross  or, perhaps, rushing inward to form it.

title: Review: Alvin Ailey Troupe Dances Exodus at Koch Theater
description: When a choreographer creates a work for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, it can seem that only one option exists: try to make another Revelations. That, after all, is the signature work, the fail-safe masterpiece that closes nearly every performance. And although its representation of struggle and spiritual transcendence through dance has inspired many bad copies, it has also served as the model for many of the best pieces made for the troupe in recent years: Ronald K. Browns 1999 Grace, Rennie Harriss 2011 Home  and now, Mr. Harriss Exodus.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Review: A Reunited Luna Plays Brooklyns Northside Festival
description: It is a pretty momentous occasion, Sean Eden of Luna calmly observed between songs at the bands concert on Thursday evening in McCarren Park in Greenpoint. It was a homecoming of sorts: the first New York City appearance in a decade by a band that had distilled a certain New York sound. It was also the first big concert of this years Northside Festival, which is striving to become Brooklyns version of the South by Southwest festival in Austin and continues through the weekend.

title: Carbs, Georgian Style
description: Ton Caf provides a taste of home to Brighton Beachs Russian population.

title: Mexico Chases World Record: Biggest Selfie
description: The country that brought us the most Thriller dancers and biggest smooch fest is now attempting to collect another trophy: the worlds biggest selfie.

title: Comfort Food From the Caucasus, Served Up in Brooklyn
description: On a recent Friday evening in Brighton Beach, a cool breeze made its way inland from the water, and Ton Caf, New Yorks oldest Georgian bakery, seemed a wrinkle in time, the stations of immigration all represented at once. A jazz band played just loud enough to drown out the conversation of a middle-aged trio of Russians at the corner table, two men and a woman with weathered faces methodically making their way through a bottle of vodka. At another table, four young men, recent immigrants from the Caucasus, argued and laughed. At a third table, two American families were enjoying the food and wine.

title: Israels Gay Pride Parade
description: Thousands marched in Tel Avivs gay pride parade, including last years Eurovision song contest winner, the drag performer Conchita Wurst.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening! Heres the latest.

title: Review: Either/Or, at University Settlement, Is Inspired by Boredom and Writers Block
description: Writers block and boredom were the inspiration behind works presentedatUniversity Settlementon the Lower East Side by the new-music ensembleEither/Or.The good news: Anthony Coleman had managed to finish the score to his Flaubert/Sofa/Sentence ahead of time, andGiorgi Janiashvilis Muffling Fog: After Martin Heidegger was only intermittently dull. A performance that includes an on-screen, nude Hitler salute by one of the composers can be called many things, but not boring. For the most part, the evening felt like a protracted fit of artistic petulance and self-indulgence.

title: Review: Boston Early Music Festival Makes Monteverdi Its Main Attraction
description: BOSTON  To say that Monteverdi has swallowed the Boston Early Music Festival this year would not be quite right. That would, after all, take a considerable gulp.

description: In Noah Baumbachs recent movie, While Were Young, Josh and Cornelia, aging Generation X Brooklynites (played by Ben Stiller and Naomi Watts) who are desperately trying to reclaim their youth, are struck by what passes for home dcor in the Bushwick loft of their new, painfully on-trend young friends Jamie and Darby (Adam Driver and Amanda Seyfried).

title: Drawn & Quarterly: A Starting Syllabus and Creators to Watch
description: DOGS & WATER (2004) (ANDERS NILSEN) Man and his kind-of best friend in a post-apocalyptic dystopia; spare and haunting.

title: 25 Years of Drawn & Quarterly, Champion of Female Cartoonists
description: When the first issue of Drawn & Quarterly sneaked into comics shops in April 1990, it seemed as if its 23-year-old founder, editor and janitor, Chris Oliveros, was trying to single-handedly conjure a future for the testosterone-confused medium that most of his fellow fans and creators couldnt imagine.

title: Jenis Ice Cream Finds Listeria Again, and Closes Its Facilities
description: Just weeks after reopening, Jenis Splendid Ice Creams in Ohio has once again shuttered its production facility and retail locations after finding a potentially lethal food-borne bacteria in its factory.

title: Review: Hamari Adhuri Kahani Tours a Bad Marriage and the Jungle
description: For a romance, marriage  especially arranged marriage  does not get a good name in Mohit Suris florid melodrama Hamari Adhuri Kahani (Our Incomplete Story). The movie may suffer from a surfeit of excesses, but it does have arresting, if overwrought, things to say about domestic abuse in India.

title: Beach Rose Thrives in Salt and Sand
description: As thorny as it is beautiful, the beach rose is as close to native as you can get without originating here. It is happiest in nutrient-poor, shifting sands and gravel, where it grows in full sun, sprayed with sea salt day and night through all four seasons.

title: Beach Rose Thrives in Salt and Sand
description: As thorny as it is beautiful, the beach rose is as close to native as you can get without originating here. It is happiest in nutrient-poor, shifting sands and gravel, where it grows in full sun, sprayed with sea salt day and night through all four seasons.

title: Inside C-Squat
description: C-Squat is soon expected to pass into the hands of its residents, virtually all of them artists and musicians.

title: An Abrupt End to Brittney Griner and Glory Johnsons Marriage
description: The brief and tumultuous high-profile union between the professional basketball stars Brittney Griner and Glory Johnson appears to be ending in much the same way it began  with drama.

title: Photographs From the History of C-Squat, a Punk Homestead
description: When squatters moved into 155 Avenue C in the late 1980s, they found the brick walk-up gutted by fire and abandoned; they climbed between floors using ladders. They later hung stairs and rebuilt the building, which was called C-Squat and in the 90s became known for the punk shows in its basement.

title: The Dowdy Patient
description: So who is that dowdy person that always comes at lunchtime? my officemate asked.

title: Thom Browne Resort 2016
description: Looks from the collection.

title: A Tale of Two Cities, in 1886, and Events That Shaped a State
description: In 1886, 127 years before Bill de Blasio successfully invoked his tale of two cities metaphor to address income inequality, Henry George almost won the mayoralty of New York by juxtaposing the economic gains of the Gilded Age with the growth of poverty.

title: Review: Milkdreams Is Like Taking Dance Lessons From a Baby
description: If youre one of the more than 1,069,000 people who have watched the YouTube video Baby Modern Dance, or one of the more than 50,700 who have viewed the similar Milkdreams Rehearsal With Ivo, then you may have a sense of what goes on in Alexandra Bellers milkdreams. In those videos, a few adult dancers allow a delighted toddler  Ms. Bellers son Ivo Hart  to lead their rehearsal, following along with his resilient moves to cello music. Whether swatting the air or catching his own fall, Ivo turns out to be a resourceful improviser.

title: Trade Deals Setback Left Wall Street Unmoved. Why?
description: The rejection earlier today by the House of a bill that was seen as essential for President Obama to make progress on his ambitious agenda of tighter economic integration with the Asia Pacific region came as a major surprise to most commentators.

title: Chicago Court Gives Woman Frozen Embryos Despite Ex-Boyfriends Objections
description: In a closely watched, long-running dispute over who gets custody of frozen embryos when the man and woman who created them disagree, an appeals court in Chicago ruled 2 to 1 on Friday that a woman whose fertility was destroyed by cancer treatment could use embryos she created with her ex-boyfriend, over his objections.

title: Israels Abortion Committees
description: Tel Aviv

title: Honda Links a Rupturing Takata Airbag to a 7th Death
description: Honda Motor on Friday confirmed that a rupturing airbag inflater fatally wounded the driver of a 2005 Civic in a crash in April. Counting this, at least seven deaths have been linked to defective airbags made by the Japanese supplier Takata.

title: MERS Tarnishes Korean Presidents Image as Leader
description: SEOUL, South Korea  It used to be an often-cited story about Park Geun-hye, the president of South Korea: When her father, the longtime dictator Park Chung-hee, was assassinated by his spy chief in 1979, her first reaction was to ask whether there was any unusual movement by the North Korean military along the border.

title: Indianapolis Rallies Around Its Gay Citizens After a Law Sets Off a Flood of Support
description: INDIANAPOLIS  In a state perhaps best known for its hallowed speedway and lean-to-the-right politics, the pageantry of the past week might have seemed unexpected.

title: Review: H {N)Y P N(Y} OSIS, Out of This World, at Park Avenue Armory
description: What happens when the Park Avenue Armory puts its immense Wade Thompson Drill Hall at the disposal of an artist, and money is apparently no object?

title: Citys Diversity Effort Gets Financial Backers
description: New York Citys effort to promote diversity among the staffs, boards and audiences of its cultural organizations  announced earlier this year  has been buttressed by $150,000 from foundations. The most recent award, of $100,000, comes from the Ford Foundation to support the roll out of the plan after the citys Department of Cultural Affairs has completed a survey of arts groups later this year. The Mertz-Gilmore Foundation and the Rockefeller Brothers Fund each previously provided $25,000 to design the survey. Tom Finkelpearl, the departments commissioner, was to announce the new funding on Saturday during a presentation on diversity with Jane Chu, chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Arts, at the annual Americans for the Arts convention in Chicago. Getting a frank discussion started about the issue of diversity at cultural organizations is absolutely critical to the future of the sector and of the City, Darren Walker, the president of the Ford Foundation, said in a statement. The survey, designed by the firm Ithaka S+R, will collect data on the diversity at cultural organizations, taking into account factors like age, race, ethnicity, disability and gender.

title: Pakistan Warns Aid Groups to Follow Unspecified Rules
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  After the police shut down the offices of a major Western aid group, Pakistans interior minister warned Friday that other foreign organizations operating in Pakistan faced greater scrutiny and the possibility of expulsion if they failed to adhere to unspecified rules and laws.

title: Lightning RookieAndrei Vasilevskiy Steps Up Confidently
description: BRANDON, Fla.  The Tampa Bay Lightning conducted practice as usual on Friday but without their starting goalie, Ben Bishop. Their highly skilled forwards shared and carried the puck with ease, knifed past defenders and launched shot after shot.

title: Success of Kurdish Forces Is a Rare Bright Spot for U.S. Policy in Iraq
description: SULTAN ABDULLAH HILLS, Iraq  Since retaking these barren hills in northern Iraq from the jihadists of the Islamic State, Kurdish pesh merga forces have dug in: excavating trenches, unfurling barbed wire and coordinating with the United States-led military coalition to identify targets for airstrikes.

title: Tunisian Consular Workers Are Seized by Libyan Militia
description: TUNIS  An armed group stormed the Tunisian consulate in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, and kidnapped 10 consular employees on Friday, the Tunisian Foreign Ministry said in a communiqu.

title: No Putts on Sundays, but Bring Your Dog
description: The Sunday slumber for the Old Course, a rule dating back centuries, is simultaneously charming and maddening.

title: Sundays on the Old Course at St. Andrews: No Golfers Allowed
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  For those who arrive at the birthplace of golf on a sunny Sunday morning, the rules of play are simple. You can pretty much do anything you want on the historic grounds of the Old Course, as long as it does not involve actually hitting a drive or rapping a putt.

title: Young Murdoch Views TV as Real Killer App in a New Digital World
description: Soon after James Murdoch moved back to New York from London a few years ago, a friend introduced him to a young tech entrepreneur named Joe Marchese.

description: As big a setback as Fridays vote on Capitol Hill was for President Obamas efforts to advance his trade agenda, it was an even bigger rebuff for the leaders of American business.

title: Teenager Hopes to Skip School, of the Golf Variety
description: HARRISON, N.Y.  The Henderson family experienced failure last week. Before arriving at the Manulife L.P.G.A. Classic a few hours from their home in Ontario, Brooke Henderson and her father, Dave, had talked about the goal they wanted to hit during the week. Dad is the caddie and, knowing his daughters game as he does, said that three under par would be ideal. Brooke agreed.

title: Broken Boys, Thieves, Killers, and Now Escapees
description: The killers seemed the wrong match to put in adjoining cells, a combustible combination promising no good. They were both callous, early adopters of a life of lawlessness. They could be wily. One had demonstrated escape skills. The other was a systematic schemer, reading blueprints, sketching maps, mulling over the fine details of crime.

title: Dont Go to Music School
description: Cleveland Heights, Ohio

title: Accounting for the Benefits of Mideast Peace
description: In the endless Israeli-Palestinian conflict over claims to disputed land, what has been mostly lacking is a hard-nosed calculation of the benefits of peace, the costs of war and the gray zone of the status quo. A report published this month by the RAND Corporation, a nonpartisan think tank, attempts to offer that.

title: Many Choices for Obama in Replacing Billington at Library of Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Only 10 presidents have had the opportunity to nominate a librarian of Congress to oversee Americas largest trove of intellectual treasures and to serve as the chief of the sprawling research institution for the nations lawmakers.

title: Jack Dorsey Returns to Twitter as Chief, to Shrugs and Quips
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For the last two years, the normally dapper Jack Dorsey has hardly been seen at the offices of Twitter, the social networking company he co-founded, even though he works a block away. So he shocked many when he returned on Thursday with a beard so wild that his own mother made fun of it on Twitter.

title: Egyptian Doctors Shame Government With Facebook Images of Filthy State-Run Hospitals
description: In Egypt, where two presidents have been forced from office in the past four years after street protests largely organized on Facebook, the social network became a rallying point for anger at the countrys rulers again this week, in the form of a new page dedicated to showing images of deplorable conditions in state-run hospitals.

title: Westchesters Tortured Road
description: Another summer, another opportunity to ask the nagging question: When will Westchester County end its fight with the federal government over a court-ordered fair-housing plan, set aside its impassioned resistance to desegregation and get on with its life?

title: When Playing a Patient Is Part of the Training
description: Students training to be doctors and other health care professionals need practice, and at some schools, that means practicing on other students. But examining and being examined by classmates brings up significant privacy issues that schools need to address.

title: Scott Walkers Wisconsin Audition
description: Anticipating a Republican presidential bid by Scott Walker, the two-term governor of Wisconsin, both The New York Times Magazine and The Washington Monthly recently published lengthy articles about him. (The Times feature, which is in the magazine this weekend, was published online Friday.) Both articles focus on Walkers successful battles with labor. As they should: If he runs for president, his record of union-busting will be at the very center of his campaign.

title: White House Weighs Sanctions After Second Breach of a Computer System
description: WASHINGTON  The White House on Friday revealed that hackers had breached a second computer system at the Office of Personnel Management, and said that President Obama was considering financial sanctions against the attackers who gained access to the files of millions of federal workers.

title: In College, Big Hits Are Back, Back, Back
description: OMAHA  The American flag in center field at TD Ameritrade Park hung limp when Rhett Wiseman, the junior right fielder for Vanderbilt, the defending College World Series champion, stepped in on Friday afternoon for his turn in batting practice. Ten minutes later, the left-handed-hitting Wiseman counted six balls that had cleared the fence in right and right-center.

description: An internal memo paints a dismal picture of the Obama administrations efforts to counter messaging by the Islamic State.

title: ISIS Is Winning the Social Media War, U.S. Concludes
description: WASHINGTON  An internal State Department assessment paints a dismal picture of the efforts by the Obama administration and its foreign allies to combat the Islamic States message machine, portraying a fractured coalition that cannot get its own message straight.
