description: As the fifth inning of no-hit ball concluded, and Michael Pinedas night began to take on a historic sheen, Manager Joe Girardi could not keep himself from fretting.

title: Mets Are Shut Out by Blue Jays on Unfamiliar Ground
description: TORONTO  Only two ballparks in the major leagues have AstroTurf, and the Mets do not visit either very often. But Rogers Centre is one of them, so before their game Wednesday, the Mets were on the field, testing how it felt and played.

title: In Iowa, Bush Addresses a Burning Question: Why Jeb!?
description: PELLA, Iowa  Two days after announcing his entry into the presidential race, Jeb Bush engaged head-on perhaps the most glaring question about his campaign, when he was asked by a voter on Wednesday if his newly unveiled logo  Jeb!  was meant to dodge the family name.

title: In Iowa, Bush Addresses a Burning Question: Why Jeb!?
description: PELLA, Iowa  Two days after announcing his entry into the presidential race, Jeb Bush engaged head-on perhaps the most glaring question about his campaign, when he was asked by a voter on Wednesday if his newly unveiled logo  Jeb!  was meant to dodge the family name.

title: Cosmos Knock Off New York City F.C., Another Local Rival, in Open Cup
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Few people understand the dynamics of the United States Open Cup match between New York City F.C. and the New York Cosmos on Wednesday night better than Mike Petke, the former coach of the Red Bulls.

title: Nine Killed in Shooting at Black Church in Charleston
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  A white gunman opened fire Wednesday night at a historic black church in downtown Charleston, S.C., killing nine people before fleeing and setting off an overnight manhunt, the police said.

title: Bartolo Colon andR. A. Dickey Combine for Over 80 Years and Many Baffled Hitters
description: TORONTO  Travis dArnaud wandered over to the Blue Jays side of Rogers Centre on Wednesday afternoon, shaking hands and saying hello to friends he had made during his few years in the organization, before he was traded to the Mets.

title: The Shining, in Food Form
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: Standout Summer Products With Year-Round Staying Power
description: Each year, a slew of beach- and fruit-inspired beauty products hits the shelves in May and June, only to quickly disappear in favor of gourd- and spice-infused concoctions come fall. But this summer, a handful of sophisticated items have year-round staying power.

title: Recipes From Storm King, Inspired by the Artists Lynda Benglis and Luke Stettner
description: For this years Storm King Summer Solstice event, a starlit dinner in the fields of the Hudson Valley art center, the chefs Peter Hoffman, of the restaurant Back Forty West in New York City, and Shelley Boris, of Fresh Company in Garrison, New York, sought inspiration right on-site. This summers exhibitions at Storm King include Lynda Benglis: Water Sources, which features large-scale sculptures and fountains, including the joyful, voluminous Pink Lady sculptures that gave rise to the chefs chilled borscht with lavender cream and beet crystals; as well as an indoor/outdoor exhibition of Luke Stettners work, including a charcoal installation that inspired their stewed and grilled octopus with tarragon, lemon and olive oil. Ahead of the celebration this Saturday, chefs Hoffman and Boris shared recipes for the two dishes exclusively with T.

title: Few Vehicles Equipped for Easy Child Safety Seat Installation, Study Finds
description: Installing a child safety seat in a vehicle has been a confusing, sometimes difficult task for many parents. A new study released on Thursday has backed up many parents complaints, finding that only a handful of vehicles deserved the highest rating for ease of installation.

title: Word of the Day | amok
description: amok  \-mk, -mk\  adverb and adjective

title: Hong Kong Legislature Rejects Beijing-Backed Election Plan
description: HONG KONG  In quiet negotiations as well as public protests, they have pleaded and demanded for nearly two decades that Beijing allow Hong Kongs leader to be elected by the general public. But in a dramatic vote on Thursday, pro-democracy lawmakers here rejected a bill that could have been their last best chance to achieve that goal.

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE ASTRONAUT WIVES CLUB Life magazine bought the rights to their stories. Jacqueline Kennedy invited them to the White House. Created by Stephanie Savage (Gossip Girl) from Lily Koppels book, this series ventures into the kitchens and boudoirs of the First Ladies of Space: seven women with iconic last names  Carpenter, Cooper, Glenn, Grissom, Schirra, Shepard and Slayton  who kept their families grounded while their men shot for the stars. The series purports to tell the real story behind the Project Mercury publicity machine, but it is so enamored of the early-60s aesthetic that it cant resist adding its own flawless, cameo-faced gloss to its heroines, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. But the excitement is found not in motel rooms or boozy barbecues but inside the command center at NASA, where early launches were terrifying. The creators, she added, may have wanted to avoid belittling their heroines in a space age version of Desperate Housewives, but they did them a different disservice by sugarcoating them almost as much as NASA did some 50 years ago.

title: 60 Million People Fleeing Chaotic Lands, U.N. Says
description: UNITED NATIONS  Nearly 60 million people have been driven from their homes by war and persecution, an unprecedented global exodus that has burdened fragile countries with waves of newcomers and littered deserts and seas with the bodies of those who died trying to reach safety.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: This is America. I should be able to have a howitzer or a bazooka if I want one.

title: Neymars Red Card Adds to Brazils Loss at Copa Amrica
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Neymar, the superlative Brazilian soccer star, jumped over a sign barrier last month while celebrating a late Champions League goal and an imminent victory for Barcelona that was watched by tens of millions of viewers.

title: Elisabeth Elliot, Tenacious Missionary in Face of Tragedy, Dies at 88
description: Elisabeth Elliot, a missionary who inspired generations of evangelical Christians by returning to Ecuador with her toddler daughter to preach the Gospel to the Indian tribe that had killed her husband, died on Monday at her home in Gloucester, Mass. She was 88.

title: Reactions to the Defeat of the Hong Kong Election Plan
description: Hong Kongs legislature voted down a plan on Thursday to change how the semiautonomous Chinese territory chooses its leader. The package would have allowed voters to directly elect Hong Kongs top official in 2017, but pro-democracy politicians said the Chinese government-backed proposal placed too many controls on who could appear on the ballot.

title: Indias Earliest Photographers
description: For someone who ended up with the title Bold Warrior of Photography, Raja Deen Dayal started out rather cautiously. Instead of quitting his job as a surveyor at the Public Works Department in Indore, India, once he discovered photography in the 1870s, he waited about a decade before taking a two-year furlough to see if he could handle it.

But now, many have joined Western governments in opposing Beijings latest plan to impose new controls on foreign organizations.

title: Why Obamas Plan to Send Advisers to Iraq Will Fail
description: LAST week President Obama approved an additional 450 troops to join the roughly 3,000 already in Iraq. Living inside secure bases nicknamed lily pads, they will train Iraqi soldiers for a few weeks via lecture and drill instruction. The graduates will then be sent outside the wire to fight the Islamic State.

title: Destructive Health Care Proposals
description: Frustrated by their inability to repeal the Affordable Care Act and unable to produce a conservative alternative to replace it, House Republicans are moving two bills to repeal small but important provisions of the law  a tax on medical device manufacturers and an independent board to clamp down on out-of-control Medicare spending. The two bills would harm the federal budget and do nothing to help consumers, but were approved by the House Ways and Means Committee and are expected to pass the House on Thursday.

title: A Rebuke to Military Tribunals
description: In 2008, Ali al-Bahlul, a propagandist for Al Qaeda who has been held at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, since early 2002, was convicted by the military tribunal there and sentenced to life in prison. But officials had no evidence that Mr. Bahlul was involved in any war crimes, so they charged him instead with domestic crimes, including conspiracy and material support of terrorism.

title: What Its Like as a Girl in the Lab
description: ITS 7 p.m. on a Friday night, and Im still in the lab. Earlier in the day, as I was looking through old data, I unexpectedly found the answer to a question that Id been trying to address for a year. It was one of those rare eureka moments in science. But its not as though in an instant a spotlight fell on the pictures of cells Id been staring at, clearing up all mystery.

title: Church Massacre Suspect Held as Charleston Grieves
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  The mass murder of nine people who gathered Wednesday night for Bible study at a landmark black church has shaken a city whose history from slavery to the Civil War to the present is inseparable from the nations anguished struggle with race.

Theycarried the usual images of Mr. Xi leading his identically dressed entourage, as he shook hands and waved to well-wishing bystanders. Photos and videos seeminglyshared by onlookerson Weibo, the microblogging platform, did not diverge from the script.

title: Mali Must Disarm the Militias

The French, aided by the Chadian and Malian Armies, swiftly took back most of the territory controlled by the extremists. Their mission, Operation Serval, was held up as a rare example of a successful Western intervention against terrorist groups.

description: Chris Maiurro and Kathryn Bringle lived in a one-bedroom in South Park Slope, Brooklyn, the neighborhood where they had met seven years ago.

title: Review: Pixars Inside Out Finds the Joy in Sadness, and Vice Versa
description: Can movies think? This is a longstanding critical question, usually answered in the negative. Literature, the thinking goes, is uniquely able to show us the flow of thought and feeling from within, but the cameras eye and the two-dimensional screen cant take us past the external signs of consciousness. We can look at faces in various configurations of pleasure or distress, but minds remain invisible, mysterious, beyond the reach of cinema.

title: Getting More Children to Play (No League Necessary)
description: The crises in front of a commissioner can shift at any time. At the moment, Rob Manfred is closely monitoring a federal investigation into allegations that the St. Louis Cardinals illegally infiltrated the database of the Houston Astros. Of lesser concern, but still a potential embarrassment, is the possibility that eight Kansas City Royals will be voted to start the All-Star Game next month.

We know politicians are real folks who care about real folks because they are always using the word folks: city folks, country folks, hardworking folks, younger folks, older folks, black folks, white folks; even very kind folks in the media (says Ted Cruz), folks who are here undocumented (Chris Christie) and folks who dont have a full regard for the right to privacy (Rand Paul).

title: Letter of Recommendation: Farmer in the Deli
description: Near the northern border of Fort Greene, Brooklyn, at the corner of Myrtle and Adelphi, there is a grocery store called Farmer in the Deli, which is open all day and all night. In addition to a rather clunky pun for a name, Farmer also has a motto: We dont make sandwiches, we build them. Both of these things are nearly meaningless but give you a sense of the bravado that distinguishes this bodega from all the others lining Myrtle Avenue.

title: LeBron James Has Plenty of Virtues, but Humility Isnt Among Them

But in the aftermath of the Warriors convincing performance against the Cleveland Cavaliers, much of the focus was heaped on LeBron James, who turned in one of the most heroic performances in finals history yet failed to carry his team to a title.

title: Today in Politics: The Congressional Money Wars Are Heating Up
description: Good Thursday morning from Washington, where trade is back on the agenda and President Obama heads to the West Coast. The campaign trail remains active, but Jeb Bush canceled the last appearance of his announcement week blitz because of the mass shooting at a Charleston, S.C., church. In Congress, attention is returning to budget talks.

title: Comedy Central in the Post-TV Era
description: Backstage at Cobbs Comedy Club on the first Saturday in May, Trevor Noah, fresh from the stage, stood sweating through a blue T-shirt, beside a refrigerator stocked with energy drinks. He guzzled from a can as well-wishers popped into his dressing room, getting in their hellos and handshakes before Noahs second set of the evening. Noah is a 31-year-old comedian from South Africa, and in September, he is scheduled to take over for Jon Stewart as host of The Daily Show. For this reason, Noah gave an especially warm welcome to one backstage visitor: Kent Alterman, the president of content and original programming at Comedy Central, the network Noah had just joined. Alterman had flown from Los Angeles, where he lives and works, to San Francisco, where Cobbs is located, to watch Noah perform. He helped lead the search for Stewarts replacement, but tonight would be his first time seeing Noah work a crowd in person. Ive known Trevor a few years now, and hes someone weve had our eyes on, Alterman said. But Ive never actually seen him do stand-up before.

title: Morning Agenda: Wall Street Loses A Force of Nature
description: WALL STREET LOSES A FORCE OF NATURE  | With the death of James B. Lee Jr. on Wednesday, Wall Street lost one of its most colorful and influential deal makers,  Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in DealBook. Mr. Lee, a vice chairman of JPMorgan Chase, was an early pioneer of syndicated loans and played a key role in the world of leveraged buyouts and private equity, financing deals for Henry Kravis of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Stephen A. Schwarzman of the Blackstone Group and the late Theodore J. Forstmann of Fortsmann Little.

title: But Arent You Already Married? The Supreme Court, Same-Sex Marriage, and Kids
description: My wife and father have a wager on the pending Supreme Court marriage equality decision. Optimism is running strong on both sides: The bet assumes victory and is just a quibble over the split. My wife says 5-4; my father (always the idealist) says 6-3. The winner gets a bottle of 20-year-old port. Not Champagne? I asked. Oh, well be drinking that anyway, my wife said. And we will. We have, in fact, already set aside a few bottles. But in the midst of our anticipatory reveling Ive been wondering just how well explain the decision to our children.

title: In Iceland, Seeking a Luxury Hotel Amid the Rustic Charm
description: It was 3 a.m. by the time we turned down the desolate road that leads to the Ion Luxury Adventure Hotel, an hours drive east of Reykjavik, Iceland. Propped up by knock-kneed, tubular stilts, this ominously gorgeous Brutalist slab of glass, steel and concrete juts out from the base of Mount Hengill, an active volcano, over a mossy green lava field.

title: Nino Cerrutis Stylish Life, Told Through His Clothing
description: FLORENCE, Italy  I hate the word elegant, Nino Cerruti, arguably among the more elegant men of the 20th century and, at 84, perhaps also the 21st, said Tuesday morning. Its artificial.

title: Abercrombie & Fitch Reinvention Continues With New Creative Director
description: The reinvention of Abercrombie & Fitch continues apace. After covering up the barely clad store staff with actual shirts, making the randy-teenagers-romping-the-fields ads G-rated, and bringing in a new mens wear chief from Club Monaco, the retailer is capping it all off with the appointment of a new creative director: Katia Kuethe, former creative director of Lucky magazine.

description: South Korean automakers, originally seen as laggards in quality, are quickly closing the gap with their competitors, a major study shows.

description: Needless to say, theres a lot to explore in Pope Franciss encyclical, Laudato Si  On the Care of Our Common Home, so Ill be doing a string of posts, as time permits, on particular sections. This is not a climate encyclical. It is about humanitys relationship with the environment, including through agricultural practices. [Read Justin Gillis on the climate elements, and explore this annotation of environmental passages by Gillis and The Timess religion reporter Laurie Goodstein.]

title: Greece Deal Still Possible, Merkel Says
description: Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, said that Germany aimed to keep Greece in the eurozone and that there would be a deal with creditors if Greek leaders were willing.

title: Classical Playlist: Sibelius, Dvorak and Zorn
description: SIBELIUS: Complete Works for Mixed ChoirHeikki Seppanen, conductor; Estonian Philharmonic Chamber Choir(Ondine)If you mostly know Sibelius from his visionary symphonies, you might be surprised by the works on this two-disc set. The Finnish choral tradition was rich and active when Sibelius came of age as a composer in the late 1880s, and he wrote choral works all his life, from his student days in Helsinki until 1954 when, at 89 and three decades after his final symphony, he did an arrangement of a favorite Christmas song. The pieces on this rewarding recording range from folk songs suffused with Finnish character to enigmatic works with sometimes dark lyrics. There are festival and school songs, patriotic anthems, a cantata for an academic degree ceremony and, inevitably, two versions of Finlandia. Most of the pieces are a cappella. Many unfold in clear, block-chord settings of the texts. If you want to stump friends with a guessing game, play the beguiling, slightly strange Glade of Tuoni from this recording and ask them to identify the composer. Youll win, as you will by picking up this album. (Anthony Tommasini)DVORAK: Symphony No. 9; VARSE: Amriques Ludovic Morlot, conductor; Seattle Symphony(Seattle Symphony Media)It seems at first a bit perverse, pairing Dvoraks warm and friendly New World Symphony with Varses bellicose and blistering vision of new worlds. More fascinating in any case than the theme of the composers physical and psychic encounters with new worlds, whether fleeting or permanent, is the distance musical possibilities themselves had traveled in the mere three decades between the Dvorak (1893) and the Varse (1922), the great watershed having been Stravinskys The Rite of Spring (1913), which Varse mines for all it is worth. The live performances here do equal justice to the coziness and the riotous upheavals. (James R. Oestreich)JOHN ZORN: Hen to PanJay Campbell, cello; Stephen Gosling, piano; Michael Nicolas, cello; Chris Otto, violin; Tyshawn Sorey, drums(Tzadik)The one constant in this feverishly changeable recording of recent chamber works is Mr. Campbell, an amazing musician whos game for both Mr. Zorns technical challenges and his permeating intensity. Much of this album is taken up by three iterations of Ouroboros (2014), a seething, frenetic duet for two cellos that can also be performed with an improvising drummer (here the skittering Tyshawn Sorey). The poise of the gorgeous piano trio The Aristos (2014) and the delicacy of Occams Razor (2013), for cello and piano, are mixed in with uncertainty and collapse. The extremes to which Mr. Zorn flings his performers and listeners are not in themselves new, or newly juxtaposed, but he writes with such sensitivity, assurance and joy that it always somehow seems fresh. (Zachary Woolfe)

title: Theologian Condemns Ecological Sin
description: Metropolitan John Zizioulas of Pergamon says that the environmental crisis is a spiritual problem, during a news conference on Thursday about Pope Francis encyclical on climate change.

title: U.S.G.A. Prizes the Flexibility of the Open Course; the Players Are Less Sure
description: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash.  Mike Davis, the executive director of the United States Golf Association, has heard the emotional critiques of the worlds best golfers as they assess the idiosyncratic layout of Chambers Bay Golf Course, the site of the United States Open.

title: Daily Report: Uber Ruling Spurs Debate Over Workers
description: In a ruling that fuels a long-simmering debate over some of Silicon Valleys fastest-growing technology companies and the work they are creating, the California Labor Commissioners Office said that a driver for the ride-hailing service Uber should be classified as an employee, not an independent contractor, Mike Isaac and Natasha Singer report.

title: Taliban Strike Crucial District in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban fighters overran part of a crucial district in the southern province of Helmand early Thursday, residents of the area said, demonstrating the insurgents growing power in an area that American and British troops had long fought to keep out of Taliban control.

title: Checkmating the Presidential Debates
description: Imagine a presidential debate in which the two finalists have far more power to clash on the show, partisan audience claques are barred, social media are offered innovative roles, and a chess clock format allows a candidate to slap an interruption of an adversarys point for instant rebuttal. No less fantastic, imagine a format that scrapped the noxious post-debate Spin Alley where partisan cadres of campaign gurus immediately descend to massage news workers with corrective nuances, postscripts and bromides while the debate stories are still being written.

title: Photo Released of Church Attack Suspect
description: Police in Charleston, S.C., released a surveillance photo of the man suspected of killing nine people in a church on Wednesday night.

title: Scott Walker Moves Toward Candidacy With Fund-Raising Arm
description: Scott Walkers official entry into the presidential race came a step closer on Thursday when the Wisconsin governor sought contributions to a newly created testing the waters committee.

description: Scott Walkers official entry into the presidential race came a step closer on Thursday when the Wisconsin governor sought contributions to a newly created testing the waters committee.

title: With Tourist Missing, Worry Spreads on Camino de Santiago in Spain
description: MADRID  Like many thousands of people from around the world, Denise Thiem, an American tourist, was inspired by a 2010 movie called The Way when she set out three months ago to walk the Camino de Santiago, an ancient Catholic pilgrimage whose popularity has grown significantly in recent years.

title: Review: In William Larsons Fireflies, Fax Transmissions as Art
description: Before there was email or the Internet, there was the revolutionary fax machine. In a statement accompanying this show, the photographer William Larson describes seeing a demonstration of the technology in 1969, in which an image of a well-known celebrity (Muhammad Ali) was sent from Chicago to Philadelphia. The transmission took six minutes, and Mr. Larson, witnessing the event in Philadelphia, was impressed by the pictures high quality. After this, he obtained a Graphic Sciences DEX 1 Teleprinter for the Tyler School of Art at Temple University, where he taught. From 1969 to 1978, he made the electro-carbon prints on view here.

title: Vice Gets a New Columnist: A Founding Member of Pussy Riot
description: After being an artist, activist, inmate, speaker and actor, Nadya Tolokonnikova is adding another title to her rsum: online columnist.

title: Candidates React to Charleston Church Shooting
description: The church shooting in Charleston, S.C., happened as the city was the focus of attention in the presidential race, with Hillary Rodham Clinton appearing in the area Wednesday and Jeb Bush scheduled there today (he canceled his appearance because of the events). The Timess live blog on the shooting captures reaction from the candidates.

title: Candidates React to Charleston Church Shooting
description: The church shooting in Charleston, S.C., happened as the city was the focus of attention in the presidential race, with Hillary Rodham Clinton appearing in the area Wednesday and Jeb Bush scheduled there today (he canceled his appearance because of the events). The Timess live blog on the shooting captures reaction from the candidates.

title: 1915: British Hero Dies In Accident
description: Flight Sub-Lieutenant R.A.J. Warneford, the gallant young British aviator who ten days ago destroyed a Zeppelin airship single-handed and returned safely to the British lines, to be rewarded with the Victoria Cross and the Cross of the Legion of Honor, is dead  killed by a fall while making a trial flight on a new machine at the Buc aerodrome near Paris. The tragic accident, which has cut short a career of great promise and robbed England of the valued servant who first pricked the Zeppelins bubble reputation of invulnerability to aeroplane attack, occurred at five oclock on Thursday afternoon.  The New York Herald, European Edition, June 19, 1915

title: Thinking About the All Too Thinkable
description: The path toward non-Grexit  toward Greece and its creditors reaching a deal that keeps it in the euro  is getting narrower, although its not yet completely closed. Ive been reticent on the subject, for fear of adding my bit to the crisis atmosphere, and I still intend to keep it cool. But there are a few things that seem to need saying.

title: Thinking About the All Too Thinkable
description: The path toward non-Grexit  toward Greece and its creditors reaching a deal that keeps it in the euro  is getting narrower, although its not yet completely closed. Ive been reticent on the subject, for fear of adding my bit to the crisis atmosphere, and I still intend to keep it cool. But there are a few things that seem to need saying.

title: Dow Jones Begins New Round of Layoffs
description: Dow Jones, the parent company of The Wall Street Journal, began a sweeping round of job cuts on Thursday, including eliminating entire teams of reporters and closing international bureaus.

title: Mr. Curry
description: Not quite British-style curries in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Mr. Curry Speaks Its Own Language
description: The curry at Mr. Curry, a wonderful, evanescent, not-quite-restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, owes allegiance less to a particular nation than to a state of mind.

title: Distant British Past Is Also Present for Salisbury
description: SALISBURY, England  Arthur Pendragon, in his robes and sword, his queen by his side, stood in the long shadow of Salisburys magnificent cathedral, which has Britains tallest spire and the best-preserved of the four surviving copies of Magna Carta. He was fulminating happily about the intrinsic rights of English men and women, prevented from free access to the other nearby magnificent place of worship, Stonehenge.

title: Viewfinder: Claudia Ficca and Davide Luciano
description: Work from Claudia Ficca and Davide Luciano, who recreate scenes from The Shining using food.

title: Fashion Is Unavoidable at Pitti Uomo
description: FLORENCE, Italy  During the Pitti Uomo trade show, mens fashion is unavoidable. It spills into the streets, busy with the double-breasted jacket brigade. At the sacred aperitivo hour in the Piazza Ognissanti, the crowds sipping spritzers on the terrace of the St. Regis hotel were treated to an alfresco fashion show by Ports 1961. Guests on a balcony of the nearby Westin Excelsior watched, too, and there were faces pressed to the windows at office buildings and residences around the square.

title: Fitbit Shares Surge 48 Percent in Market Debut
description: Shares of Fitbit soared in their trading debut on Thursday, even after the company priced its initial public offering above an already heightened range.

title: Restaurant Report: Prima in Honolulu
description: When you pull up to this highly regarded restaurant in one of Honolulus sprawling suburbs, the first instinct is to double-check your GPS. The ambitious culinary experiment is bizarrely sandwiched in a plaza between a Foodland grocery store and a Baskin-Robbins.

title: Blurring the Museum-Gallery Divide
description: Ever since Mark Rosenthal left his job as head of 20th-century art at the National Gallery in Washington to become an independent curator, museums around the country have sought his talents. Now art galleries are trying to hire him, too  but not just for his scholarship.

title: Hotel Review: Praktik Bakery Hotel in Barcelona
description: From 89 euros a night, or about $96 at $1.08 to the euro.

title: With Charleston Shooting, a Time to Stop Teaching Children About the History of Racial Violence
description: In the wake of violence and tragedies, I often find myself writing about, and thinking about, how to approach the topic with my children, who may be frightened by the facts or, at an older age, by our inability to offer a satisfying explanation for why people do the terrible things they sometimes do.

title: Anish Kapoor Sculpture Vandalized at Versailles
description: PARIS  Vandals spray-painted an enormous, curved sculpture in the garden of the 17th-century palace of Versailleson Wednesday that its creator, Anish Kapoor, had once characterized as a sexual symbol of the vagina of a queen taking power.

title: Anish Kapoor Sculpture Vandalized at Versailles
description: PARIS  Vandals spray-painted an enormous, curved sculpture in the garden of the 17th-century palace of Versailleson Wednesday that its creator, Anish Kapoor, had once characterized as a sexual symbol of the vagina of a queen taking power.

title: A Clip from the Film Eden
description: Flix de Givry and Greta Gerwig star in a film about the rise of electronic music in Paris.

title: Romancing Authors
description: Jonathan Galassi, the longtime head of Farrar, Straus & Giroux, didnt stray far for the setting of his first novel, Muse, which takes place in the world of New York publishing. (Erica Wagner reviews Muse this week.)

title: A Right Age to Change One's Sex?
Israeli Police Investigate Arson at Loaves and Fishes Church
description: JERUSALEM  A Catholic church at a revered site near the Sea of Galilee in northern Israel was damaged by fire early on Thursday, in what the police are treating as an arson attack and possible hate crime.

title: Richard Zabel, Bhararas Deputy, Moves to Elliott Management
description: If Preet Bhararas office were adapted for a Hollywood script, Richard B. Zabels character would probably be akin to Dr. John Watson or perhaps Mr. Spock, a trusted lieutenant to a prominent leading man.

title: Supreme Court Says Texas Can Reject Confederate Flag License Plates
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that Texas did not violate the First Amendment when it refused to allow specialty license plates bearing the Confederate battle flag. Such plates, Justice Stephen G. Breyer wrote for the majority, are the governments speech and are thus immune from First Amendment attacks.

title: Rob Delaney, a Hit on Twitter, Turns to Television With Catastrophe
description: Rob Delaney is onstage at the Bell House in Brooklyn, telling jokes about deviant sex acts with a car commercial smile.

title: Limits on Church Signs Ruled Unconstitutional
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Thursday unanimously ruled that an Arizona town had violated the First Amendment by placing limits on the size of signs announcing church services.

title: In Brian Williams Decision, NBC Clings to the Past
description: In the end, NBC decided that it couldnt bring him back or let him go.

title: Ex-Rikers Captain Is Sentenced to 5 Years in Inmates Death
description: A former captain at Rikers Island was sentenced on Thursday to five years in prison for violating the civil rights of an inmate, Jason Echevarria, who died after swallowing a soap ball under the captains supervision.

title: When Doctors Dont Talk to Doctors
description: I could tell my patient was dying. In the final stage of liver failure, she lay listlessly in her hospital bed, her skin ashen and her eyes dull. Intractable intestinal bleeding, likely related to her underlying disease, had landed her in the intensive care unit. Although all patients in intensive care are tenuous, it was clear she was worse off than most.

title: Arianna Huffington Renews Contract for Four Years
description: Arianna Huffington, a founder of The Huffington Post, has signed a new four-year contract to remain chairwoman, president and editor in chief of the publication, ending speculation that she might leave now that its parent company, AOL, was acquired by Verizon.

title: 1940: Hitler And Mussolini Meet in Munich
description: In the midst of Nazi military pomp, Fuehrer Adolf Hitler and his eleventh-hour ally Premier Mussolini met today [June 15] in Munich where on Sept. 19, 1938, peace in our time was arranged through the partitioning of Czecho-Slovakia. In a four-hour conference, they agreed on the attitude to be assumed by the German and Italian governments towards the French requests for an armistice. Traveling presumably in opposite directions, the two dictators left Munich soon after their meeting ended.  New York Herald Tribune, June 19, 1940

title: Fathers Day  Solved!
description: There are two types of fathers: those who say, Dont get me anything for Fathers Day and mean it, and those who say the same thing and dont.

title: House Sends Trade Bill Back to Senate in Bid to Outflank Foes
description: WASHINGTON  The House on Thursday approved a bill to give President Obama accelerated negotiating authority to pursue a sweeping, legacy-building trade agreement with 11 Pacific Rim nations, Part 1 of a complex legislative strategy devised by Republicans to get a trade package to Mr. Obamas desk after Democrats derailed the measure in the House last week.

title: Londons Most Ramshackle Saturday Market
description: Some of Londons most historic markets, such as Spitalfields, have been swept up in a wave of regeneration that leaves niche businesses withering in the wake of big brands. Smithfield, the capitals 800-year-old meat market is the next (contentiously) earmarked for a facelift. Others, like Borough Market  nowadays more of a gourmet tourist destination than a local amenity  are victims of their own success. Which makes below-the-radar spots like Netil Market, a small community of creative start-ups in London Fields, to the east of the city, such a rarity. This motley assortment of sheds, vans and shipping crates, which sits in the shadow of the London Overground, has a charming, if ramshackle, feel. Theres a barber, an optician, a jeweler and lots of street food vendors, says Paul Firmin, a co-founder of the lifestyle boutique and scent brand Earl of East London, which launched on the market last summer. Its like a little modern-day High Street.

title: Papal Encyclical Heartens Proponents of Fossil-Fuel Divestment
description: The word divestment is nowhere to be found in the nearly 200 pages of the papal encyclical released Thursday, but by addressing the threat of climate change in such a forceful way, Pope Francis is likely to add momentum to the movement by big institutions to sell holdings tied to fossil-fuel stocks.

title: Making Video Games For Everyone (Not Just the Able-Bodied)
description: In the video game Perception, sound is as important as sight  if not more so. Start the games trailer and youll enter the aural landscape of a haunted house, complete with flapping moths, creaking doors, a creepy talking doll and, amid it all, the regular taps of the heroines cane.

title: Dylann Roof, Suspect in Charleston Shooting, Flew the Flags of White Power
description: LEXINGTON, S.C.  The Facebook profile picture chosen by Dylann Storm Roof in May is thick with symbolism. It shows Mr. Roof, a scowling young white man, wearing a black jacket adorned with two flags  one from apartheid-era South Africa, the other from white-ruled Rhodesia  that have been adopted as emblems by modern-day white supremacists.

title: New DNA Results Show Kennewick Man Was Native American
description: In July 1996, two college students were wading in the shallows of the Columbia River near the town of Kennewick, Wash., when they stumbled across a human skull.

title: F.C.C. Votes to Move Forward With Plan to Subsidize Broadband for Poor Americans
description: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday voted along party lines to approve a proposal to explore subsidizing broadband Internet for poor Americans. The plan, introduced last month by the agencys Democratic chairman, Tom Wheeler, helps pave the way for sweeping changes to a $1.7 billion phone subsidy program.

title: F.C.C. Votes to Move Forward With Plan to Subsidize Broadband for Poor Americans
description: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday voted along party lines to approve a proposal to explore subsidizing broadband Internet for poor Americans. The plan, introduced last month by the agencys Democratic chairman, Tom Wheeler, helps pave the way for sweeping changes to a $1.7 billion phone subsidy program.

title: The Shootings in a Charleston Church
description: Where the attack happened, some statistics behind hate crimes, and maps of Charlestons shifting population.

title: Full Speech: Obama on Charleston Attack
description: The president spoke on Thursday about the church shooting in Charleston, S.C., and expressed his deep sorrow over the senseless murders that took place Wednesday night.

title: Obama on Gun Violence in America
description: The president discussed the shooting in Charleston, S.C., saying, We as a country will have to reckon with the fact that this type of mass violence does not happen in other advanced countries.

title: Review: True Detective, Season 2 on HBO, Plays a Symphony of Misery
description: There are plenty of people who insist that auteur-driven television series like True Detective are the 19th-century novels of the visual age. Thats certainly arguable, though in fairness, the compliment should go both ways  Balzac, Dickens and Trollope are the showrunners of the written word.

title: The Real Town Behind True Detective Season 2
description: Vernon, Calif., The Times wrote in 2011, is a bleak, 5.2-square-mile sprawl of warehouses, factories, toxic chemical plants and meat processors that looks like the backdrop for Eraserhead, the David Lynch movie set in an industrial wasteland.

title: The Real Town Behind True Detective Season 2
description: Vernon, Calif., The Times wrote in 2011, is a bleak, 5.2-square-mile sprawl of warehouses, factories, toxic chemical plants and meat processors that looks like the backdrop for Eraserhead, the David Lynch movie set in an industrial wasteland.

title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Looking for something to do this weekend?

title: The Charleston Shooting: What Happened
description: A 21-year-old white man is suspected of opening fire on a prayer meeting he had been attending at an African-American church in Charleston, S.C., on Wednesday night.  Nine people were fatally shot before he fled in a black sedan. (Our live blog has the latest.) This is security footage of him entering the church.

title: Clues to the Mood for True Detective, Season 2, on HBO
description: Before the first season of HBOs True Detective, all anyone really knew about the show was that it involved a grisly murder in Louisiana and that it featured two bona fide movie stars: Matthew McConaughey and Woody Harrelson. Then it became a hit, stirring the Internet into a frenzy and earning 12 Emmy nominations.

title: Paintings First Time in New York? No Way, No How, Says Brooklyn Man
description: Its not often that art history  even a small, relatively recent piece of it  is rewritten by a retired school-bus-company manager from Brooklyn. But thats what happened this week, when Ed Miranda, of East Flatbush, read a review in The New York Times of an exhibition at the Frick Collection featuring Frederic Leightons lush Victorian masterpiece, Flaming June, which the museum said has made its maiden voyage to New York from its permanent home at the Museo de Arte de Ponce in Puerto Rico.

title: Paintings First Time in New York? No Way, No How, Says Brooklyn Man
description: Its not often that art history  even a small, relatively recent piece of it  is rewritten by a retired school-bus-company manager from Brooklyn. But thats what happened this week, when Ed Miranda, of East Flatbush, read a review in The New York Times of an exhibition at the Frick Collection featuring Frederic Leightons lush Victorian masterpiece, Flaming June, which the museum said has made its maiden voyage to New York from its permanent home at the Museo de Arte de Ponce in Puerto Rico.

title: Douglas Carter Beane Returns to His Childhood Home
description: READING, PA.  Douglas Carter Beane took the bus here from Manhattan because he still doesnt drive, never has. He bypassed that rite of passage nearly 40 years ago, too busy making theater to care. As a teenager in Wyomissing, a comfortable suburb just across the Schuylkill, he dreamed of a future in New York City. Who would need a drivers license there?

title: Resurrecting Inges Aching Empathy in Off the Main Road
description: For much of the 1950s, William Inge was atop the Broadway heap. He wrote four successful plays. He won a Pulitzer and an Oscar.

title: Weekday Car Traffic to Be Banned in Parts of Central and Prospect Parks
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Thursday that he will close large parts of New York Citys two most celebrated parks to car traffic on weekdays.

title: Brian Williams Gets New Role at Lower Salary
description: After four months of twisting in the wind, Brian Williams can finally get back to work at NBC, but not without a humbling blow. Mr. Williamss return includes a demotion, a lower salary and an apology tour that began on Thursday with NBC News staff members in New York and Washington, and will continue on national television with an interview on the Today show on Friday.

title: Time to Catch Up on Baseball
description: Now that the basketball and hockey playoffs are over, its time to test your knowledge of the baseball season so far.

title: Lil Quinquin and The Wire: Crimes in a Small Town and a Big City
description: A onetime professor of philosophy, Bruno Dumont may be the most high-minded exponent of the discomfitingly visceral art films that have been called the New French Extremity or cinma du corps.

title: In Report on Data Collection Practices, WhatsApp and AT&T Fail the Test
description: In the post-Snowden era, tech companies are increasingly being rated not only for the quality of their gadgets and services, but also for how they handle government requests for customer data. In the Electronic Frontier Foundations annual report on data collection practices, tech companies like Yahoo, Apple and Adobe earned top marks, while WhatsApp and AT&T came in last.

title: In Report on Data Collection Practices, WhatsApp and AT&T Fail the Test
description: In the post-Snowden era, tech companies are increasingly being rated not only for the quality of their gadgets and services, but also for how they handle government requests for customer data. In the Electronic Frontier Foundations annual report on data collection practices, tech companies like Yahoo, Apple and Adobe earned top marks, while WhatsApp and AT&T came in last.

title: Still Deadlocked With Greece, Europe Sets Emergency Summit Meeting
description: LUXEMBOURG  European leaders will try again in an emergency summit meeting on Monday to break the deadlock between Greece and its international creditors after a meeting of eurozone finance ministers ended on Thursday with no deal on Greeces bailout.

title: Charleston Church Shooting Suspect Is Captured
description: Charlestons police chief said that the suspect in the shooting at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church was caught in Shelby, N.C.

title: Kacey Musgraves and Other Tomatoes Give Country Its Bite
description: When Kacey Musgraves had her Nashville breakthrough two years ago, she was, depending on the angle you viewed her from, an outsider hero or a savvy infiltrator. Her musical tastes skewed toward the 1950s and the 70s, and her subject matter skewed liberal  even when she was singing about marijuana or same-sex love, she did it under a traditionalist cloak.

title: Who Can Identify Themselves as Black?  Reporters Notebook
description: In the digital world, opinions travel with gigabit quickness. Everyone is a pundit and everyone has the right answer.

title: A Bauhaus-Style Villa
description: The home was designed by Arthur Korn, who fled Nazi Germany in the 1930s.

title: Beyond Climate  A Hidden Gem in the Popes Encyclical on Making Social Media Matter
description: The main conversation around Pope Franciss remarkable encyclical letter is appropriately on the core messages  that human-driven climate change is dangerous; access to energy matters; that consumptive capitalism is a problem, not a solution.

title: Charleston Church Shooting Suspect Is Captured
description: Charlestons police chief said that the suspect in the shooting at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church was caught in Shelby, N.C.

title: Denmark Votes in Close Race
description: Prime Minister Helle Thorning-Schmidt and the opposition leader Lars Lokke Rasmussen cast their votes Thursday in Copenhagen.

title: After Charleston Shooting, a Sense at the White House of Horror, Loss and Resolve
description: WASHINGTON  The shooting massacre of a black pastor and his parishioners at a South Carolina church on Wednesday night once again confronted President Obama with a moment of racial turmoil in a country that for all its progress has yet to completely shed the burden of hatred and division.

title: A Trove of 19th-Century Engravings Conjures a Lost World
description: In storage for more than a hundred years, thousands of 19th-century graphics and medals designed by Rudolph P. Laubenheimer, a self-described engraver, die sinker and medailleur, will be auctioned this month. The sale, run by Archives International Auctions in Manhattan on June 25, was initiated by his descendants in Maine and will offer part of the contents of Laubenheimers New York City workshop.

title: Officer Fatally Shoots a Man Who Slashed Him in Brooklyn
description: A 58-year-old man who attacked a uniformed New York City police officer with a knife near an elevated Brooklyn subway station on Thursday was shot dead by the officer after he refused to drop the knife, police officials said.

title: Fishing Camps Move Beyond Tents
description: Historically a sport for bare-bones tent camping, fly fishing is upping its game, said Mike Fitzgerald, the president of Frontiers Travel, which specializes in fly-fishing trips and other excursions for the outdoorsy type.

title: Canadian Senator Expelled From Partys Caucus Over Claims of Affair With Teenager
description: OTTAWA  The governing Conservative Party removed a member of Canadas Senate from its caucus on Wednesday night after The Toronto Star reported that he had had an extramarital affair with a teenage girl.

title: Hungarys Plan to Build Fence to Deter Migrants Is Criticized
description: LONDON  The European Union was supposed to be about breaking down borders and barriers. But critics say that message appears to have been lost on Hungary, which drew international condemnation this week for its governments plans to erect a fence along the Serbian border to keep out migrants.

title: Teva Ruling Clears Way for Generic Version of Multiple Sclerosis Drug
description: The first generic version of a multiple sclerosis drug went on the market Thursday, hours after a federal appeals court again invalidated a patent for the brand-name drug, Copaxone, a major moneymaker for Teva Pharmaceutical.

title: In Athens, Austerity Makes Contemporary Art Palatable
description: Austerity measures have been bad for Greeks, but good for tourism, which shot up 28.8 percent in the first three months of this year compared with the same period in 2014. Another beneficiary? Artists. Rent for studio space is significantly cheaper than in other European capitals, and the political and economic turmoil have provided plenty of artistic fodder  not to mention a frustrated, attentive audience. In the wake of these woes, artists, curators, critics and nonprofits are finding that contemporary art is having its moment in a city best known as the epicenter of the ancient world.

title: The Murders at Mother Emanuel Church in Charleston
description: The shooting in Charleston on Wednesday night left nine people dead  nine worshipers who had come to the historic Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church for peace and evening prayers. Witnesses said the white shooter was muttering deeply racist comments as he fired into the predominantly African-American congregation. If so, this was a crime bred by a particularly craven form of racial hatred. And it raises disturbing questions about how another obsessed individual in America got his hands on another deadly weapon.

title: Royal Ascot Style Guide
description: The five-day Royal Ascot meet in England requires its patrons to adhere to strict dress codes.

title: A Scrimshaw Collectors Treasured Carvings
description: Collecting scrimshaw is a dicey hobby, given the prevalence of forgeries in the field  plastic resin copies are known as fakeshaw.

title: In Basel, Resting Spots for the Weary
description: The sheer number of sectors at Art Basel  Galleries, Statements and Feature on the Messeplatz, plus the gigantic Unlimited and the intimate public art of Parcours, in a charming medieval courtyard across town  can make scurrying around to check out all the work a bit exhausting. Its convenient, then, that the worldwide uptick in interactive art spectacles has provided fairgoers and exhibitors something that can ease weary bodies: a place to sit down.

title: In Basel, Resting Spots for the Weary
description: The sheer number of sectors at Art Basel  Galleries, Statements and Feature on the Messeplatz, plus the gigantic Unlimited and the intimate public art of Parcours, in a charming medieval courtyard across town  can make scurrying around to check out all the work a bit exhausting. Its convenient, then, that the worldwide uptick in interactive art spectacles has provided fairgoers and exhibitors something that can ease weary bodies: a place to sit down.

title: Hilary Masters, Novelist and Son of American Poet, Dies at 87
description: For a 7-year-old, Hilary Masters sounded precociously lyrical when he arrived in New York for the first time and remarked, Oh, boy, Mom, what glory is ahead of me!

title: Currency Demotion Strikes Unwelcome Chord at Hamilton Rehearsal
description: The cast of Hamilton is feeling giddy. Their show, which begins performances on Broadway next month, is the talk of the town, and is selling well. Their subject, Alexander Hamilton, is resurgent in the popular imagination. But on Thursday, as they gathered to begin rehearsals, there was one sour note in the air: just aday earlier, the Treasury Department announced that it was going to redesign the $10 bill to feature a woman, keeping Hamilton on the currency, but presumably in a less prominent position.

title: Currency Demotion Strikes Unwelcome Chord at Hamilton Rehearsal

title: How the Search for Dylann Roof Unfolded
description: After a deadly shooting at Emanuel A.M.E. Church in Charleston, S.C., details of the case and suspect were released, intentionally and by mistake, and an arrest was made in less than 24 hours.

title: Killings Add Painful Page to Storied History of Charleston Church
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church is one of the oldest, most storied black congregations in the South. Its members met in secret in the years when black churches were outlawed here before the Civil War, and it contains a shrine to one of its founders, who helped organize a slave revolt in 1822.

title: Killings at a Black Church in Charleston
description: To the Editor:

title: Long-Lost Merce Cunningham Work Is Reconstructed in Boston
description: Merce Cunningham used chance to choreograph his legendary solo dance Changeling. Now chance has given new life to this long-lost work.

title: A Retrospective of Wall Painting in Chelsea
description: When somethings painted directly on the wall, it has a certain immediacy and freshness, said Mel Bochner, the conceptual artist whose word paintings were inspired partly by the psychological and political power of graffiti scrawled on walls during the 1968 student riots in Paris. Theres no interference between the viewer and the experience.

title: Summer Wine: 20 for $20
description: Hot-weather drinking requires its own genre of wines: light, easygoing, blithe and, above all, refreshing. These sorts of wines are enjoyable year-round, but in the sweaty summer months, the desirable becomes the imperative.

title: Gavin Brown Moving Gallery to Harlem
description: Harlem may be far from the madding crowd of galleries in downtown Manhattan and Brooklyn. But this summer Gavin Brown is closing shop on Greenwich Street in the West Village and moving his gallery to a former brewery at 461 West 126th Street.

title: A Pair of Kings Will Succeed Ken Watanabe in The King And I
description: When Ken Watanabe steps down from his role as the King of Siam in the Tony-winning revival of The King and I in July, hell be replaced by Jose Llana, who starred as Filipino President Ferdinand Marcos in the Public Theaters smash Here Lies Love.

title: A Pair of Kings Will Succeed Ken Watanabe in The King And I
description: When Ken Watanabe steps down from his role as the King of Siam in the Tony-winning revival of The King and I in July, hell be replaced by Jose Llana, who starred as Filipino President Ferdinand Marcos in the Public Theaters smash Here Lies Love.

title: An Exclusive Clip From Mia Hansen-Loves Eden
description: Take one glance at the title and premise of Eden, a fictionalized study of the French house music scene through the eyes of the up-and-coming D.J./producer Paul (Flix de Givry), and you might be expecting a completely different film. What could have been a hedonistic two-hour rave in the hands of others is instead, with Mia Hansen-Love at the helm, a hungover look at the morning after the party. The 33-year-old director, whos built her career on tackling pain  loss, depression, suicide  had a major advantage when approaching the golden era of electronic music in France: she, and her co-writer and brother, Sven, lived through it.

title: Violent History: Attacks on Black Churches
description: The killing of nine people at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C., is among a long list of attacks targeting predominantly black churches in the United States.

title: Qaeda Branchs Twitter Posts Appear to Show U.S. Hostage Before His Death
description: A branch of Al Qaeda has posted a series of photographs on Twitter that appear to show Warren Weinstein, an American aid worker, in the months before he was killed in a United States drone strike while being held hostage in northwestern Pakistan.

title: Carnegie Deli to Remain Closed at Least 2 More Weeks
description: The Carnegie Deli, which was found in late April to have been stealing about half of the gas it used for cooking and heating, will remain closed for at least two more weeks, a lawyer for the owner said.

title: An Ant With the Right Coat for 158-Degree Weather
How to Find Hassle-Free Playing Fields With Priceless Views
description: The paperwork and fees for booking athletic fields in New York City can make playing ball feel more like applying to college. Avoid bureaucracy  and enjoy the waterfront views  at these uncomplicated places.

title: Hats and Decorum Reign at Royal Ascot
description: The five days of racing at Royal Ascot attract not only some of the finest horses but also an elegantly dressed crowd that must adhere to strict dress codes.

title: Want to See Royal Ascot Races? Bettor, Bring Your Top Hat
description: ASCOT, England  While Americans view the Kentucky Derby as the time and place to break out their best hats and go to the races, the overall finery on display pales in comparison to what one sees during the five-day Royal Ascot meet here.

title: DNA May Help Track Ivory Poachers
description: DNA evidence retrieved from elephant dung, tissue and hair can help identify the origins of illegal ivory, a new study finds. Researchers at the University of Washington and Interpol developed a method to extract DNA from samples of ivory, and compared the gene sequences with those obtained from dung and tissue samples.

title: Seeking Travel Questions (Kids Only Need Apply)
description: Last year I wrote an essay about the importance of seemingly ordinary yet prized mementos  souvenirs I didnt buy but, rather, found or was given, be it stones from the Irish Sea or a 2-cent euro coin that I spied on a Paris sidewalk. Some objects, like a little book of Shakespeare quotes, given to me by a British tour guide, Ive had since I was a young student.

title: Lynda Benglis: Water Sources
description: This exhibition runs through Nov. 8 at Storm King Art Center.

title: Review: Lynda Benglis Celebrates the Fluidity of Nature at Storm King
description: The most compelling temporary exhibition produced by the Storm King Art Center in recent years, Lynda Benglis: Water Sources focuses on a heretofore unfamiliar but important dimension of Ms. Bengliss distinguished career: creating working fountains. The shows main attraction is a quartet of gorgeous fountains rising from temporary, circular pools embedded in the lawn outside the centers home building.

title: Missing a Father I Hardly Knew
description: The psychic started to laugh.

title: Review: Tony Danza at the Caf Carlyle Cabaret
description: Late in his show Standards and Stories, at Caf Carlyle on Wednesday, Tony Danza, that talented eternally boyish guy from the neighborhood with the ingenuous grin and cocky attitude, pulled out an obscure ballad, I Dont Remember Ever Growing Up, that hit an unexpectedly poignant note. Its composer, Artie Butler, wrote the music to that inescapable nightclub standard Heres to Life, with lyrics by Phyllis Molinary. I Dont Remember Ever Growing Up, whose narrator has reached an age when life goes by at twice the speed of light, leaving you with just your memories, is in the same vein of wistful summing up songs, although not half as good.

title: Former Israeli Envoy Weighs In on Frayed Relations Between Obama and Netanyahu
description: JERUSALEM  Divvying up blame for the icy relationship between President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has been a favored parlor game in both countries for years.

title: Report Finds Growth in Arts Donations
description: Gifts of $200 million and more helped boost Americans overall donations to the arts 9.2 percent in 2014, the highest increase in nine categories tracked by Giving USA, an annual report on charitable contributions.

title: Report Finds Growth in Arts Donations
description: Gifts of $200 million and more helped boost Americans overall donations to the arts 9.2 percent in 2014, the highest increase in nine categories tracked by Giving USA, an annual report on charitable contributions.

title: For Automakers, Fuel Economy Targets May Be Less of a Stretch
description: WHEN David Key drove his new mostly aluminum-body Ford F-150 pickup home this year, he knew he had made the right choice.

title: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
description: 41 YEARS AGO

title: Music Shows With a Brooklyn Feel, but Getting to Them Is a Hike
description: THE mountain looms large in the imagination of musicians. Whether its in Strausss Alpine Symphony, Led Zeppelins Misty Mountain Hop or spirituals like Go Tell It on the Mountain, it has long represented ambition and perseverance, or an escape from the mundane, a conquest blown to mythic proportions.

title: Amy Schumer to Open for Madonnas Shows in New York
description: Madonna announced on Thursday that Amy Schumer, the comedian of the moment, would open the New York dates on the singers Rebel Heart tour this fall, including shows at Madison Square Garden on Sept. 16 and 17, and one at Barclays Center in Brooklyn on Sept. 19. Tickets for all three shows are still available via Ticketmaster.

title: Amy Schumer to Open for Madonnas Shows in New York
description: Madonna announced on Thursday that Amy Schumer, the comedian of the moment, would open the New York dates on the singers Rebel Heart tour this fall, including shows at Madison Square Garden on Sept. 16 and 17, and one at Barclays Center in Brooklyn on Sept. 19. Tickets for all three shows are still available via Ticketmaster.

title: Review: Alvin Ailey Falters in Duet, Rises With Powerful Group Work
description: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater showed that a popular song, no matter how beloved, can kill a dance, and that a forgotten score can inspire a choreographer to explore an unfamiliar world. Continuing its season at the David H. Koch Theater on Wednesday, the company bookended two works by its founder  Night Creature, led by a beaming Hope Boykin, and Revelations  with a restaging of a duet and a new production of a powerful group work.

title: Protecting the Babysitter
description: Our 4-year-old son has a playmate whose parents have become friends. Our college-age babysitter met the playmate and her father at the playground. She reported that while the children were playing, the father asked for her phone number and to meet her for dinner. She said it was obviously not to discuss babysitting. My wife and I are conflicted about saying something to the wife. Regardless, there will be a huge elephant in the room when we next meet. What do you suggest?

title: A Fearless Culture Fuels U.S. Tech Giants
description: With this months announcement that the European Union is investigating Amazon for possible anticompetitive behavior in the sale of e-books, antitrust fervor in Europe seems to have hit fever pitch. Apple, Google and Facebook are all subjects of investigation, and Amazon is now the focus of at least three separate inquiries.

title: Review: Stanley Cowell, in a Rare Performance at the Village Vanguard
description: A standard description of a jazz performance begins with a couple of isolated moments or events. Somebody played something, it had meaning or an impact, time stopped, the audience smiled. The pianist Stanley Cowell is leading a band at the Village Vanguard for the first time this week, and describing his early set there on Wednesday in those terms is no problem.

title: Demote Hamilton on the $10 Bill? Not So Fast, Treasury
description: The Treasury Department has announced that it intends to redesign the $10 bill and substitute a portrait of a famous American woman for Alexander Hamilton, one of the founding fathers. Many people think its about time a woman was featured on the nations paper currency, particularly after a pair of failed efforts to persuade Americans to use one-dollar coins, both of which happened to have women on them. But why choose to shove aside Mr. Hamilton? Binyamin Appelbaum, who writes about economic policy, and Josh Barro, who writes on financial issues for The Upshot, discussed it over email.

title: University of Washington and Chinese University Unite to Form Technology Institute
description: SEATTLE  With hometown companies like Amazon and Microsoft, this bustling region on the Puget Sound easily ranks in the top tier of technology hubs in the United States.

title: Review: David Salle Paintings Deliver Colliding Culture at Skarstedt Gallery
description: DAVID SALLE

title: Arkansas Town Frets About Losing a Courthouse, and an Identity
description: OSCEOLA, Ark.  The baked stone floor tiles of the Mississippi County Courthouse here bear little traffic these days. The offices, which hold documents like marriage records in thick, bound books, are mostly quiet and empty. On the third floor, some of the courtrooms ceiling tiles are browned by water or missing.

title: ISIS-Imposed Fuel Embargo Threatens Syrias Medical Centers
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Islamic State fighters are preventing fuel shipments from reaching rebel-held parts of northern Syria, causing severe shortages that are grounding ambulances, paralyzing medical centers and shutting down bakeries, according to antigovernment activists and aid workers.

title: Giants Display a West Coast Offense With a Crisper Edge at a Minicamp
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Giants held their mandatory minicamp last June, their lack of familiarity with the West Coast offense being installed by the new coordinator Ben McAdoo was readily apparent. Play calls were met with confusion. Assignments were missed. Routes were run incorrectly. The out-of-sync quarterback Eli Manning misfired often.

title: First Draft Focus: Faith, Freedom and Rand Paul
First Draft Focus: Faith, Freedom and Rand Paul
What I Love | Vikram Chatwal
description: The Manhattan hoteliers home in Old Brookfield, N.Y., has space for his most cherished guests, his family.

title: New Rules Let Companies Sell Stakes to Investors of Modest Means
description: Growing companies seeking to raise up to $50 million have a new financing option, starting Friday: a process that will open some private businesses to a wide pool of new investors.

title: Supreme Court Permits New Hearing for Mentally Disabled Inmate
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Thursday issued several decisions in criminal cases, including ones on the death penalty, testimony from children and jury selection.

title: Jack Rollins Dies at 100; Managed Comedy Greats Like Woody Allen
description: Jack Rollins, a producer and a sharp-eyed talent manager who saw more than a shy gag-writer in Woody Allen and believed that the manic improvisations of Robin Williams would crack up audiences, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 100.

title: Bernie Sanders Draws Union Support Pressing Pensions Issue
description: With union members chanting Bernie! Bernie! behind him, Senator Bernie Sanders sought to burnish his populist credentials for president on Thursday as he introduced a bill to protect the pensions of millions of retirees from the threat of deep cuts.

title: Bernie Sanders Draws Union Support Pressing Pensions Issue
description: With union members chanting Bernie! Bernie! behind him, Senator Bernie Sanders sought to burnish his populist credentials for president on Thursday as he introduced a bill to protect the pensions of millions of retirees from the threat of deep cuts.

title: Review: George Caleb Binghams Serene Images of Rivers and Frontier Life, at the Met
description: Figuratively speaking, George Caleb Bingham tamed the Wild West. Working on paper and canvas, he gave a veneer of gentility and preternatural, even timeless calm to the Midwestern river valleys in the decades before the Civil War. The results still look very much alive, even radical today, feeling all-American both aesthetically and historically but with echoes of European painting.

title: Houses of Parliament Are Crumbling, Report Finds, and There Is No Quick Fix
description: LONDON  The Palace of Westminster, Britains gorgeous seat of Parliament, is crumbling, with leaky pipes, hazardous, antiquated wiring and roofs that threaten to collapse. It is slowly sinking into the banks of the River Thames. And then there is the asbestos, and the rats.

title: Agencies, Hoping to Deflect Comets and Asteroids, Step Up Earth Defense
description: In grappling with the threat of doomsday rocks from outer space, Hollywood has always been far ahead of the federal government, cranking out thrillers full of swashbuckling heroes, rockets and nuclear blasts that save the planet.

title: On Location | Bel Air
description: A home is renovated to accommodate a blended family of six children.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Charleston Suspect Moved
description: Dylann Roof, 21, the suspect in the killing of nine people at a Charleston church, was moved from the jail in Shelby, N.C., after his arrest there.

title: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
description: Greece and More  Pictures of the Day

title: June 18, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Greece, South Korea, China and the United States.

title: June 18, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Greece, South Korea, China and the United States.

title: Despite Tensions, U.S. Company Officials Attend Russian Economic Forum
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  For a few days at least, profits seem to be trumping politics in Russia.

title: Review: Folk City at the Museum of the City of New York
description: A well-worn 12-string guitar that belonged to Lead Belly, scratched up from years of strumming, and the sounds of Pete Seeger picking a banjo and praising hard-working Americans greet a visitor to the new exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York. With photographs, documents, instruments, videos, manuscripts and plenty of songs for headphone listening, the show is a fond recap of the folk revival from its agitprop origins and idealistic fervor to its fleeting pop peak.

title: Waterloo Re-enactment
description: The Battle of Waterloo redrew Europes map 200 years ago.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Review: The Cartel, by Don Winslow, Continues a Drug Saga
description: On the opening page of The Cartel, Don Winslow mixes a babys cry with the sound of a helicopters blades in a predawn raid. Thats reminiscent of his 2005 novel, The Power of the Dog, which also used a baby on its opening page. The baby is dead in his mothers arms, that book began, and went on to describe the horrific image of a bullet-riddled Madonna and child in Mexico. It was the first step into what would become Mr. Winslows drug war version of The Godfather, with all the grand ambition that implies.

title: Review: Keely Garfield Mines Kitsch, and Past Material, in Pow
description: Anything by the choreographer Keely Garfield is worth watching multiple times. There is so much to see, so much to delight in and puzzle through, that once is rarely enough. Happily for her audience, Ms. Garfield, too, believes in revisiting her own material. In Pow, seen on Wednesday at Roulette in Brooklyn, she doesnt restage her previous work so much as reimagine and repurpose it, arranging old snippets into something new.

title: Comedy Listings for June 19-25
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Joyce Ann Brown, Shackled by Her Name to Anothers Crime, Dies at 68
description: It was Joyce Ann Browns great misfortune that long before the 1980 robbery and murder that altered her life forever, she had been arrested on an unrelated charge.

title: Review: Festival for Contemporary Performance Opens With Film, Boulez and Chaos
description: At the beginning of a film shown on Wednesday at the opening event of the Institute and Festival for Contemporary Performance at Mannes College the New School for Music, a piece of paper with the word fracture written on it is slowly burned. Viewers then see a pencil connecting the lines of Mallarms poem Un Coup de ds Jamais nAbolira le Hasard (A Throw of the Dice Will Never Abolish Chance). The text is followed by images of a wild-looking score  whose chaotic flourishes and indecipherable passages are printed in seemingly random formation.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for June 19-25
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for June 19-25
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Classical & Opera Listings for June 19-25
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for June 19-25
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Theater Listings for June 19-25
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for June 19-25
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Spare Times for June 19-25
description: Make Music New York (Sunday) On the summer solstice, the streets, plazas, parks and waterfronts of the five boroughs will be alive with music during this free outdoor extravaganza, which features over 1,200 concerts from dawn to dusk (above, a scene from a previous festival). Many events feature audience participation, like a West Village singalong, featuring the music of J.S. Bach and his sons.

title: Senate Passes, Then Blocks, Military Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday passed a $600 billion defense policy bill that would rein in pension costs, ban the use of torture and authorize lethal offensive weapons for Ukraine. But it then immediately rejected a measure to pay for it, the first battle in a spending fight that could end in a government shutdown this fall.

title: Ghosts of Americas Atomic Arsenal
description: Scattered through the United States are facilities that speak to a tense era, where nuclear Armageddon was one button away.

title: Spare Times for Children for June 19-25
description: Party on Wheels

title: Anatomy of a Scene | The Tribe
description: Myroslav Slaboshpytskiy narrates a sequence from The Tribe.

title: Myroslav Slaboshpytskiy Narrates a Scene From The Tribe
description: Words are not spoken aloud in The Tribe, but volumes are expressed in this Ukranian feature set at a school for the deaf. The film, from Myroslav Slaboshpytskiy, uses a nonprofessional cast that communicates in sign language. In this scene, a new student (Grigoriy Fesenko) participates in a fight organized by a gang he is set to join. The sequence happens in one unbroken take and fills the screen with extras and intricate fight choreography.

title: Deal Is Near on Far-Reaching Reforms at Rikers, Including a Federal Monitor
description: New York City officials have tentatively agreed to sweeping reforms that would remake Rikers Island, including the appointment of a federal monitor to oversee the jail complex, explicit prohibitions against guards striking prisoners in the head and even the introduction of body cameras worn by guards.

title: Review: Dope, a Teenage Comedy, Plays With Stereotypes
description: A coming-of-age story that is at once a parody of, and a tribute to, 90s-vintage ghetto dramas, Dope wears its pop-culture obsessions on its sleeve. So does its hero, Malcolm (Shameik Moore), a teenager navigating his senior year of high school in a rough part of Los Angeles. And not only his sleeve: Malcolms whole look, from his high-top fade to his vintage Air Jordans, expresses a geeky commitment to hip-hops golden decade, which for him lasted from roughly 1988 until 2001 (that is, from It Takes a Nation of Millions to Hold Us Back to The Blueprint.)

title: This Weeks Movies | June 19, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Inside Out, Dope and The Overnight.

title: Rand Paul and the VAT That Dare Not Speak Its Name
description: In an op-ed in todays Wall Street Journal, Senator Rand Paul announced his tax plan. While Herman Cain had his 9-9-9 plan, you can think of Mr. Pauls approach as the 14.5-14.5 plan: He would replace all of todays federal taxes with a 14.5 percent flat personal income tax and a 14.5 percent value-added tax.

title: Review: In The Overnight, Newcomers Try Hard to Make Friends
description: Bland meets bold in The Overnight, a comedy that coyly dips its toe and a few other body parts in the new sexual revolution. With its couple-on-couple story, the movie comes across as a skittish redo of Paul Mazurskys 1969 sex comedy, Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice, about two chummy straight married couples who end up between the sheets together. Mr. Mazurskys dramatically shaded comedy is somewhat of a feature-long tease, despite its famous image of the four lined up in bed. (Bob and company arent the swingers that they try to be.) But its also a sharp exploration of the kind of middle-class social anxieties that vibrate through The Overnight.

title: Movie Review: The Overnight
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews The Overnight.

title: Review: Eric Revis Trio Lets the Music Lead the Way at the Jazz Gallery
description: The Eric Revis Trio, in its current form, is a young band that has already started to cut its path toward a rare and mystifying cohesion. One moment that suggested as much on Wednesday night, in an impressive opening set at the Jazz Gallery, landed near the homestretch, after about an hour of alert collective improvisation.

title: Thione Ballago Secks Arrest at Odds With Religious Image in Senegal
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Thione Ballago Secks high tenor croon has floated into Senegalese ears for generations, and his mournful Afro-Cuban rhythms and deep Muslim faith have powered a renowned career as a West African musical icon in this music-infused land.

title: Cuba Offers Its Citizens Better Access to Internet
description: MEXICO CITY  Cuba, one of the Western Hemispheres least-wired countries, is poised to expand access to the Internet by introducing about three dozen Wi-Fi hot spots around the island and reducing the steep fees that Cubans pay to spend time online.

title: Movie Review: Inside Out
description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews Inside Out.

title: Free Dance in Summertime New York
description: The best part about summer dance isnt that its free: Quality matters as well. This years River to River Festival, presented by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, is up to its usual good with performances and works by Twyla Tharp, the Trisha Brown Dance Company and Souleymane Badolo.
