Outdoor festivals like SummerStage, Celebrate Brooklyn! and Lincoln Center Out of Doors round out the  yes, happily free  programming. Here we highlight the artists behind some choice offerings, and list other performances you should consider adding to your calendar. These conversations have been edited and condensed.

title: Movie Review: Dope
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Dope.

title: Dance Listings for June 19-25
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Q. and A.: Peter J. Li on the Clash Over Eating Dogs in China
description: An estimated 10 million dogs are killed for food each year in China. About 10,000 are expected to be slaughtered as the Yulin Summer Solstice Lychee and Dog Meat Festival gets underway this weekend in the southern city of Yulin.

title: Few Vehicles Equipped for Easy Car Seat Installation
description: A study released on Thursday found that only a handful of vehicles deserved the highest rating for ease of child safety seat installation. The study, conducted by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, rated 102 vehicles on how easily a child safety seat could be installed. It focused on the vehicles so-called Latch system, which consists of three anchors that the seat is secured to. Only three models received the highest rating of Good: the BMW 5 Series, Mercedes-Benz GL-Class and the Volkswagen Passat. Children are safer when in an age-appropriate child restraint, but these are not always easy to install, especially when using a vehicles seatbelts. And if the restraint is not properly anchored to the vehicle, a child could be severely injured in a crash. The federally mandated Latch system, which stands for Lower Anchors and Tethers for Children, was meant to be easier than using seatbelts to attach safety seats.

title: Meningitis Vaccine Mandate for Seventh Graders in New York Passes
description: Seventh graders in New York State would be required to be vaccinated for meningitis, a deadly disease spread by saliva droplets, and could be excluded from school if they were not, under a bill passed this week by the State Legislature.

title: Tech Companies Fly High on Fantasy Accounting
description: Technology shares have been powering the stock market recently, outperforming the broader stock indexes by wide margins. The tech-heavy Nasdaq 100, for example, is up 19 percent over the last 12 months, almost twice as much as the Standard & Poors 500-stock index, which has risen 10 percent.

title: Much More Than 2 Cents About a Woman on the $10 Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The secretary of the Treasury, Jacob J. Lew, asked for the publics comments on his newly announced decision to put a womans portrait on the $10 bill. And as might be expected for the first such redesign in the age of social media, boy  er, girl  is he getting comments.

title: Orange Is the New Black Season 3, Episode 12 Recap: Clanging Themes
description: Season 3, Episode 12: Dont Make Me Come Back There

title: Orange Is the New Black Season 3, Episode 12 Recap: Clanging Themes
description: Season 3, Episode 12: Dont Make Me Come Back There

title: No Sanctuary in Charleston
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  ON Wednesday night, while my son watched TV, I logged on to Facebook to check my friends updates. Immediately I saw a post about a shooting at Emanuel A.M.E., a historic black church in downtown Charleston that is a stones throw from my office at the College of Charleston. I made my son turn from his show to the news coverage. We stayed up and discussed what had happened. I prayed that I didnt know anyone who had died, but I did.

title: Tunisia: Gunmen Free Officials in Libya
description: Ten consular officials kidnapped from the Tunisian Consulate in Libya were released overnight after days of negotiations, the Tunisian state news agency reported Thursday. The 10 were abducted from their consulate in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, last Friday by armed militiamen. A Tunisian court on Wednesday ruled that Walid Qulaib, a Libyan militia leader detained in Tunisia, would be extradited to Libya. Tunisian news outlets have reported that the kidnapping was carried out by members of a militia group who were demanding the release of Mr. Qulaib.

title: Longtime Tenants in Manhattan See an Effort to Push Them Out
description: The message was clear to Tommy McCarthy as soon as the sturdy metal gates were installed on his stoop and on those of nearly 20 other buildings along his block in Manhattan south of Columbia University.

title: Review: Phantom Halo, a Crime Caper With Thomas Brodie-Sangster
description: Samuel, a busker who declaims Shakespeare for passers-by, and his brother, Beckett, who relieves audience members of their wallets, can almost keep hunger and the landlord at bay until a sadistic mobster comes to collect on the debts of their father, Warren (Sebastian Roch), a has-been actor and drunken gambler.

title: Championing Environment, Francis Takes Aim at Global Capitalism
description: WASHINGTON  The encyclical on the environment that Pope Francis released on Thursday is as much an indictment of the global economic order as it is an argument for the world to confront climate change.

title: Review: Manglehorn Stars Al Pacino as an Aging Curmudgeon
description: After pairing with Nicolas Cage for the 2014 film Joe, the director David Gordon Green sets loose another star, Al Pacino, in Manglehorn. Mr. Pacino brings his peculiar brand of soulful jive to the lonely Texas locksmith of the title, comfily playing a hunched, courtly curmudgeon who loves his cat and gets along with others fine, but sometimes acts as if he hated everyone, as someone else helpfully puts it.

title: New York Legislature Agrees to 5-Day Extension of Rent Regulations
description: ALBANY  With major issues unresolved, state lawmakers agreed on Thursday to briefly  and retroactively  extend rent regulations and planned to continue working into next week, prolonging a session that has already gone past its planned expiration date.

title: Review: Burying the Ex, a Joe Dante Zombie Tale
description: Thanks in part to persistent advocacy from the former Chicago Reader critic Jonathan Rosenbaum, Joe Dante is increasingly seen as an underappreciated talent of 1980s and 90s Hollywood: a director who laced even mercenary-sounding projects (Gremlins 2: The New Batch, Small Soldiers) with sophistication, satire and a sense of film history.

title: Anti-Immigrant Party Gains in Denmark Elections
description: In an election that turned on economic uncertainty and fierce debates over immigration, Danish voters on Thursday ousted their center-left government in a clear swing to the right that unexpectedly elevated an anti-immigrant, anti-European Union party that had been on the margins of the countrys politics.

title: At Cannabis Trade Show, Vendors Tread a Careful Line
description: A question hung in the air at the Cannabis World Congress and Business Exposition at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan on Thursday: How do you show off your wares in a place where actually using them would be illegal?

title: In the Footsteps of Other Popes, Francis Seeks Worldly Change
description: When an elderly Pope Leo XIII released a document in 1891 on the rights of workers to unionize and of owners to hold private property, European capitalists and socialists alike cried foul. Why should we listen, they fumed, to a popes pronouncements on economics and politics?

title: Recalling Nine Spiritual Mentors, Gunned Down During Night of Devotion
description: When Tywanza Sanders, the poet and peacemaker of the family, saw the man draw his gun during Bible study and point it as his elderly aunt, Susie Jackson, he shielded her and tried to talk the gunman into laying down his weapon, a relative said Thursday.

title: Review: The Face of an Angel Dabbles in Murder and Culpability
description: In The Face of an Angel, a fictional meditation on the horrific murder of the British student Meredith Kercher in Italy in 2007, the director Michael Winterbottom has a grand time doing two things: slapping the wrists of news reporters and pontificating on the truth.

title: Review: Balls Out, a Sports-Movie Satire Packed With S.N.L. Talent
description: You lot are a ragtag team of varied archetypes, says the coach Grant (Nick Kocher) to the motley intramural football team the Panthers. That self-awareness underscores this modest, nimble and, um, winning comedy from Andrew Disney, which acknowledges sports-movie conventions even as it exploits them.

title: Many Ask, Why Not Call Church Shooting Terrorism?
description: The massacre of nine African-Americans in Charleston has been classified as a possible hate crime, apparently carried out by a 21-year-old white man who once wore an apartheid badge and other symbols of white supremacy. But many civil rights advocates are asking why the attack has not officially been called terrorism.

title: Phil Mickelsons Bogey Putt Goes a Long Way
description: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash.  Phil Mickelson stood on the 14th tee at Chambers Bay Golf Course, the longest par 4 in the 120-year history of the United States Open. On Thursday, the hole measured 528 yards, and Mickelson looked fidgety, twirling his driver in anticipation of his shot.

title: Review: ABCD 2, TV Dance Stars Try to Rebuild Their Team and Reputation
description: We dance to express, not to impress, says Suresh (Varun Dhawan), leader of the troupe the Mumbai Stunners, in Remo DSouzas Bollywood spectacular ABCD 2. Really? You wouldnt think so from this sequel to Mr. DSouzas ABCD: Any Body Can Dance, from 2013. For all the movies flashy pyrotechnics and pulverizing techno-ish musical numbers, gleaning an emotional pulse can be challenging.

title: Review: Hippocrates Offers Life, Death and Teachable Moments
description: Lives are lost and saved, vitals checked, brows furrowed, turfs protected and glasses clinked in Hippocrates: Diary of a French Doctor, which is more or less what its title announces. Theres also a scene in which most of the characters boogie down, because, as a friend observed, a French movie isnt a French movie unless it has a scene in a disco or the eras equivalent. Throw in bureaucratic entanglements and workers uniting  and voil!

title: Before Charlestons Church Shooting, a Long History of Attacks
description: In 1868, three men assassinated the Rev. Benjamin Randolph in broad daylight as he was boarding a train in Abbeville County, South Carolina. Randolph, a black man, had recently won a seat in the State Senate and was then campaigning for the Republican slate. Having served as an Army chaplain with the 26th Regiment United States Colored Troops, Randolph asked the Freedmens Bureau to send him where he can be most useful to his race. He settled in South Carolina in time to take part in the 1865 rededication of the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston. It was that churchs long history of spiritual autonomy and political activism that caught the attention of the white vigilantes who gunned him down and rode away. Randolphs fate was repeated yesterday with the murder of nine people, including the pastor of the church, the Rev. Clementa Pinckney, who, like Randolph, also served as a state senator.

title: Review: Eden, a D.J.s Passion for Electronic Music, by Mia Hansen-Love
description: Within seconds of opening, Eden has slipped from the dark throb of a Parisian rave to the misty light of an early-morning forest, the shift in illumination mirrored repeatedly in the narrative beats of its heros journey. The year is 1992, and Paul (Flix de Givry)  young, pale and delicately handsome  is falling hard for the soulful sounds of garage, the warm and pulsing dance music that began in Larry Levans Paradise Garage in New York City.

title: Proposed Rule for Big Trucks Aims at Cutting Fuel Emissions
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Friday introduced a major climate change regulation intended to reduce planet-warming carbon pollution from heavy-duty trucks.

title: Review: In Significant Other, a Young Man Pines as His Pals Pair Off
description: Jordan Berman, the hapless but lovable protagonist of Joshua Harmons entirely delightful new play, Significant Other, seems to see tiers of tulle, sprays of babys breath and ill-fitting bridesmaids gowns wherever he looks. While Jordans romantic life consists of a stalkerish crush on a co-worker that carries little promise of fulfillment, his longtime girlfriends are moving into firm relationships leading to walks down the aisle. Jordan, loyal friend that he is, can only watch in smiling support and increasing loneliness as the bubbling urban life he has led with his friends turns into a series of archived Instagram moments before his watering eyes.

title: One Who Might Steal a Kiss
description: In utter loneliness a writer tries to explain the inexplicable  JOHN STEINBECK

title: Review: Infinitely Polar Bear Traces a Dads Ups and Downs
description: In movies, true-life family stories tend to come so drenched in despair or smothered in treacle that its a surprise anyone gets out intact. In her sweet, somewhat nutty feature debut, Infinitely Polar Bear, the writer-director Maya Forbes looks back on her 1970s childhood in a fictional re-creation that, as it brightly skips along, can make you feel like Scrooge for thinking its a bit of a snow job. Thats especially the case because the father here, Cam Stuart (the infinitely warm Mark Ruffalo), is an endearingly down-and-out eccentric with manic depression.

title: Tiger Woodss Former Caddie Is Still Vocal as He Returns to Work for Another Ex-Boss
description: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash.  During the cloudy, midmorning opening round of the United States Open at Chambers Bay Golf Course on Thursday, a familiar face arose from behind a small hill where the tee on hole No. 2 sat. The scene immediately prompted a fan behind the ropes to shout, Welcome back, Stevie!

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: June 19
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images from Dannemora, N.Y., where two inmates escaped, and Staten Island, home to Eric Garner.

title: Review: In The Wanted 18, Palestinians Hide Cows From Israeli Forces
description: The Palestinians plan was carried out in darkness and was later deemed to be dangerous for the security of the state of Israel. Armed Israeli soldiers and helicopters were mobilized, while the Palestinians moved in stealth under a strict curfew.

title: Review: Gabriel Stars Rory Culkin as a Young Man With Mental Illness
description: The title character in Gabriel (Rory Culkin), a young adult with some kind of mental illness, is headed from a psychiatric hospital to his mothers house. First, though, he shows up at the college where Alice (Emily Meade), a childhood girlfriend, is enrolled. Only when he learns shes away on break does he make his way home.

title: Worker Is Killed During Attack at Upper West Side Shop
description: A young man working in a store on the Upper West Side was killed on Thursday during what appeared to be a robbery, the police said.

title: Review: Evaporating Borders Examines the Immigrant Crisis in Cyprus
description: Rived into Turkish and Greek regions, Cyprus is no stranger to internecine conflict, but as Evaporating Borders demonstrates, waves of immigration to the island have met with fresh rancor. Iva Radivojevics diffuse documentary essay melds a first-person voice-over thats part musing, part news summary, with impassioned interview subjects and photography that encompasses postcard shots, protest-rally footage and overly mundane glimpses of city life.

title: Henry Louis Gates: If Clementa Pinckney Had Lived
description: I have no doubt that had the Rev. Clementa C. Pinckney lived, he would have become known  and celebrated  across our country for his leadership, rather than sealed immortally in tragedy, one more black martyr in a line stretching back to the more than 800 slave voyages that ended at Charleston Harbor.

title: Correction Officer Accused of Smuggling Contraband Into Manhattan Detention Complex
description: A New York City correction officer, an inmate and two relatives have been accused of smuggling contraband into the Manhattan Detention Complex, law enforcement officials said on Thursday.

title: Clip: 3  Minutes, Ten Bullets
description: A scene from the documentary.

title: Residents Near Prison Bolt Their Doors After Escape
description: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y.  In some ways, residents say, normalcy has started creeping back.

title: Review: 3  Minutes, Ten Bullets Explores a Gas Station Slaying in Florida
description: 3  Minutes, Ten Bullets is the rare trial documentary in which the testimony from both sides seems to corroborate a basic sequence of events. No one in the film disputes that Michael Dunn, who is now serving a life sentence without the possibility of parole, shot and killed Jordan Davis, 17, in a gas station parking lot in Jacksonville, Fla., in 2012. Everyone seems to agree that Mr. Davis had refused to turn down rap music that Mr. Dunn had complained was too loud.

title: New Jersey Man Is Charged With Planning to Aid ISIS
description: A 21-year-old New Jersey man was charged on Thursday with planning to travel overseas to support the Islamic State, the latest in a string of arrests targeting young men in the New York City region who are suspected of sympathizing with the terrorist group.

title: Al Qaeda Denies U.S. Strike Killed Key Jihadist in Libya
description: Al Qaedas branch in North Africa, in a stinging statement issued Thursday, denied that the jihadist leader Mokhtar Belmokhtar had been killed in an American airstrike in Libya this week.

title: Mets Under Nelson Doubleday Were a Lesson in Turning Around a Team
description: Nelson Doubleday Jr.s death on Wednesday is a reminder of how a man born to privilege and extreme wealth can turn a desultory team around by hiring the right people.

title: Review: Rubble Kings Recounts a Death That Led to a Gang Truce and Changed the Bronx
description: For all its gritty landscapes, Shan Nicholsons new documentary, Rubble Kings, is a smooth and sleek Bronx tale of how the gangs that overwhelmed that borough in the early 1970s would eventually sow the seeds of hip-hop culture.

title: Review: Doctor Faustus, All That Heaven Wont Allow
description: Psst, Mephistopheles, are you still around, making deals on behalf of the Devil? Promise to give me back the two hours I spent enduring the Classic Stage Companys misguided production of Christopher Marlowes Doctor Faustus, and maybe we can come to an agreement. Eternal damnation doesnt seem all that bothersome if my memories of this show, starring Chris Noth as the titular soul seller and Zach Grenier as Mephistopheles, can be permanently erased.

title: Hits but No Milestone for Alex Rodriguez in Yankees Win
description: Fifteen minutes before the first pitch, Alex Rodriguez  three hits shy of 3,000 for his career  was loosening up by himself on the right-field grass at Yankee Stadium.

title: F.C.C. Will Continue Plan to Subsidize Broadband for the Poor
description: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday voted 3 to 2 along party lines to approve a proposal to explore subsidizing broadband Internet for poor Americans. The plan, introduced last month by the agencys Democratic chairman, Tom Wheeler, helps pave the way for sweeping changes to a $1.7 billion phone subsidy program.

title: U.S. Open 2015: Tiger Woods Watches Another One Slip Away
description: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash.  On the first morning of the United States Open, Henrik Stenson and Dustin Johnson charted the course for the great unknown that was Chambers Bay with matching five-under-par 65s.

title: Word of the Day | bereaved
description: bereaved  \bi-revd, be-\  adjective and noun

title: R. A. Dickeys Knuckleball Dances as Mets Appear to Sit This One Out
description: TORONTO  The three years R. A. Dickey was a Met, possibly the best three years of his career, Dan Warthen, the Mets pitching coach, watched his bullpen sessions with great delight. Dickey was constantly tinkering with his stride, trying to perfect his knuckleball, and he would give Dave Racaniello, the bullpen catcher, fits.

title: Tom Benson Is Found Capable of Running Saints and Pelicans
description: Tom Benson, the owner of the New Orleans Saints and the New Orleans Pelicans, is capable of running the teams, according to a state court judge in Louisiana.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) WHIPLASH (2014) Andrew (Miles Teller), an aspiring jazz drummer at a highly selective Manhattan music school, falls in thrall to Fletcher (J. K. Simmons, in an Oscar-winning portrayal), a charismatic and terrifying instructor whose pedagogical methods include browbeating, humiliation and cymbal throwing. In this second feature from Damien Chazelle, a blood bath, literal and figurative, ensues. For all its dexterity and assurance, the movie has its share of false notes and rhythmic stumbles, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. A few plot twists test the limits of credibility. And there is something a little dispiriting  if sadly unsurprising  about the way Mr. Chazelle turns a historically African-American art form into the existential arena for a couple of white guys. Still, he added, the battle of master and disciple is exciting and terrifying to witness, and, at its best, the film can feel as wild and spontaneous, as risky and precise, as a live jam session.

title: Corrections: June 19, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: The church must introduce in its teaching the sin against the environment. The ecological sin.

title: Fantastic Man Magazine and Its Influence on Mens Fashion
description: Stefano Tonchi, the editor of W Magazine, called it very influential in redefining mens identity in the last decade.

title: Ghosts of Americas Atomic Arsenal
description: Sprinkled throughout the back roads of America are the remains of Armageddon. Or what could have been Armageddon had the Cold War between the United States and the Soviet Union suddenly gone hot.

title: Ghosts of Americas Atomic Arsenal
description: Sprinkled throughout the back roads of America are the remains of Armageddon. Or what could have been Armageddon had the Cold War between the United States and the Soviet Union suddenly gone hot.

title: Worlds Refugees: Huge Problem, Meager Response
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Flawed Methods for Evaluating Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: How Dominicans Treat Children of Haitian Descent
description: To the Editor:

title: Hearts Broken Open
description: Last month, I asked readers if they had discovered a purpose in life and, if so, how they had discovered it. A few thousand wrote essays. I was struck by how elemental life is. Most people found their purpose either through raising children or confronting illness or death.

title: Voodoo, Jeb! Style
description: On Monday Jeb Bush  or I guess thats Jeb!, since he seems to have decided to replace his family name with a punctuation mark  finally made his campaign for the White House official, and gave us a first view of his policy goals. First, he says that if elected he would double Americas rate of economic growth to 4 percent. Second, he would make it possible for every American to lose as much weight as he or she wants, without any need for dieting or exercise.

title: Clinical Trials Need Cancer Patients
description: I HAVE a very rare and aggressive type of skin cancer  Merkel cell carcinoma  for which there is no approved cure, and Im participating in a clinical trial to deal with it. If successful, the trial will show that the drug Im being given at least manages what is now an often fatal disease.

title: The Slow Death of Trans Fats
description: The Food and Drug Administration has ordered the food industry to remove artificial trans fats from the food supply within three years, bringing closure to a prolonged battle to eliminate the artery-clogging substances from American diets. The agency on Tuesday issued its final determination that partially hydrogenated oils, the primary source of trans fats in processed foods, are no longer considered safe and may no longer be added to food after June 18, 2018, unless a manufacturer can present convincing scientific evidence that a particular use is safe.

title: More Community Service, Not Less
description: It would be hardhearted and counterproductive to squeeze any more money from the already meager federal funding for public service programs that help struggling schoolchildren, veterans, the elderly and communities stricken by natural disasters. Yet a House subcommittee this week approved a spending bill that cuts federal financing for the already beleaguered Corporation for National and Community Service, which oversees many programs, the most well known of which is AmeriCorps.

title: The Pope and Climate Change
description: The issue of climate change  unlike, say, the economy  may not be a matter of everyday concern to many Americans or most citizens of the planet. The debate is too often clouded by ideology and well-financed attempts to sow doubt about the underlying science. Even among those aware enough to worry, the long-term consequences can seem remote. As one futile international conference after another has attested, the facts alone have not been enough to move world governments to take decisive action.

title: Britain Invites U.S. Official to Join Review of Its Military
description: LONDON  In an effort to allay concerns in Washington about cuts in British military spending, an American official has joined a British review panel that was established to determine the future of Britains armed forces.

title: R.B.S. Says Customer Accounts Are Fully Updated After Technology Failure
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Friday that it had updated all customer accounts after a technology failure this week that meant about 600,000 transactions were not processed.

title: Test Yourself | Using the Force for Fashion
description: Below, several paragraphs from a June 16 article, A Star Wars Inspired Runway Show With Galactic Support.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Church Massacre Suspect Held as Charleston Grieves
description: In Church Massacre Suspect Held as Charleston Grieves, Nick Corasaniti, Richard Prez-Pea and Lizette Alvarez report on a shooting in Charleston, S.C.

title: South Korean Official Says MERS Outbreak Seems to Be Easing
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Koreas outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome, the largest outside Saudi Arabia, appears to be easing, a senior government health official said on Friday.

title: Were Back!
description: America deepens its footprint in Iraq once more.

title: Taking the Work Out of Short-Term Rentals
description: If the idea of renting out your home on Airbnb, HomeAway or similar vacation rental sites sounds intriguing, but the thought of posting photos, managing bookings and getting your apartment ready seems far too daunting, read on.

title: After Slight Improvement, Tiger Woods Still Makes an Early Exit
description: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash.  For Tiger Woods, the second round of the United States Open on Friday was not the disaster that Thursdays first round had been. He shot a six-over-par 76, which was a four-stroke improvement from the day before, when he endured his worst round ever at the Open.

title: George Osbornes Discreet Ambition
description: LONDON  One election spawns another. In the contest in May between the Conservative and Labour parties for national power, the Tory prime minister, David Cameron, prevailed by a small but decisive margin. The horse race to succeed his vanquished opponent, Ed Miliband, is now consuming Labour. But  at a slower pace  the Conservatives are also assessing the runners and riders to take the place of Mr. Cameron, who has said he will not lead his party into the next general election in 2020.

title: Climate Change and Moral Responsibility
description: On Tuesday, the British medical journal The Lancet will publish a landmark report highlighting the inalienable and undeniable link between climate change and human health. We warmly welcome the reports message of hope, which confirms the fact that climate change is more than just a technical or financial challenge (as Pope Francis did in his encyclical letter on June 18) and confirms the voice of health in the discussion on climate change. Indeed, the central premise of the Lancet commissions work is that tackling climate change could be the single greatest health opportunity of the 21st century.

title: Fridays Travel News and Tips
description: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Charleston Grieves Victims of Shooting
description: Residents lay flowers at a memorial in front of the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C., where a gunman killed nine people during a Bible study.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Ask Well: Can You Drink Too Much Water?
description: Question:

title: Fidelity Offers to Take Colt Group Private
description: LONDON  Fidelity said on Friday that it had offered to acquire the shares it did not already own in the British information technology provider Colt Group in an all-cash deal that valued the company at 1.7 billion pounds, or about $2.7 billion.

title: New York Today: Soccer in the City
description: Good morning on this brightening Friday.

title: New York Today: Soccer in the City
description: Good morning on this brightening Friday.

title: Telecom Italia Raises $887 Million in I.P.O. of Wireless Tower Unit
description: LONDON  Telecom Italia raised 780 million euros, or about $887 million, in the initial public offering of its wireless telecommunications tower unit, Infrastrutture Wireless Italiane, late Thursday.

title: Chinese Stocks Stagger to End of Rough Week
description: HONG KONG  Chinese stocks plunged on Friday, capping their worst week in years and prompting the perhaps inevitable question: Has the countrys tremendous stock market rally finally come to an end?

title: In Charleston, Raw Emotion at Hearing for Suspect in Church Shooting
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  One by one, they looked to the screen in a corner of the courtroom on Friday, into the expressionless face of the young man charged with making them motherless, snuffing out the life of a promising son, taking away a loving wife for good, bringing a grandmothers life to a horrific end. And they answered him with forgiveness.

title: China Lets Citizens Fingers Do the Talking to Report Graft
description: Mao once said, Only by letting people supervise the government can the government remain effective. The Communist Partys top antigraft agency has apparently taken that to heart in its own wired way.

title: The 6.7.15 Issue
description: Re: Trolls

title: The Good Survives
description: As a child, I would often recite poems to banish some painful or unpleasant memory. Words became a kind of talisman, as they are in this poem, a way of willing the mind to recollect all the good that lives alongside what we want to forget.

title: How to Train a Cadaver Dog
description: Drug dogs are trained on drugs, and cadaver dogs are trained on cadaver, says Mary E. Cablk, a scientist at the Desert Research Institute in Nevada who studies scent detection. Training a cadaver dog requires regular contact with human blood, decaying flesh and bones. In the United States, dog handlers can legally obtain bodily components like human placenta and blood, but not always easily, and trainers like Cablk often resort to using their own blood. Some substitute commercially available ersatz odors (the most common is Sigma Pseudo Corpse Scent, which comes in three kinds: recently dead, decomposed and drowned). But deceased humans produce unique volatile organic compounds, and canines have a keenly attuned sense of smell, so you should practice on the real thing. You dont want to put other people at risk, Cablk says  searches are often in dangerous areas, like collapsed buildings  to find what is ultimately a dead pet.

title: Juneteenth Is for Everyone
description: SOME two months after Gen. Robert E. Lee surrendered on April 9, 1865, effectively ending the Civil War, Maj. Gen. Gordon Granger steamed into the port of Galveston, Tex. With 1,800 Union soldiers, including a contingent of United States Colored Troops, Granger was there to establish martial law over the westernmost state in the defeated Confederacy.

title: Exclamation-Point Architecture
description: The graphic designers Justus Oehler and Uta Tjaden live in a 1928 Bauhaus-style villa in Berlin, designed by Arthur Korn, who fled Nazi Germany in the 1930s. When the couple first saw the landmark house in 2003, it had been empty for three years and badly damaged by water from burst pipes. With the help of the architect Florian Holl, who largely preserved Arthur Korns floor plan, the villa was returned to its original design. The villa is one of only about a dozen buildings Korn designed in Berlin, not all of which survived.

title: Apologize for Slavery
description: A WEEK of absurdity around a confused racial con artist, and a massacre in a black church brings us to this: Today is the 150th anniversary of Juneteenth, when the last of the American slaves were told they were free. Now, to put it to good use, at a time when a post-racial era seems very much out of reach.

title: Changing Views on a Female President
description: On Saturday, Hillary Rodham Clinton told thousands of people at a rally on Roosevelt Island in New York City that she wanted the United States to be a place where a father can tell his daughter yes, you can be anything you want to be, even president of the United States. It was a line she used in her concession speech in 2008 and one that highlights what could happen if she or, less likely, Carly Fiorina win her partys nomination and ultimately the presidency. Nearly 100 years after women were given the right to vote, Americans may send their first woman to the Oval Office.

title: Identification, Please
description: Im standing on a high lookout near a spectacular three-tiered waterfall in Australias Blue Mountains National Park. The peaks in the far distance reflect sunshine scattered through a haze of aromatic eucalyptus oil; the light has turned them a pale and dusty blue. At my feet the land falls away into a virgin forest of graceful, pale-barked trees that runs as far as the eye can see. Farther up the slope are leggy shrubs with flowers resembling bright plastic hair curlers: banksias, I think. When a small bird appears in the foliage below I fix it in my binoculars. White, black and acid yellow, it has eyes like tiny silver coins, and it is wiping its downcurved beak on a branch of a shrub with strappy leaves. I dont know what the shrub is, and Im not sure what the bird is, either. I think its a honeyeater, but I dont know what anything is, not precisely. The air smells faintly of old paper and something strangely like jet fuel. I feel lost and very far from home.

title: Holding Back Tears After American Pharoahs Triple Crown
description: Given time to think about how I felt witnessing American Pharoahs Triple Crown sweep on June 6, my conclusion may be surprising: I felt robbed and a bit sad. Sure, I also felt joy and enormous gratitude toward my employer, NBC, which entrusts me with the responsibility of interviewing the winning jockey on horseback. But I have waited my whole life for this Triple Crown.

title: Depressed? Try Therapy Without the Therapist
description: Elle is a mess. Shes actually talented, attractive and good at her job, but she feels like a fraud  convinced that todays the day shell flunk a test, lose a job, mess up a relationship. Her colleague Moody also sabotages himself. Hes a hardworking, nice person, but loses friends because hes grumpy, oversensitive and gets angry for no reason.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 2 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: In The Times this week: a video and an article about a transgender teenager.

title: Dozens Die in India After Drinking Tainted Liquor
description: NEW DELHI  Dozens of people in India have died after drinking toxic liquor in a Mumbai-area slum, the police said on Friday.

title: Today in Politics: Charleston Shooting Leads to a Campaign Pause
description: Good Friday morning from Washington, where news of a mass shooting in Charleston, S.C., has rippled across the campaign trail and prompted candidates to weigh in, the trade fight has helped shift focus from a Democrat-led filibuster in the Senate, and Senator Rand Paul is looking to a social media app to woo young voters.

title: Today in Politics: Charleston Shooting Leads to a Campaign Pause
description: Good Friday morning from Washington, where news of a mass shooting in Charleston, S.C., has rippled across the campaign trail and prompted candidates to weigh in, the trade fight has helped shift focus from a Democrat-led filibuster in the Senate, and Senator Rand Paul is looking to a social media app to woo young voters.

title: Morning Agenda: Emergency Meeting on Greece Set for Monday
description: EMERGENCY MEETING ON GREECE SET FOR MONDAY | European leaders called an emergency summit meeting for Monday after a meeting of eurozone finance ministers ended on Thursday without a deal on Greeces bailout,  James Kanter writes in The New York Times. Too little progress has been made, Jeroen Dijsselbloem, the head of the Eurogroup of finance ministers, said at a joint news conference on Thursday with Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, and Pierre Moscovici, the European commissioner for financial affairs. No agreement as yet is in sight, said Mr. Dijsselbloem. There was still a chance to reach a deal, he said, though very little time remains.

title: E.C.B. Agrees to Extend Lifeline to Athens
description: Extending its lifeline to Greek banks, the European Central Bank on Friday increased its emergency funding of the countrys financial system after efforts failed on Thursday to broker a deal on Greeces flailing bailout.

title: Russia and Greece Flaunt Solidarity at Business Forum, but Deals Are Scarce
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  The leaders of Russia and Greece produced a grand pageant of solidarity, friendship and supposed economic cooperation at Russias annual gathering for global business executives Friday, but the embrace seemed mostly about thumbing their noses at Europe.

title: Jon Stewart Addresses Charleston Shooting in Daily Show Monologue
description: For the past 16 years, a major part of Jon Stewarts job has been to write and deliver jokes during his opening monologue at The Daily Show.

title: Inside Out': Pixars Convincing Argument Against Childhood Happiness
description: In Pixar movies, inventive plots, engaging characters and stunning visuals come as no surprise. But the best thing about the studios newest production, Inside Out, may be its commitment to celebrating the worst.

title: Perfectly Reasonable Questions: Portraying Unions in a Scott Walker Story
description: Last weeks cover story in The Times Magazine, Scott Walker and the Fate of the Union, drew hundreds of reader comments  and some mail to the Public Editors office. Two of the emails presented questions that I decided to pose to the magazines editor, Jake Silverstein.

title: Brian Williams Says Fabrications Came From Bad Urge Inside of Me
description: Brian Williams tried to repair his sullied reputation with the public on Friday during his first interview since being removed as anchor of Nightly News on NBC, but crisis communications experts, critics and social media users said his efforts fell short of making a convincing argument.

title: Kindergarten Manners, Revisited
description: Dear Diary:

title: Kindergarten Manners, Revisited
description: Dear Diary:

title: When America Says Yes to Government
description: In recent years, the federal government has adopted a large number of soft interventions that are meant to change behavior without mandates and bans. Among them: disclosure of information, such as calorie labels at chain restaurants; graphic warnings against, for example, distracted driving; and automatic enrollment in programs designed to benefit employees, like pension plans.

title: Car Shopping? How to Identify Flood Damage Before Buying
description: HEAVY rains and flooding this spring have soaked thousands of cars  and that means used-car shoppers should be on alert for vehicles that could be hiding serious water damage.

title: Broadening a Transgender Tale That Has Only Just Begun
description: What a difference it makes when an actual trans person plays the role.

title: Home Renovation for a Modern Family in Bel Air
description: It wasnt quite The Brady Bunch, but Robin Maguire and Marc Schabergs house hunt did involve two single parents, six children, a blended family and a midcentury home in Southern California. And the renovation phase had a sense of urgency, because Ms. Maguire, who worked in real estate development before becoming a novelist and painter, had given up her house to live with Mr. Schaberg, a film financier, in his cramped post-divorce apartment.

title: Motorist Who Alerted Police Speaks Out
description: Deborah Dills, a motorist on her way to work on Thursday, called in the tip that led the police to Dylann Roof, who is accused of killing nine people at a church in Charleston, S.C.

title: A First Look at the Mets New Round of Artist Videos
description: Watch the video on Vimeo.

title: A First Look at the Mets New Round of Artist Videos
description: Watch the video on Vimeo.

title: Popcast: Tomatoes Giving Country Its Bite
description: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the women of country music.

title: Berlin Opera to Bring in a New Young Director
description: The leadership at the Staatsoper in Berlin will grow younger by a generation. The opera house says Matthias Schulz, 37, will replace Jrgen Flimm, 73, as intendant, or general director, in 2018.

title: Berlin Opera to Bring in a New Young Director
description: The leadership at the Staatsoper in Berlin will grow younger by a generation. The opera house says Matthias Schulz, 37, will replace Jrgen Flimm, 73, as intendant, or general director, in 2018.

title: List of Requirements for Twitters Next Leader Runs Deep
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The job requirements for the next chief executive of Twitter are forbidding.

title: Solange Knowless Attack Handbag Now Comes in 18-Karat Gold
description: In what may be the ultimate example of fashion high-low thinking, Anya Hindmarch, the British luxury handbag maker, is about to unveil a new incarnation of her signature Walkers Crisps bag  the evening purse in the shape of a crumpled bag of potato chips that became really famous when Solange Knowles used one to attack her brother-in-law, Jay Z, while in an elevator after the 2014 Met Gala. The bag will be offered in 18-karat yellow gold, as well as in white gold and rose gold.

title: At BAMcinemaFest, Provocations Old and New
description: Nicely synced to summer, BAMcinemaFest again provides a lineup of new films that easily outdistances the multiplex these days. (Among them are Chad Gracias documentary Russian Woodpecker, an award-winning investigation of the Chernobyl disaster, and The Invitation, a drawing-room thriller by Karyn Kusama, who directed Jennifers Body. Both will be screened on Friday.)

title: Review: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl
description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews Me and Earl and the Dying Girl.

title: Disappearing Porpoise: Down to 97 and Dropping Fast
description: The worlds most endangered porpoise is disappearing much faster than previously believed, according to a new report from the International Committee for the Recovery of the Vaquita.

title: Adjusting to Apples New Photo Software
description: Q. I am trying to leave iPhoto behind and get used to the Photos app for OS X on my Mac, but all the familiar controls for adjusting the color, contrast and other aspects of the image seem to have moved or have disappeared. For example, where are the Sharpness and De-Noise sliders that were under the Adjust tab in iPhoto?

title: Daily Report: Big Challenges Ahead for Twitters Next Chief
description: The job requirements for the next chief executive of Twitter are forbidding, Vindu Goel reports for The New York Times.

title: Daily Report: Big Challenges Ahead for Twitters Next Chief
description: The job requirements for the next chief executive of Twitter are forbidding, Vindu Goel reports for The New York Times.

title: 1890: Germans Proud of Heligoland
description: Germany is thrilling with pleasure over the cession of Heligoland by England. The National Zeitung says, With a surprise as gratifying as it is great, Germany will hear of her acquisition of Heligoland. Kaiser William II has thus begun his reign by proving himself to be a true Mehrer des Reichs  augmenter of the Empire.

title: Fifty Shades Fan Fiction Assumes a Life of Its Own
description: In a note to readers on the dedication page of her new novel, Grey, E. L. James sounds a bit like the exasperated mother of whiny, demanding children.

title: Alzheimers Supplements Targeted by U.S. Senator
description: A United States Senator this week raised concerns about dietary supplements that claim to protect against dementia and Alzheimers disease and urged 15 major companies and retailers to explain why they sell dubious supplements.

title: Toyota Defends Diversity Hiring After American Is Arrested
description: TOKYO  Toyota Motor was forthright, even proud, about why it promoted a group of foreign and female managers this spring: The automaker wanted more diversity in an executive suite dominated by Japanese men.

title: Mariane Pearl: Revisiting the Cuba of My Youth
description: My cousin Julias porch in Havana is bare, except for three plastic chairs and a bench, but her front yard is a local hot spot where everyday life unfolds. On my last visit there, our gaze fell on a skinny man with green eyes and skin the color of dark chocolate sucking on an avocado seed as he eavesdropped on a shouting match between a couple of chess players. Another man, gaptoothed and wearing a baseball cap, came along to loudly mock them all. This joyous and endless cacophony amid the incomparable Cuban soundtrack of salsa music, the frantic crowing of a rooster and the barking of more dogs than I can count was music to my ears. A satisfying journey to Cuba for me involves dedicating time to giving in to my surroundings. So I settled in eagerly for the magic realism that is Julias life.

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Munich

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Munich

title: Stuff We Liked
description: The articles, maps, graphics and other Internet ephemera that The Upshot staff liked this week:

title: New Faces
description: This seasons standout models.

title: Clemente, the Double Outsider
description: Today there is an abundance of Latinos in Major League Baseball, but not when Roberto Clemente took right field for the Pittsburgh Pirates 60 years ago this spring.

title: In Myanmar, Cash Remains King, and It Had Better Be Clean
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Some of the practices of Myanmars dictatorship have eased in recent years: Political prisoners have been released, censorship of news media has been lifting, and the erstwhile empty roads of the countrys largest cities are now jammed with imported cars.

title: Pot Enthusiasts Convene In Entrepreneurial Bliss
description: Cannabis conference? the doorman politely asked, signaling a mood hardly mellow but deep into profit-making as the Cannabis World Congress and Business Exposition displayed the wares and wisdom of the nations flourishing marijuana industry.

title: The YouTube Brawler Kimbo Slice Tries an M.M.A. Comeback
description: It seems like an eternity ago in the fast-maturing world of mixed martial arts, but there was a time when a man named Kimbo Slice was the most talked about fighter in the country.

title: Death to Data Journalism
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Charleston Shooting Reignites Debate About Confederate Flag
description: On Thursday, hours after a white gunman killed nine people in a black church in Charleston, S.C., a Confederate flag continued to fly over the grounds of the states Capitol.

title: A German Writer Translates a Puzzling Illness Into a Best-Selling Book
description: MANNHEIM, Germany  IF Giulia Enders had not contracted a mysterious illness as a teenager that left her covered with sores, she, like most of us, might never have thought much about her digestive tract, except when it was out of whack. She might never have enrolled in medical school, either, and she almost certainly would not have written a best-selling book about digestion last year that has captivated Germany, a nation viewed, fairly or not, as exceedingly anal-retentive.

title: Hannibal Season 3, Episode 3 Recap: He Left Me With a Smile
description: Season 3, Episode 3: Secondo

title: Hannibal Season 3, Episode 3 Recap: He Left Me With a Smile
description: Season 3, Episode 3: Secondo

title: A Sea Change in Treating Heart Attacks
description: CAMDEN, N.J.  Yvette Samuels was listening to jazz late one night when she felt a stabbing pain down her left shoulder. She suspected a heart attack  she had heard about the symptoms from watching a Rosie ODonnell standup routine on television  and managed to scratch on the door that connected her single room to her neighbors. He found her collapsed on the floor.

title: 1940: Reds Mass in Baltic Area
description: BERLIN  As France waited for armistice terms and Great Britain faced possible invasion, a drama was being unrolled today in eastern Europe which under other circumstances would have attracted primary attention. With a million or more Soviet troops occupying the three Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, the Soviet-German pact of non-aggression of last August, which at no time was based on anything more substantial than opportunism, appeared to have been liquidated in fact though not in theory.

title: Log On and Hit Like  Facebook Measures the Candidates
description: If elections were won based on Facebook chatter, Hillary Rodham Clinton, Senator Bernie Sanders and Senator Rand Paul would be the front-runners in early primary season states.

title: Log On and Hit Like  Facebook Measures the Candidates
description: If elections were won based on Facebook chatter, Hillary Rodham Clinton, Senator Bernie Sanders and Senator Rand Paul would be the front-runners in early primary season states.

title: Ralph Roberts, Cable TV Pioneer Who Built Comcast, Dies at 95
description: Ralph J. Roberts, who at the dawn of the cable television industry bought a small cable service in Tupelo, Miss., and built it into Comcast, today the largest cable television company in the nation, died Thursday night in Philadelphia. He was 95.

title: Mortgage Market on the Mend
description: New research from TransUnion, the credit information service, predicts that some 1.5 million homeowners who were forced out of the mortgage market after the housing bust will have recovered sufficiently to re-enter the market sometime between now and 2017.

title: The Computer as a Financial Planner
description: COMPUTER-GENERATED investment advice has gotten a lot of attention in the last few years. And for good reason.

title: Phil Jackson Talks About N.B.A. Draft, Carmelo Anthony and More
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  On the afternoon of May 19, Phil Jackson, the president of the Knicks, met with Steve Mills, his general manager, at the teams practice complex here. Mills had a couple of hours before he was expected to report to a Midtown Manhattan hotel, where he would represent the team at the N.B.A.s annual draft lottery.

title: Parents, Remembered
description: BETTYVILLEA MemoirBy George Hodgman278 pp. Viking, $27.95.

title: The Divers Clothes Lie Empty, by Vendela Vida
description: Midway through The Divers Clothes Lie Empty, Vendela Vidas nameless protagonist finds herself sitting in a private V.I.P. lounge in the Regency Hotel in Casablanca. She is chatting with the personal bodyguard of an American movie star. The bodyguard describes his interest in the evolutionary theory of punctuated equilibrium, in which species, faced with a dramatic change in their circumstances, adapt rapidly. The young woman, who is being vetted for the part of stand-in to the famous actress in a film being shot in Casablanca, feigns amiable curiosity. She is desperate to appear sufficiently sane and normal to get the job; she doesnt want the bodyguard to realize that she herself is living proof of punctuated equilibrium, that the sequence of events that have occurred in the 48 hours since her arrival in Casablanca have propelled this previously unremarkable woman into committing a series of frauds that could get her into an awful lot of trouble.

title: Inside the List
description: Born Funny: The actress and comedian Ali Wentworth hits this weeks hardcover nonfiction list with Happily Ali After (new at No. 13), an essay collection about her mostly sincere efforts at self-improvement as her 50th birthday approached. I realized I faced some obstacles in my path to spiritual enlightenment, she writes in the introduction. I have been accused of being cynical and jaded on this particular subject. I dont read self-help books, except the ones that guarantee Ill lose 40 pounds in one hour. And I enjoy being codependent. My best life is never going to resemble, say, Angelina Jolies; I dont have the cheekbones, cant fly my own plane, and refugees make me too sad. But perhaps I could step up the consciousness a notch. This is Wentworths second book, after the 2012 best seller Ali in Wonderland, a comic memoir about her political childhood (her mother was Nancy Reagans social secretary), her Hollywood career and her life as Mrs. George Stephanopoulos. That books fans included Jackie Collins  who called it, in these pages, the funniest thing she had ever read  and Charlie Rose, who on his show asked Wentworth where her sense of humor came from. I was born funny, she told him. I think its instinctual. I dont think you can be taught. ... And I love being unscripted. I mean, this kind of thing to me is one of my favorite things to do. I dont think youre going to see me on Law and Order: SVU any time soon, you know.

title: The Ghost Network, by Catie Disabato
description: When you start a movement to shift culture away from the society of the spectacle, who better to push its goals than a pop star? That question, and the action it inspires, is the driving force behind Catie Disabatos The Ghost Network, a smart and thorny debut novel with a mystery at its heart.

title: Keep It Fake, by Eric G. Wilson
description: Toward the end of his terrific new philosophical investigation, Keep It Fake: Inventing an Authentic Life, Eric G. Wilson admits that, as with many of us, learning how to be a good dad was something he had a tough time figuring out. On the cusp of fatherhood he was working too much, and drinking too much  sound familiar?  and battling depression. But he had the good sense and good luck to find an excellent psychiatrist.

title: In the Country, by Mia Alvar
description: In Tagalog movies, the bida, or hero, battles the kontrabida, or villain, for the affections of a beautiful woman. As his family cheers at the bidas victory in the opening story of In the Country, Steve, a Filipino expat on a visit home, reflects: The script had succumbed, in the end, to our demands.

title: All Involved, by Ryan Gattis
description: In recent years, riot footage has practically become a subgenre of documentary filmmaking. We recognize the hallmarks  advancing police phalanxes, protesters in retreat, looters, burning cruisers, cameras tracking airborne projectiles  without always understanding the causes. While the 1992 Los Angeles riots lacked the exhaustive citizen reportage of more recent incidents, there was enough videotape running back then to give the rest of the country the lasting impression of a restless city entirely engulfed in chaos. In his latest novel, All Involved, Ryan Gattis imagines a narrative that, while mostly tangential to that chaos, attempts to give it more meaningful context through personalization.

title: Lori Roys Let Me Die in His Footsteps, and More
description: Open LET ME DIE IN HIS FOOTSTEPS (Dutton, $26.95) anywhere and Lori Roys melodious voice will float off the page, calling your attention to the way honeybees are soothed into a kind of stupor by the scent of lavender, or instructing you in the wisdom of hanging milk snakes by the front door to keep away evil. And when the teller of this Southern Gothic yarn really wants to engage your mind, her insinuating voice will direct you to the last public hanging held in the United States and a lingering curse on the Kentucky farming town that hosted the spectacle in the early dawn of a cold, damp day in 1936.

title: Circus Mirandus and Return to Augie Hobble
description: So all the worlds a stage, and we are merely players hoofing upon it? I bet Shakespeare picked up that nugget at Stratford-upon-Avon Middle School. Middle school ushers in the Narcissistic Age, a mannerist phase that comes between the magic years of learning to read and the disheartening Enlightenment that occurs between early high school and, say, midlife crisis. An Enlightenment that has to take in the reality of death.

title: Dahlov Ipcars Black and White, and More
description: The night, as a fervent lyric made famous by Patti Smith implies, may not belong to preschoolers. But it is nonetheless a time  and mystery-laden phenomenon  that fascinates all young children, and arouses fear in many. From the ritualized consolations of Goodnight Moon to the antic rebellion of In the Night Kitchen, picture books have charted countless courses through the dark. The tradition continues in three new books and one notable reissue.

title: Ratscalibur and Super Fly
description: Animals can be an authors best friend. Talking animals, to be precise. Since the dawn of folklore, anthropomorphic beasties have been reliable go-to guys when a story simply wouldnt be as much fun with plain old human protagonists. And so it is that Josh Lieb, in Ratscalibur, layers on the fur  and the claws, and the skinny pink tails  to transform the archetypal unassuming kid fulfills prophecy and saves the kingdom plot into a witty mash-up of favorite fantasy motifs.

title: More Happy Than Not, by Adam Silvera
description: If only for the outsize cultural imprint left by The Hunger Games, it is reasonable to argue that young adult fiction has done a far more aggressive job grappling with social inequality than much of what is rendered today in the name of literary fiction, a world where poor and working-class characters are so often visible merely at the periphery, if they are visible at all. The novel Panic, for example, by the best-selling Y.A. author Lauren Oliver, is set in a small town so devoid of prospects that graduating seniors spend their time battling it out in a game whose grand prize is the unimaginable sum of $67,000. In Laurie Halse Andersons The Impossible Knife of Memory, a teenager returns home after several years on the road with her truck-driver father, an Iraq war veteran who suffers from PTSD. We are far, in other words, from the moneyed insularities of Exeter.

title: How Not to Respond to the Murders in Charleston
description: The world has seen an outpouring of grief and outrage since nine people were gunned down in a clearly racist act of vicious murder in a historic black church in Charleston, South Carolina. There are many appropriate and decent ways to mourn those victims, to denounce the avowed racist who is accused of murdering them, and to ruminate on the state of race relations in our country.

title: Science Panel Tries to Reinject Reality into Flood Insurance Pricing
description: Federal flood insurance in the United States is a mess, with politics continuing to trump data, and taxpayers paying the price.

title: Tips for Choosing Variable Annuity With Income Rider
description: Buying a variable annuity with a guaranteed income rider can be incredibly confusing  and many investors walk away with products that they dont fully understand.

title: Variable Annuity Plus Guaranteed Income Merits Careful Scrutiny
description: ASK retirees to design the perfect investment and it would surely be a guaranteed paycheck for life, providing protection in the markets darkest hours, yet allowing them to profit during upswings.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE MASTER OF CONFESSIONS: The Making of a Khmer Rouge Torturer, by Thierry Cruvellier. Translated by Alex Gilly. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $16.99.) Cruvellier, who has reported on some of the worlds most notorious war crimes, recounts the trial of Duch, the director of the Khmer Rouges S-21 prison, where thousands of people were killed. His exhaustive account includes a sly commentary on the whims and limits of the international justice system.

title: Under the Influence
description: The many inspirations of the actor and musician Jason Schwartzman.

title: Disneys Teen Beach 2, a Return to Sun and Bubble Gum
description: Their endless summer has ended. In Teen Beach 2 (Friday, 8 p.m. Eastern), the sequel to the 2013 Disney Channel smash musical, its been three months since Mack (Maia Mitchell) and Brady (Ross Lynch) surfed 50 years into the past and onto the set of Wet Side Story. But in real life, the only epic wave is the one drowning their love.

title: Royal Ballet Returns to New York After More Than a Decade
description: LONDON  Death is here, knock, knock, knock! Monica Mason called out cheerily as two dancers circled the Royal Opera House studio here. Another dancer lay prone in the center, and Ms. Mason moved among the Royal Ballet principals, calling out counts, stretching her arms as she echoed their movements and reminding them of accents or nuances.

title: In an Age of Less, the Critic Demands More
description: In a new book, a cultural sage with long experience heading a major performing arts institution chides a music critic for paying scant attention over the years to what, in the sages view, really matters in the running of orchestras and opera companies: earned and contributed income, cost controls, responsible budgeting and such.

title: Eiko Brings A Body in a Station to the Fulton Center
description: Usually, Eiko dances as part of the twosome known as Eiko and Koma. But since last fall, shes also been dancing as a lone figure in crowded train stations. Her A Body in a Station, part of a series of solos called A Body in Places, had its premiere in October at 30th Street Station in Philadelphia. Now, as part of the Lower Manhattan Cultural Councils River to River Festival, A Body in a Station is coming to the gleaming Fulton Center.

title: Amazing Grace, a Musical About Slavery, to Begin Previews
description: Hamilton isnt the only new historical epic musical opening on Broadway this summer. With far less fanfare but large ambitions, not to mention budget ($16 million), Amazing Grace tries to tell an overtly religious story about Americas original sin through a portrait of John Newton, an 18th- and 19th-century slave trader turned abolitionist who wrote the well-known hymn named in the title.

title: From Doris Salcedo, Domestic Vessels of Trauma and Loss
description: A survey of Doris Salcedos haunted, haunting sculptures opens on Friday at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. The best are made from pieces of domestic furniture in dark wood that are customary in Bogot, the Colombian capital, where Ms. Salcedo was born in 1958.

title: Jacquelin Harris, Dancer and Math Major, on Her First Year With Alvin Ailey
description: Not many dancers spend their days dashing between rehearsal and multivariable calculus class. But that was college for Jacquelin Harris, one of the newest members of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

title: The Boston Early Music Festival Celebrates Charpentier
description: Orpheus for once caught a break. Marc-Antoine Charpentier never finished his pastoral chamber opera La Descente dOrphe aux Enfers (1685-86).

title: Bang on a Can Marathon and Make Music New York for Fathers Day
description: Ties? Socks? Forget the tired old Fathers Day staples and celebrate Dad with music this year. Its never been easier (or cheaper): Sunday brings both the Bang on a Can Marathon to the newly spiffy Brookfield Place (now featuring one of the citys best food courts) and a swarm of more than 1,000 live performances across town as part of Make Music New York. Yes, all free.

title: King Sunny Ad to Perform in New York
description: The Nigerian bandleader King Sunny Ad doesnt play in North America often  the last time was in 2009  but the spaces between live exposures to his music are long enough for you to recover your hunger for it. Hunger helps: His music comes in big servings. There tends to be over a dozen members in his African Beats band: harmonizing chorus singers; percussionists building multitiered, melodic rhythm on talking drums and shakers; sometimes a pedal-steel guitarist; and Mr. Ad himself, singing Yoruba oral literature in a soft voice and playing sweet, consonant bursts on his electric guitar.

title: Male Models to Watch This Season
description: Arianna Pradarelli, a casting director and T contributor, calls out some of the spring/summer 2016 runways most exciting new faces.

title: Male Models to Watch This Season
description: Arianna Pradarelli, a casting director and T contributor, calls out some of the spring/summer 2016 runways most exciting new faces.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE MEURSAULT INVESTIGATION, by Kamel Daoud. Translated by John Cullen. (Other Press, paper, $14.95.) This rich and inventive Algerian novel imagines the story of the Arab murdered on the beach in Camuss The Stranger.

title: Chris Christie Suggests That Changing Gun Laws Wont Stop Violence
description: Speaking in the wake of the church shooting in Charleston, S.C., Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey suggested on Friday that changes to the gun laws would not effectively stop such violence.

title: Chris Christie Suggests That Changing Gun Laws Wont Stop Violence
description: Speaking in the wake of the church shooting in Charleston, S.C., Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey suggested on Friday that changes to the gun laws would not effectively stop such violence.

title: Memories Made, and Found, on a Moped
description: On a return trip to Bermuda, a son, now also a father, hopes to solve a longtime family mystery.

title: Andrew McCarthy: My Return Trip to Bermuda
description: Our scooter zipped past a small sign and I caught a fleeting glimpse. My sleep-deprived brain latched hold of something and went scrolling back through the years. Could this be it?, I thought.

title: Greek Premiers Address at Russian Forum
description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece addressed the St. Petersburg Economic Forum on Friday, as his country struggles to reach a deal with its creditors to avoid defaulting on debt payments.

title: Toddlers Have Sense of Justice, Puppet Study Shows
description: Children as young as age 3 will intervene on behalf of a victim, reacting as if victimized themselves, scientists have found.

title: Greece and Its Creditors Pummel Each Other, but Fight Is Not Over Yet
description: Like prizefighters, the two sides of the negotiations over the Greek bailout have been circling each other, throwing punch after punch.

title: Breaking News: The Rush to Cover a Shooting in Charleston
description: Steve Kenny is a senior editor on the news desk.

title: Brian Williams, in Raw Form, Delivers an Apology on Today
description: He couldnt say the L word.

title: Giving More Globally, and Less Locally
description: There was a lot of good news this week in the annual report on American philanthropy published by the Giving USA Foundation. Overall giving passed its prerecession peak, according to the organizations calculations. Generosity in nearly every category was up, in some cases strongly.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: When I Grow Up
description: This week, Heather Havrilesky and Meghan Daum discuss new books about bringing up children and redefining adulthood; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Vendela Vida talks about her new novel, The Divers Clothes Lie Empty; questions from readers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Iran Still Aids Terrorism and Bolsters Syrias President, State Department Finds
description: WASHINGTON  Iran continued its terrorist-related activity last year and also continued to provide broad military support to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, the State Department said Friday in its annual report on terrorism.

title: Bain and Other Private Equity Firms to Buy Italian Payments Company
description: LONDON  A consortium of private equity firms that includes Bain Capital agreed on Friday to acquire the Italian payment and clearing services company Istituto Centrale delle Banche Popolari Italiane for 2.15 billion euros, or about $2.4 billion.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: High-Heels, Fats and Test-Tube Babies
description: Take the Quiz

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: When I Grow Up
description: This week, Heather Havrilesky, Meghan Daum and Vendela Vida.

title: Jeb Bush Pledges Debate on Gay Marriage After Court Ruling
description: Jeb Bush told a gathering of religious conservatives here on Friday that the debate over same-sex marriage should continue irrespective of what the courts say, signaling that he would not consider a Supreme Court decision favorable to gay rights as the last word on the subject.

title: Jeb Bush Pledges Debate on Gay Marriage After Court Ruling
description: Jeb Bush told a gathering of religious conservatives here on Friday that the debate over same-sex marriage should continue irrespective of what the courts say, signaling that he would not consider a Supreme Court decision favorable to gay rights as the last word on the subject.

title: Lawmakers Push to End Military Transgender Ban
description: Unlike the ban on openly gay troops repealed in 2011, the policies that prohibit transgender people from joining the armed forces have historically attracted minimal, if any, interest on Capitol Hill.

title: Clinical Trial of Experimental Ebola Drug Is Halted
description: In a setback for efforts to combat Ebola, an experimental drug that researchers had considered one of the most promising potential treatments has not worked in patients in Sierra Leone, the drugs developer said Friday.

title: Jeremy Scotts Moschino Collection
description: Mr. Scott presents his Moschino collection in Florence, Italy, with Katy Perry and ASAP Rocky in attendance.

title: At Moschino, Jeremy Scott Lightens Things Up
description: FLORENCE, Italy  Hes the funniest man in the fashion industry, Katy Perry said backstage at the Moschino show Thursday, held in a series of frescoed salons of the fabled Palazzo Corsini here alongside the Arno. She was talking about an old pal, the designer Jeremy Scott.

title: In English, French Paper Urges Britain to Heed Waterloo and Stay in E.U.
description: PARIS  The French, it seems safe to say, have had a hard time getting over Waterloo.

title: Stephen Colberts Digital Nation
description: When Donald J. Trump arrived on an escalator and announced on Tuesday that he would seek the 2016 Republican presidential nomination, he set off a gold rush among late-night comedians who could not wait to satirize his bombastic, digressive declaration speech.

title: Gap Grows Smaller, H.R.C. Picks a Pantsuit and Taylor Swift Is Always Ready for a Zip Line
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: Gap Grows Smaller, H.R.C. Picks a Pantsuit and Taylor Swift Is Always Ready for a Zip Line
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: Lindsey Grahams Niece Recalls Dylann Storm Roof as Strange
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  The killing of nine people Wednesday at the historic Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church hit close to home for many South Carolinians.

title: Lindsey Grahams Niece Recalls Dylann Storm Roof as Strange
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  The killing of nine people Wednesday at the historic Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church hit close to home for many South Carolinians.

title: Quiz: How Toxic Is Your Work Environment?
description: Take the quiz and find out how your workplace compares to those I have studied.

title: Usher and Justin Bieber Will Face Copyright Lawsuit
description: Justin Bieber and his mentor, Usher, will face a jury trial to determine whether they illegally copied parts of a song after a federal appeals court ruling on Thursday. Devin Copeland (better known as the R&B singer De Rico) and his songwriting partner, Mareio Overton, filed a $10 million lawsuit against Mr. Bieber and Usher in 2013, saying that various versions of a song called Somebody to Love recorded by the artists shared beats, time signatures and lyrics with a song of the same title they wrote in 2008.Justin Bieber and his mentor, Usher, will face a jury trial to determine whether they illegally copied parts of the song Somebody to Love after a federal appeals court ruling on Thursday.

title: Usher and Justin Bieber Will Face Copyright Lawsuit
description: Justin Bieber and his mentor, Usher, will face a jury trial to determine whether they illegally copied parts of a song after a federal appeals court ruling on Thursday. Devin Copeland (better known as the R&B singer De Rico) and his songwriting partner, Mareio Overton, filed a $10 million lawsuit against Mr. Bieber and Usher in 2013, saying that various versions of a song called Somebody to Love recorded by the artists shared beats, time signatures and lyrics with a song of the same title they wrote in 2008.Justin Bieber and his mentor, Usher, will face a jury trial to determine whether they illegally copied parts of the song Somebody to Love after a federal appeals court ruling on Thursday.

title: Hatred or Heritage?
At Home, Many Seniors Are Imprisoned by Their Independence
description: What she mourns most, says Solange DeLaPaz, are the mundane pleasures and rituals of her once-active life. A weekly manicure at the corner nail salon. Saturday excursions to Macys shoe department.

title: Julie Johnston, a Late Call-Up for U.S., Continues Her Ascent
description: EDMONTON, Alberta  After leading the United States to the womens under-20 world soccer championship in 2012, Julie Johnston met Christie Rampone, a fellow center back and the longtime captain of the senior national team.

title: Selfies
description: Selfies with presidential hopefuls

title: Vikram ChatwalsMany-Roomed Getaway
description: When Vikram Chatwal, the Manhattan hotelier responsible for a string of boutique hotels including the Dream Midtown, escapes from SoHo to his country house in Old Brookville, N.Y., assorted family members are often there to greet him.

title: Matchmaking Season for Republican Presidential Candidates and Economists
description: Its the economists version of social networking.

title: New York Prison Officer Is Placed on Leave Amid Escape Investigation
description: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y.  A corrections officer at the maximum-security prison where two inmates escaped this month has been put on administrative leave in connection with the investigation, officials said on Friday, and the New York State Police said officers were investigating a possible sighting of the escapees.

title: Popcast: Women and Country Music
description: On this weeks Popcast, we discuss the situation for women in country music right now. The occasion is Kacey Musgraves new album Pageant Material  for which, as Mr. Caramanica wrote in Arts and Leisure this week, shell be pegged as an agent of change, a palliative for this genres many illsbut also a recent statement by the country-radio consultant Keith Hill that women listeners, the prime demographic of country radio, preferred to hear male singers. To what degree is Ms. Musgraves album a satisfying response? Other singers discussed: Carrie Underwood, Miranda Lambert, Kelsea Ballerini, Ashley Monroe, Angaleena Presley, Laura Bell Bundy, Mickey Guyton, Jana Kramer, Cam, Maddie & Tae, Reba McEntire.

title: Popcast: Women and Country Music
description: On this weeks Popcast, we discuss the situation for women in country music right now. The occasion is Kacey Musgraves new album Pageant Material  for which, as Mr. Caramanica wrote in Arts and Leisure this week, shell be pegged as an agent of change, a palliative for this genres many illsbut also a recent statement by the country-radio consultant Keith Hill that women listeners, the prime demographic of country radio, preferred to hear male singers. To what degree is Ms. Musgraves album a satisfying response? Other singers discussed: Carrie Underwood, Miranda Lambert, Kelsea Ballerini, Ashley Monroe, Angaleena Presley, Laura Bell Bundy, Mickey Guyton, Jana Kramer, Cam, Maddie & Tae, Reba McEntire.

title: No Time to Be Nice at Work
description: MEAN bosses could have killed my father. I vividly recall walking into a hospital room outside of Cleveland to see my strong, athletic dad lying with electrodes strapped to his bare chest. What put him there? I believe it was work-related stress. For years he endured two uncivil bosses.

title: Greek Pie on the Skinny Side
description: Aglaia Kremezi has no problem making phyllo dough at home in Greece whenever she makes anything pie-like. And she makes a lot of pies.

title: Gun Control Voices in Congress All but Silent After Charleston Shooting
description: WASHINGTON  After the fatal shootings at a landmark black church in Charleston, S.C., Senator Joe Manchin III, who sponsored gun safety legislation that failed in Congress two years ago, released a statement lamenting the nine souls who were lost.

title: TriBeCa Tower Inspired by a Glass Vase
description: Yet another tall residential tower designed to stand out against the Manhattan skyline is poised to enter the market  this time in Lower Manhattan.

title: A Brooklyn Record
description: A three-story brick townhouse in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, sold for $15.5 million, the highest price ever paid for a single residence in the borough.

title: Two Israeli Men Are Attacked, and One Killed, Near Settlement in the West Bank
