title: Blood Pressure, the Mystery Number
description: Almost half a century after rigorous studies showed medicines that lower blood pressure prevent heart attacks, strokes and deaths, researchers still do not know just how low blood pressure should go. More than 58 million Americans take these drugs, but this fundamental question remains unresolved.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Review: Make Music New York Teaches Buildings How to Sing
description: New Yorkers generally dont need much encouragement to make noise. But twice a year, at the summer and winter solstices, Make Music New York invites them to come together to play, sing and listen to an array of sounds as diverse as the city itself.

title: A Possibly Lifesaving Guide to Heart Attacks
description: Tremendous progress has been made in treating heart disease, but it is still the biggest killer of Americans, accounting for one in seven deaths. Here are answers to some common questions about the symptoms and treatment of heart attacks and narrowed aortic valves.

title: Berlin Philharmonic Selects Kirill Petrenko to Succeed Simon Rattle
description: When the Berlin Philharmonic announced on Monday that its next chief conductor would be Kirill Petrenko, the Russian-born music director of the Bavarian State Opera in Munich, the organization was awarding one of the most prestigious posts in classical music to a widely respected artist who has largely shunned the spotlight courted by some of his peers.

title: Dunton Hot Springs
description: This remote getaway offers lavish meals and a nearby 1,600 acres to enjoy.

title: Review: Trisha Brown: In Plain Site Sends Dancers Gamboling in the Grass
description: If you were taking a waterfront stroll along the bottom tip of Manhattan late Sunday afternoon, you may have happened upon seven people dressed in white, their limbs twisting gently in the breeze like the branches of the surrounding trees. This was not a color-coordinated group of tai chi practitioners. This was the Trisha Brown Dance Company, performing an excerpt from Ms. Browns final work, Im Going to Toss My Arms  if You Catch Them, Theyre Yours (2011).

title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Review: Merce Cunninghams Crises Opens Dance at the New Whitney
description: In the 1950s, the choreographer Merce Cunningham became an early exponent of what would become the Theater of the Absurd, alongside the playwrights Beckett, Ionesco and Pinter. With Crises (1960), he made a nonnarrative dance drama in which human behavior becomes inscrutable, absurd and dark. Its dances show one man and four women; whats still startling is how wild, independent and driven the women are.

title: Mayor de Blasio Poised to Hire Nearly 1,300 Police Officers
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio, in a sharp shift from his initial objections, is poised to hire nearly 1,300 additional officers for the New York Police Department, a surprising addition in a $78.5 billion budget deal announced by city leaders on Monday night.

title: Data Mining Start-Up Enigma to Expand Commercial Business
description: The deaths of five people, including three children, in a raging fire that engulfed a home in New Orleans last November was a terrible tragedy, the citys first deputy mayor, Andy Kopplin, said.

title: Walter Scheib, Innovative Former White House Chef, Is Dead at 61
description: Walter Scheib, who brought American cuisine prepared in a lighter style to the White House as its executive chef during the administrations of Bill Clinton and George W. Bush, was found dead on Sunday near a hiking trail outside Taos, N.M. He was 61.

title: Computer Failure Leaves State Dept. Unable to Issue Visas
description: The United States has been unable to issue visas to travelers around the world for two weeks because of a computer hardware failure that remains unresolved, State Department officials said Monday.

title: A Complicated Rescue
description: A man fell deep inside a cave in Spain, suffering such serious injuries that neither he nor his friends could get him out.

title: Third-Party Groups Sue F.E.C. to Try to Open Up Presidential Debates
description: As the 2016 presidential campaign gets into gear, one of the biggest debates so far has been about the debates. For some Democrats, such as Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, there arent enough planned. For lesser-known Republicans, the polling criteria could make it difficult for them to even get on the stage.

title: F.B.I. Struggles to Pinpoint the Fingers Behind a Hacking
description: WASHINGTON  As F.B.I. agents try to build a case against personnel in the St. Louis Cardinals front office who are accused of breaking  into the network that housed the Houston Astros closely guarded baseball intelligence, they are struggling with one particular aspect of the investigation: determining who, specifically, had his hands on the keyboard.

title: Hacking Grounds Flights of Polands National Airline
description: Dozens of flights of Polands national airline, LOT Airlines, were grounded for several hours on Sunday, stranding thousands of passengers at Chopin Airport in Warsaw, after what the airline described as a computer attack by unidentified outsiders.

title: Takata Is Said to Have Stopped Safety Audits as Cost-Saving Move
description: In the middle of what would become the largest automotive recall in American history, the Japanese airbag manufacturer Takata halted global safety audits to save money, according to internal company emails cited in a report published on Monday by a Senate committee.

title: In Performance | Wolf Hall
description: A scene from the Royal Shakespeare Companys adaptation of Hilary Mantels novels about Thomas Cromwell (Ben Miles) and King Henry VIII (Nathaniel Parker), on Broadway at the Winter Garden Theater.

title: Mayor de Blasio to Make Lunar New Year a School Holiday
description: Mayor Bill de Blasios administration is expected on Tuesday to add the Lunar New Year to the New York public school calendar, allowing the citys Asian families to celebrate an important holiday with their children without tarnishing attendance records.

title: Stillbirth: Share Your Story
description: Stillbirth is not uncommon in the United States, but it remains shrouded in silence. We invite you to share your experience.

title: Silence of Stillbirth
description: One in 160 pregnancies in the United States ends in stillbirth. Eleni Michailidis lost her baby, Alexander, at 38 weeks. This is her story.

title: After a Stillbirth, a Silent Delivery Room
description: Dr. Eleni Michailidis, 38, gave birth to a stillborn son, Alexander, in February. Stillbirth is not uncommon in the United States, affecting 1 in 160 pregnancies, but the experience is rarely discussed. Dr. Michailidiss narrative has been condensed and edited for space and clarity.

title: A Chinese Miner With a Heart of Gold
description: Sim Chi Yin says her story about miner afflicted with a serious lung disease has turned into a universal love story.

title: Frank Discussions on Race Help Define Hillary Clintons 2016 Campaign
description: In one of the most striking speeches of his 2008 presidential campaign, Barack Obama spoke about his candidacy as evidence that the country could transcend its racially divisive roots.

title: Planet Fitness Files to Go Public
description: Planet Fitness began a sprint toward the stock markets on Monday, filing for an initial public offering roughly two years after allying itself with a private equity firm.

title: Wikipedia Pages of Star Clients Altered by P.R. Firm
description: LOS ANGELES  Even by her own account, the supermodel Naomi Campbells 1994 album Babywoman didnt amount to much.

title: The Silence of Stillbirth
description: After Dr. Eleni Michailidis delivered a stillborn son, she and her husband sought to honor their infant and the experience. She tells her story in this video:

title: AirAsia Faces Red Tape and Tough Competition in India
description: DELHI  When the fast-growing Malaysian carrier AirAsia wanted to expand, India looked like the ideal frontier.

title: Risk of Extreme Weather From Climate Change to Rise Over Next Century, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  More people will be exposed to floods, droughts, heat waves and other extreme weather associated with climate change over the next century than previously thought, according to a new report in the British medical journal The Lancet.

title: 3 Convicted of Misdemeanors in World Trade Center Jump
description: Three sky divers who parachuted off the 1 World Trade Center tower were acquitted on Monday of the most serious felony charge against them but convicted of three misdemeanors after a two-week trial in Manhattan.

title: WPP Bets on Music in Marketing Venture with Alex Da Kid
description: CANNES, France  The advertising giant WPP has formed a joint venture with the music producer and songwriter Alex Da Kid, a move that represents a deeper push by the company into branded content.

title: Georgia: $2.2. Million Penalty for Illegal DNA Testing
description: A jury in Atlanta awarded $2,225,000 on Monday to two warehouse workers whose employer required them to submit DNA samples in violation of the federal Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act. The employer, Atlas Logistics Group Retail Services, was trying to identify someone who had been defecating in a warehouse. The two men were told to provide cheek swabs for DNA analysis. Neither was a match, and both sued. The case is the first brought under the act, which prohibits employers from obtaining genetic information about their employees.

title: Unicef Report Describes Grim Trends for the Poorest Children
description: Unicef warned Monday of what it described as grim trend lines for the worlds poorest children over the next 15 years, saying in a new report that many millions face preventable deaths, diseases, stunted growth and illiteracy.

title: Reversing Course, Pakistan Says Save the Children Can Stay
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Under pressure from Western allies, the government of Pakistan on Monday reversed its decision to expel Save the Children from the country, indicating that the aid agency could continue its operations albeit on a smaller scale and with tighter restrictions.

title: Take Down the ConfederateFlag, Symbol of Hatred
description: Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina acted in the interest of her state and the nation on Monday when she called on the Legislature to remove the Confederate battle flag from the State Capitol grounds, after a white man charged with killing nine African-Americans was seen waving the flag in photographs.

title: Lester Holt Reflects on Rise to NBCs Anchor Chair
description: When Lester Holt was a young broadcast journalist, he dreamed of one day sitting in the chair of the renowned news anchor Walter Cronkite.

title: All-Star Votes Grow in Number, if Not in Value
description: Omar Infante has played 14 years in the major leagues, a career that should not make him a punch line. But Infante, simply by playing for the Kansas City Royals, has come to symbolize a ridiculous wrinkle in the fan voting for All-Star Game.

title: Government in Ethiopia Is on Track to Win With 100% of Vote
description: Ethiopias governing party and its allies are poised to control every seat in the nations Parliament, according to official results announced Monday by the countrys electoral board.

title: With a Tap of Taylor Swifts Fingers, Apple Retreated
description: In an age of depressed record sales, her albums sell by the millions. Her tours fill arenas around the world. And a complimentary tweet to her nearly 60 million followers can help kick-start another singers career.

title: Karl-Anthony Towns Pursues Perfection From Atop the N.B.A. Draft Class
description: METUCHEN, N.J.  Two days before his only visit with the Minnesota Timberwolves, who are expected to select him No. 1 in Thursdays N.B.A. draft, Karl-Anthony Towns dripped sweat in a shallow corner of the 3-point arc at St. Josephs High School.

title: Optimism for an Agreement on Greek Debt, but Not for Long-Term Stability
description: BRUSSELS  Greece and its European partners appeared on Monday night to be heading for a deal by the end of the week that would secure further funding for Greece and a likely promise of more debt relief in return for changes in the pension and tax systems, European Union officials said.

title: The Loneliness of the Short-Seller
description: For some, they are the scourge of Wall Street. Yet short-sellers  investors who stake bets against stocks  are often the first to sound the alarm on a markets froth or a companys fraud.

title: U.S. Says Drone Killed an ISIS Member Linked to Benghazi Attack
description: WASHINGTON  An American drone strike last week killed a midlevel operative with the Islamic State who had been a conduit for the militant groups outreach to extremists in North Africa, Defense Department officials said on Monday.

title: Sean Combs Arrested in Kettlebell Assault at U.C.L.A.
description: Representatives for Sean Combs, the hip-hop mogul known as Diddy, who was arrested Monday and charged with assault with a deadly weapon at University of California, Los Angeles, said on Tuesday that his actions were solely defensive in nature to protect himself and his son.

description: More than 1.5 million people have fled their homes amid the violence and hunger in South Sudan, swelling villages and refugee camps.

title: As South Sudan Crisis Worsens, There Is No More Country
description: MALAKAL, South Sudan  In places where the fighting is fiercest, no one is even attempting to count the dead.

title: Council of Conservative Citizens Promotes White Primacy, and G.O.P. Ties
description: The Council of Conservative Citizens opposes all efforts to mix the races, and believes that the American people and government should remain European in their composition and character. It would severely restrict immigration, abolish affirmative action and dismantle the imperial judiciary that produced, among other rulings, the 1954 Supreme Court decision that integrated American education.

title: Jordan Spieth Avoids Sting and Creates Buzz
description: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash.  Failing is not the worst feeling in the world. If Jordan Spieths Grand Slam hopes had disappeared in the cup along with Dustin Johnsons eagle putt on the 18th hole of Chambers Bay Golf Course on Sunday night, he would have learned from the few poor shots he hit in the final round and moved on.

title: New York Taxi Agency Passes Rules on Price Estimates for Ride-Hailing Apps
description: Livery-cab passengers hailing rides through smartphone apps in New York City will get estimated fares for so-called surge pricing and itemized receipts, under rules passed Monday by the Taxi and Limousine Commission as it tries to keep pace with rapid changes in technology.

title: Health Care Law Spurs Merger Talks for Insurers
description: President Obama signed the Affordable Care Act more than five years ago. At the time, members of the health care industry  hospitals, doctors and insurers  were anxious about what it would do to the business. Everyone had an opinion, but nobody knew for sure.

title: One Dead as Druse Attack Israeli Ambulance in Golan Heights
description: JERUSALEM  Scores of Druse residents of the Golan Heights attacked an Israeli military ambulance late Monday as it transported two men wounded in the Syrian civil war, according to a military spokesman, killing one of the Syrians and critically injuring the other.

title: Seeking Refuge in South Sudan
description: More than 1.5 million people have fled their homes amid the violence and hunger in South Sudan, swelling villages and refugee camps.

title: Laura Antonelli Dies at 73; Popular, and Seductive, Italian Actress
description: Laura Antonelli, who by her own account was an ugly, clumsy teenager before transforming herself into one of Italys leading and most seductive film actresses, died on Monday at her seaside home in Ladispoli, west of Rome. She was 73.

title: After Elk River Spill, Congress Will Vote on Bill Regulating Toxic Chemicals
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va.  James Lewis still remembers the licorice smell of the water and how his skin itched when he showered.

title: Daniel Villanueva, a Creator of Univision, Dies at 77
description: Daniel D. Villanueva, a former professional football player who as a founder of the Univision network built a Spanish-language broadcasting empire spanning the United States, died on Thursday in Ventura, Calif. He was 77.

title: Holdouts From Rougher Era Endure at Lower East Side Club
description: Despite its name, Los Amigos Fishing and Hunting Club, with headquarters in a disheveled storefront on a still-gritty corner of the Lower East Side of Manhattan, had not seen a gun in nearly a decade  the clubs upstate deer hunting trips and fishing expeditions forgone long ago as its members aged into their 60s, 70s and 80s. Tracking bucks had given way to pastimes no more vigorous than dominoes as the club slipped into its sixth decade on Rivington Street.

title: Traveled Far and Wide
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  We have a word ladder by Jules P. Markey today, and this word ladder takes us back to the Bob HOPE and Bing CROSBY ROAD to  movie series.

title: Monday at the Womens World Cup
description: MONDAYS RESULTS

title: Womens World Cup: U.S., Helped by Red Card, Ejects Colombia
description: EDMONTON, Alberta  It began as a fascinating match of the establishment against the insurgent, an evolutionary tug of war in womens soccer, with the United States trying to maintain its hold as a traditional power and Colombia trying to break through to a new era of parity.

title: Panel Is Named to Investigate Handling of Allegations Against French Troops
description: A former justice of Canadas Supreme Court will lead an independent panel that will examine how the United Nations handled an inquiry into accusations that French peacekeepers not under United Nations command sexually abused children in the Central African Republic, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon announced Monday. In a statement, he said the former justice, Marie Deschamps, would be joined on the panel by Hassan Jallow of Gambia, the prosecutor of the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda; and Yasmin Sooka, the executive director of the Foundation for Human Rights in South Africa. Mr. Ban created the panel because of questions over whether United Nations rights officials had acted appropriately when they learned of the accusations. The abuse is alleged to have taken place from December 2013 into mid-2014. Although the organization was quick to investigate the allegations, the French authorities did not learn about them until last July, when a United Nations human rights officer leaked the report to them.

title: The Mystery of a Long-Missing Relic Is Solved and Returned to the Public
description: No one, it seems, had been actively looking for it. Still, the disappearance of a lamppost that had sat at the Manhattan entrance to the Queensboro Bridge for decades had been somewhat of a local mystery.

title: Transcript: Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina on Removing the Confederate Flag
description: Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina on Monday called for the removal of a Confederate battle flag from the statehouse grounds, after the symbol was embraced by a white man accused of killing nine black people last week. Here is a transcription of her speech, with a video excerpt.

title: W.N.B.A. Suspends Isiah Thomass Bid to Own Part of Liberty
description: Isiah Thomass bid for partial ownership of the Liberty hit a jagged edge Monday when the W.N.B.A. announced that the league and the team had agreed to indefinitely suspend the application process for Thomas, who was recently installed as president of the Liberty.

title: Four Prominent Chilean Politicians Are Charged With Tax Fraud
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Four prominent opposition politicians and members of Chiles Congress were charged Monday with tax fraud in a high-profile corruption case related to illegal campaign financing.

title: Divisive Symbolism of a Southern Flag
description: Supporters of the flag have said they view the shooting and the flag as unrelated. But Cornell William Brooks, the national president of the N.A.A.C.P., has called it an emblem of hate.

title: Man Sought in Connection With Attacks on Asian Women Is Found Dead
description: Investigators in Manhattan found the body of a 25-year-old man who was sought in connection with a series of attacks on Asian women and had apparently hanged himself, the police said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: There is no more country.

title: Michael Pineda Battered in His Shortest Outing of Season
description: Michael Pineda pitched brilliantly in his last start, throwing six hitless innings on the way to his eighth win of the season. Mondays matchup provided him a prime opportunity to continue the run.

title: A Most Provenal Meal
description: This summer, a British chef and a Montrealer sommelier aim to serve up the most Provenal meal in the south of France at a pop-up restaurant in the Grand Htel Nord Pinus in Arles. For her part, Laura Vidal, who founded the Paris Popup project with chef Harry Cummins in 2012, describes the four-course, prix-fixe bistro menu simply as an ode to Provence. But it is crafted almost entirely of local ingredients and with decidedly regional flavors. From the hotels dining room and an open-air terrace in the Place du Forum  a beautiful square beloved by locals in the small, ancient city that has recently been experiencing an intense revival of its traditional identity as a center for the arts (the Fondation Vincent Van Gogh reopened just last year there after an expansion and renovation)  the pair will serve lunch and dinner each Wednesday through Saturday until the end of August.

title: In Pittsburgh, One Baker Requires a Whole Year to Create the Perfect Loaf
description: Barely six months old, Pittsburghs Bread and Salt bakery is fast becoming known for its pane locale (local bread), made in a former slaughterhouse in the centuries-old Italian baking tradition of using organic flour, natural fermentation and local grain. Its owner and founder, the baker Rick Easton, acknowledges that the loaves ugly, formless and dark appearance belies their addictive flavor  which he accredits to the 100% stone-milled, high-extraction wheat flour crop he develops with a farmer in Weatherbury Farms in Avella, Pa. At the beginning of the season, Easton experiments with different wheat crops and handling techniques to find the right texture for bread he will serve that year. The result is a pane that feels like whole wheat, but the germ is retained so that the richness and natural oils produce an incredible amount of flavor and sweetness. From a customers perspective, its great to be able to think about wheat in that way, Easton explains. People are used to this supermarket bread that has a two-hour process. My process is 24 hours, and then were talking about crop planning that went in a year ago. So last year, someone was thinking about the grain that you would eat today. Below, Easton shares a recipe for enjoying his signature loaf  or your own favorite, local bread.

title: Final-Round Viewership
description: The United States Opens final round on Sunday was seen by an average of 6.7 million viewers on Fox. The audience peaked at 11.2 million from 10 to 10:30 p.m. Eastern. The Sunday viewership fell from a 9.6 million average the last time the Open was held in the Pacific time zone, in 2012, but last years Open in Pinehurst, N.C., had only a 4.6 million average.

title: Fewer Poor Uninsured After Health Law, Study Finds
description: WASHINGTON  The share of poor Americans who were uninsured declined substantially in 2014, according to the first full year of federal data since the Affordable Care Act extended coverage to millions of Americans last year.

title: The Roberts Courts Surprising Move Leftward
description: This term so far shows potential for a greater percentage of liberal decisions than any since 1969.

title: Word of the Day | elliptical
description: elliptical  \i-lip-ti-kl, e-\  adjective

title: Whats On TV Tuesday
description: 8 A.M. (HBO Signature) LIFE IS BEAUTIFUL (1997) Roberto Benigni, below, directed and stars in this Oscar winner for best foreign language film about an Italian Jew who concocts a ruse involving an elaborate game to protect his son (Giorgio Cantarini) from the realities of a Nazi concentration camp. Mr. Benigni effectively creates a situation in which comedy is courage, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. And he draws from this an unpretentious, enormously likable film that plays with history both seriously and mischievously. Piety has no place here, nor do tears until the final reel. Life Is Beautiful plays by its own rules.

title: Con Ed Employee Stabs Mother of His Child, Then Attacks 2 Co-Workers, Police Say
description: A Con Ed employee armed with a knife and an ax barged into a Manhattan office where his childs mother worked on Monday and stabbed her several times, the police said, then went to his job and attacked two co-workers.

title: U.S. Scolds China for Online Attacks
description: WASHINGTON  Top Obama administration officials admonished China in a bilateral meeting on Tuesday for sponsoring online attacks against businesses, but they remained silent  at least publicly  on the suspected role of Chinese hackers in the recently discovered theft from government computers of personal data on millions of federal employees and contractors.

title: Samsung Heir Apparent Apologizes for Hospitals Role in MERS Outbreak
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The man being groomed to run Samsung Group, the largest of South Koreas family-controlled conglomerates, apologized Tuesday for a Samsung hospitals failures in dealing with the countrys outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome.

title: A Chinese Miner With a Heart of Gold
description: He Quangui spends his days in a bed connected to a battered oxygen machine that pumps air into his lungs. The monotonous sound is punctuated only by his gasping cough. Like many of his fellow villagers in a mountainous area of Shaanxi Province in China, he answered the governments call to leave his farm and make a better living as a migrant worker in the 1990s.

title: Fracking and the Franciscans
description: Pope Francis is one of the worlds most inspiring figures. There are passages in his new encyclical on the environment that beautifully place human beings within the seamless garment of life. And yet over all the encyclical is surprisingly disappointing.

title: A Republican Case for Obamas Cuba Policy
description: Washington  I WAS born in Havana in November 1953, about six years before Fidel Castro led a revolution in Cuba. In July 1960, my family fled to the United States in search of freedom. Like many Cubans, they left behind close relatives, a business, property and memories. We lost everything.

title: The Iran Deals Fatal Flaw
description: PRESIDENT OBAMAS main pitch for the pending nuclear deal with Iran is that it would extend the breakout time necessary for Iran to produce enough enriched uranium for a nuclear weapon. In a recent interview with NPR, he said that the current breakout time is about two to three months by our intelligence estimates. By contrast, he claimed, the pending deal would shrink Irans nuclear program, so that if Iran later decided to break the deal, kick out all the inspectors, break the seals and go for a bomb, wed have over a year to respond.

title: Race, Guns, a Flag and Charleston
description: To the Editor:

title: War Crimes and the Gaza War
description: The United Nations report on last years Gaza war is another marker of the deadly, endless struggle between Israelis and Palestinians. It found serious violations of international humanitarian law that may amount to war crimes by both Israel and the Palestinian militants during a 50-day war that killed 2,251 Palestinians, including 1,462 civilians, and destroyed 18,000 homes in the Gaza Strip.

title: Time for New Yorks Legislature to Address Important Issues
description: New York lawmakers return to Albany on Tuesday to face a huge mess of half-done legislative measures and unresolved compromises. Their to-do list includes not only big, complicated issues but also routine matters like local sales taxes that are about to expire in counties and cities across the state. Gov. Andrew Cuomo and the two new leaders of the Assembly and the Senate need to end this stalemate and guide lawmakers to better solutions.

title: Why Women Apologize and Should Stop
description: EVERYONE knows what dirt tastes like. Last week, I ordered a salad at a restaurant and found myself crunching on a shoddily washed leaf. I took a few more sandy bites before explaining the situation to my waiter, apologizing and asking to see the menu once again.

description: The Guggenheim has become something of a brand over the years, with satellite locations in Venice and Bilbao, Spain, and one planned in Abu Dhabi. Now the museums proposed branch in Helsinki, Finland, is a step closer to reality, with the selection of a design that features charred timber and glass punctuated by a lighthouselike tower overlooking South Harbor.

title: Disney Has No Comment on the Recent Reversal of Layoffs
description: I have been covering the immigration beat for The New York Times for nine years, so I sensed that my recent story about layoffs of technology employees at Walt Disney World would draw our readers interest. The employees had been replaced by temporary immigrants, mainly from India, brought in by an outsourcing company, and the laid-off workers had to train the new ones in order to receive a severance.

description: When Jeb Bush finally did what he had been widely expected to do and formally announced his candidacy for president of the United States, his campaign came with all the accouterments of a contemporary political operation: new brand logo (a bright red Jeb!), website (Jeb2016.com) and multicultural pageantry.

description: LONDON  Ladbrokes, the British sports betting company, said on Tuesday that it was in talks with its gambling rival Gala Coral Group about a possible merger.

title: Preparations Proceed for Chinas World War II Parade
description: Chinahas releasednew details regarding its plans to stage a rare military parade in the heart of Beijing on Sept. 3.The eventwill commemorate the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II, and it will be the first time China has held a parade to observe the event.

title: Who Sounds Gay?
description: This short documentary explores the reasons that some men sound stereotypically gay, whether they are or not.

title: Who Sounds Gay?
description: For the last few years, Ive wondered why some men sound gay. I began asking people for their thoughts on the subject, and received a surprising range of answers. Some people said the gay voice was a put-on, like a man in a conspicuously sparkly dress. Others thought gay men sounded gay just to let other gay men know they were. Some thought that every man who sounds gay is gay, even if he claims otherwise. A lot of people said, Wow, I dont know.

title: New York Today: What Grows Below
description: Good morning on this changeable Tuesday.

title: Teenage Blogger to Undergo Mental Tests
description: A court ordered Amos Yee, 16, who had been arrested for online comments about the founding father of modern Singapore, to be sent back to a mental health institute, pending a psychiatric report.

title: Singapore Court Wants Teenage Blogger Held for Psychiatric Review
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  A Singapore court ruled on Tuesday that a teenage blogger who was convicted of obscenity and insulting religious feelings after he posted a video criticizing the late leader Lee Kuan Yew this year should be held for two weeks pending a psychiatric examination.

title: Burundis Bit-Part Politics
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  As I thought about the recent violence in the Central African nation of Burundi, I recalled a trip I made there three years ago. I realized that something Id seen in 2012 was a key to why the coup attempt in May by a group of army officers had failed.

title: Brazils Shaken Optimism
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Recent months have been pretty discouraging for Brazilians like me who were thrilled when Luiz Incio Lula da Silva took over the office of president in 2003. Many of us believed that Partido dos Trabalhadores (Workers Party) would finally turn our nation into a fair country. But corruption scandals, an economic recession and opportunistic alliances with former rivals have replaced optimism with an old sinking feeling: The defeatism that had been dormant since the early 1990s is now knocking at the door again, whispering to us, Nothing will ever work.

title: Britain Threatens E.U. Exit Over 3 Little Words in Treaty
description: LONDON  As an agglomeration of about 500 million people who speak at least two dozen tongues, the European Union is no stranger to disputes over language.

title: The Town Shrink
description: High Bridge, spanning the Harlem River and connecting Manhattan to the Bronx, is the oldest bridge in New York City. It is also an aqueduct, or used to be. Built in the 1840s, when public health officials across the country were battling cholera, it carried clean water from upstate to a growing urban population. In just a few decades, planners would build not just aqueducts but the so-called sanitary greens that today we call parks, including Highbridge Park, on the Manhattan side of the bridge. A side benefit of High Bridge was the walkway above the aqueduct that allowed Bronx pedestrians to reach Manhattan. By the 1960s, though, the aqueduct was no longer in use, and city planners, working to fight what was then called urban blight, decided to disconnect the boroughs. The Parks Department closed the old bridge, cutting off an artery.

title: Talking With Rob Decker, a Real-Life Roller Coaster Tycoon
description: From their earliest days, roller coasters have been designed to inspire awe (and an element of fear) among riders. Rob Decker, senior vice president of planning and design at Cedar Fair Entertainment, which operates 14 theme parks in the United States and Canada, tries to make sure that the roller coaster experience continues this tradition, while reinventing how theme parks can continue to attract visitors. We have a broad group of guests, Mr. Decker said. We have roller coaster enthusiasts and our family audience, so we try to balance the two and create a great environment for everyone.

title: The Rabbit-Hole of Relevant
description: When a law has a name like Patriot or Freedom, its a sign that you should read the fine print. Somewhere down there, in the terraced subclauses of some forgettable subsection, is a word with a special meaning, a word that offers shelter and concealment to whatever it is that the law actually does. Consider the word relevant. You and I use the word to distinguish what matters (the relevant) from what does not (the irrelevant). But to the National Security Agency, there was no irrelevant. Pointing to one appearance of the word in a 2006 update of the USA Patriot Act, the agency argued it could demand records of any one of our phone calls, on the very slight chance of some distant connection to terrorism. A secret court agreed, ordering phone companies to serve up our records on an ongoing daily basis  24 hours a day, hundreds of billions of calls in all. No one knew about it until Edward Snowden revealed the existence of the program in 2013. Earlier this month, President Obama signed the USA Freedom Act, which is supposed to close this loophole. Will it? That depends on a fresh pile of fine print.

title: Can the Bacteria in Your Gut Explain Your Mood?
description: Eighteen vials were rocking back and forth on a squeaky mechanical device the shape of a butcher scale, and Mark Lyte was beside himself with excitement. We actually got some fresh yesterday  freshly frozen, Lyte said to a lab technician. Each vial contained a tiny nugget of monkey feces that were collected at the Harlow primate lab near Madison, Wis., the day before and shipped to Lytes lab on the Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center campus in Abilene, Tex.

title: NATO Refocuses on the Kremlin, Its Original Foe
description: CAMP ADAZI, Latvia  After years of facing threats far beyond its borders, NATO is now reinvigorating plans to confront a much larger and more aggressive threat from its past: Moscow.

title: The Patient I Abandoned
description: John was 7 when I met him, and dealing with more than any child could be expected to endure. For the first years of his life, he had been witness to his fathers alcoholic binges, which often involved shouting, breaking objects and hitting John and his mother. His mother struggled too, with depression and a crack addiction. When John was 5, the states Child Protective Services removed him from the home and placed him in a series of foster-care arrangements. Although his father disappeared, never to be heard from again, his mother underwent court-mandated substance-abuse treatment and was later allowed to see John in supervised visits. Eventually, she regained custody  which was right before he and I met.

title: Today in Politics: South Carolina Takes Step Toward Folding Its Confederate Flag
description: Good Tuesday morning from Washington. The conversation after the shooting in Charleston, S.C., almost immediately turned to the Confederate flag, which the gunman embraced in online postings and which hung at the states Capitol. On Monday, Gov. Nikki R. Haley called for it to come down.

title: Pro-Democracy Demonstrators Decamp in Hong Kong
description: The week after a vote in Hong Kongs legislature ended nine months of intense debate about how Hong Kong will select its next leader, another ending loomed outside the Legislative Council complex, this time for the tent city of pro-democracy demonstrators.

title: Morning Agenda: Winners and Losers in Health Care Mergers
description: WINNERS AND LOSERS IN HEALTH CARE MERGERS | About a year and a half after the Affordable Care Act was signed into law, an analyst asked Mark T. Bertolini, Aetnas chief executive, about possible mergers in the health care industry. Mr. Bertolini said, I expect and we expect that consolidation will continue going forward here as health reform shakes out winners and losers in the process. In the  latest DealBook column, Andrew Ross Sorkin takes a look at the possible winners and losers as the health care industry moves toward consolidation on a large scale, especially as the countrys biggest health insurers, like Anthem and Aetna, set their sights on smaller rivals.

title: New Jersey Poll Shows Drop in Chris Christies Approval Ratings

title: Quartz Introduces Atlas, a Search Engine for Its Charts
description: Online publishers have learned that when explaining a complicated subject, like an economic crisis or health care reform, simplicity is often the best route for attracting readers. One way of doing this: Write a post that promises everything can be understood in one chart.

description: This weeks video features a scene from Part 1 of Wolf Hall, the Royal Shakespeare Companys two-part adaptation of Hilary Mantels novels about Thomas Cromwell (Ben Miles) and King Henry VIII (Nathaniel Parker). The show, which received Tony nominations for both Mr. Miles and Mr. Parker, as well as for best play, is at the Winter Garden Theater through July 5.

description: LONDON  Top executives and managers at banks operating in Britain could have their bonuses clawed back for up to 10 years after any finding of misconduct under new rules announced by British regulators on Tuesday.

title: James Horner, Film Composer, Dies at 61; His Score for Titanic Was a Hit, Too
description: James Horner, the prolific composer whose vaulting theme music for Titanic earned him two Oscars and became the best-selling orchestral soundtrack ever, died on Monday morning when the single-turboprop plane he was flying solo crashed and burned in the Los Padres National Forest in Southern California. He was 61.

description: LONDON  Michel Demar, the chairman of the agricultural and chemical giant Syngenta, took to the Internet on Tuesday to outline the criteria necessary for the company to consider a takeover offer from Monsanto as serious.

title: Luxury at Fendi, Etro, Canali and Kiton
description: MILAN  Among the elder-statesmen brands of Milan, the past is present. Family companies (some still held by families, others now passed into corporate hands) are a defining feature of the landscape here, and its not uncommon to chat with someone whose surname has been stitched onto garment labels for decades. But history is no longer enough to guarantee interest. Wrestling with tradition is a seasonal sport.

title: Can a New Investor (and Ron Frasch) Propel Proenza Schouler?
description: The New York fashion brand Proenza Schouler has long been an object of investor and acquisition desire: full of potential, only 13 years old, with an outsize fashion reputation (five CFDA Fashion awards, including three for womens wear designers of the year), yet a relatively undeveloped retail presence.

title: Calls to Drop Confederate Emblems Spread Nationwide
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  What began as scattered calls for removing the Confederate battle flag from a single state capitol intensified with striking speed and scope on Tuesday into an emotional, nationwide movement to strip symbols of the Confederacy from public parks and buildings, license plates, Internet shopping sites and retail stores.

description: LOS ANGELES  In a move that is as much about emphasizing a growth strategy as keeping a valued executive, Lions Gate Entertainment on Tuesday promoted Tim Palen to the unusual position of chief brand officer.

title: 1965: Kennedy Urges Nuclear Ban
description: WASHINGTON  Sen. Robert F. Kennedy today [June 23] called on the Johnson administration to give top priority to the problem of halting the spread of nuclear weapons  a problem he termed more urgent than the war in Vietnam. He added that at an appropriate time and manner the United States must vigorously pursue negotiations on this subject with China. China is there, China will have nuclear weapons. And without her participation it will be infinitely more difficult, perhaps impossible in the long run to prevent nuclear proliferation. Sen. Kennedy urged that in the journey towards peace the partial nuclear test ban treaty of 1963 be extended to cover certain underground tests.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 24, 1965

title: Edible Marijuana Labels Often Have Potency Wrong, Study Says

description: From a small island to the capital in Athens, here is a glimpse into some of the lives of Greeks as their country struggles to repay billions in debt.

description: The bipartisan push to remove the Confederate battle flag from South Carolinas State House building resonated across the United States, but in Mississippi it had special meaning.

title: The Ribbon, a Blue Ribbon Restaurant, Opens on the Upper West Side
description: The Ribbon For Upper West Siders bemoaning the recent closing of Ouest and the areas general scarcity of ambitious restaurants, this opening is well timed. Its the latest entry from the Bromberg brothers, who own eight Blue Ribbon establishments around the city, and has the earmarks of the quintessential neighborhood restaurant. But its fried chicken, served only on Sunday and Monday evenings, may make it a destination. The large menu includes cheese plates, pts (and chopped liver), raw-bar items, latkes, rotisserie meats and a burger, but none of the sushi served at some other Blue Ribbons. Were going back to our roots: French, but also what we grew up with, like prime ribs at Grandmas house, said Eric Bromberg, who owns the restaurant with his brother, Bruce. You enter a spacious dark-wood bar area, with tables; a couple of steps lead down to the big windowed dining room. Theres an open kitchen where the chef, Martin Brock, works behind glass (opens Wednesday): 20 West 72nd Street, 212-787-5656, theribbonnyc.com.

title: Ex-Partner Sues Joshua Newman, Promoter of CrossFit Ventures
description: The legal woes continue to mount for Joshua B. Newman, the serial entrepreneur charged by federal prosecutors with defrauding investors in high-intensity training ventures. Now, a former business partner is suing him.

title: Chinese City Defends Dog Meat Festival, Despite Scorn
description: YULIN, China  It was the night before the summer solstice, and the tables at a streetside food stall here were set for the annual feast: steamed pumpkin, sauted morning glory, smashed cucumbers and cold-skin rice flour noodles. At the center of each table were the two traditional dishes most essential to the celebration here: fresh lychees and heaping bowls of stewed dog, pungent with ginger, garlic, dried orange peels, bay leaves and fennel.

title: With Phones Lagging, BlackBerry Reports $28 Million Loss
description: OTTAWA  BlackBerrys introduction of two phones aimed at its traditional base of corporate users failed to reverse the companys slide in the handset market, the company said in releasing its earnings on Tuesday.

description: Hiroshi Mikitani, founder and chief executive of the Japanese e-commerce giant Rakuten, will join the board of Lyft, the company announced on Tuesday.

title: Twelve Cabins, Private Hot Springs and One Large Teepee
description: Getting to Dunton Hot Springs is no small feat: Arriving from the small, mountainous town of Durango, Colo., drive west along the San Juan National Forest for a few hours. When you reach the even smaller town of Dolores, follow the West Dolores River down a winding county dirt road for 45 minutes to reach the microscopic town of Dunton. If you get thereapproaching sunset, a thin coil of smoke from a campfire might herald your destination.

title: Flying Tiger Copenhagen: Where All That Glitters Is  Glitter
description: I associate Denmark with Danishes, tolerance, Legos, bicycles, seeded bread, peaceful nationalism and a sense of responsibility toward the socially disadvantaged. All good things.

description: Senator Rand Paul weighed in Tuesday on the controversy surrounding the Confederate battle flag in South Carolina, saying it was time to put it in a museum during a radio interview.

description: Former Gov. Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, discussing the subject of high school friends in an interview with The Skimm. Mr. Chafee and Mr. Bush went to Phillips Academy (known as Andover), a boarding school in Massachusetts, from 1967 to 1971.

description: BRUSSELS  For regulators here, the divide between European telecom companies and American tech companies is fast eroding.

description: Robert Wilsons highly regarded production of Samuel Becketts Krapps Last Tape  which he designed, directed and stars in  is coming to New Jersey next March as a highlight of the 2015-16 Peak Performances season at Montclair State University.

description: The Season 2 debut of HBOs True Detective starring Colin Farrell, Vince Vaughn and Rachel McAdams drew 3.2 million total viewers on Sunday, according to Nielsen. It was the second-highest rated episode in the seriess history, after last seasons finale.

description: We can confidently conclude that modern extinction rates are exceptionally high, that they are increasing, and that they suggest a mass extinction under waythe sixth of its kind in Earths 4.5 billion years of history.

title: John Elkann, an Emerging Deal Maker Not to Be Underestimated
description: Everyone in the auto industry knows Sergio Marchionnes views on consolidation. For years, Mr. Marchionne, the Italian-Canadian executive who welded former laggards Fiat and Chrysler into a coherent whole, has shouted from the rooftops that the only way to ensure long-term viability for manufacturers like his is to crunch them together and take out capacity.

description: Residents of Karachi, Pakistan, describe their days in the extreme temperatures that have claimed hundreds of lives during Ramadan, when Muslims traditionally fast.

description: The photographer David Severn documents the life of the Nottinghamshire and Derbyshire coalfields.

title: Tom Holland Is the New Spider-Man
description: LOS ANGELES  Talk about two itsy-bitsy guys climbing up the Hollywood spout: Sony Pictures and Marvel Studios on Tuesday announced that they had handed the next big-budget Spider-Man movie to an unknown director, Jon Watts, and that a little-known British actor, Tom Holland, had been cast in the title role.

title: Britain Holds Rwandan Spy Chief on War Crimes Warrant from Spain
description: LONDON  The chief of Rwandas intelligence service, who is wanted in Spain on war crimes charges, was being held in London on Tuesday after his arrest prompted diplomatic and political protests and reopened debate about responsibility for killings in Rwanda two decades ago.

title: When Parents Compare Siblings, the Results Can Show On Report Cards
description: Its hard for parents of more than one child not to compare them. Our minds like to sort and categorize, and the result is often either labeling (athletic, academic) or ranking (better than, stronger than, more able in one area or another). New research suggests that those thoughts, even if they stay unexpressed, may affect our childrens academic successes. The same research suggests that those parental expectations form early and arent affected by changes in a childs performance.

title: Southern Front Pages Reflect Shifting Politics
description: Throughout South Carolina, newspapers treated Gov. Nikki Haleys call to remove the Confederate battle flag from the grounds of the State House  a seismic shift in that states politics  as huge news.

title: Scott Walker, Set for a Bigger Stage, Faces G.O.P. Revolt in Wisconsin
description: MADISON, Wis.  As Gov. Scott Walker prepares to announce his campaign for president next month, promising to bring what he calls big bold leadership to Washington, as he did in Wisconsin, he faces a cloud over that story line: Republicans back home are in revolt.

title: Tidal, Jay Zs New Music Streaming Service, Loses Another Chief
description: In the latest setback for Tidal, the new streaming music service from Jay Z, its top executive has left the company after just two months on the job.

title: Karachi Heat Wave Death Toll Tops 650 During Ramadan Fast
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Karachis poor learned long ago to cope with the many adversities that afflict Pakistans most crowded and chaotic city, including flooding, street violence and political crises. But since a suffocating heat wave descended on Karachi three days ago, killing at least 650 people, they have found no respite and no escape.

description: With development booming and an influx of media companies relocating to Lower Manhattan, restaurateurs are seeing an uptick in business.

description: A man wielding a machete struck a 31-year-old woman in the arm in Bryant Park on Tuesday in what the police said appeared to have been a random attack.

title: No Home Advantage Lately for British Wild Cards
description: LONDON  Andy Murray ended 77 years of British torment in 2013 when he became the first British man to win Wimbledon since 1936. But as this years tournament approaches, a drought still persists for Murrays compatriots.

title: #CharlestonSyllabus: A Reading List to Contextualize the Massacre
description: Last summer, when the unrest in Ferguson, Mo. began, Marcia Chatelein, a Georgetown professor, crowdsourced a reading list about race, African-American history, civil rights and policing by collecting suggestions via the Twitter hashtag #FergusonSyllabus.

description: At the start of talks between the United States and China in Washington on Tuesday, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said both nations must work together.

title: Tentative Deal in Albany Would Extend Rent Laws; Key Issues Are Unresolved
description: ALBANY  At the end of a trying session that has dragged nearly a week past its scheduled conclusion, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders reached a tentative deal on Tuesday on a range of knotty issues, including a new agreement on rent regulations covering about one million New York City apartments.

title: Persecution and the Black Church
description: Now that a few dayshave passed, its worth saying something about the much-discussed initial response to the massacre at Charlestons Emanuel A.M.E Church, in which a scattering of Republicans and Fox News personalities suggested that this was anti-religious violence, an anti-Christian attack, rather than the white supremacist violence (shaped by whatever demons occupy the shooters mind) that it quickly proved to be.

title: Retailers Ban Sale of Merchandise Bearing Confederate Flag
description: The debate over the Confederate battle flag has spilled into the world of commerce as major retailers including Walmart, Sears and eBay have banned the sale of merchandise bearing the Civil War symbol.

title: Confederate Flag Sales Soar as Retailers Pull Stock
description: Entering a debate that has played out for years mostly in the political realm, many of the nations largest retailers abruptly decided this week to stop selling merchandise tied to the Confederate battle flag.

title: An Updated Five-Bedroom Farmhouse in the Algarve Region
description: The house, with two guesthouses, a pool and a tennis court on 1.3 acres, is on the market for $1.98 million.

title: Dick Van Patten, Harried Father on Eight Is Enough, Dies at 86
description: Dick Van Patten, the cheerful, round-faced actor best known for his role as the firm if harried suburban father at the center of the hit television series Eight Is Enough, died on Tuesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 86.

title: A Two-Year, 100-Billboard Celebration of Going West
description: Though blizzards and rent checks will always revive New Yorkers dreams of avocado trees and sunshine, for a certain set of creatives, the allure of the American West is so pass its history. Starting tonight, the Manifest Destiny Billboard Project, a two-year, 100-billboard journey from sea to shining sea along Interstate 10, kicks off its culminating festivities in Los Angeles. Transit west has a long and speckled past, a combination of the best and worst things about what we do, says the director of the public-art nonprofit Los Angeles Nomadic Division, Shamim Momin, who co-curated two Whitney Biennials before herself moving to California. The vision of manifest destiny, she says, has had all sorts of applications over time, many of which have been devastating to different communities. And yet it is also so ingrained in the history of being American, the way we think about aspiration and ambition, achievement and taking. It ties to everything from the capitalist impulse to notions of exploration, and to the desire to know.

title: Charleston Rally to Take Down the Flag
description: South Carolina leaders spoke at a rally in Charleston on Tuesday, saying it was time for the Confederate battle flag to be removed from the grounds of the state house.

title: Indie Music, Illustrated
description: Damien Florbert Cuypers illustrates Full Moons entire band lineup.

title: Where True Detective and the Triangle Offense Meet
description: The deeper we went on the triangle offense, the more we felt as if we were inside some sort of antechamber of the True Detective Carcosa lair. So we tracked down Joshua Walsh, the artist whose work defined the first season of that HBO show, and invited him to contemplate the many mysteries of the triangle. What he came up with is a series of clocks based on the principles outlined in Tex Winters book, The Triple-Post Offense.

title: Mirror Images
description: The visual soliloquy of modern African portraiture.

title: U.N. Condemns Both Sides in Syria for Attacking Civilians
description: GENEVA  United Nations investigators condemned Syrias government and armed opposition groups on Tuesday for deliberately targeting civilians with bombing and artillery attacks that were causing unspeakable suffering.

title: Cherries Add a Sweet Touch to Tabbouleh
description: This year, I get two cherry seasons: the one that is just ending in California (and is coming into full swing in other parts of the country), and the one that I enjoyed in late May in France. Every year, usually in summer, I visit a dear friend in the Luberon region of Provence. I went earlier this time, and her cherry trees were heavy with fruit.

title: New York City Settles Wrongful Conviction Case in Brooklyn for $6.25 Million
description: Jonathan Fleming, who was cleared last year of a murder conviction after a decades-old phone receipt supporting an alibi emerged, has reached a $6.25 million settlement with New York City for years of imprisonment.

title: Qualcomm in Venture With Chinese Chip Maker
description: HONG KONG  Chinas largest maker of chips has a new plan to help it close a wide gap with rivals, and the company has found some unlikely partners to help.

title: Aprons on Parade: From the Rabbit Hole to the Kitchen
description: Ever since Alice fell down the rabbit hole in her white pinafore, aprons have been something of a fashion statement.

title: Charleston Residents Seek Lasting Change From Moment of Unity
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  From a wicker chair on the porch of her daisy yellow bungalow, Cheryl Lee panned from right to left, pointing to the houses on the block  the blue one, the brick one, the light green one  that had transitioned from black ownership to white.

title: Why I Cant Forgive Dylann Roof
description: I DO NOT forgive Dylann Roof, a racist terrorist whose name I hate saying or knowing. I have no immediate connection to what happened in Charleston, S.C., last week beyond my humanity and my blackness, but I do not foresee ever forgiving his crimes, and I am wholly at ease with that choice.

title: Bouygues Rejects Altices $11 Billion Offer for Telecom Business
description: Bouygues, the French diversified industrial group, said on Tuesday that its board had rejected an unsolicited takeover offer from Altice for its mobile and broadband business, Bouygues Telecom.

title: New Yorks Public School Students Sweat Out the End of the Semester
description: When Julian Marsano, a fifth-grade teacher at Public School 124 in Brooklyn, arrived to begin this last week of school, he had a challenging schedule mapped out for his students.

title: Climate Change Calls for Science, Not Hope
description: Is the American approach to combating climate change going off the rails?

title: Indie Music, Illustrated
description: This August, the one-day-only Full Moon music festival will celebrate its fifth anniversary (after four consecutive sold-out years) in a new location: a pop-up space, the Brooklyn Mirage, that will feature 20-foot living walls, tropical plants and beach sand imported from the South of France. For the occasion, the festivals curators, Matte Projects, reached out to the French artist, illustrator and frequent T contributor Damien Florbert Cuypers to illustrate the festivals entire indie-leaning 14-act lineup (rather than booking stadium-filler names, Full Moon operates as a boutique festival, opting for on-the-verge discoveries). Matte and Cuypers shared the illustrations exclusively with T.

title: Irans Supreme Leader, Khamenei, Seems to Pull Back on Nuclear Talks
description: TEHRAN  With exactly a week left before the deadline for a final agreement to limit Irans nuclear program, the countrys supreme leader appeared to undercut several of the central agreements his negotiators have already reached with the West.

title: Facts & Figures: Discrimination Against Christians
description: About half of Americans either mostly or completely agree with the statement, discrimination against Christians has become as big a problem as discrimination against other groups, according to a survey conducted by the Public Religion Research Institute.

title: Paris, Undeterred, Tries Again for an Olympics, in 2024
description: PARIS  Paris kicked off its bid to host the 2024 Summer Olympics on Tuesday in the presence of French politicians and athletes, and appeared to be hoping that this time would be a charm.

title: Review: Mr. Robot Debuts on USA
description: Occupy Wall Street, the protest movement that erupted in 2011, didnt do much to curb the financial industry. It didnt die out, though. It went Hollywood.

title: New Faces on the Runway
description: A look at some of the models in the mens shows in Milan.

title: Obama Interview Sets Download Record for Maron Podcast
description: President Obamas podcast interview with Marc Maron was historic in more ways than one: it was not only the first time that an elected official has appeared on the WTF With Marc Maron show (and almost certainly the first time that a sitting president has recorded an interview in a comedians garage), but it was also the programs most downloaded new episode ever.

title: Hillary Clinton on Charleston Shooting
description: On Tuesday, Hillary Rodham Clinton, a candidate for the 2016 Democratic presidential nomination, called last weeks church shooting in Charleston, S.C., an act of racist terrorism.

title: Review: American Ballet Theaters Swan Lake Adds Drama to Romance
description: Last season, American Ballet Theaters opening night of Swan Lake took a dramatic turn that had nothing to do with evil sorcerers transforming princesses into swans. Gillian Murphy, the companys resplendent virtuoso, was injured during the second act; Hee Seo took over. On Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House, drama occurred for all the right reasons: A particularly ravishing Ms. Murphy, joined again by Marcelo Gomes as Prince Siegfried, flew through the role of Odette-Odile with not only the strength she is known for, but also with wit, amplitude and finespun vulnerability.

title: Ben Carson Assails Foes for Playing Down Race in Charleston Shooting
description: Ben Carson, the retired neurosurgeon who is running for president, accused his Republican rivals on Tuesday of tap-dancing around the issue of race in the wake of the Charleston, S.C., shooting.

title: NATO Refocuses on Russia
description: Military training exercises this month in Latvia, a former Soviet republic, underline the seismic shift for an alliance that had been focused on threats far beyond its borders.

title: Review: Men on Boats Blurs Genders in Recalling John Wesley Powells Expedition
description: If summer has you hankering for fitness-testing excursions through the dangerous outdoors, you will surely want to spend time with the hearty title characters of Men on Boats, who are churning up bright clouds of testosterone hovering over the Wild Project in the East Village.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Review: Poliuto, a Rare Donizetti Bel Canto Thriller
description: LEWES, England  On a sunny day at the Glyndebourne Festival here, an hours train ride from London, bees buzz amiably through wildflowers, sheep bleat in the open pasture, and champagne glasses clink amid high-society chatter. Only the croquet lawn is safe from picnic tables, as patrons claim preferred spots early in the afternoon.

title: Italian Street Style
description: Style on the streets of Florence and Milan during the mens fashion shows.

title: Italian Street Style
description: Style on the streets of Florence and Milan during the mens fashion shows. See the photos.

title: Review: Wild Women of Planet Wongo, a Musical Comedy With a Sci-Fi Bent
description: Bushwick, in Brooklyn, as it inches closer to being devoured by Williamsburg, can still look otherworldly in its more remote precincts. How appropriate then to find the quaint musical cum dance party Wild Women of Planet Wongo there on a desolate block at Brooklyn Fire Proof. Not to be confused with the Z-movie Wild Women of Wongo, from 1958, this spoof more recalls the seminal sci-fi cheese-fest Cat-Women of the Moon, from 1953.

title: At the Milan Mens Wear Shows, Sporty Parachute Nylon Gets an Update for Spring/Summer 2016
description: At this point, its no secret that athletic-wear and technical fabrics have infiltrated the world of high fashion. But theres something new and refreshing about the billowing parachute-nylon coats that appeared in the shows for Brioni, Jil Sander and Z Zegna during this mens fashion week in Milan. The flowing jackets, in a restrained palette of cool grays and blues and paired with sharply tailored silhouettes, imbue the sporty fabric with an air of minimal sophistication.

title: Synthetic Drug Manufacturing Is an Open Secret in China
description: Just before dawn on Dec. 29, 2013, the southern Chinese fishing village of Boshe awoke to a scene reminiscent of a Hollywood action flick: Over 3,000 police officers, backed by helicopters and speedboats, burst into traditional stone houses in search of illegal drugs. With cameramen in tow, the police destroyed 77 methamphetamine labs, seized three tons of crystal meth and more than 100 tons of meth ingredients. Among the 182 people arrested were a former local Communist Party chief and 13 other officials.

title: Pictures of the Day: Armenia and Elsewhere
description: Armenia and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Credit Karma Raises $175 Million
description: Credit Karma, an online personal finance company, has obtained $175 million in new financing from the investment firms Tiger Global Management, Valinor Management and Viking Global Investors.

title: June 23, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Armenia, India, United States and Kenya.

title: Review: First Peoples Finds the Drive to Explore in Our DNA
description: The narration is often overwrought, and so is the soundtrack, but First Peoples, a five-part science series beginning on Wednesday on PBS, certainly alerts you to one thing: If your most recent idea of paleoanthropology involves an image of one of the Leakeys dusting off an ancient fibula, you seriously need an update.

title: A Reimagining in Washington Divides the Neighbors
description: WASHINGTON  From her second-floor bedroom window two miles north of the United States Capitol, Doris Newton can gaze across a grassy field and reservoir at the Founders Library Clock Tower at Howard University, her alma mater. She fervently hopes the view wont change.

title: Review: Karen Mason, a Well-Seasoned Belter, at Dont Tell Mama
description: Ive come home at last! Norma Desmonds triumphant announcement in the semioperatic ballad, As If We Never Said Goodbye, from Sunset Boulevard has rarely been put to more powerful use than in Karen Masons show at the Midtown cabaret Dont Tell Mama on Monday evening. Ms. Mason, who was a stand-in for three Broadway Normas  Glenn Close, Betty Buckley and Elaine Paige  captured the characters scarily compelling essence in clawing body language. This dramatic tour de force was especially impressive because as a nightclub singer, Ms. Mason is utterly guileless.

title: Grisly ISIS Video Seems Aimed at Quashing Resistance
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Propagandists for the Islamic State released a video on Tuesday showing the groups fighters incinerating, drowning and blowing up men accused of helping the United States and American allies bomb its bases.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Review: Souvenir Undone Beckons Its Audience Through Historic Fort Jay
description: Rachel Tess, a Portland, Ore., choreographer now based in Sweden, is obsessed with relationships between forms: architecture and choreography, silence and sound, light and dark. Ms. Tess, a Juilliard graduate whose scenes resemble dioramas, may have discovered the performance site of her dreams at Governors Island, where, as part of the River to River festival, she presented Souvenir Undone on Friday at the Fort Jay magazine, a medley of arched brick rooms once used to store gunpowder.

title: A Conversation With Barbara S. Fox
description: Ms. Fox is the founder and president of the Fox Residential Group, a boutique brokerage firm that does business mainly in Manhattan and Brooklyn. The firm, which was founded in 1989, has about 50 agents.

title: Review: What Happened, Miss Simone? Documents Nina Simones Rise as Singer and Activist
description: Partway through What Happened, Miss Simone?, an often electric, bracingly urgent documentary on the singer-musician Nina Simone, we reach that catastrophic year 1968, and the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. On screen, photographs of other murdered black men flicker past  Malcolm X, the civil rights activist Medgar Evers and the Black Panther Fred Hampton  followed by a photo of a young black mourner holding a sign that reads: You better kill all blacks. I cant be the only American who will despair at the relevance of those words in 2015.

title: Saved
description: An Irish ship that has been helping the Italian Navy patrol the Mediterranean had a very busy Monday.

title: Living in Merrick, N.Y.
description: A nautical flavor, good schools and a reasonable commute to Manhattan attract young families to the hamlet in Nassau County on Long Island.

title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Vanderbilt Rape Case Is Declared a Mistrial
description: A Tennessee judge on Tuesday upended one of the countrys highest profile cases of campus sexual assault and declared a mistrial in the proceedings against two former Vanderbilt University football players who were convicted in January of aggravated rape.

title: Devin Allens Inside Story in Baltimore
description: Devin Allen, the Baltimore photographer whose Instagram photos landed on the cover of Time Magazine, wants to teach young people how to tell their own stories.

title: In Yulin, Its Dog Lovers vs. Dog Eaters
description: As part of the summer solstice celebrations in Yulin, China, thousands of canines are slaughtered and served up in a controversial dog meat festival.

title: Netflix Announces a 7-for-1 Stock Split
description: Netflix, the streaming video service, announced on Tuesday that its board had approved a seven-for-one stock split after a strong year in which its shares had doubled.

title: Don Featherstone, Inventor of the Pink Flamingo (in Plastic), Dies at 79
description: Don Featherstone did not invent Phoenicopterus ruber: Nature took care of that eons ago. But what Mr. Featherstone did nearly six decades ago  in the process indelibly altering the landscape of midcentury America  was to cast the creature in plastic and attach slender, rodlike legs for planting it in the ground.

title: What You Get for ... $2,650,000
description: Ocean views in California and Maine and a contemporary in Atlanta

title: For Egypt, TV Shows Shocking Twist Is Its Sympathetic Jews
description: CAIRO  The scene is Cairos Jewish Quarter in 1948, and Laila Haroun has news for her parents. Her brother, Moussa, has left to settle in the new state of Israel in spite of the war with Egypt and its Arab allies.

title: Cuomo on Tentative Deal
description: At a news conference on Tuesday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced a budget agreement that includes an extension of rent regulations for more than two million tenants.

title: Tech Companies Line Up Behind Containers and the Cloud
description: An unusual combination of big and small tech companies are working on ways to accelerate the development of cloud computing technologies.

title: LG Listens to Conservationists and Preserves a Landmark
description: What preservation is really all about, the critic Ada Louise Huxtable noted almost 50 years ago, is the retention and active relationship of buildings of the past to the communitys functioning present.

title: Sorrowing Ireland Buries Its Own
description: The bonds that knit a small country, its resemblance to a large and far-flung family, its citizens deep capacity for empathy  all of that was on full and stunning display last week in Ireland. It was a time of shock and grieving over the accident at an apartment building in Berkeley, Calif., that left six young Irish citizens dead and seven injured. Most were college students, working in the United States through the J-1 summer visa program. They were at a birthday party when a balcony gave way.

title: Controversial Confederate Symbols
description: The Confederate battle flag and other symbols of the Confederacy have come under renewed criticism. Here are recent protests and calls for the removal of Confederate symbols from public places.

title: Recent Commercial Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Greek Debt Blueprint Gets a Cold Reception in Athens
description: ATHENS  Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras faced anger and resistance on Tuesday from members of his own radical left political party, complicating his efforts to strike a deal this week with Greeces creditors, as some lawmakers and party officials criticized concessions by the Greek side and expressed doubts about voting for a deal in Parliament.

title: Dashcam Video of Dylann Roof Arrest
description: Police in Shelby, N.C. Tuesday released video of the arrest of Dylann Roof, the suspect in last weeks mass shooting at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C.

title: Hillary Clinton Says Confederate Flag Shouldnt Fly Anywhere
description: As lawmakers across the South spoke out against the Confederate battle flag and the nations largest retailers pulled items with its image from their shelves, Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday called the flag a symbol of our nations racist past.

title: Ackman Raises $1 Billion in Bond Offering
description: Pershing Square Holdings, an investment firm founded by the billionaire investor William A. Ackman, has raised $1 billion from investors in the bond market as it shores up capital for its next investment.

title: Maneuvers and Dutch Defenses That May Complicate Mylan-Teva Takeover War
description: Hostile takeover wars are unnerving for companies and investors alike in any industry. But the multi-front war involving the generic drug makers Teva Pharmaceutical Industries and Mylan is even more daunting.

title: Attorney General Faults Liquid Nicotine Retailers for Improper Packaging
description: The crackdown on retailers that sell liquid nicotine used in e-cigarettes escalated Tuesday as the New York attorney general reached a settlement with four businesses that failed to secure the potentially toxic substance in child-resistant packaging.

title: Coping? Students in France Just Arent
description: PARIS  There is no easy translation or even a firm concept of the word coping in French, so when it turned up last week in a question on the national exam to earn a high school degree, it set off a fracas among the 350,000 or so students who took the test.

title: Armenias Electric Yerevan Protesters Return to Streets Despite Arrests and Water Blasts
description: Thousands of protesters confronted riot police in the Armenian capital, Yerevan, for a second night on Tuesday, just hours after a previous demonstration was dispersed with blasts of water and more than 200 arrests.

title: Report Cites Dry-Rotting in Collapse of Balcony in Berkeley
description: LOS ANGELES  The apartment building balcony that collapsed last week in Berkeley, Calif., killing six students, was supported by wooden beams with extensive rotting from water damage, city officials said Tuesday.

title: Vatican Lays Groundwork for Discussions on Family
description: ROME  A working paper released on Tuesday by the Vatican for a much-anticipated fall gathering of the worlds bishops laid the groundwork for fresh discussions on issues like the Roman Catholic Churchs ban on same-sex unions and the sacrament of communion for divorced Catholics who have remarried outside the church.

title: Sweet Briar CollegeIs Saved but Is Not in the Clear
description: SWEET BRIAR, Va.  Marina Biel was 16 when she first set foot on the bucolic campus of Sweet Briar College, and she knew instantly she would apply nowhere else. When she enrolled last fall as a freshman engineering student, she said, I had my four years planned out, and everything was perfect.

title: Quebec Leader Defends Limits on Freedom of Expression
description: Quebecs premier said Tuesday that the government must draw a line in the sand on freedom of expression, as he defended legislation under consideration by provincial lawmakers that would restrict Islamic face coverings for women and hateful speech deemed to foment violence.

title: At the Womens World Cup, a Memento Players Are Stuck With and Stuck To
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba  Before the United States played Sweden in a Womens World Cup match here this month, some American fans waited in line for hours to be the first to enter the stadium. When the gates finally opened, it was like the running of the bulls.

title: South Carolina Governor Points to Personal Reasons, Not Politics, for Shift on Confederate Flag
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Gov. Nikki R. Haley was at home in Columbia last Wednesday night, when the gunman began shooting and killing inside the historic black church here.

title: Future Is About to Arrive for Phil Jackson and the Knicks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Phil Jackson stepped to the lectern at about noon Tuesday and said, Im here to speak about nothing that I can speak about.

title: As Greece Calms, Investors Find Other Concerns
description: Greed and fear are the primal forces that in the past have driven the stock market to its highs and lows. Now the dominant emotion among investors seems to be lukewarm enthusiasm.

title: Flag Supporters React With a Mix of Compromise, Caution and Outright Defiance
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  It has been quite a few years since the lost cause has appeared quite as lost as it did Tuesday. As the afternoon drew on and their retreat turned into a rout, the lingering upholders of the Confederacy watched as license plates, statues and prominently placed Confederate battle flags slipped from their reach.

title: Chemical Safety Bill Advances
description: The House on Tuesday easily passed a measure that would make the first major changes in 39 years to a law intended to protect people from exposure to toxic chemicals. The House voted. 398 to 1, to pass a bill designed to update and strengthen the 1976 Toxic Substances Control Act, which has been criticized as outdated and toothless by environmental advocates and the chemical industry. The Senate is expected to take up a companion bill next month. The bills would require the Environmental Protection Agency to begin studying the health effects of about 64,000 chemicals that are used in commerce. But public health advocates complain that the pace of study would be too slow.

title: Mexico: Deadly Fire Hits Nursing Home
description: A fire Tuesday killed 16 residents of a nursing home on the outskirts of Mexicali, the capital of Baja California, officials said.
