One especially gratifying and praiseworthy feature of the majority opinion was that it explicitly invoked the logic of health reform to justify the interpretive jiggery-pokery (can this be made into a dance step?) that so infuriated Scalia. From the opinion:

title: The Supreme Courts Ruling on the Health Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Mario Biaggi, 10-Term Bronx Congressman, Dies at 97
description: Mr. Biaggi was a highly decorated former New York City police officer who became a popular congressman only to land in prison in a wave of corruption scandals in the late 1980s.

title: How to Get Smart About Iran
description: With less than a week to go before the June 30 deadline for a nuclear deal between Iran and the major powers, there is an intensifying debate in Washington about the strengths and weaknesses of any agreement that might emerge. There are also growing questions about whether  after 19 months of negotiation  an agreement is even possible, given what appears to be a growing intransigence on the Iranian side.

title: Review: In A New Brain, Heading into Surgery and Singing the Whole Way
description: Jonathan Groff was born to suffer incandescently. He has other talents, too. But put him in a spotlight with a heart full of anguish and eyes on the brink of floods, and his face blossoms into radiant beatitude, like a model posing for Rubens as a martyred saint.

title: An Advance May Double the Capabilities of Fiber Optics
description: Researchers have announced an advance that could double the capacity of fiber-optic circuits, potentially opening the way for networks to carry more data over long distances while significantly reducing their cost.

title: Alice: 150 Years of Wonderland
description: A look at Lewis Carrolls work, on display at the Morgan Library & Museum.

title: What I Love | Kurt Elling
description: When hes not on the road promoting his music, the baritone jazz singer lives with his family on the Upper West Side.

title: Review: Richard Barrett Brings His Electronic Scores to Spectrum
description: One measure of the esteem in which the British composer Richard Barrett is held at Spectrum, the Lower East Side performance space? An excerpt from the score for tendril, his 2013 piece for harp and electronics, is printed on the front of the spaces new T-shirts. A more traditional measure is the three-concert series Spectrum is devoting to Mr. Barretts work. It began on Wednesday with a riveting program featuring members of the ensemble TILT Brass. This was, for New York listeners, an all-too-rare dip into a vivid, expressive, communicative repertory. I think its fairly easy to follow whats going on, Mr. Barrett said by way of introducing the first piece, Aurora (2010). Thats not entirely right  these are dense, complicated scores  but it captures the fundamental accessibility of his music.

title: Clementa Pinckney, Called to Pulpit and Politics in a Life Cut Short
description: RIDGELAND, S.C.  The morning worship had ended at St. John A.M.E. Church, and as Clementa Pinckney walked through the simple country sanctuary with its 10 rows of pews, he was startled to hear a disembodied voice. It was soft, almost whispery, and yet clearly audible. Preach, it said. I have called you to preach the Gospel.

title: Looking at the Birth of Lewis Carrolls Alice, 150 Years Old
description: THE chief virtue of Alices Adventures in Wonderland, G. K. Chesterton once wrote, was Lewis Carrolls celebration of flux, an escape into a world where things are not fixed horribly in an eternal appropriateness, where apples grow on pear-trees, and any odd man you meet may have three legs.

title: The Scene
description: Dries Van Noten Mens at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Photo Diary: Dries Van Noten Spring/Summer 2016 Mens
description: Scenes from Paris Fashion Week, captured by Schohaja.

title: The Independent Art Fair Finds a Sleek Home in TriBeCa
description: Since its founding in 2010 as an art fair that works very hard not to look or feel like an art fair, Independent has prospered in its home in the funky old building on West 22nd Street that once housed the Dia Center for the Arts, whose rough brick walls practically breathe downtown art history.

title: Review: Doris Salcedos Forceful Political Art in Guggenheim Retrospective
description: Politically speaking, you dont have to be a house to be haunted. All you need to be is someone who keeps an eye on the news; who pays attention to loss through violence; and feels a personal stake in that loss, as if it were happening to people you know and care about, to people who live in your home.

title: Lower East Side Story
description: During the decades Clarence Elie-Rivera spent living and photographing on the Lower East Side, he watched it go from rough to rich.

title: Judge Delays Kansas Ban on 2nd-Trimester Abortion Procedure
description: A Kansas state judge on Thursday temporarily blocked a new law that would have banned the most common method of abortion in the second trimester.

title: Review:Joan Mir,Oiseaux Dans lEspace
description: The Birth of the World, Joan Mirs clairvoyant masterpiece from 1927, presaged much of postwar American painting  the early date can elicit a double take when you see it at the Museum of Modern Art. Its expansive surface of thin gray pours and washes, and the delicate lines and shapes in black, red and white that dance across them, open a pathway to so much: the automatic drawing of Surrealism, the frank painterliness and scale of Abstract Expressionism and the lightness and elegance of Color Field painting.

title: Review: Sarah Charlesworth: Doubleworld Studies Perceptions Shaped by Photography
description: In 1990, when Sarah Charlesworth characterized her interest in photography as an engagement with a problem rather than a medium, she spoke for many photo-based artists. Called the Pictures Generation, they were born around 1950 and emerged in the late 1970s and early 80s, standing on the shoulders of the Conceptualists, and for them, photography was very much a problem. It sold products, objectified women, glorified men, mythologized nations and rarely told the truth. The Pictures artists were less focused on taking photographs than on making them  through appropriation, distortion and rephotography  to expose the mediums many manipulations, fictions and tricks.

title: A Guide to Gay Pride Weekend in New York
description: THE series of efficiently scheduled excursions that our colleagues in the Travel section of The New York Times call 36 Hours have urged readers to go park hopping in Lima, honey shopping in Savannah and espresso sipping in Antigua. For Gay Pride weekend in New York, we set out to put a spin on the idea. We wondered just how much gay we could cram into three days, especially knowing that the Supreme Courts coming decision on same-sex marriage could make this Pride month historic.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, June 28 to July 4, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Pictures of the Day: United States and Elsewhere
description: United States and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Clint Dempsey Receives Two-Year Ban From U.S. Open Cup
description: Seattle Sounders forward Clint Dempsey was barred from the United States Open Cup for at least two years on Thursday, his second punishment in a week for tearing up a referees notebook during a match in the tournament on June 16.

title: June 25, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from the United States, Chile, Iran and India.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Venture Capital Firm Formation 8 Creates Vehicle Focused on Asian Start-Ups
description: Since its inception, the investment firm Formation 8 has aimed at connecting American start-ups with Asian technology titans.

title: The Day of Struggle Against the U.S.
description: One of the worlds most secretive nations makes no secret at all of its hostility to America.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: The Supreme Court Keeps the Fair Housing Law Effective
description: Housing discrimination doesnt have to be intentional to be illegal. That is the point of the Supreme Courts ruling on Thursday interpreting the Fair Housing Act of 1968 in accord with clear congressional intent, and preserving a well-established and critical tool in the long-running battle to ensure a more integrated society.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: On the Jindal Campaign: Reporters Notebook
description: KENNER, La.  Years ago in college, I overheard a fraternity leader tell one of his frat brothers that the secret to success is to act as if: Act as if you had it all figured out; as if you were a wise, swaggering senior even though you were really a nave, nerdy sophomore.

title: In N.H., Marco Rubio Is Pressed on Trade and Immigration
description: SALEM, N.H.  Senator Marco Rubio defended his conservative credentials on two issues that are roiling the right  immigration and trade  as he returned to the campaign trail on Thursday.

title: Review: From Royal Ballet, a Blend of Enchantment and Intensity
description: The diverse beauties and eloquence of Royal Ballet style became doubly evident on Wednesday, when the company presented a double bill of contemporaneous ballets by Frederick Ashton and Kenneth MacMillan that is the centerpiece of its season. The ballerina Marianela Nuez was deeply impressive in MacMillans Song of the Earth (1965), the first performance of this important ballet in New York since 1976. As Titania in Ashtons Shakespearean adaptation The Dream (1964), Sarah Lamb, more relaxed than she had been in Tuesdays gala account of the same ballet, rose with the rest of the cast to make the ballets poetic comedy all the more spellbinding.

title: Review: Escher/Bacon/Rothko, a Dance Triptych From Zvi Gotheiner
description: Apart from being visual artists with powerful visions and immediately recognizable styles, M. C. Escher, Francis Bacon and Mark Rothko wouldnt seem to have much in common. But each has been an inspiration to the choreographer Zvi Gotheiner, who has now made a three-part dance that sets his interpretations of those artists side by side like the panels of a triptych. The connecting sensibility is his.

title: Hooray for Obamacare
description: Was I on the edge of my seat, waiting for the Supreme Court decision on Obamacare subsidies? No  I was pacing the room, too nervous to sit, worried that the court would use one sloppily worded sentence to deprive millions of health insurance, condemn tens of thousands to financial ruin, and send thousands to premature death.

title: Review: Roomful of Teeth Duels With Sounds of the Financial District
description: By 8 p.m. on any given weekday, most of the human bustle has drained out of the financial district in Lower Manhattan. On Wednesday evening, too, when an outdoor concert by the vocal ensemble Roomful of Teeth began on the elevated plaza at 28 Liberty Street, there was little traffic noise to contend with. Instead, the thrum of building generators, garbage compactors and air-conditioning units created a metallic haze from which the singers voices first emerged indistinctly, like figures seen through dry ice.

title: Prison Term Sought for Private Eye Who Hacked Email
description: In the end, the amount of money a New York private investigator made from people who paid him to illegally pilfer the emails of possibly dozens of people he was investigating was small  just $5,000.

title: River to River Festival Heads for a Grand Finale
description: Resist the air-conditioned indoors. The River to River festival in Lower Manhattan ends this weekend with enough free entertainment to make you forget the temptation of a chilly movie theater.

title: Comedy Listings for June 26-July2
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: Humans Contemplates When Robots Are Routine Accessories
description: No one would blame you for being confused. A new series turned up Wednesday on the USA Network called Mr. Robot that is about humans. And on Sunday, AMC will unveil a series called Humans that is largely about robots. But if you cant keep them straight, watch both. Mr. Robot is pretty darn good. Humans is too.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for June 26-July 2
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for June 26-July 2
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Classical & Opera Listings for June 26-July 2
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: FarmBorough Festival, a Country Music Kickoff in the Big City
description: Three weeks ago at Randalls Island, it was Ray-Bans, ironic T-shirts, snapbacks and Lana Del Rey. This weekend its cowboy boots, denim shorts, trucker hats and Brad Paisley. New York, home of hip-hop and downtown experimentalism, may not seem like the most hospitable place to host a major country music festival.

title: Theater Listings for June 26-July 2
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: New York Asian Film Festival Features Ringo Lam, Hong Kong Crime Master
description: Its been not quite 30 years since a group of young Hong Kong-based moviemakers, now in or near their 60s, reinvented the gangster film, infusing the motifs of the American crime drama with the balletic action, nimble style and thematic preoccupations of their hometown industry. John Woo began the process with A Better Tomorrow in 1986 and became the movements standard-bearer in the United States, eventually directing a string of big-budget Hollywood films. The prolific Johnnie To emerged later, with Breaking News and his Election films, and is now a major presence on the international festival circuit.

title: Five Artists, Five Book Reviews
description: Must a book review take the form of prose  or can it be pure image? For this first art-themed issue of the Book Review, five pathbreaking contemporary artists create visual works of literary criticism, paying homage to the inspiration theyve found in fiction, philosophy and poetry.

title: Movie Listings for June 26-July 2
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Empty but Also Stocked, Hunting Cabins in AdirondacksAre Ideal Hideout for Escapees
description: OWLS HEAD, N.Y.  Locals call them hunting camps, and despite their rustic simplicity, or perhaps because of it, they are a beloved fixture of the deep woods in the Adirondacks.

title: Rick Owens Fashion Show Is Overshadowed by a Models Message
description: PARIS  It was Look 25 that stood out, and not for any of the intended reasons.

title: Dance Listings for June 26-July 2
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: The Art Issue
description: The Art Issue

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for June 26-July 2
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Charter Makes Its Case for 2 Mergers, Telling F.C.C. Its No Comcast
description: Charter Communications, in an attempt to distinguish itself from Comcast and its failed takeover of Time Warner Cable, promised federal regulators on Thursday that a pair of deals totaling $67.1 billion would pose no threat to the growing market for online video because the combined companys future depended more on broadband than on its legacy video business.

title: Spare Times for June 26-July 2
description: Midsummer Night Swing

title: Review: Shakespeare and Love Cuddle Up in The Princess of France
description: After a brief introduction from a radio announcer, The Princess of France opens with a burst of Schumann  the first movement of his spring symphony  that sets a mood of high emotional drama. The music accompanies, and almost overwhelms, an aerial view, shot from a rooftop, of a pickup soccer game. It starts out five on five, but the members of one team switch sides, leaving an overwhelmed goalie facing nine opponents.

title: Spare Times for Children for June 26-July 2
description: Frolic!

title: This Weeks Movies | June 26, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Ted 2, The Princess of France and What Happened, Miss Simone?

title: A Gem From Jacob deGrom and a Victory Dont Mask the Mets Larger Problems
description: MILWAUKEE  Mets Manager Terry Collins held his hands out, palms up, hopping around, his eyes wide, pleading frantically with the second-base umpire, Larry Vanover.

title: Review: What Happened, Miss Simone?
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews What Happened, Miss Simone?

title: Movie Review: The Princess of France
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews The Princess of France.

title: Movie Review: Ted 2
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Ted 2.

title: The Roberts Courts Reality Check
description: Sometimes the Supreme Court moves in mysterious ways. The health care decision was not one of those times.

title: State Dept. Gets Libya Emails That Hillary Clinton Didnt Hand Over
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department said on Thursday that 15 emails sent or received by Hillary Rodham Clinton were missing from records that she has turned over, raising new questions about whether she deleted work-related emails from the private account she used exclusively while in office.

title: Review: Advantageous Portrays a Future Where More Things Remain the Same
description: The past looks a lot like the present in Advantageous, a science-fiction fantasy in a deliberately subtle key. Its set in the near future and big-city life appears to hum along very much as it does now, what with the digital billboards and soaring glass-and-metal towers and despite the occasional zippy, low-moving aircraft. The director Jennifer Phang never explains whos piloting those sleek flying discs or setting off the periodic explosions that scarcely rock this world. The most urgent concerns for Gwen (Jacqueline Kim) throb out a familiar beat: child, career, enough water to live.

title: Humana Said to Pursue Sale as Supreme Court Ruling Gives Insurers a Lift
description: A new round of consolidation in the health insurance industry appeared closer as companies seek to grow larger, driven in part by cost-cutting and opportunities that are part of the Affordable Care Act.

title: A Turning Point for Health Care  and Its G.O.P. Opponents
description: FOR the second June in four years, the Supreme Court, led by its conservative chief justice, John G. Roberts Jr., has affirmed the legal framework of the Affordable Care Act of 2010  the signature achievement of the Obama-era Democratic Party and a national social policy landmark. In so doing, the Roberts court assured the permanent expansion of social protections in America, and also saved the Republican Party from a no-win explosion its own extreme right-wingers tried to ignite.

title: Review: In Batkid Begins, a Boys Simple Wish Whips Up Frenzied Adulation
description: In the last few decades, the image of the cancer patient has transformed from that of private victim to public warrior. That extreme pendulum swing, however, is only one thread in the cord of concern woven by Batkid Begins, Dana Nachmans awestruck documentary about the overwhelming response to a childs simple wish.

title: Sleuth Work Leads to Discovery of Art Beloved by Hitler
description: BERLIN  The recent startling recovery of long-lost artworks made for Adolf Hitler and his chief architect, Albert Speer, began with a telephone call to a Berlin art dealer.

title: Nurse Pleads Guilty to Taking Kickbacks From Drug Maker
description: A Connecticut nurse has pleaded guilty to federal charges of accepting $83,000 in kickbacks from Insys Therapeutics, an Arizona drug manufacturer that sells the powerful painkiller Subsys, as prosecutors appear to be intensifying their investigation into the company, which is under scrutiny for its marketing practices.

title: Review: In Kna the Dreamweaver, a Princess Faces a Call to Duty
description: Fairy tales often concern themselves with definitions of bravery, qualities of true love or characteristics of a real princess. All three questions come up for Kna, princess of an indigenous Tboli family in the Philippines.

title: Review: In A Little Chaos, a Guileless Kate Winslet Offsets a Lavish Versailles
description: The silky growl and insinuating gaze of the British actor Alan Rickman make him a prime candidate to play a jaded aristocrat privy to every dirty secret within his purview, whether political or sexual. And in A Little Chaos, which Mr. Rickman directed, he portrays Louis XIV, the French king of kings, putting the finishing touches on Versailles, the royal chateau outside Paris where he moved his court, the better to exert control. The year is 1682.

title: Review: In A Borrowed Identity, Hearts Torn Between 2 Worlds in Israel
description: There is sublime literary pacing in A Borrowed Identity, Eran Rikliss well-observed adaptation of two autobiographical novels by the Arab-Israeli author and journalist Sayed Kashua (who wrote the script). The film examines the often frustrating struggles for Arabs trying to assimilate into Israeli culture, as experienced by Eyad (played at first by Razi Gabareen and later by Tawfeek Barhom), a bright child raised by a loving family, including a politically active father (Ali Suliman), in Tira, a predominantly Arab town in Israel.

title: In a First, New Jersey Jury Says Group Selling Gay Cure Committed Fraud
description: In the first court verdict of its kind, a jury in New Jersey on Thursday found that a prominent group offering gay conversion therapy violated the states Consumer Fraud Act by claiming it could help men overcome unwanted homosexual urges.

title: New Hampshire Poll Shows Bernie Sanders in Dead Heat With Hillary Clinton
description: The next time Hillary Rodham Clinton visits New Hampshire, she need not look over her shoulder to find Bernie Sanders; the Vermont Senator is running right alongside her in a statistical dead heat for the 2016 Democratic presidential nomination, according to a  CNN/WMUR poll released on Thursday.

title: 2015 N.B.A. Draft: Kristaps Porzingis Is a Big Project for the Rebuilding Knicks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Phil Jackson has been adamant about wanting to do things his way as president of the Knicks. So when it came to the N.B.A draft and his first opportunity to make a first-round selection, he maintained that he was not going to be swayed by public opinion or television draftniks or the potential reaction of the teams long-suffering fans.

title: Review: The Midnight Swim Investigates a Mothers Watery Death
description: THE MIDNIGHT SWIM

title: Rebels in Ukraine Cleansing Donetsk of Perverted Art
description: Russian-backed separatists who seized control of a modern art space in the Ukrainian city of Donetsk last year have destroyed a monumental sculpture there, according to the exiled directors of the center, known as Izolyatsia, or Isolation.

title: Review: Big Game Stars Samuel L. Jackson as a President in Dire Straits
description: Yes, its about hunting, and a 13-year-old boys rite of passage through violence. But the irresistible fable-thriller Big Game  the second feature from the Finnish director Jalmari Helander (Rare Exports: A Christmas Tale, from 2010)  has got a heart.

title: Patrick Macnee, 93, Dapper and Unflappable in The Avengers, Dies
description: Patrick Macnee, who wielded a lethal umbrella and sharp repartee as the dapper secret agent John Steed on the 1960s television series The Avengers, died on Thursday at his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 93.

title: Review: A Murder in the Park Challenges David Protesss Innocence Project
description: In 1999, when Anthony Porter was cleared of the 1982 murders of two teenagers in Chicagos Washington Park and released from death row, the case drove Gov. George Ryan to suspend capital punishment in Illinois. Praise poured in for David Protess, a Northwestern University journalism professor, and the students in his Innocence Project, who contended that Mr. Porter couldnt have been the killer and produced a videotape in which a man named Alstory Simon said he had done it.

title: Jeb Hensarlings Fight Against Ex-Im Bank Succeeds, for the Moment
description: WASHINGTON  A year ago, an entrepreneur from California came before the House Financial Services Committee, a Purple Heart pinned to his lapel from his Marine Corps service in Vietnam, to plead for the Export-Import Bank  and by extension his livelihood.

title: Review: In Felt, Amy Everson Plays an Eccentric, Troubled Artist
description: Felt is a movie of ambiguities, starting with its title. (Noun or verb?) But this vague, arty horror film from Jason Banker (Toad Road), who shares a story credit with his star, Amy Everson, is at once underwritten and overconceptualized. Reading about the filmmakers intentions is more rewarding than watching the results.

title: Review: Noah Buschels Glass Chin, an Updated Working-Class Noir
description: Ordinary is our enemy, J. J., a loan shark/restaurateur/art investor/monologuist in a sharkskin-gray suit and skinny tie, says to the former boxer he torments in Glass Chin. That could be the filmmaking motto of the writer and director Noah Buschel in his latest movie-mad feature, replete with hyperstylized shots, philosophizing speeches and no-way-out plotting.

title: Top State Court Backs New York Citys Taxi of Tomorrow
description: The Taxi of Tomorrow will become New York Citys standard taxi  maybe not tomorrow, but soon.

title: Review: Escobar: Paradise Lost Stars Benicio Del Toro as Drug Lord
description: Some historical figures, like the drug lord Pablo Escobar, loom so much larger than life that even an experienced director might hesitate to approach them head on, choosing instead to refract legend through the gaze of a less dazzling sidekick. In Escobar: Paradise Lost, no one is less likely to dazzle than Nick, the Canadian surfer who serves as our colorless conduit to Colombian crime.

title: Review: The Little Death Plays With Narrative Form and Fetish
description: Early on, The Little Death helpfully explains that its title comes from the French idiom for orgasm. That eagerness to enlighten characterizes this comedys gentle, considerate tone. It also underscores why, in the end, the film doesnt work.

title: Womens World Cup 2015: France and Germany to Meet Earlier Than Expected
description: FRIDAYS GAMES

title: Harold Battiste, Musician, Mentor and Arranger, Dies at 83
description: Harold Battiste Jr., who was raised on Lasalle Street in New Orleans to the rhythms of the nearby Dew Drop Inn and went on to become a jazz musician and educator, a recording industry pioneer, and a mentor and arranger who advanced the careers of Sonny and Cher, Sam Cooke, Dr. John and others, died on June 19 at his home in New Orleans. He was 83.

title: Review: Fresh Dressed Follows Hip-Hop From the Streets to the Runway
description: From the beginning, hip-hop fashion has been about a tug of war between relatability and aspiration. Early in the new documentary Fresh Dressed, DMC of Run-DMC says about his groups street-influenced style, Dressing this way lets them know, Oh, hes just like me.

title: Jason Rezaians Life in Iranian Prison Is Ever More Difficult
description: Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post reporter incarcerated in Iran for nearly a year, is finding prison life ever more difficult and has only recently become aware of the global support for him, including a plea for his release from Muhammad Ali, Mr. Rezaians mother, Mary, said on Thursday.

title: End of a Pastoral Shortcut for Central Parks Drivers
description: New Yorkers engage in many behaviors to satisfy their compulsion for expedience  dialing up for a carton of General Tsos when they really could be cooking, spending $4 for a latte when the coffee maker at home sits idle, e-hailing Uber when the subway is right there.

title: Putin Breaks Silence With Call to Obama Touching on Ukraine and ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama spoke with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Thursday in their first direct contact in four months as the United States and Russia try to manage their conflict over Ukraine while still working together on other issues like Syria and Irans nuclear program.

title: Review: In Runoff, a Rural Family Hits Desperate Times
description: Anyone nave enough to daydream about fleeing the pressures of the city for a simpler life running a farm is strongly advised to see Runoff. The movie is the impressive directorial debut of Kimberly Levin, a former biochemist who knows a thing or two about agricultural chemistry. Filmed in Kentucky, this story of the Freemans, a rural family struggling to survive in the face of brutal pressure from agribusiness, is a Halloween nightmare.

title: A PBS Show, a Frustrated Ben Affleck, and a Loss of Face
description: In January 2014, Henry Louis Gates Jr. was over the moon.

title: Lawmakers Agree to Help Veterans Agency Fill a Budget Gap
description: WASHINGTON  Republican lawmakers said Thursday that they would support legislation allowing the Department of Veterans Affairs to shift money from another program to cover a $2.5 billion budget shortfall that would otherwise threaten medical care for many patients in coming months.

title: Review: In Max, a Shellshocked Dog Reverts to His Heroic Self
description: One of the most memorable televised arguments Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert ever had was about Benji the Hunted and Stanley Kubricks Full Metal Jacket. Ebert gave thumbs up to Benji and thumbs down to Full Metal, the opposite of Siskels votes. The two critics then fell into a contentious debate about the inherent relativism of movie reviewing, with Ebert insisting that every film needs to be judged in its proper context. Benji the Hunted, he claimed, was good for what it was, which was a sentimental childrens movie about a brave dog. Full Metal Jacket may have been a superior movie, but as the much-anticipated work of a master filmmaker, it fell short of the standard of greatness.

title: Review: In 7 Minutes, From Jay Martin, a Bank Robbery Plan Implodes
description: The title of Jay Martins tightly wound debut film, 7 Minutes, is the time that three aspiring bank robbers imagine it will take to pull off a heist that might net them a half-million dollars. These nave co-conspirators  Sam (Luke Mitchell), a former high school football star with a pregnant girlfriend and a nightmarish factory job; his drug-dealing older brother, Mike (Jason Ritter), who is married with a small child; and his best friend, Owen (Zane Holtz)  fantasize that robbing Sam and Mikes crooked uncles bank will be a snap.

title: India: Severe Flooding Kills Dozens
description: At least 41 people have been killed in severe flooding caused by heavy monsoon rains that have lashed part of the western state of Gujarat, officials said Thursday. Thousands of houses were destroyed in seven districts in the southwestern part of Gujarat, said Bipin Bhatt, the director of the states disaster management authority.

title: N.B.A. Draft: Karl-Anthony Towns Is No Surprise at No. 1, but Then Comes a Scramble
description: Minutes after Karl-Anthony Towns walked across the stage, down the steps and off toward his new career in Minnesota as the N.B.A. drafts No. 1 overall pick Thursday, activity began to buzz in two separate corners of the designated players area, the first rumblings that the night might veer quickly from expected.

title: Defense Tries to Put Focus on Sanity of Aurora Gunman
description: DENVER  A psychiatrist who examined James E. Holmes in jail days after Mr. Holmes carried out a shooting rampage in a Colorado movie theater testified Thursday that the gunman had a psychotic mental illness that revealed itself through delusions, severe anxiety and a stark emotional disconnect from the world.

title: George Winslow, Child Actor Who Had a Moment With Marilyn, Dies at 69
description: George Winslow, a child actor with a deep, raspy voice and deadpan delivery who made a big move on Marilyn Monroe in Gentlemen Prefer Blondes, died on June 14 at his home in Camp Meeker, Calif. He was 69.

title: Remembering the Rev. Clementa Pinckney
description: Mourners remembered the Rev. Clementa C. Pinckney on Thursday as his body lay in repose at the Capitol in Columbia, S.C.

title: Phil Austin (a.k.a. Nick Danger) of Firesign Theater Dies at 74
description: He pronounced his name Regnad Kcin, because from behind his desk thats how he read it, backward, through his glass office door. But listeners to Firesign Theater radio broadcasts and record albums knew him as Nick Danger, the loopy fictional detective who strode out of the fog, into the smog, focusing his third eye, hidden under his hat, on solving crime.

title: Review: Leon Bridges Reveals Classic Soul and Something More Personal
description: Wednesday night, Leon Bridges was wearing a drapy, short-sleeved, wide-collared shirt tucked into high-waisted, form-fitting slacks held up with a thin belt. The look was somewhere between 1957 and 1963, as was the sound. Mr. Bridges is a soul man of the classic sort  or, at least, thats how the sales pitch goes.

title: Pen Without Ink
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  I cant tell you how much I loved this puzzle, but I loved it a lot.

title: F.C.C. Chairman Sees No Need to Set Aside More Airwaves for Smaller Cell Carriers
description: The countrys top communications regulator on Thursday rejected calls to dedicate more airwaves for smaller wireless carriers in an auction expected next year.

title: New Yorks First Gay Pride Parade
description: 45 YEARS AGO

title: 2015 Womens World Cup: Loss of Megan Rapinoe and Lauren Holiday Complicates Task for the U.S.
description: OTTAWA  Jill Ellis interrupted a reporters question halfway through a news conference at TD Place Stadium late Thursday afternoon. Her arms were folded tightly in front of her, at rest on a table behind a dazzlingly blue, strategically placed sports drink. She had a warm smile on her face.

title: A Victory for Same-Sex Marriage, With Roots in New York
description: Friday morning, sitting in her apartment on lower Fifth Avenue, Edith Windsor was dialed into a conference room at a Midtown Manhattan law firm to hear the news that Supreme Court had decided that people of the same sex were entitled to marry.

title: Texas Dept. of Housing and Community Affairs v. Inclusive Communities Project
description: The Supreme Court, in a 5-to-4 vote, endorsed a legal theory that civil rights groups say is crucial to fighting housing discrimination.

title: Review: The Set Up: Saya Lei Interprets the Works of a Burmese Master
description: In dance collaborations, cultural exchange can be dangerous: There is always the potential for appropriation, the killing of a technique or the watering down of a tradition. Knowingly, the contemporary American choreographers Wally Cardona and Jennifer Lacey go for danger.

title: Washington Reacts to Health Care Ruling
description: Democrats tell their Republican colleagues to stop resisting the Affordable Care Act, and Republicans pledge to continue fighting.

title: Health Law Ruling Elicits Sighs of Relief and Vows to Continue Fighting
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats said it was finally time to accept that the Affordable Care Act was here to stay. Republicans vowed to keep trying to get rid of the law, but conceded that at this point, their best chance would be by winning back the White House next year.

title: Ex-Friend of State Senator Tells of a Cover-Up
description: State Senator John L. Sampson threatened to silence people cooperating with investigators, a key witness testified on Thursday at the senators obstruction trial.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 26, 2015
description: Congress passed the Affordable Care Act to improve health insurance markets, not to destroy them.

title: Word of the Day | arrhythmic
description: arrhythmic  \a-rith-mik\  adjective

title: Nets Select Chris McCullough, a Slim Prospect of Their Own
description: The Knicks took a tall, thin prospect with their first pick in Thursdays N.B.A. draft. Hours later, the Nets basically did the same. Picking 29th in the first round, the Nets selected Chris McCullough, a 6-foot-9 forward who hails from the Bronx, played at several preparatory schools and then had his freshman season at Syracuse cut short after just 16 games when he tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee in January.

title: Astros Starter Shines as Bats Fall Silent
description: HOUSTON  When Houston Astros catcher Hank Conger was acquired from the Los Angeles Angels in November, he was used to watching players like Mike Trout, Albert Pujols and Josh Hamilton  established sluggers who were expected to hit the ball out of the park.

title: How a Love Story Triumphed in Court
description: A Cincinnati real estate agent, his deceased husband's aunt and their funeral director found themselves at the center of Obergefell vs. Hodges, the biggest Supreme Court same-sex marriage case in U.S. history.

title: In Supreme Court Case, a Couple Not Recognized in Life or Death
description: When the Supreme Court makes its decision, expected in the coming days, on whether to establish a national right to same-sex marriage, the love story of Jim Obergefell and John Arthur will be front and center. As the lead plaintiff in the case against Ohios ban on gay marriage, Mr. Obergefell, 48, has become a very public face of the national movement.

title: Celebrating Love, Grieving Loss as Charleston Funerals Begin
description: For a region grieving since a gunman killed nine people in a Charleston church last week, a new phase of mourning began Thursday, with the first of the victims funerals, for Ethel Lance.

title: Whats On TV Friday
description: 8 P.M. (Disney) TEEN BEACH 2 (2015) Their endless summer has ended. In this sequel to the 2013 Disney Channel smash musical, its been three months since Mack (Maia Mitchell) and Brady (Ross Lynch) surfed 50 years into the past and onto the set of Wet Side Story. But in real life, the only epic wave is the one drowning their love. Enter Lela (Grace Phipps) and Tanner (Garrett Clayton), reprising their Annette Funicello-Frankie Avalon impression, and a magic necklace that zaps them into the present, where Lela discovers an aptitude for calculus, a taste for flavored lip gloss and a desire to be more than a dreamboats girlfriend. But if she and Tanner dont return to 1962, Mack and Brady might never meet. Like the original, Teen Beach 2 mashes up Beach Blanket Bingo, Back to the Future, Grease and Glee in bubble-gum tracks like Best Summer Ever and Gotta Be Me. Its big-kid stars are young adults by now, but its still the little kids (and their parents) who will want to sing along.

title: To Police New York in the Future, Bratton Looks to His Past
description: It has been billed as a blueprint for policing New York in the decades to come, an opportunity to get more officers back into the citys neighborhoods and connected to the people they are assigned to serve. And as William J. Bratton, the police commissioner, laid out his vision for the future on Thursday, he made it clear that it was very much informed by the experience of the past.

title: Things to Do in Westchester, June 28 to July 4, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Escape From East Berlin, Reissued Five Decades Later
description: Scores of film artists fled Nazi Germany during the 1930s and found their way to Hollywood. Only a handful of these refugees returned after World War II to make German-language films.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, June 28 to July 4, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, June 28 to July 4, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Documentary Filmmakers Talk About Manipulation in Their Work
description: The opening of Cartel Land drops viewers into an outdoor Mexican meth lab at night; the head chef sits down for an interview. The scene might be enough of a jolt to viewers, but what they wont know  unless theyre familiar with meth cooking  is that it was shot over two nights. The filmmaker, having gone to great lengths to secure access once, insisted on going back a second time to film more of the days-long drugmaking process.

title: 9 Killed When Plane Carrying Cruise Passengers Crashes in Alaska
description: Emergency workers recovered the remains of nine people killed when a small plane slammed into a cliff in rural Alaska the day before, defying wind, rain and low cloud cover on Friday to retrieve the bodies from a steep rock face, according to emergency officials and media reports.

title: Penelope Spheeris Reissues Decline of Western Civilization Films
description: The arrival of The Decline of Western Civilization Collection as a pristine extras-filled box set from Shout Factory this week is to budding punks what a new Star Wars movie is to, well, all the other kids: something they never thought theyd get to experience in their lifetimes.

title: Restaurant Review: Quenas in Harrison Offers Tastes of Peru, With Asian Influences
description: Where to begin? Perhaps with the small, informal dining room of Quenas, a family-run restaurant in Harrison, its soaring walls splashed in deep red and decorated with Peruvian memorabilia. Or, on a warm summer evening, with a cold Peruvian beer or a glass of sangria sipped under umbrellas on the patio. Or maybe just fast-forward to dessert, putting aside for now the savory Peruvian dishes this kitchen turns out.

title: Corrections: June 26, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Review: Rincn Taqueria in Norwalk
description: Those who dine out frequently enjoy discovering a sleeper, an unpretentious gem of a restaurant tucked away from the beaten path. Well, I have a sleeper for you, but its hidden in plain sight in a small strip mall on the Post Road on the south edge of Norwalk.

title: A Farmer Reclaims Liberian Roots in New Jersey
description: Morris Gbolo spends a lot of time thinking about the home-cooked dinners he and his wife, Ernestine, used to enjoy before they fled their home amid civil war in Liberia 12 years ago.

title: Picnics to Go Are Growing in the Hamptons
description: The local harvest may be delayed by an unusually cold spring this year, but as the sweet corn, heirloom tomatoes and summer squash come to market, several new picnic purveyors on the East End will be dreaming up ways to enjoy them alfresco. For many of us, a French baguette and a hunk of artisanal cheese from the Village Cheese Shop in Mattituck make a magnificent movable feast. But recently, picnic options from East Marion to Southampton have expanded, reflecting a locavore-inspired mission: Food that is grown in these fields can also be savored in them.

title: Lower East Side Story
description: The bad old days of the Lower East Side seem almost as quaint, and as distant, as the neighborhoods heyday a century ago, when its streets were abuzz with immigrants spilling out of overcrowded tenements.

title: The Robert E. Lee Problem
description: The debate about the Charleston Bible study shooting has morphed into a debate about the Confederate battle flag and other symbols of the Confederacy. This is not a trivial sideshow. Racism is not just a personal prejudice and an evolutionary byproduct. It resurfaces year after year because its been woven by historical events into the fabric of American culture.

title: In Karachi, a Fatal Mix of Heat and Piety
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  WHEN I go to buy my drinking water, I dont ask for water. I ask for Nestl. Then I drive home with five 20-liter plastic bottles and make sure that we make every cup of tea, and all our ice, from this water. Like other people in this city, I believe the tap water is poisonous. During the summer, many of us follow the practice of putting out a water cooler on the street for passers-by. There are chic restaurants, cafes and art galleries in my neighborhood, but not a single public source of clean drinking water. Street vendors, security guards, trash pickers and maids rushing from one job to another often stop by to have a drink from this cooler. Like most such water coolers, mine is secured with a padlock; even the plastic tumbler is tied to it with a small chain.

title: Cinven Agrees to Buy a Majority Stake in Synlab
description: LONDON  Funds advised by BC Partners have agreed to sell a majority stake in Synlab, one of Europes largest independent providers of laboratory services, to the European private equity firm Cinven.

title: When Public Housing Is Across the Street
description: This spring, city officials announced they would encourage private developers to build on land inside public housing complexes, potentially making luxury apartments their neighbors.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Supreme Court Allows Nationwide Health Care Subsidies
description: Note: Were experimenting with a new format for this feature. Tell us what you think!

title: Europcar Shares Decline in Early Trading After Paris I.P.O.
description: LONDON  Shares of Europcar, a French rental car company, declined more than 3 percent in early trading in Paris on Friday after its initial public offering.

title: Test Your Grammar | Aerial Courses in the Trees
description: Weve been experimenting a bit this week with new formats for Test Yourself. On June 22 we tried out a punctuation quiz, on June 23 a verb-tenses quiz and on June 25 our first grammar quiz.

title: J. K. Rowling Says Harry Potter Play Will Open Next Summer
description: LONDON  J. K. Rowling, the author of the Harry Potter books, announced on Twitter on Friday that Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, a new stage play centered on the blockbuster series, will premiere in London next summer.

title: French Authorities Hold Suspect in Beheading and Explosion at Chemical Plant
description: ST.-PRIEST, France  A deliveryman who French security officials say once had links to radical Islamist groups drove his truck into an American-owned chemical plant near Lyon on Friday, set off an explosion and, in a macabre twist, mounted his bosss severed head on the plants gate.

title: Fridays Travel News and Tips
description: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Ask Well: Assessing Knee Supports
Hair Thats Long, Sleek, High School Approved
description: As part of a monthly ritual during the school year, Avery Sion, 12, and her friends would hop into the back seat of one of their mothers cars to get shuttled to a favorite hangout.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Take Your Medicine
description: Obamacare gets a clean bill of health from the Supreme Court.

title: In California, Water Restrictions Above Ground and Leaks Below
description: LOS ANGELES  Californians have been ordered to save water because of the drought. But one of the best ways to save it is to not lose it in the first place. That is why many cities in this thirsty state have declared a war on leaks.

title: 1915: Prussia Debates Food Supplies
description: LONDON  There were stormy scenes in the Prussian Diet yesterday during the debate on the measures taken to provide for the food supplies of the people during the war.

title: Palestinian Shot After Opening Fire on Israeli Forces in West Bank
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  A Palestinian man was shot after he opened fire on Israeli forces in the occupied West Bank early Friday, the Israeli Army said.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: June 26
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of the continuing search for two escaped prison inmates.

title: New York Today: Capturing the Hunt
description: Good hazy Friday morning.

title: Chinas Stock Market Plunges
description: SHANGHAI  Share prices in China plunged on Friday in one of the sharpest sell-offs in years, accelerating a downturn this last week in what has been, for much of this year, the worlds best-performing stock market.

title: Yemeni Heritage, Saudi Vandalism
description: For more than 10 years, I was one of a number of American and Yemeni archaeologists surveying and excavating sites dating to the fabled South Arabian kingdoms and beyond, to prehistoric times. We were members of the Dhamar Survey Project, started by the University of Chicago and named for a historic town in highland Yemen.

title: China Investigates a Top Sports Official Over Corruption
description: One of Chinas top sports officials is under investigation for corruption, the Communist Partys antigraft agency announced.

title: The 6.14.15 Issue
description: RE: LABOR

title: Morning Agenda: Humana Said to Pursue Deal to Sell Itself
description: HUMANA SAID TO PURSUE DEAL TO SELL ITSELF | Humana, the smallest of the big five health insurers in the United States, could reach an agreement by next week to sell itself to another insurer, according to a person briefed on the matter,  Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook. Among the suitors are Aetna and Cigna, which have both been the targets of takeovers themselves as insurance companies look to cut costs through consolidation and take advantage of the opportunities that are part of the Affordable Care Act.

title: Post Time
description: What are the instances in which perception changes, in which we suddenly see our parents in a different light? Reading this poem, I thought of what Ive come to understand about my own fathers life that I could not before his death, and how a long-ago moment between us now seems like a last-minute window, when any outcome was still possible.

title: How to Go Undercover
description: Learn to walk the walk and talk the talk, says Cody Carlson, who wore a hidden miniature video camera during the year and a half he worked stints at places like a dairy farm in upstate New York, a pork producer in Pennsylvania and two egg farms in Iowa. His goal was to capture irrefutable evidence of mistreatment that animal rights groups could later use in lawsuits and public-awareness campaigns. Before going undercover, the 31-year-old Carlson spent weeks in anthropologist mode, observing livestock auctions, volunteering at pet stores, studying the lingo and aesthetics that would allow a New York City kid to blend in at hog barns.

title: Why Im Afraid of Therapy
description: When I was growing up, my father was fascinated by people talking about themselves. Books, movies, television  if it had an extended scene of self-analysis, he was reading it or watching it. Part of this enchantment was pure anthropological interest: My father grew up poor in Honolulu, a third-generation Japanese-American whod gotten up and out of his neighborhood. His idea of culture was shaped largely by his discovery of writers and filmmakers  Philip Roth, Woody Allen, Wallace Shawn  whose definition of an intellectual life included exposing their own fantasies and grotesqueries to an audience that was assumed to be (and in fact was) interested, even beguiled, by them. To my father, the very idea of talking about himself to a stranger for 50 minutes must have seemed equal parts horrifying and seductive, the equivalent of spending a day eating nothing but fudge.

title: Why Was This Patient Walking on Pins and Needles?
description: She had traveled in Africa. Could she have caught something there that was causing strokes?

title: Michael Bachs Preservation Through Photography
description: In 2000, Michael Bach quit taking photos, for good, or so he believed. After graduating from the Yale School of Art, Bach had spent two decades as a teacher and a landscape photographer until he had a mental breakdown that culminated in a suicide attempt. He sold all his equipment, including his large-format camera. I felt like a failure, Bach said. I didnt want anything around me to remind me of photography.

title: Today in Politics: G.O.P. Finds Much to Add to Justices Final Say on Health Care Law
description: Good Friday morning from Washington, where the Supreme Court has taken over both the Capitol and the campaign trail. Its ruling in favor of a central provision of the Affordable Care Act prompted declarations of victory from the White House and increased pledges to repeal the law from the Republicans looking to move in.

title: Finding Paradise in Turkeys Munzur Valley
description: Deep in the rugged heart of eastern Anatolia, the Munzur River flows from the base of a skyscraping limestone massif, wending its way into the world across a grassy valley cradled between dog-toothed peaks and forested hills. The water is impossibly clear and numbingly cold and, to most of those who visit its source, sacred. Its easy to feel close to God here, I was told by one follower of the mystical Alevi religion, who, like hundreds of other women, men and children, had come to the springs  called Munzur Gozeleri  on a scorching July afternoon.

title: Exploring Tule Lake, an Austere Land With a Complex History
description: At night during the 1940s, Tule Lake in California used to be lit up like Las Vegas, a sprawling megalopolis, which was filled with wooden barracks, tanks, guard towers and a mess hall instead of casinos.

title: A Refuge for Racists
description: In one of the little acts of subversion that creeps into The Simpsons every now and then, a helicopter from Fox News was shown in 2010 with a logo, Not Racist, But #1 With Racists.

title: Energizing the Green Revolution in Africa
description: In the summer of 2005, Andrew Youn, an M.B.A. student at Northwestern Universitys Kellogg School of Management, was traveling in western Kenya when he met two women, farmers who were living profoundly different lives.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 3 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: A short video from the Summer of Science series.

title: Singleminded
description: Im almost unmedicated. Each morning, I take just 100 milligrams of bupropion. At bedtime, I take a quarter milligram of lorazepam. Ive eliminated trazodone. And Im single. My ex and I are friends again  we were friends for years before we dated  and now that my heartbreak has receded, I dont miss the upstream swim of that relationship. I still pop awake in the middle of the night, and often stay awake for two or three hours, but theres a peacefulness to my days now. Summer is helping. It always does.

title: Junya Watanabe Man: Spring 2016 Menswear
description: Paris

title: After MERS, South Korea Authorizes Prison for Quarantine Scofflaws
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Stung by the outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome, South Korea has passed a law authorizing prison terms of up to two years for people who defy quarantine orders or lie about their possible exposure to an infectious disease.

title: Maison Margiela: Spring 2016 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Video Reviews of Ted 2, The Princess of France and What Happened, Miss Simone?
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Ted 2, The Princess of France and What Happened, Miss Simone? See all of this weeks reviews.

title: ZestFinance Takes Its Big Data Credit Scoring to China
description: Financial technology start-ups are creating new models of lending. They mine streams of digital data with clever software to calculate creditworthiness instead of relying on a persons credit history, the main ingredient in traditional credit scoring.

title: Americans Are Delaying Major Life Events Because of Money Worries
description: ABOUT half of American adults have postponed a major life decision in the past year for financial reasons, mainly because they lack sufficient savings or are worried about the economy, or both, a new survey finds.

title: Should Happy Hour Be Banned?
A Kindergarten Form Asks: Vaginal Birth, or C-section. Why?
description: My husband fills out most of the forms in our marriage. So when we received a humongous packet of forms at a kindergarten prematriculation session, he immediately got to work. Hunched over the voluminous pile, he meticulously yet mindlessly checked little boxes and filled in the blanks. But a question I just happened to glance caught my attention:

title: Hillary Clinton Visits Virginia, a Bellwether State in 2016 Race
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton will make the first stop of her presidential campaign in Virginia on Friday to headline the local Democratic Partys Jefferson Jackson dinner.

title: Peppy and the Pretzel Man
description: Dear Diary:

title: China Issues Report on U.S. Human Rights Record, in Annual Tit for Tat
description: Police brutality, racial discrimination, torture of terrorism suspects, horrifically overcrowded prisons, rising income inequality and endemic poverty. These are just some of the human rights abuses in the United States highlighted by China on Friday in response to the State Departments annual human rights report.

title: 1940: Republicans Oppose War
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Republican National Convention adopted today its 1940 platform upon which it will make its stand for the Presidency, without a floor fight on the controversial foreign relations plank and without a single dissenting voice being cast against it.

title: More Migrant Talks Needed, Merkel Says
description: The migrant crisis is the biggest challenge the European Union faces, the German chancellor said. European leaders have agreed to a voluntary program to take in asylum seekers.

description: When Zheng Churan, one of the Feminist Five whose detention in March made international headlines, was taken into custody, one of her greatest fears was about the food.

title: The N.B.A. Draft Needs a Mens Wear Makeover
description: When did we decide that elite male athletes were exempt from the normal rules of dress? That, in fact, the more ridiculous and outr they look, the better?

title: Nets Trade Mason Plumlee for Rondae Hollis-Jefferson of Arizona and Steve Blake
description: Two years after taking him in the first round, the Nets parted ways with center Mason Plumlee on Thursday night, sending him to the Portland Trail Blazers. In exchange, Brooklyn got the Blazers first-round pick, Rondae Hollis-Jefferson, and the veteran point guard Steve Blake.

title: Tunisia Attack Kills at Least 38 at Beach Resort Hotel
description: SOUSSE, Tunisia  At least one gunman disguised as a vacationer attacked this placid Mediterranean resort on Friday, killing at least 38 people at a beachfront hotel  most of them British tourists  before he was shot to death by the security forces.

title: Hollande Calls for Unity After Attacks
description: The French president said useless divisions and unbearable suspicion must be resisted after a victim was decapitated in an assault on a factory near Lyon, France, on Friday.

title: Terrorist Attacks in France, Tunisia and Kuwait Kill Dozens
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In a matter of hours and on three different continents, militants carried out attacks on Friday that killed scores of civilians, horrified populations and raised thorny questions about the evolving nature of international terrorism and what can be done to fight it.

title: Creative Advice for Donald Trump, a Proudly Egotistical Showman
description: In Fred Daviss imagination, a whole new Donald J. Trump would have announced for president last week: a softer, humbler version of the Donald, with a common touch and a demeanor far removed from (in Mr. Daviss words) the proudly egotistical showman of reality television fame.

title: A Memo for a Vision on How to Overhaul Donald Trump
description: Fred Davis, a top adviser and creative director to Senator John McCains 2008 presidential campaign, laid out his vision for overhauling Mr. Trump in a memo last month to Mr. Trumps campaign manager. The pitch was as far as things went: Mr. Davis now advises Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, another likely Republican presidential candidate.

title: Waldorf Astoria and Hotel Workers Union Reach $149 Million Deal for Severance Payouts
description: When a Chinese insurance firm bought the Waldorf Astoria Hotel for $1.95 billion this year, it said it planned to convert part of the aging building into high-end condominiums, while maintaining a smaller five-star hotel.

title: Clinton Volunteers on Hunt For Brooklyn Apartments
description: When Jesse Lehrich heard he might have a chance to work on Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign, he did what most young staffers did. He moved to New York as an unpaid volunteer until Mrs. Clinton officially announced her candidacy and opened her headquarters in Downtown Brooklyn.

description: CARLOS URRUTIAS job is to fly a private jet. But when he is on board the Bombardier Challenger 300, which he has flown for tens of thousands of hours, he does much more than that.

title: SiriusXM Settles Royalty Dispute Over Old Recordings
description: For the last two years, the music industry has been watching a series of lawsuits centered on an obscure aspect of copyright law: whether the performers on older recordings should get royalties when their songs are played on digital radio services.

title: Daily Report: The Promise of Faster Fiber-Optic Transmissions
description: Researchers have announced an advance that could double the capacity of fiber-optic circuits, potentially opening the way for networks to carry more data over long distances while significantly reducing their cost, John Markoff reports.

M. Stern Architects, sold for $18,000,000 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

description: Setting bail is a difficult task for judges. They must try to foretell whether the defendant is likely to commit another crime, hurt someone or skip out on the next court date.

description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani Taliban on Friday warned that they would take action against an electricity company if power failures continued to plague Karachi, a southern port city that is reeling from a devastating heat wave that has killed at least 1,000 people in recent days.

title: The Spring/Summer 2016 Mens Shows Elevate Basketball-Inspired Looks to a Full-Court Press
description: At the spring/summer 2016 mens wear shows in London, Milan and Paris, the athletic trend shows no signs of abating, with heavy-hitting designers including Louis Vuitton, Valentino and Prada showing looks that could seamlessly transition from the runway to the three-point line. (In a decidedly retro twist, this springs defining luxury item may well be a track suit or pair of tiny, shiny shorts.) The love for the ballers, it seems, is mutual: another trend thats only gaining steam is the appearance of athletes like Carmelo Anthony and Amare Stoudemire at mens fashion week shows and parties, having left their jerseys at home in favor of sharp, dapper duds. Game recognize game, after all.

description: This interview with Tae Hea Nahm, managing director of the venture capital firm Storm Ventures, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

description: This week, Holland Cotter discusses four new books and the contemporary art scene; Alexandra Alter has notes from the publishing world; Jonathon Keats talks about art theft and forgeries; questions from readers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Souvenirs, Instagram Style, at Louis Vuitton, Valentino,Rick Owens, Yohji Yamamoto and Dries Van Noten
description: PARIS  As a ruthless devourer of history, fashion is perhaps without equal. This thought recurred over the first few days of the Paris mens wear shows as designers blithely made visual and literal reference to historic events of which, in many cases, they may have only the dimmest perception.

description: The president spoke after the Supreme Court ruled that the Constitution guarantees a nationwide right to same-sex marriage, saying, When all Americans are treated as equal, we are all more free.

description: The main scholarly association covering the post-Soviet world has announced a new fellowship named partly for a controversial scholar, bringing to an end an episode that prompted intense debate about academic freedom amid the fraught politics of the Ukraine crisis.

description: HOW will the Supreme Courts ruling on same-sex marriage alter the way Americans feel about the country, and how we feel about ourselves?

description: As I was reading Ashlee Vances Elon Musk: Tesla, Space X and the Quest for a Fantastic Future, I was alternately awed and disheartened, almost exactly the same ambivalence I felt after reading Walter Isaacsons Steve Jobs and Brad Stones The Everything Store: Jeff Bezos and the Age of Amazon.

title: 1965: Nasser Juggles Asian Leaders
description: CAIRO  President Gamal Abdel Nasser was kept running last night playing host to the leaders of Asias three biggest nations. His problem was to keep them from bumping into each other. The president of the United Arab Republic came to Cairo airport with visiting Chinese Premier Chou En-lai to welcome President Sukarno of Indonesia.

title: Stillbirth: Your Stories
description: Few families are prepared when a baby dies prior to delivery. Here, parents who have navigated this difficult experience are sharing their insights.

title: Ian McKellen and Derek Jacobi in a Gay Pride March Debut
description: When Ian McKellen and Derek Jacobi come sailing down Fifth Avenue in convertibles at the Gay Pride March on Sunday, they will not only be grand marshals at the annual event but also first-time attendees.

title: The Price of Gay Marriage
description: The Supreme Courts decision affirming the right to same-sex marriage across the United States is a joyous moment for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender Americans. Recognition of our equal dignity, and of our right to the same legal protections straight couples enjoy, is a civil rights milestone. But it could also be the swan song for the movement for gay freedom that began after World War II.

title: Charleston, S.C., Mourns a Beloved Leader
description: President Obama spoke at the funeral for the Rev. Clementa C. Pinckney, the South Carolina senator killed during the shootings on June 17.

title: Voices From Burundi
description: Few voters apparently went to the polls in Burundi on Tuesday in a presidential election that is widely expected to give President Pierre Nkurunziza a controversial third term.

title: Jimmy Fallon Injures Hand and Cancels Friday Tonight Show
description: A scheduled taping of NBCs Tonight show was canceled on Friday after its host, Jimmy Fallon, was injured. A post on the programs official Twitter account said: Hey guys  unfortunately tonights taping has been cancelled due to Jimmy injuring his hand. Hes totally fine but well be airing a repeat. The guests scheduled to appear had included Benicio Del Toro, Taylor Kitsch and Penn and Teller.

title: Fire-Roasted Potatoes, Brooklyn Style
description: Some kids grow up with backyard grills. Others have campfires, clambakes or pig roasts.

title: Elephant Rumba
description: In this video, elephants appear to be dancing to a rumba. They did not react to the tango.

title: In N.B.A. Draft, Knicks Take a Break From Catering to Carmelo Anthony
description: It is entirely possible that Phil Jackson  or rather Steve Mills  worked the phones into the dying seconds of the Knicks five-minute allotment after the third pick of the N.B.A. draft Thursday night, shooting for a deal that would have brought them a veteran and an escape hatch from what seemed like the dreaded No. 4 slot.

title: Witness Describes Tunisia Beach Attack
description: At least one gunman opened fire and killed dozens on Friday in the city of Sousse.

title: Where Nice Evenings Are Recalled by Kurt Elling
description: The note-bending, soul-patch-sporting, Grammy-winning jazz singer Kurt Elling lives with his wife, Jennifer, and their daughter, Luiza, in a two-bedroom rental on the Upper West Side. The window in the eat-in kitchen offers a view of glorious sunsets (much photographed by the family); there are gracious prewar touches like molding; and the closet space, by New York standards, is abundant.

title: Same-Sex Marriage Is a Right, the Supreme Court Rules, 5-4
description: The decision came against a backdrop of fast-moving changes in public opinion.

title: On Gay Marriage, John Roberts Invokes  the Aztecs?
description: John Robertss dissent in todays same-sex marriage ruling includes an odd paragraph accusing the majority of blindness to truths as old as humanity. The misguided majority, he says, orders the transformation of a social institution that has formed the basis of human society for millennia, for the Kalahari Bushmen and the Han Chinese, the Carthaginians and the Aztecs. Just who do we think we are?

title: Pinto Beans and Bacon: The Quintessential Cowboy Meal
description: I am sitting on the back of a horse, urging a herd of Hereford cows and calves to move along, leaving no strays behind. These creatures are leaving their winter quarters near a dried-up salt lake in a California desert valley and heading to the grassy mountain pastures for the summer.

title: Obamas Responses to Mass Shootings
description: Over the course of his presidency, as he has had to repeatedly address mass shootings, President Obamas public statements on the attacks have seemed to become angrier and more exasperated.

title: President Obama Eulogizes Charleston Pastor as One Who Understood Grace
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  In one of his presidencys most impassioned reflections on race, President Obama eulogized the Rev. Clementa C. Pinckney on Friday by calling on the nation to emulate the grace that he displayed in his work and that the people of South Carolina demonstrated after the massacre of nine worshipers at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church.

title: Hudson Square Emerging
description: Developers have begun marketing condominiums at 70 Charlton, which broke ground last August on Charlton Street. These are among the first of what ultimately may be several thousand units to be built in the Hudson Square neighborhood as a result of rezoning in 2013 to encourage residential development.

title: Grandparents Who Move to Be Closer to Grandchildren
description: GERALD HARDAGE and his wife, Edie, were driving around in the Rocky Mountains in Colorado during a family visit when something clicked inside them. One granddaughter was crawling, and the other was 3 years old. Mr. Hardage said, We should just move here, and I said, O.K.,  Mrs. Hardage, now 64, recalled.

title: Greek Prime Minister Calls for Referendum on Bailout Terms
description: ATHENS  In an unexpected move, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras went on national television early Saturday to call for a referendum on July 5, so that Greek citizens can decide whether to accept or reject the terms of a bailout deal proposed by the countrys creditors.

title: Three Attacks In Three Hours
description: Fridays attacks in France, Tunisia and Kuwait came at roughly the same time, but there was no immediate indication that they had been coordinated.

title: Where Same-Sex Couples Live
description: The biggest practical effect of the Supreme Courts decision establishing a national right to marriage will be felt in a band of cities that starts in Texas, moves through the Southeast and up into the industrial Midwest  from Dallas and Houston through New Orleans and Atlanta, and up into Nashville and Columbus, Ohio.

title: 1896 | Parliamentary Language and a Racial Slur
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: A Profound Ruling Delivers Justice on Gay Marriage
description: To the list of landmark Supreme Court decisions reaffirming the power and the scope of the Constitutions guarantee of equal protection under the law  from Brown v. Board of Education to Loving v. Virginia to United States v. Windsor  we can now add Obergefell v. Hodges.

title: Winners and Losers in the 2015 N.B.A. Draft
description: It will be years before the 2015 N.B.A. draft can be properly evaluated, but based on what we know about the players so far, some teams appear to have come out of the day as winners or losers. Left out of this list are the Minnesota Timberwolves, who had the top pick and took the best player.

description: Geoff Macdonald, the womens tennis coach at Vanderbilt University, analyzes which players have made a strong impression heading to the All England Lawn Tennis Club.

(It really does).

description: Ben Ratliff and Ben Sisario discuss Apple Music, the much-anticipated music-streaming service to be launched June 30.

description: Confusion about the intricacies of upcoming consumer disclosure rules is causing at least one major lender to retreat from certain loan products.

description: BRUSSELS  Facing a migration crisis that has infused Europes usually arid and consensual decision-making with angry passions, European leaders ended an ill-tempered discussion early Friday about what to do with a vague pledge to spread 40,000 migrants around the Continent.

title: The Scene
description: Comme Des Garons Plus at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Dr. Jennifer Downey and Robert Reid: Yes, They Can Get a Witness
description: Four years after her husband left her, and after decades of advising lovelorn but risk-averse patients to get out there, Dr. Jennifer Downey decided the time had come to heed her own advice.
